HEADLINE: No Republican, but Still a Thorn

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
At first glance, Patrick J. Buchanan appears sapped of the political potency that made him an important player in the 1996 Presidential campaign. His pitch then to the economically distressed now carries little appeal given the resurgence in New Hampshire. His comments about Hitler in his new book have drawn denunciations from all quarters.
In fact, Mr. Buchanan's failure to make a dent in polls of Republican voters practically drove him to the Reform Party. Even his bid for that party's nomination is hardly assured. Others with marquee names or fatter bank accounts -- Donald J. Trump, Jesse Ventura, Ross Perot -- may have an easier time navigating the byzantine, and costly, Reform Party rules for getting on state ballots. 
 And yet for all his apparent weaknesses, Mr. Buchanan may be the wild card of the 2000 campaign. He could cause incalculable mischief for both Republicans and Democrats because Mr. Buchanan has the unusual potential to strike a chord both among grass-roots conservatives and with union members who usually vote Democratic. He is, perhaps, the only candidate since George Wallace who has some appeal to those wings of both parties.
"He's an expert on getting attention for himself," said Scott Reed, who ran Bob Dole's Presidential campaign in 1996, "and he'll look to keep both parties in line on issues that he cares about like trade and his nationalist agenda."
Even if he does not ultimately win the Reform nomination next summer, Mr. Buchanan -- with his knack for forcefully and unabashedly speaking his mind -- could help drive the discourse in the coming months. As a longtime television commentator, he is a master at commanding television coverage -- and uttering the perfectly provocative sound bite.
The nightmare scenario for politicians on both sides would be for Mr. Buchanan to pop up on nationally televised debates next fall and bash both parties, much as he did in his announcement today.
Mr. Buchanan poses the biggest threat to Republicans because he still has a following in that party. On issues like human rights in China and national sovereignty, Mr. Buchanan could force Republican candidates to move to the right, something that could hurt them in a general election.
But the most daunting challenge for Republicans may be how to react to Mr. Buchanan. His hard-edged oratory at the Republican convention in 1992 frightened President George Bush's campaign. Some of the President's aides said Mr. Bush was more damaged by his handling of Mr. Buchanan -- giving him a prime speaking slot at the convention -- than by Mr. Buchanan's challenge itself.
Advisers to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican front-runner, said they were concerned that Mr. Buchanan, never warm to the Bush family, would use his new platform to upbraid the Governor.
Mr. Buchanan could also torment Democrats, particularly because of his appeal to labor. Even though he would have no formal role in the Democratic primaries, he could prod the Democratic contenders into stands that could hurt them in a general election, like making tougher environmental and worker safety regulations a priority to negotiating future trade treaties.
But there is another, more fundamental, reason for the Republicans to have more to fear. Except for 1976, when Jimmy Carter drew just over 50 percent of the vote, no Democratic Presidential candidate has ever drawn more than 50 percent since 1964. So the more divided the vote, the better for Democrats.
Mr. Buchanan's appeal to conservatives in a general election could also spell trouble for Republicans because it could enable Democrats to gain footholds in Southern and Mountain states where they might not have been competitive.
But for now at least, Mr. Buchanan has to get past Mr. Trump and others as he seeks the Reform nomination. That is why in his announcement today Mr. Buchanan did not dwell on topics like abortion and cultural values and concentrated on campaign finance reform, trade and other issues championed by the party's founder, Mr. Perot.
Yet Mr. Buchanan may have trouble convincing Reform members that he deserves their nomination. For all his emphasis on the party's issues, Mr. Buchanan hardly fits the mold of Mr. Perot -- or Mr. Ventura -- when he mentioned in his remarks that he had been a "Goldwaterite" and spoke with pride about his service to President Richard M. Nixon.
"The Buchanan candidacy has the highest likelihood of transforming the Reform Party from a party that connected politics to ordinary people to one that is ideological -- and potentially marginalized," said Steven J. Rosenstone, dean of the College of Liberal Arts at the University of Minnesota and an expert on third parties. "With Buchanan you get an attitude and ideology, and that's a risk for the Reform Party."
Increasingly, Republicans appear uneasy with Mr. Buchanan as well. His support among Republicans has stood at about 4 percent in recent polls by ABC News.
"Pat Buchanan didn't quit the Republican Party as much as the Republican Party quit Pat Buchanan," said Gary Langer, ABC's polling director.
His strains with Republicans will probably make it far less likely that Republican candidates would cave to Mr. Buchanan, as they did in 1992.
"Let's assume George W. Bush is the nominee," said Mickey Edwards, a former Republican House member from Oklahoma who teaches at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "I don't see him being pushed."
Indeed, advisers to Mr. Bush insisted that they would never consent to include Mr. Buchanan in a candidates' debate.
If Mr. Buchanan wins the Reform nomination, he will get $12.6 million in Federal money because Mr. Perot drew more than 5 percent of the vote as the party's candidate in 1996. But while that would seem like a fortune to Mr. Buchanan's bare-bones operation, it would not go far in a general election.
"I like Pat a lot," said Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, who has made a cause of opposing new campaign spending restrictions. "But the notion that $13 million is a pot of gold is laughable on its face. That's about half a Senate race in New York. We're talking about running for President of the United States."

HEADLINE: For Gore and Bradley, A Search for Distinction

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley have a lot more in common than either would like to admit to Presidential primary voters.
Each will try to emphasize differences that matter to those voters when they debate for the first time in New Hampshire on Wednesday night. But in fact, the two Democrats have spent the bulk of their public service careers as generally liberal members of Congress, with a quite similar approach to the job. 
 Their likenesses start with their voting records, during Mr. Bradley's 18 years in the Senate and Mr. Gore's 8 years there, after serving 8 years in the House. Mr. Bradley, plainly seeking to run to Mr. Gore's left on issues from health insurance to gun control, was a bit more liberal in the eyes of old-fashioned liberals and environmentalists. But to some groups, like the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and conservative groups, their records were almost identical.
But a Congressional record, if it means anything at all, is more than a compilation of votes, and the Bradley-Gore similarities extended well beyond the yeas and nays.
Each was effective in learning a complex, "eyes glaze over" issue and putting it on the national agenda.
For Mr. Gore, there was global warming, arms control questions and computer technology. "I think my work on arms control made a contribution at a critical time toward the creation of a new consensus on strategic stability," Mr. Gore said in a recent interview. And he said his work on environmental issues also helped to generate a consensus, both for the Superfund program to clean up toxic waste sites and for addressing global environmental problems.
For Mr. Bradley, there was third world debt, international trade and tax simplification. He was central to the 1986 tax reform act that lowered tax rates and closed loopholes, which he pursued with "a single-mindedness that was sometimes irritating to my family," he said in an interview. But in the end, he added, "it became the symbol of doing very big things in a bipartisan way."
Neither man was known in Congress as an orator. But Mr. Gore rose to a dramatic occasion to explain his vote to authorize war in the Persian Gulf in 1991, when he broke with almost all other Democrats, including Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee. Mr. Bradley was unaccustomedly eloquent the next year in warning of deteriorating race relations.
Neither was especially chummy with colleagues, though Mr. Gore had more friends in the House than both of them put together had in the Senate. Mr. Gore's run for the Presidency in his first Senate term made him seem presumptuous to some senators, and he was snidely labeled Prince Albert.
That lack of loyal allies may be one reason why neither had a striking record of getting laws passed, though each had a few accomplishments. A more telling reason may be that neither served long enough to head a committee, though Mr. Bradley dealt impressively with Western water rights as a subcommittee chairman. In a similar position, Mr. Gore first began warning of global warming and the greenhouse effect.
In a campaign, each will try to make an issue out of past votes, especially as proof of comparative constancy and sincerity, as reasons to trust their promises for the future.
Mr. Gore, for example, has criticized Mr. Bradley for voting in 1992, 1994 and 1996 for school vouchers that parents could use to pay private and parochial school tuition. The New Jersey Senator said he supported only an "experiment," and today he opposes vouchers. That quarrel is intended to attract the votes of public school teachers.
Similarly, Mr. Bradley's insistence that he has been "a consistent and unwavering supporter of a woman's right to choose" whether to have an abortion is directed at another important Democratic primary constituency: voters for whom abortion rights are the prime issue.
Mr. Gore's current position is indistinguishable from Mr. Bradley's, but before he first ran for President in 1987 it was generally anti-abortion.
In the House, he generally opposed Federal funding for abortions for poor women on Medicaid. In the mid-1980's, the Tennessee Representative regularly wrote constituents who asked his views: "I have strongly opposed Federal funding of abortions. In my opinion, it is wrong to spend Federal funds for what is arguably the taking of a human life."
But by the time he was seeking votes in Democratic Presidential primaries in 1988, Mr. Gore was equivocating, and by 1992 he supported his party's position in favor of Medicaid financing for abortions.
The environment is an important point of comparison. Mr. Gore has built much of his reputation in that area, although when it came to voting records, the League of Conservation Voters judged him "right" just 64 percent of the time, compared with 84 percent for Mr. Bradley.
Mr. Gore is best known for big concepts, like global warming and the threat to the ozone layer. The legislative results were not always dramatic, although he led a successful effort to limit CFC's in the 1990 Clean Air Act and was deeply involved with the Superfund program in the House. But since the Clinton Administration has not been as dedicated to those concerns as Mr. Gore was as a lawmaker, they sometimes seem to do him little good today.
Mr. Bradley is known more for specifics -- for filibustering an effort to undo Federal protection of millions of acres in Utah, for securing the Sterling Forest preserve in New Jersey and New York and, most of all, for the 1992 California water rights legislation. That law forced farmers to pay more than a token price for Central Valley water and made the water available for urban use.
That legislation began as an issue that Mr. Bradley said "I knew nothing about" but was his to deal with when he became a subcommittee chairman. He studied it, held hearings, found allies and maneuvered the bill into law, using election year pressures to get President George Bush to sign it.
Mr. Gore was among an influential band of House Democrats who threatened in 1983 to oppose deployment of the MX missile unless the Reagan Administration would start talking to Moscow about arms controls. In the Senate he was among the advocates of reducing the use of multiple warheads.
One successful legislative effort that brought Mr. Gore recent grief was technology. In March he said he "took the initiative in creating the Internet." Republicans laughed him off the political stage for that one, with Dan Quayle saying if that was true, he had invented spell-check. In fact, Mr. Gore's efforts to promote supercomputing and high-speed communications networks are acknowledged by the developers of the process to have played an essential role.
Today, Mr. Gore makes his Internet boast in more convoluted language: "My work on technology included efforts to promote funding for the technologies that were used by people who expanded early prototypes of the Arpanet that later became the Internet." He grinned and added, "I hope I have buffered that adequately."
Mr. Bradley's greatest Senate accomplishment was the 1986 tax reform act that "nobody in Washington thought would really happen," as he put it in the interview.
Tax fairness was an issue he brought to Washington. "I had always been upset by a system where people who were able to use loopholes paid less than people who did not," he said. He put the idea in a book, pestered colleagues, worked with the Reagan Administration and Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Finance Committee, and ultimately lobbied the House by playing basketball with members in the House gym -- an activity he had avoided since his election in 1978.
But that was 13 years ago. Since 1986, he said, "billions of loopholes have come back in and rates have gone back up."
Mr. Bradley argues that his work on various trade measures, from the Uruguay Round to the North American Free Trade Agreement, played important roles in strengthening the economy. And he was an early critic of Moscow's economic policies in the last days of the Soviet Union.
One issue central to his Presidential campaign on which he was almost invisible in Congress is health insurance. In the 1993-94 fight over President Clinton's plan or various alternatives, the Finance Committee on which he served was a central battleground. He explained his inactivity by saying he followed the lead of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the committee chairman, who waited in vain for Republicans to compromise.
To one longtime observer of Congress, Norman J. Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, what made both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley "considerably better than average Senators" was their ability to bring issues to national attention. "Other than Pat Moynihan," he said, "I couldn't pick someone better in the House or Senate to put an issue into play."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ford to Add Safety Bars To Its Big Pickup Trucks
Ford Motor plans to install hollow, energy-absorbing steel bars below the front and rear bumpers of all of its industrial-sized pickup trucks in the 2001 model year to reduce the risk that they will ride over cars in crashes.
Ford is also studying adding such bars to four-wheel-drive versions of its big Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator sport utility vehicles and the F-150 pickup truck to make them less dangerous to other motorists. Page C2. 

Oil Profits Rise, but Stocks Fall
Large oil companies said that third-quarter earnings rose substantially, with some more than doubling. But investors had anticipated the gains because of the increased price of crude oil and took profits. Even ARCO, which showed a sevenfold rise in operating earnings, lost $3.125 a share, to $90.875. C4.
 
Dreamworks and Imagine in Venture
Dreamworks SKG and Imagine Entertainment announced they would create a new Internet entertainment company, to be called Pop.com, and World Wide Web site with a variety of offerings for the rapidly approaching digital entertainment world. C10.
 
Stocks Falter on Profit Taking
Stock prices weakened as traders, worried about higher interest rates, took profits in large capitalization issues after last week's bounce in major averages. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 120.32 points, to 10,349.93; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 8.02, to 1,293.63, and the Nasdaq composite index edged down 0.57, to 2,815.95. C12.
 
Treasury bond prices recouped early losses. The yield on the 30-year bond, after climbing to a two-year high of 6.40 percent, ended at 6.35 percent, up from 6.34 percent on Friday. C12.
 
American Express Meets Forecasts
American Express said its third-quarter profit rose 13 percent, to $648 million, or $1.42 a share, meeting expectations as customers spent more with its credit cards and increased investments with its financial planners. C4.
 
3M Profit Gain Tops Forecasts
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, the maker of Post-It notes and Scotch tape, reported a greater-than-expected 18 percent gain in third-quarter earnings. C4.
 
Buffett Leads MidAmerican Deal
Berkshire Hathaway, the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, is leading an investor group that will buy MidAmerican Energy Holdings for $2 billion. The price, $35.05 a share, represents a 29 percent premium to Friday's closing. The Buffett group, which will also assume about $7 billion in debt, plans to take the company private. C4.
 
Group Plans Wireless Net Access
A group of big technology companies led by Cisco Systems and Motorola said they planned an alliance to create products that would allow consumers to get high-speed Internet access through a wireless system. C2.
 
U.S. and China Finish Meetings
United States-Chinese talks brought no visible progress toward China's proposed entry into the World Trade Organization. C7.
 
Hong Kong Begins Share Sale
Hong Kong's Government begins reselling stock that it bought in a massive market intervention a year ago. Analysts wonder if the sale isn't too much for the market to bear. C6.
 
BMW Raises Stake in Rolls-Royce
BMW raised its stake in aircraft engine maker Rolls-Royce P.L.C. and gave Rolls control of the two companies' joint venture so that BMW can focus on its money-losing Rover unit. C7.
 
French Group Takes Brazilian Stake
A French aerospace consortium agreed to acquire a stake in Embraer, the Brazilian aircraft maker, possibly giving the French companies an advantage in bids to renovate Brazil's fleet of fighter jets. C8.

HEADLINE: Buchanan Bolts G.O.P. for Reform Party Run

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Oct. 25

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan put aside a lifetime of Republican fervor today and shifted his lagging Presidential quest to a run for the Reform Party nomination.
"Our vaunted two-party system is a snare and a delusion and a fraud upon the nation," Mr. Buchanan told a crowd of cheering supporters as he bolted the Republican Party, showing his fiery instinct for insurgency. "Our two parties have become nothing but two wings on the same bird of prey." 
 As visceral on the stump as ever, Mr. Buchanan, his campaign for the Republican nomination frozen in the single-digit doldrums, lambasted the two major parties as havens for big-money donors and "hollow" candidates who have "rigged the game" against him.
"We choose not to play our assigned walk-on role in their sham election," Mr. Buchanan declared to the delight of a partisan crowd that included Reform Party officials and loyalists from his three failed bids for the Republican Presidential nomination.
"Only the Reform Party offers the hope of a real debate and a real choice of destinies," he insisted in resorting to the alternative ticket created by Ross Perot as a lever of populist power in the 1992 Presidential election.
In a bizarre contest for the 2000 nomination taking shape between Reform Party factions, Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, has quit the Republican Party and is threatening to challenge Mr. Buchanan, denouncing him as a "Hitler lover." Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, the party's major elected figure, openly questions Mr. Buchanan's switch of parties. While Mr. Perot is proclaiming neutrality, even the Buchanan supporters agree that Mr. Perot remains a quixotic figure.
As soon as Mr. Buchanan confirmed his third-party course, he was attacked by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican front-runner who is considered the candidate most likely to lose votes next year should Mr. Buchanan attract serious numbers of conservative voters.
Insisting that Mr. Buchanan left the Republican Party for no reason other than a failed candidacy, Mr. Bush criticized Mr. Buchanan's isolationist views, in particular his thesis that Hitler had initially presented no serious threat to the United States in World War II.
"Pat sees an America that should have stayed home while Hitler overran Europe and perpetrated the Holocaust," Mr. Bush contended in a statement expressing confidence that most conservative Republicans would not follow Mr. Buchanan. In the weeks before Mr. Buchanan's announcement, Mr. Bush had refrained from harsh criticism in the hope of keeping him in the party.
But Mr. Buchanan hardly apologized for his views as he rued the decline of "all the great empires of Europe" and the rise of "a superstate in Europe that pays homage to the great god Mammon" which, he said, ties up American soldiers in a "godless new world order."
"They call us isolationists, and that's one of the nicest things they call us," he declared, drawing laughter from the crowd at the Doubletree Hotel here in the western Washington suburbs, miles from what Mr. Buchanan termed "the Beltway elites."
"Well, if they mean I intend to isolate America from all the bloody, territorial, tribal and ethnic wars of the 21st century, I plead guilty!" he boomed, drawing the crowd to its feet in a wave of applause and cheers.
Once more offering himself as the unabashed candidate of America First policies, Mr. Buchanan vowed to "rescue our lady, America" from what he termed "the cultural and moral pit into which she has fallen."
"We need a timeout on legal immigration to ease the downward pressure on workers' wages," he maintained, "And to defeat the forces of separatism that threaten us and nations all over the world."
With fresh campaign logos and a new red, white and blue Internet site (www.buchananreform.com) the 60-year-old politician sought to retool his candidacy with a speech laced with the sorts of lines that first brought him success as a speech writer for President Richard M. Nixon.
The crowd roared as he denounced President Clinton as "our own Elmer Gantry, whose desecration of the temples of our civilization and personal misconduct disqualify him" as the nation's leader.
Supporters roared again as Mr. Buchanan declared, "The appeasement of Beijing is a bipartisan disgrace!"
And they stood and cheered as he bitterly denounced the Supreme Court and vowed to "herd the Justices back into the narrow stalls" of constitutionalism. "What is a self-governing people doing meekly waiting each week for nine jurists to tell us how we may live and how we should govern ourselves?" he demanded, playing to the libertarian instincts of the Reform Party even as he denounced the legalization of abortion in "that abomination they call Roe v. Wade."
Wielding a palette filled with shades of national sovereignty, Mr. Buchanan attacked employment quotas as un-American, declaring: "The backsliding toward hyphenated Americanism must end." In short order, he attacked the United Nations, global economic treaties and "I.M.F. bailouts of deadbeat dictators."
In abandoning a Republican primary contest dominated solidly so far by Mr. Bush, Mr. Buchanan set a course in which he must now fight state by state to win support for the nomination.
"We've got to get on 30 ballots," said Bay Buchanan, Mr. Buchanan's sister and chief strategist.
Ms. Buchanan noted the campaign had hired Matt Sawyer, an election law specialist who had helped Mr. Perot navigate the thicket of widely varying state election laws.
Beyond the 30 states on which Ms. Buchanan is focusing, the Reform Party was already established in 20 states where the Buchanan camp was counting on help from such party veterans as Pat Choate, Mr. Perot's confidante and former Vice-Presidential running mate. Mr. Choate has been openly piloting Mr. Buchanan's veer toward the Reform ticket.
Reform Party rules require a prospective nominee to try to qualify for the ballot in the 29 states, plus the District of Columbia, where the party does not have an automatic slot. The nominee will be selected at a party convention in July.
Mr. Choate conceded Mr. Buchanan might have a problem because of the opposition expressed by Governor Ventura, who is encouraging talk of a Trump candidacy.
"It's not helpful, but it will not keep him from getting the nomination," Mr. Choate said of Mr. Buchanan's chances, estimating that the enthusiastic crowd here of more than 300 people included a majority of the party's current state chairmen.
Republicans have asserted that money, not principle, prompted the switch by Mr. Buchanan. The Reform nominee will be entitled to $12.6 million in Federal campaign funds. But Bay Buchanan said that was not reason for the Reform venture, while Mr. Buchanan insisted that disgust drove him from the Republican Party.
"The Republican Party has been good to me," he told the crowd. "And I have tried to be loyal to it. But as John F. Kennedy said, 'Sometimes party loyalty asks too much.' And today, it asks too much of us."
Expressing anguish at quitting his life-long party, Mr. Buchanan nonetheless beamed in summoning his followers to a new course, using his old imagery of an assault on the castle of the establishment.
"You don't know this peasant army," he said, grinning. "We have not yet begun to fight."
Mr. Buchanan, ever a history buff, noted this was St. Crispin's Day -- a reference to King Henry V's defeat of the superior forces of France at Agincourt on this day in 1415. "Let's make a little history," he said, looking eager as he took up a different battle flag.

HEADLINE: To the Rear, March!

 BODY:
Early on, George W. Bush and some other prominent Republicans went through the motions of trying to prevent Patrick Buchanan's announcement that he was "ending my lifelong membership in the Republican Party." But in the end, no one seemed very upset by Mr. Buchanan's exit or by Donald Trump's simultaneous defection to the Reform Party. But while Mr. Trump's presidential dreaming had the feel of a self-indulgent lark, Mr. Buchanan's seems a blend of financial scheming, retro rage and perhaps a bit of self-delusion. Does anyone believe that Mr. Buchanan's "peasant army" really exists? It may be ready to storm the castle, but it certainly did not help its man in the G.O.P. polls.
Mr. Buchanan's failure to make the grade against Mr. Bush and John McCain will not matter, of course, if he can get hold of the party's $12.6 million in federal funds. Then Mr. Buchanan, a wealthy Washingtonian, will have all the money he needs to mount his faux-populist crusade against the "money boys and the Beltway elites." 
 Fittingly, he embarked on his departure with an allusion to the St. Crispin's Day speech in Shakespeare's "Henry V," a paean to what true leadership meant at the end of the Middle Ages. He then went on to promise battle on a number of issues that most Americans have already worked through. At a time when American culture and economic values are on the march around the globe, Mr. Buchanan wants to save America "before she disappears into a godless New World Order." His mission, he said, is to end the racial quotas that have helped minorities enter the mainstream and to force a "time out" in the immigration that perpetually revitalizes an immigrants' nation. He promised to keep America from entering "all the bloody, territorial, tribal and ethnic wars" of the 21st century, thus crippling the halting but vital effort to find international remedies to genocidal conflicts.
Such efforts to isolate America from the real issues of the 21st century should help isolate Mr. Buchanan. Already his views on why the United States should not have entered World War II against Hitler's Germany have drawn understandable outrage, not only from veterans but also historians. Mr. Trump, who sees himself as a possible antidote to the Buchanan forces, calls Mr. Buchanan a "Hitler lover." Mr. Buchanan has rejected such a label, but his warlike oratory draws fringe voters and surrounds his candidacy with the persistent whiff of racism and anti-Semitism.
Mr. Buchanan seems to believe that his divisive social views will open up pockets of discontent in the middle class and that his protectionist trade policy and promises of job protection can pull in suburban and union workers normally loyal to the major parties. First, of course, he must wrest the Reform Party from the likes of Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, Ross Perot, whose ambitions for the party are still fairly cloudy, and perhaps even Mr. Trump. Meanwhile, we have to wonder if the idealists who initially joined the Reform Party think that roster adds up to a rational definition of reform.

HEADLINE: Argentina After Mr. Menem

 BODY:
Argentine voters have clearly wearied of the flamboyant style of President Carlos Saul Menem, who rode the old populist party of Juan Domingo Peron to power in 1989 and has held office ever since. On Sunday they resoundingly elected Fernando de la Rua, the decidedly uncharismatic, non-Peronist Mayor of Buenos Aires, to succeed Mr. Menem after his second term ends in December.
Yet a more positive aspect of Mr. Menem's legacy was evident in the campaign and voting, which were notable for their democratic ordinariness in a country where presidential transitions have typically been accompanied by calls to class warfare and rumblings of military revolt. During his two terms Mr. Menem successfully weaned the military of its addiction to coups, completed Peronism's evolution from a demagogic movement to a responsible political party, and returned Argentina to the mainstream of international affairs after decades of protectionism and reflexive opposition to Washington and much of the modern world. 
 Many of Mr. Menem's achievements stemmed from his unexpected decision early in his first term to embrace free trade and monetary orthodoxy. Until then, Argentine democracy was chronically weakened by frequent bouts of hyperinflation that sometimes provided the excuse for military intervention. But the Menem years were also marred by charges of judicial manipulation and corruption. For many years, human rights issues stemming from the "dirty war" of the 1970's and early 1980's were shoved aside until public opinion forced the government to re-examine cases of military kidnapping, torture and murder.
Throughout all this, Mr. Menem retained much of his personal popularity. But the Argentine Constitution prevented him from running this year. the Peronists ran a candidate, Eduardo Duhalde, who seemed to portend a continuation of the past decade's cronyism without its reforms. The voters preferred Mr. de la Rua, who promised to halt corruption and end the impunity of the politically well connected from prosecution.
That will be his biggest challenge, and it will not be easy. Mr. de la Rua will have to work with Menem-era judges and a Peronist-dominated Senate. What he will most likely not have to worry about is military plotting or an opposition that does not respect democracy's ground rules. For that, Mr. Menem deserves much of the credit.

HEADLINE: John Chafee, Republican Senator and a Leading Voice of Bipartisanship, Dies at 77

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, the last of the Rockefeller Republicans and an increasingly isolated voice of internationalism and bipartisanship in his party, died on Sunday.
Senator Chafee died of heart failure at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., a Washington suburb, his office announced. He was 77. 
 His major domestic efforts involved the environment and health policy, and he was responsible for a vast expansion of Medicaid, the Federal health program for the poor, in the 1980's.
A Marine veteran of Guadalcanal and the Korean War, Mr. Chafee made his last major effort in the Senate this month in seeking to postpone a vote on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. When the Senate went ahead and voted on the pact that would have banned underground nuclear testing, he was one of four Republicans to support ratification.
In his final Senate speech, on Oct. 13, he said, "We signed this treaty recognizing that discouraging other nuclear powers and would-be nuclear powers from testing these weapons would lessen the unthinkable possibility that the nuclear option would ever be employed."
Far from threatening American security, he said, the treaty "locks in a status quo in which the United States has an enormous advantage."
In partisan terms, his death will not change the Senate's 55-to-45 Republican advantage. Lincoln C. Almond, Rhode Island's Republican Governor and a Chafee protege, will appoint a successor to serve until Jan. 3, 2001. Among the early favorites is Lincoln Chafee, the Senator's son, who is the Mayor of Warwick. Lincoln Chafee was already a candidate for his father's seat after the elder Chafee announced on March 15 that he would retire when this term ended.
The most immediate impact in the Senate could be on environmental issues. Senator Chafee, as chairman of the Committee on Environment and Public Works, has bottled up a number of pro-business changes in environmental laws that other Republicans want. Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire, who announced this year that he was leaving the Republican Party but who still enjoys its seniority, is next in line for the chairmanship.
But a spokesman for Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, said today that it was "premature for any kind of discussion" of the chairmanship.
In a larger sense, Mr. Chafee's death leaves the Senate with only two relatively moderate Republicans in positions of power.
Senator John W. Warner of Virginia is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, and Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana heads the Agriculture Committee. But neither has been as eager as Mr. Chafee to work with Democrats or as ready to cross the Republican leadership.
In recent years the Senate has lost a significant group of Republicans who found it natural to seek bipartisan alliances: Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, John C. Danforth of Missouri, Nancy Kassebaum Baker of Kansas, Hank Brown of Colorado.
Today that talent, exemplified by Mr. Chafee, was cheered chiefly by Democrats. Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a frequent collaborator on issues like health care and welfare reform, said: "We lost one who was part of our centrist coalition, and the country has lost someone who was always putting his country ahead of party politics. He was part of a group that should be growing in numbers, not diminishing, but we become more polarized each year.
"The Senate and this country have lost a leader who put his country's interests before partisan politics."
President Clinton, who had hoped in vain for Mr. Chafee's help on national health insurance in 1993 and 1994, said today: "Rhode Island and America have lost a great leader and a fine human being, who in 23 years in the Senate and in his service as Secretary of the Navy, always put his concern for the American people above partisanship. When you think of the term 'bipartisan,' you immediately think of John Chafee."
And while some Republican conservatives have sniped at Mr. Chafee over the years, and even dumped him from the chairmanship of their party conference in 1990, their reactions today were warm.
Senators were visibly upset as they spoke and after they left the floor. One whose voice broke with emotion was Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, declined to speak to a reporter about a national security budget matter, saying he had just finished giving a Chafee tribute.
John Hubbard Chafee was descended from one of the "five families" of Rhode Island, Yankees who ran the state before immigrants changed its political complexion in the 30's.
He was at Yale when World War II began and he enlisted in the Marines, serving in battles at Guadalcanal and Okinawa, and was commissioned as a second lieutenant. He returned to Yale and went to Harvard Law School before being recalled to active duty in Korea in 1951.
He practiced law and served six years in the Rhode Island Legislature, becoming minority leader of the State Assembly. In 1962 he became only the third Republican elected governor in 30 years, squeaking through by 398 votes.
He was an unabashedly liberal governor. He pushed for anti-discrimination laws in housing and employment before the Federal Government passed them. He advocated the construction of Interstate 95, developed parks throughout the small state and pushed through a state plan of health care for the elderly before Congress enacted Medicare.
In Presidential politics, Mr. Chafee had opposed Barry Goldwater's bid for the 1964 Republican nomination, and in 1968 he backed Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York against Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan. While Mr. Rockefeller got all 14 of Rhode Island's delegate votes, it was not nearly enough.
Mr. Chafee himself was victim of a political upset that fall, losing a bid for a fourth term as governor to Frank Licht. Mr. Chafee had halted his campaigning after his 14-year-old daughter, Tribbie, had died a few weeks before the election after being kicked in the head by a horse.
 But despite his support for Mr. Rockefeller, the Nixon Administration found a place for him, and he reveled in the post of Navy Secretary. His most striking decision was made on May 6, 1969, when he blocked any court martial of the commander and the intelligence officer of the Pueblo, which had been captured by North Korea in 1968.
They had been held prisoner for 11 months, and Secretary Chafee said, "They have suffered enough." Moreover, he concluded that the capture was the result of a failure shared by the entire Navy chain of command.
"The major factor which led to the Pueblo's only confrontation by unanticipated bold and hostile forces was the sudden collapse of a premise which had been assumed at every level of responsibility and upon which every other aspect of the mission had been based -- freedom of the high seas," he wrote. "The consequences must in fairness be borne by all, rather than by one or two individuals whom circumstances had placed closer to the actual event."
He resigned in 1972 and ran for the Senate against Claiborne Pell. But in a strongly Democratic state, he lost despite Mr. Nixon's landslide. After that Mr. Chafee returned to practicing law in Providence, until he ran again for the Senate in 1976 and won.
The Senate he joined in 1977 was a far less partisan institution than today's, and he could support President Carter and the Panama Canal treaty without repercussions from his Republican colleagues. And when Ronald Reagan was elected in 1980, Mr. Chafee eagerly proclaimed it a Republican victory, not a conservative one, and promised moderate support on major issues like the economy.
But he also moved forward with his own priorities. Year after year in the 1980's, as Congress cut the budget for other social programs, he engineered expansions of Medicaid, extending coverage to millions of pregnant women and children.
Taken together, the changes altered a basic concept of Medicaid, breaking the link that for more than two decades had tied Medicaid eligibility to the receipt of cash welfare benefits. As a result of his efforts, Congress allowed and in some cases required states to help pay medical bills for certain low-income people who were not receiving welfare.
Mr. Chafee helped write a provision of the 1996 welfare law intended to guarantee continued Medicaid coverage for families losing cash assistance.
Sara Rosenbaum, a professor of health law and policy at George Washington University, said: "Senator Chafee was involved in virtually every important change in the Medicaid program since the late 1970's. He led efforts to expand maternal and child health programs. He had an undying commitment to Medicaid recipients with disabilities. He made great efforts to preserve and strengthen the health care safety net, assuring adequate payments for community health centers that care for huge numbers of uninsured patients."
Despite fighting the Reagan Administration over military spending, he was elected to the Senate Republicans' third-ranking position, chairman of the Republican Conference, in 1984. He was ousted from that position in 1990 by the more conservative Thad Cochran of Mississippi, who in turn was pushed aside by more conservative rivals.
But that year he also played a central role in reauthorizing the Clean Air Act, one of the nation's landmark environmental laws. That was only one of the achievements hailed by environmentalists today. Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club, cited that bill and also said Mr. Chafee played an even greater role later as a "one-man front line" defending laws against the "Republican far-right wing."
"No one will ever know how many bad things did not happen in the last three years because John Chafee was there," Mr. Pope said. At least one of Mr. Pope's evils was easy to identify. When Republicans recaptured the Senate in 1995, Mr. Chafee became chairman of the Environment Committee. He showed a chairman's power when he simply refused to bring up a rewritten version of the landmark Clean Water Act of 1972. The House-passed measure would have weakened or revoked a number of pollution control requirements.
In the 1990's, despite the loss of his formal Republican Party leadership position, his friend Senator Bob Dole of Kansas put him in charge of a task force to define Republican policy on national health insurance. The Chafee group rejected the idea of requiring employers to buy coverage for their workers, which was central to the Democratic plan, but instead advocated requiring people to get insurance, with Federal subsidies for those who could not afford it.
As the issue heated up in 1993 and 1994, Mr. Dole backed away from it. When Mr. Chafee, Mr. Breaux and others struggled, in dozens of meetings in a Capitol hideaway, to compromise with the Clinton plan, they could get no more than a handful of Republicans who would vote to break the Dole filibuster. Their effort, like Mr. Clinton's, foundered.
Mr. Danforth, a central ally in that cause and a frequent dinner companion during late Senate nights, reflected today that one of the best things about Mr. Chafee at that moment was that "when it fell apart, there was no bitterness." Mr. Danforth added: "He was a person who really wanted to make things better. He was the opposite of an 'aginner.' "
And while the big effort failed, elements of the Chafee-Breaux "Mainstream Coalition" plan reappeared in law in later years, and Mr. Chafee played a major role in getting a plan to insure more children -- though it was initiated by Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah -- enacted in 1997.
But while Mr. Chafee clashed often with the increasingly conservative Republican Senate leadership, he was hardly predictable. Among his last votes was opposition to an effort to cut off debate on campaign finance legislation last week. He said the bill had been weakened too much.
He is survived by his wife, Virginia; four sons, John Jr., of Los Angeles, Lincoln, of Warwick, Quentin, of North Kingstown, R.I., and Zechariah, of Providence, R.I.; a daughter, Georgia Nassikas of McLean, Va.; three sisters, Janet Cushman of Quebec, Susan Welch of Bethany, Conn., and Alexandra Reynolds of North Kingstown, and 12 grandchildren.
Mr. Chafee's sense of history was central to his final public appearance, last Thursday night. He spoke at the Washington National Cathedral to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the National Trust for Historic Preservation.
He said: "Naysayers may ask, What difference does saving one train station or post office truly make in the future of America? My response is this: Preservation is not just about preserving brick and mortar, lintel and beam. It is about the quality of life, and the possibility of a bright future. Carl Sandburg expressed the danger of losing touch with our past when he said, 'If America forgets where she came from, if people lose sight of what brought them along, then will begin the rot and dissolution.' "

HEADLINE: Growers' Lament: The Crop's Bright Red, but So Is the Ink

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: ENTIAT, Wash.

 BODY:
In one way, the news this year from Bruce Grim's orchard, and from orchards all over this region that proudly calls itself the Apple Capital of the World, is very good news indeed. "Vintage!" Mr. Grim proclaimed as he plucked a red Delicious from a tree and sliced it open with a pocketknife. "Lots of crunch. Lots of snap."
"Great internals," he said, referring to the flavor and texture. "Terrific external, too," he added, appraising the color. 
 But wide agreement about the outstanding quality of this year's crop in the nation's top apple-producing state belies a disturbing trend: no one here seems to be making any money growing apples.
For the last several years, growers here have had to deal with some of their worst times ever, a result of stagnation in domestic demand, grocery-industry consolidation that gives large buyers the upper hand in negotiating price, and a flood of imports from China that has driven the price of apples used in making juice so low that last year many farmers, rather than picking all their product, simply let some of it rot in the orchard.
That the nation's economy is roaring along in so many other respects only makes the plight of those who grow this most American of fruits all the more frustrating.
"I keep reading about the big economic boom in Seattle," 150 miles to the west, on the other side of the Cascade Mountains, said Grant Daniel, a grower just across the Columbia River from Mr. Grim. "Well, there's no boom going on out here on these orchards."
Last year the state's apple growers saw their lowest return in three decades, with the typical family orchard, of 50 acres, losing between $70,000 and $100,000, according to the Washington Growers Clearing House Association, an industry group. The association says that 20 percent of the state's growers have gone out of business in the last five years and that another 20 percent, or 800 orchards, will do so over the next three years.
"A lot of people have financed this year's crop on the credit card," said Kirk Mayer, the association's manager. "They're basically trying to buy their orchard all over again from the bank. But it's a very uphill proposition."
Washington State grows about half of all the nation's apples, followed by New York and Michigan, with about 10 percent each. Growers of all apple varieties in those states and elsewhere around the country received an average of 17.1 cents a pound for their product last year, 18 percent to 29 percent less than in the three years before and, after adjustment for inflation, one of the lowest prices since the Great Depression, said Kraig Naasz, president of the U.S. Apple Association, a national trade group.
The decline in prices for juice apples, generally of lower quality than apples marketed for eating, has been even more stark. Having averaged $189 a ton in 1995, those prices have dropped consistently since then, to an average of $40 a ton last year; many growers around here say they got as little as $10 a ton.
The apple association, arguing that "a flood of cheap apple-juice concentrate imports from China is drowning much of our industry in a sea of red ink," filed a petition earlier this year with the United States Department of Commerce and the Government's International Trade Commission. The association argued that China, now the largest apple producer in the world, was dumping its product -- that is, deliberately undercutting American apples by selling at below-cost prices -- and sought punitive tariffs on the United States' Chinese apple-juice imports. A decision is expected later this fall.
In the meantime, though, many growers here either have given up or say they are on the verge of going broke. Many say, too, that they are particularly angry that even as the prices they receive have plunged in recent years, the cost to the consumer has actually inched upward slightly over the last decade.
It is not at all hard to understand just why that is happening. Consolidation in the grocery industry, for one thing, has clearly given an advantage to the buyers.
"When you have over 100 suppliers in the state of Washington alone competing for the business of 5 major buyers," Mr. Naasz said, "it's easy to see who has the leverage in those price negotiations, and it isn't the apple grower."
Not that the growers themselves are necessarily immune from responsibility for their plight. For one thing, they may simply have planted too many trees in recent decades, especially those that bear the benchmark red Delicious apple, still the No. 1 seller in the grocery store but typically so plentiful that it fetches a lower price than many other varieties.
Now some growers here, in a frenzied bid to carve out their place in "niche markets," are ripping Delicious trees out of their orchards and experimenting with exotic varieties that many people find far superior in taste and quality. And other growers are completely abandoning a fruit that long provided them a livelihood.
"I think apples are a thing of the past," said George Kapral, who has been growing them for 49 years. His 40-acre orchard once bore almost nothing but apples, but he has ripped out so many apple trees over the years in favor of pear that the share for apples is now down to 4 acres; next year, it will be 2.
Part of the problem is that American consumption of apples has leveled off at around 20 pounds a person per year (compared with 35 pounds in Canada and 50 pounds in parts of Europe).
"The competition is greater than ever before for a share of the customer's stomach," Mr. Naasz said. "There are all kinds of snacks out there."
Some food critics say demand has flattened because apples simply do not taste as good as they once did. The red Delicious in particular, they say, has been bred over the years for color and size uniformity, and has lost some of its flavor in the process.
In any event, Washington growers, trying to stimulate demand, have imposed a variety of fees on themselves for a promotional campaign to persuade Americans to eat an extra apple a day.
The weather here this year -- warm, but not too warm during the day, cool at night, with just the right amount of rain -- has combined with the area's rich volcanic soil to turn out a crop of ideal quality, although one that is expected to be a bit smaller than last year's. Taken together, those factors could lead to better prices as the apples come in at warehouses this fall, said Mr. Mayer, of the Washington Growers Clearing House Association. But, he said, it will take more than one good season to make up for the punishingly low returns of recent years.
Mr. Grim, who lost $63,000 last year growing apples on his 90 acres of orchards, said many suppliers felt particularly frustrated because they grew up in a time when big families made a fine living working orchards much smaller.
"It used to be that a family could raise their kids, send them to school, have a good life in this community, growing on 10 to 15 acres," said Mr. Grim, a third-generation grower. "Well, now I'm farming about seven or eight of those, and I'm not making any money at all."

HEADLINE: $50 Million Voted to Rebuild in Flood Area

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Reacting to weeks of complaints that state officials were slow to help victims of last month's flood, New Jersey legislators passed a bill today that dedicates $50 million to repair homes damaged by Tropical Storm Floyd.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed it into law less than two hours later, and said she would travel to Washington on Tuesday to ask Federal officials for more aid. 
 The flood relief, part of an $80 million emergency aid package, will provide grants of up to $15,000 to homeowners whose property damage is not covered by insurance or Federal disaster aid. The state will also set aside $20 million to help farmers whose crops were destroyed by the summer drought and $10 million to reimburse public agencies for overtime, supplies and other flood-related costs.
The state money is in addition to the $18 million in disaster aid already given to New Jersey residents by the Federal Emergency Management Agency. One agency official said he thought that state residents would ultimately receive $100 million in loans and grants.
During a fund-raising trip to the state last week, President Clinton announced that he would release $43 million in community block grants, scheduled for next year, to state officials and municipalities..
But Governor Whitman said today that the total amount of damage might reach $1 billion and that the state Office of Emergency Management had estimated that as much as $250 million in losses were not covered by insurance. The Governor has scheduled meetings with several Congressional and White House officials in hopes of persuading them to provide additional grantsto victims of the flood.
"These state grants are going to go a long way in helping New Jerseyans recover from the devastation of Tropical Storm Floyd, but the need is still great," the Governor said.
The state's decision to grant homeowners $50 million in disaster aid was a victory for residents and elected officials from the nine New Jersey counties declared disaster areas after flooding from record-setting rain destroyed 71 homes, 75 businesses and 105 apartments and damaged another 27,000 residences and 1,700 businesses. In the weeks after the flood, some residents were so angry they picketed legislative leaders and demanded assistance.
The leader of some of those protests, Mayor Frank Gilley of Bound Brook, said he thought the state's aid package was a good, although late, beginning. Assemblyman Gerald B. Green, Democrat of Plainfield, said that legislative leaders were trying to streamline the process to provide aid the victims of future disasters.

HEADLINE: 'My Hometown,' the Sequel;
Success Transforms Springsteen's Bleak Birthplace

BYLINE: By ALAN FEUER 

DATELINE: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 22

 BODY:
The big factories are gone now, and the old-timers no longer shuffle off to the Court Jester after swing shifts at the textile mill. The local kids these days are more likely to be at home watching "Seinfeld" reruns than down by the railroad tracks drinking beer on the hoods of their hemi-powered Plymouths.
For years, Freehold has been best known as the birthplace of Bruce Springsteen, a workingman's town that inspired songs like "Thunder Road" and "My Hometown." But what was once a quiet enclave of blue-collar families, farmers and factory hands has been transformed as Freehold has found itself at ground zero of one of New Jersey's most spectacular real-estate booms. 
 In a fashion that many Springsteen fans -- let alone longtime residents -- could never have imagined, what many people here seem to fear these days are not the shuttered plants and dead-end dreams of 20 years ago, but the encroaching cul-de-sacs, minivans and suburban sprawl.
"We weathered through all the jobs pulling out, Main Street looking like a bomb went off -- and those were rough times," said Dick Jasper, 41, a plumber. "But this is different. You can't mess with so-called progress. That's the American way."
While few new buildings have gone up in the tiny borough of Freehold, the region is exploding. In the last eight years, almost 2,000 single-family homes have been erected in Freehold Township, which surrounds Freehold the way a doughnut surrounds its hole. In Howell Township, to the south, the population has doubled to 50,000 from 25,000 in the last decade.
The boom has been kind to businesses in Freehold, where Main Street, with its charming restaurants and antique shops, attracts hundreds of people every weekend from the suburbs that stretch for miles on all sides. With developers flocking to the region, officials in Freehold have been able to start restoring several long-blighted sections of the borough.
Nonetheless, the building surge has created problems, residents say. Sleepy streets are now clogged with traffic. Property and school taxes have risen. People complain about garbage collection, parking and the flood of newcomers, including Mexican immigrants competing for jobs in a tight labor market.
More important, they say, the sociable, if stifling, small-town world that Mr. Springsteen sings about is slowly disappearing. People here are struggling to balance the commercial benefits of affluence with the possible damage it could do to Freehold's hard-working, nod-to-your-neighbor roots.
"We're stuck in the middle of the boom all around us," said Mike Wilson, the Mayor of Freehold, who, as a real estate broker, sees tremendous opportunity in growth. "You can feel the traffic. There are new people moving in. But things change; it's inevitable. Nothing remains the same."
In many ways, Freehold's history is the classic American small-town story. In the 18th and 19th centuries, it served as an agricultural hub for a region of independent farmers whose grain, corn and tomatoes fed a good portion of central New Jersey.
During the Industrial Revolution, Freehold, in Monmouth County, became a borough of textile mills and glass plants before the industries moved south in the 1960's and 1970's in search of cheaper payrolls.
It was the decline of this broad-shouldered era that produced Mr. Springsteen and his vision of Freehold as a close-knit but claustrophobic place where most people ground out their lives to the metronome of an hourly wage and from which only the brave or the lucky escaped.
But Freehold's most recent incarnation is twofold, officials say. It serves as both a cozy place for young families looking for starter homes and as a prettified, service-oriented weekend destination for the multitudes in the grid of housing developments on all sides.
To get a sense of just how much things in the Freehold area have changed, a visitor need only look at two old photographs outside Mayor Wilson's office. The first, an aerial shot taken decades ago, shows Freehold surrounded by a swath of swaying cornfields. Today, rows and rows of new hulking houses are packed together so tightly they look like bull-necked men stuffed in an elevator.
The second picture is of Main Street in 1988. The sidewalks are cracked and shabby. Many storefronts are dark and drab. Some are boarded up. These days, that once-bleak strip thrives with cafes, Victorian-style street lamps and sprightly coffee joints.
But such signs of Freehold's new affluence worry some old-timers, who fear that the people attracted to these places are not the kinds of folks who have always lived in Freehold. Some longtime residents are like Frank Federici, the owner of Federici's Pizzeria, who said that although his business had grown by 25 percent in the last few years, his new customers had changed the character of the borough.
"Sure, business has been better," said Mr. Federici, 75, who was born in the apartment above his restaurant (and is no relation to Danny Federici, who plays in Mr. Springsteen's band). "But I'm not sure I like it. I used to look out the window and recognize 99 percent of the faces. Now, it's less than half."
Part of the problem is that cheap land, a slower pace of life and bucolic touches like U-Pick-'Em pumpkin patches have drawn newcomers from places like Brooklyn, Queens and western Long Island. Many are prosperous baby boomers whose children are grown and who are looking to restart their lives in large, new, custom-built houses, said Dr. James W. Hughes, a dean at Rutgers University who published a study on New Jersey's emerging wealth and population centers last month.
"The blue-collar people in towns like Freehold may not have the same desires as the new McMansion owners in terms of parkland, tax levels, schools or expansion," said Dr. Hughes, who runs the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy. "But if there's any bitterness, I think it's been mitigated by the strength of the overall economy."
Many lifelong Freehold residents would disagree. Ask them what they think about the city people, and many will say that everyone gets along. Scratch a little deeper, though, and hints of distrust and disappointment surface.
"The silly thing is this," said John Boyle, 65, a retired postman. "So many New Yorker types have come down here to live the country life that there's barely any country left."
One of the sorest issues is traffic, which, by all accounts, has become much more congested in recent years, largely because Freehold sits at the center of the highway nexus that links the subdivisions and strip malls around it.
"This town's gone crazy," said Mr. Jasper, the plumber, trapped in his mud-caked pickup the other day in a stalled line of New York-bound commuters that stretched down Route 537 in the early morning rush.
"I used to be able to do this drive in 10 or 15 minutes," he said as he looked in the rearview mirror, shaking his head at a man in a Ford Explorer behind him with a cellular phone wedged between his shoulder and his ear. "But now it takes so long, I ought to dump my truck and walk."
Another flash point is school levies. Because of the rapid population growth, the region has become inundated with school-age children. In 1997, the regional school system added a sixth high school, and in December, taxpayers will vote on whether to pay about $68 million to build additions to schools.
But in Freehold, where the population of 11,000 has barely budged, many people feel they are footing the bill for the explosion around them. "That's where you really feel this thing -- in your taxes," said John Wayne DuBois, 55, a retired municipal sewer worker. "They've gone sky high. With the regional system, you have one superintendent, six assistants and six assistant assistants, and you're talking big-time salaries there."
Mayor Wilson said property and school taxes in Freehold had increased at a modest rate of about 5 percent over the last four or five years. To people like Mr. DuBois or Doug Martin, a roofer eating lunch down the block from the American Legion, that seems like a lot.
"Hey, I consider myself lucky because the roofing business has been good to me the last few years," Mr. Martin, 51, said. "Still, my kids are in Catholic schools and I'm paying school taxes for a system I don't even use. I'm surviving. But, yeah, it's tough."
Adding to the burden of taxes, Mr. Martin said, is the increased competition for jobs brought on by immigration. He said that many people in Freehold have lost work recently to hundreds of Mexican immigrants who have come to the borough, attracted by the growth in housing construction jobs. Typically, he said, the immigrants are willing to work for lower pay than longtime residents in restaurant, construction and landscaping jobs.
"Look, no one wants to say that people can't work for a living," Mr. Martin acknowledged. "But some of these guys are illegals, and they're taking jobs from people who have lived here all their life."
Many of the immigrants know they are unwanted, said Aurelio Morales, 34, who came to Freehold from Sonora two years ago. But they stay because jobs in town are relatively well-paying and plentiful, he said.
"We want to work," Mr. Morales said. "Just live here and work."
Complaints of illegal immigration have increased to the point that the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service has appeared in Freehold several times to investigate, Mayor Wilson said.
Some complaints involve accusations that Mexican immigrants crowd several families into a single house, in violation of local ordinances. To deal with the problem, the Mayor said, the borough has established a $1,500 fine for any landlord who allows such overcrowding. In addition, borough officials have started working with local clergy members to ease a sense of fear and bias among some residents, Mr. Wilson said.
Immigration is just one of the challenges the new Freehold faces, but it seems to encapsulate the shift from small-town simplicity to suburban diversity and growth that has perplexed people who were born and grew up here.
"This is a great town and I would never leave it, never could leave it," Mr. Martin said. "But sometimes I look around and wonder what's happened to the place. It's actually hard to say. There's just not much here from when I was a kid."

HEADLINE: Mayor Says Charter Changes Will Protect the City's Gains

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Embarking on a last-minute campaign for changes in the City Charter, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday strongly urged New Yorkers to approve the revisions by telling them that the city could easily revert to a place of rampant crime and poverty after he leaves office.
Ending his relative silence of recent weeks on the subject, the Mayor told members of the New York City Partnership/Chamber of Commerce that voters' approval next Tuesday of the 14 proposals, including a cap on some city spending increases, would cement many of the successes of his administration. 
 "Every sense that someone has of logic, history, sociology, would say that after the end of this administration the city was going to go back in the other direction," Mr. Giuliani said in a 40-minute speech. "Why not? That's the way it was in the 60's, in the 70's, in the 80's, in the 90's."
"Please never, never forget the power of philosophy and ideas," he added later. "It was the power of ideas and philosophy that had this city deteriorating for 20 to 30 years, and it's the power of philosophy and ideas that has this city in a renaissance right now and we have got to make those things permanent. Charter revision gives us an opportunity to do some of that."
The proposed changes include imposing the cap on city spending increases tied to the rate of inflation, requiring a two-thirds vote by the City Council to approve any tax increases, establishing the Administration for Children's Services as an independent agency, creating a permanent organized-crime control commission and setting gun-free zones within 1,000 feet of schools.
Mr. Giuliani's passion in embracing the proposals, which were developed over the summer by a commission he appointed, and his insistence in asking voters to see them as an affirmation of his record, are something of a surprise. Just last week he chastised a reporter who asked about the charter, saying the rest of the city was more interested in the baseball playoffs.
At his daily news conference, which followed his address to the Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Giuliani said the Yankees' participation in the World Series continued to play a role in his scheduling. "Notice that today, there's no baseball today," he said, explaining his timing of yesterday's speech. "No game tonight. Today's a rest day." And, noting that Election Day is next week, he added, "We're also running out of time."
Both supporters and opponents of the charter proposals expect an extremely low turnout in next week's ballot referendum, not because of baseball but because it is an off political year in which not a single major office anywhere in the city is being vigorously contested. Election officials expect 300,000 to 500,000 people to vote, between 10 percent and 15 percent of the electorate. The 14 changes must be approved or rejected as a group, not individually.
Mr. Giuliani himself had seemed to lose interest in the revision process after his commission decided to abandon consideration of a change he had sought: a special election for mayor to be held 60 days after the office becomes vacant. Under present law, the Public Advocate succeeds to the office, and if the Mayor is elected to the United States Senate next year, he would have to end his term a year early.
The Public Advocate, Mark Green, is a political enemy of the Mayor, who was loudly criticized for trying to change the city's basic governing document simply to thwart Mr. Green's ambitions. Mr. Green, who opposes the charter changes, toned down his opposition to the process after that proposal was dropped.
In his speech yesterday, Mr. Giuliani touched briefly on the issue of mayoral succession, saying he wished it could have been included on the ballot. "The succession issue I think is also important," he said. "And I think it's a shame that it can't be done right now. I think if it were done right now, it would imperil all of the other changes." He added, "For the future of the city, it should be done."
For most of his speech, however, Mr. Giuliani spoke of how the 14 proposed changes would help perpetuate his initiatives. He said that proposals creating the school safety zones and requiring all guns to have trigger locks would help keep crime down. He said the budget proposals would help sustain the city's strong economy.
"The ideas contained in the charter revision all help to assure that the gains that we have made in the last five years, which is a relatively short period of time in the history of any city or institution, will continue in that direction," he said.
The Mayor frequently strayed from his lectern during a presentation of graphs and charts concerning his policies. At one point, he moved in front of the projector, and when he was asked to move, he dryly replied, "I'm actually trying to create a shadow -- that's the whole idea of this."
Opponents of the charter revision process, including Mr. Green and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, have described the changes as ill-conceived and largely unnecessary proposals that could be accomplished through legislation or that are already in place, having been instituted by local law or by the Mayor's executive order.
Repeating his criticism yesterday, Mr. Vallone warned that the proposed changes would handcuff the City Council in setting tax policy and could encourage future increases in property taxes. "It would be consigning this city for evermore to having one of the highest real estate taxes ever because it makes it so difficult to do anything other than adopt the real estate tax," he said.
In an effort to drum up interest in the charter referendum, the Mayor's Charter Revision Commission has sent a pamphlet to every household with a registered voter, urging support for the changes. The City Council, whose members say the proposed changes will limit their budgetary powers, also sent out a flier to 375,000 likely voters, urging them to reject the changes.
Both mailings came under attack by civic groups who said that taxpayer dollars should not be used to support or oppose the charter referendum, but simply to inform voters about it.
The New York City Campaign Finance Board had already paid $1.5 million to distribute its own information booklet, which explains the changes and includes statements from all sides.

3,000 Honor Officer Killed in Line of Duty

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
About 3,000 law enforcement officers from around the country paid their respects yesterday to a police officer who was killed last week while trying to end a standoff with a barricaded suspect.
Cpl. Steven L. Levy, 35, was the first member of the Gloucester County Police Department killed in the line of duty. He was shot to death early Thursday during a domestic disturbance in Woodbury by a suspect who killed himself. 
 Corporal Levy was the first of three officers to enter the house where the gunman, Michael DeMore, had been barricaded for hours. It is believed that Corporal Levy was shot in the face when he lowered his bulletproof shield to break down a door. Mr. DeMore, 32, an unemployed truck driver who had a history of mental problems, was found dead several hours later from a self-inflicted shotgun wound to the head.

HEADLINE: Barbara Wolff, 58, City Official Active in New York Development

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Barbara Wolff, a veteran New York City official who was instrumental in setting up the city's business improvement districts program and in the commercial revitalization program that followed the blackout of 1977, died Oct. 15 at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 58.
The cause was ovarian cancer, said George Glatter, a friend and colleague, who said Ms. Wolff had kept coming to her office until several weeks ago. 
 Ms. Wolff was assistant commissioner in charge of the neighborhood development division of the New York City Department of Business Services, a job she had held for more than a decade. The division develops and oversees economic programs designed to benefit neighborhood commercial streets, industrial areas and other economic centers in the city.
In that post and for some years earlier she played a leading role in creating the business improvement districts known as B.I.D.'s, which now number more than 40. They are self-financing organizations directed by local property owners and businesses. The districts offer a variety of services, including sanitation, security, promotion and marketing. The services are tailored to each district's needs and supplement the services the city provides.
The biggest districts include those for the Lower Manhattan, Grand Central and Times Square areas. The smallest are strips of commercial establishments in neighborhoods like the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn and the Steinway Street area of Queens.
The program has been credited with strengthening many commercial areas and some industrial ones by helping attract new businesses and persuading others to stay.
From 1977 to 1983, Ms. Wolff was with the city's Office for Economic Development as its director of commercial revitalization. Mr. Glatter, a deputy assistant commissioner in the business services department, said Ms. Wolff had directed the program, begun as a response to the damage inflicted on stores around the city in the looting that took place during the 1977 blackout.
The program has made use of Federal and city funds over the years to provide various kinds of aid to local businesses and groups.
Ms. Wolff was born in Manhattan and graduated from Hunter High School. She received a bachelor's degree from Simmons College in Boston and a master's degree in political science from the University of California at Berkeley.
She also worked for the International Labor Organization in Geneva, the United States Agency for International Development in Washington, the Parks and City Planning departments in New York and the City's Public Development Corporation, where she was a vice president.
She is survived by a brother, William Wolff of Los Angeles.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 27, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Barbara Wolff, a New York City official who was instrumental in setting up the city's business improvement districts, misstated the date of her death. It was this past Friday, not Oct. 15.
