HEADLINE: In High Technology, the Grind Evolves

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
In May 1994, Jeff Treuhaft, 25, joined a little Silicon Valley start-up called Mosaic, later to be renamed the Netscape Communications Corporation. The pace was brutal -- 18 hours a day, seven days a week in the early months -- but the work was exhilarating.
"The really tough part was that my son was 9 weeks old when I started at Netscape," he recalled. 
 Five years later, Mr. Treuhaft has two more children and a tidy nest egg from the sale of Netscape this year to America Online. Like many former Netscape executives, he is stepping back from the front lines of the Internet business, working part time as an investor and adviser to a few start-ups.
Suddenly, Mr. Treuhaft finds himself free to play with his children, feed them lunch, even tag along on a school field trip to the pumpkin patch down the road. "It seems mundane stuff," he said, "but when you finally get a chance to do it, you appreciate it."
At Microsoft, Netscape's main rival in the infamous Internet browser battle, some have made similar personal choices. Brad Silverberg, a former senior vice president, took a sabbatical in the summer of 1997 to decompress after directing Microsoft's hurried march to catch up and then gain leadership in the Internet software business. He took a solo bicycle trip through the Canadian Rockies, spent time with his wife and two children and thought about all the personal things that had been shunted aside for work.
"Time is the one thing you cannot get back," said Mr. Silverberg, 45, who now works part time as an investor and adviser to start-ups.
The trade-off choices made in so many American households of personal life versus work, time versus money, are magnified in the Internet economy. The time pressure is so intense because a lead of just a few weeks or months over a rival can be a huge competitive advantage in the Internet land rush. And the financial rewards for the front-runners can be astronomical.
Still, if the Internet is going to be a transforming technology, like electricity, it must spread throughout the economy and society, as it finds new uses and new customers.
That process, inevitably, will take time. It means carefully building big Internet businesses, not just starting them. Internet "cruising speed" will become a valued skill and a competitive edge.
For both companies and individuals, that means pacing, in one way or another, in a race that is becoming more a marathon and less a sprint. As the Internet economy matures, high-technology companies are expanding programs and policies intended to help harried workers balance their personal lives and the demands of work. A greater use of flexible hours, part-time work, day care, sabbaticals and longer vacations are all part of that effort.
According to the Radford division of the benefits firm Aon Consulting, average vacation time offered by high-technology companies has steadily increased in recent years. Forty-one percent even offer full vacation benefits to new recruits during their first year of employment, and 10 percent of Silicon Valley companies now offer sabbaticals, Radford reports.
Cisco Systems, for example, gives all new hires four weeks of vacation at the start. After surveying its employees last year, Cisco is building a day-care center on its corporate campus in San Jose. "We found supply was low, demand was high and more and more high-tech companies are doing something in child care," explained Peggy Lynch, manager of benefits for Cisco.
Two years ago, I.B.M. introduced a program allowing people to work part time while still getting the benefits and opportunities of full-time employees. One person in the program is Marie Wieck, director of XML technology, a hot new field of Internet software programming. Ms. Wieck, 39, works 32 hours a week now instead of the 60 she used to. She still travels, but she typically is in the office only three days a week, giving her more time to spend with her two young daughters. "I'll keep doing this as long as it makes sense both for the business and for me," Ms. Wieck said.
Yet it is in Internet start-ups, not established companies, where the work regimen is the most grueling. The hours are still long in today's second-generation Internet start-ups, but the perspective of the young programming whizzes does seem to have changed a bit.
Lou Montulli, 29, was one of the first engineers at Netscape. After Netscape was sold, he moved on to another Internet start-up, Epinions.com. "I really like the energy of a start-up," he said, "because it's an environment where you can really make a difference as an individual."
But these days, Mr. Montulli is working 70-hour weeks instead of the 120 hours he often did at Netscape -- a single-minded commitment to work that he acknowledges contributed to the break-up of his marriage, to the daughter of Jim Clark, a co-founder of Netscape. "I'm just not emotionally equipped to work like that anymore," he said. "I have a life."
For people with children, however, 70-hour workweeks may not be their idea of balancing work and personal lives. And the stock-option wealth created by many high-technology companies has given people like Mr. Treuhaft and Mr. Silverberg the financial freedom to do what they call "serial balancing" -- shifting from stints of intense work to time off or part-time work, and back again.
"Balance is a very difficult thing to achieve, at least in parallel," Mr. Silverberg said. "To achieve great things in one's career typically takes a tremendous amount of focus and dedication. I've tried to achieve 'balance' in a more serial way, so that hopefully it will even out over the long haul. And thanks to Microsoft, I have the freedom to do that."
In Silicon Valley, Mr. Treuhaft takes a similar approach to his period of part-time work, viewing it as a recess. "I don't think I'd call this my career," he said. "It's more catching my breath, while still pedaling the bicycle."

HEADLINE: Berkeley Faces the 90's

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"High Tech Gets Low Priority in Berkeley" (news article, Oct. 25), on the loss of companies hatched in Berkeley, Calif., reflects a sad but true tale.
With the University of California campus as its main anchor tenant, Berkeley's bountiful brain power will continue to produce more successful start-up companies that will grow up and move out of town. 
 We residents can only continue to work toward a practical and enlightened local political stance that is more in tune with the realities of the new economy.
The city should invite the developers who helped turn around Emeryville and Alameda to consider refurbishing West Berkeley, whose location and local businesses make it a valuable latent asset.

HEADLINE: Index of Consumer Confidence Falls for4th Consecutive Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence in the economy has fallen in October for the fourth consecutive month amid concerns about falling stock prices, the Conference Board, a private industry group, said yesterday.
The board's consumer confidence index dropped to 130.1 from 134.2 in September. That is 3.5 percent below a 30-year high of 139 in June and the index's lowest level since January. 
 "Confidence sags every time the stock market sags," said Chris Rupkey, a senior economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd. in New York. The Dow Jones industrial average has fallen 9 percent since Aug. 25, just after Federal Reserve policy-makers raised interest rates for the second time in less than two months.
Even after this month's decline, the confidence index is still more than the year-earlier reading of 119.3. That was also the last time the index fell four consecutive months.
Another factor in the decline may be rising interest rates. Low home-mortgage rates have benefited consumer spending in recent years by freeing up billions of dollars when homeowners refinanced their loans. As those rates have risen, interest in refinancing has dwindled.
Consumers' assessments of their situations, their expectations for the economy in the next six months and their perceptions of job availability also fell to the lowest levels since January, the Conference Board report showed.
The index gauging current conditions fell to 173.5 this month from 176.3 in September, and the six-month expectations index dropped to 101.1 from 106.2.
The share of consumers surveyed who saw jobs as "hard to get" rose to 13.3 percent -- the largest since January -- from 12.7 percent in September. Those expecting incomes to increase fell to 23.1 percent from a revised 26.8 percent a month before.

HEADLINE: A New Index Tracks Bribe-Paying Countries

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Transparency International, an independent organization that tracks corruption among government officials around the world, announced yesterday that it had added a new index to rank nations that appear to condone bribe paying by their companies doing business abroad.
The organization, based in Berlin, which released both reports, the Corruption Perceptions Index and the Bribe Payers Index, in Washington, found that once again officials in northern European countries were perceived to have the cleanest hands, while the highest levels of bribe-taking officials appeared to be in Africa, Asia, Latin America and the former Soviet bloc. 
 When it came to countries whose companies pay bribes abroad, China was perceived to be the worst offender, followed by South Korea, Taiwan, Italy and Malaysia. No country's corporations were regarded as innocent of bribe paying. But the Europeans, Australia and Canada came out best.
The idea that corruption is a third world phenomenon raises tempers in developing countries every year when the Corruption Perceptions Index is published. The survey this year is the fifth and largest.
"There was a sense in some countries that we were a group from the richer north that was singling out the poor countries" said Frank Vogl, a former World Bank official and now vice chairman of Transparency International, which he helped found in 1993. "People said that basically there is a conspiracy of corruption between the takers of bribes and the givers of bribes, and it should be recognized. We thought we would create a Bribe Payers Index."
Both indices plot perceptions, not concrete evidence, though in different ways. The Corruption Perception Index is a "poll of polls," based on data from 17 surveys from 10 independent institutions that analyze business conditions around the world. The 1999 index includes 99 countries, up from 85 last year.
The Bribe Payers Index was based on a survey conducted for Transparency International by Gallup International in 14 leading emerging-market countries. They were Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Hungary, India, Indonesia, Morocco, Nigeria, the Philippines, Poland, Russia, South Korea, South Africa and Thailand. Gallup International, which is based in London, interviewed 770 senior executives in those nations.
Mr. Vogl said in an interview on Friday in New York that the two indices were "two sides of the same coin." He said it was fashionable now to be against corruption and to demand that developing countries clean house before aid was granted.
"But there is hypocrisy," he added. "Many major industrial countries do quite well on the C.P.I. Yet they are not discouraging their own firms from corrupting foreign governments."
Although the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of industrial countries, has adopted a convention making bribery of foreign officials a criminal offense, member nations have not stopped the practice, Mr. Vogl said.
No country scored a perfect 10 on the Bribe Payers scale, where a low score indicates corrupt practices. The best rating was Sweden's at 8.3, followed by 8.1 for Australia and Canada. The United States, which has had a Foreign Corrupt Practices Act on the books for 22 years, scored 6.2. At the bottom, China registered 3.1.
On the Corruption Perceptions Index, the ranking by the perceived honesty of officials, there was one perfect score. Denmark scored 10. The United States had 7.5, behind the northern Europeans, Singapore and Hong Kong.
Transparency International, founded six years ago by a small group of people who had seen development aid fail to achieve its goals as corruption flourished, has 77 national chapters. Mr. Vogl said he was impressed less by that growth than by the explosion of public demand that governments and businesses stop corrupting one another. Concerns about corruption are finally becoming part of policy making, he said, pointing to the questions that Washington is now confronting about dealing with Russia.
"Five years ago, we couldn't get into the World Bank," Mr. Vogl said. "We were told that this was politics."
Now, he added, there is a "vast civil society movement" that is asking questions in many capitals about why health care or other services receive no money while officials buy airplanes.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Putting a French Touch on an Office Tower Lobby

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
An office building at Lexington Avenue and 57th Street is not where one might expect to encounter a little bit of Paris, a touch of Gustav Klimt and a dab of Danube, the new David Bouley restaurant in TriBeCa. But enter the recently renovated two-story lobby of 135 East 57th Street, a 32-story, 400,000-square-foot building at the northwest corner of Lexington, and that's just what the visitor sees.
"Lobbies set the tone," said Charles Steven Cohen, president and chief executive of the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation, which bought the architecturally distinguished but once economically troubled building in late 1997 for $114 million. "This is a dramatic building at a key intersection, and we wanted to put our own stamp, our own imprimatur, on it, to try to stay ahead of the market. We tried to make it warmer, lighter, like a hotel or apartment house lobby. People are putting in more hours at work, so why shouldn't the workplace resemble the residential environment?" 
 So Mr. Cohen hired a Parisian decorator noted for residential work, Jacques Garcia, whose Paris office has also superintended commissions for Danube, including its French gold, cut-velvet draperies and its black-lacquered furniture. The $1 million lobby renovation, completed in the spring, is part of a larger upgrading that includes new lighting for the 30-foot-high circle of classical columns just outside the building, and a renovation to be completed in the spring of the vest-pocket park on the building's 57th Street side.
The lobby, a mix of Italian marble and bronze trim, includes two large golden murals by Gerard Coltat, an artist from Nice, France. The murals, of women, horses and mock skyscrapers, are intended to evoke the spirit of Klimt, the turn-of-the-century Austrian painter whose intensely sensual images were replete with gold and silver gilding. (Mr. Coltat's golden Klimtish visions also grace Mr. Bouley's Danube, which opened in September at Hudson and Duane Streets.)
The lobby also includes two large imported classically inspired statues, "Auguste" and "La Venus d'Arles," and fresh flowers in two bronze urns that copy Baroque-style vases in the Parc de Saint-Cloud just outside Paris.
Mr. Garcia's work is also featured in the French Designer Showhouse now running at 34 East 69th Street. He has worked on the Hotel Costes in Paris, designed the Sultan of Brunei's 60,000-square-foot residence on the Place Vendome, and restored a 17th-century Norman chateau, Champ-de-Bataille.
Mr. Cohen said he had turned to Mr. Garcia to create a sense of warmth not often found in large office-building lobbies. "We wanted to take the hard angles and surfaces of the modern and temper and soften them with residential touches," he said. "We wanted to bring a little bit of nature into the lobby, with the fresh flowers and the parklike urns, and make things lighter. The building's lobby was magnificent, but it was a cold place. We're making it warm. The original architects were great. We merely brought in other professionals to enhance the original designs."
The gray granite-clad building, loosely classical in style, was designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox of Manhattan and won critical praise when it was completed in 1988, built by Robert Gladstone and his family. It is distinguished by a sweeping, concave facade that rises to the building's full height and wraps around a plaza on the corner of Lexington Avenue. On that corner are the classical columns, which critics said create a visual focus and anchor for the plaza that becomes the building's front yard.
Despite the building's architectural elegance, it has had a difficult history. The office tower was leased, but because of the loss in 1991 of two retail tenants -- the and D. F. Sanders housewares store and the clothing store Louis, Boston -- the owners could no longer pay operating expenses or interest on their $176 million mortgage, and the next year, the Gladstones turned over the building and the ground lease to the lenders: the Los Angeles Fire and Police Pension System, the Teacher Retirement System of Texas and the Alaska Permanent Fund Corporation, represented collectively by the Boston Company Real Estate Counsel of Boston. Mr. Cohen bought the building from the lenders.
The building caters to many financial services tenants. Among them are Global Asset Management and the Boston Consulting Group.
New tenants include Tradescape, an E-commerce full-service broker, which leased 26,000 square feet, and Interactive Flight Technologies, which leased 5,000 square feet. Annual rents on new deals in the building range from $48 to $55 a square foot, Mr. Cohen said. A new retail tenant, the Greenhouse Spa, has taken 6,400 square feet on two levels on 57th Street.
Only two floors are vacant, Mr. Cohen said -- the 9th and 10th, each about 13,000 square feet, "and there is substantial interest in both."
Mr. Cohen has also hired the landscape architect Thomas Balsley, who designed Gantry Plaza State Park on the Queens waterfront, to renovate the vest-pocket park that is open to the public on the 57th Street side. The renovation includes accent lighting, art for the walls, new tables and chairs, a food kiosk, new plantings and a corrugated steel and red enamel wall behind a waterfall in the rear of the park.
"We want the park to be an inviting oasis," Mr. Cohen said. "The water now dribbles over the stone, and you can barely see it. The red will give it a nice punch."

HEADLINE: Bar Association Panel Urges Veto of CUNY's Remedial Policy

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
A commission of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York yesterday urged the State Board of Regents to reject a remedial policy adopted by the City University of New York that would bar students who do not pass English or mathematics tests from entering the university's four-year colleges.
"The proposed changes will have an unacceptably disproportionate effect on those very-low-income, minority and immigrant groups who are most dependent on CUNY to provide a leg up onto the economic letter," the panel, the Commission on the Future of CUNY, said in a 125-page report issued yesterday. 
 Calling the policy "too rigid," the commission said that CUNY had understated the impact its changes would have.
"The one-size-fits-all approach should not apply to an issue so critical to a student's college career," said Stanley M. Grossman, a New York City lawyer who is the panel's chairman.
The commission hopes that its prestige and its report will give the Regents ammunition to make the difficult decision to reject the City University's policy.
The Regents are scheduled to vote on CUNY's policy in November. The policy was approved by CUNY's trustees last year and again in January.
Isabelle Katz Pinzler, a former acting Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights in the United States Justice Department who was special counsel to the bar panel, said the commission sent copies of its recommendations to the State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, and to CUNY's chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, on Monday evening.
Jay Hershenson, CUNY's vice chancellor for university relations, said that the chancellor had met with the bar panel and assured it that "as standards at the senior colleges are raised, safeguards will be put in place to strengthen opportunities for educational advancement."
The 15-member bar commission, which included lawyers, educators and other public figures, said that state law gave CUNY a specific responsibility to serve the "special needs of an urban constituency" and that the remedial policy did not do that.
The panel said that the new policy would discriminate against members of minority groups and women and that both CUNY and the Regents must take into account the implications of the Federal civil rights law.
It also said that it was concerned that CUNY, which it called "grossly underfunded," would not have enough money to pay for the various programs it had said it would use to help students once remedial classes were closed. Had the policy been in use last year, more than 4,300 students would have been affected, the bar group estimated, calling CUNY's estimate that fewer than 200 students would be affected far too low. The group also expressed skepticism about CUNY's need to move so quickly.
"The commission submits that there are compelling reasons not to approve the proposed amendment on remediation in its current form and on the proposed timetable," the report said.
The report on CUNY, the first of two reports the commission plans to issue, is one of the bar association's occasional studies on public policy issues; previous topics have included a Congressional code of ethics and strategic arms control.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
SharesTrade Mostly Lower; The Dow Falls 47.80 Points

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday, led lower by retailers and four companies that are being replaced in the Dow Jones industrial average.
Two stocks about to join the ranks of the 30 component issues of the Dow industrials rose -- Intel was up 3/16 a share, to 71 7/16, and SBC Communications climbed 1 5/16, to 45 9/16. 
 The two others, though, slipped a bit: Microsoft fell 1/16 a share, to 92 3/8, and Home Depot declined 1 1/4, to 70 11/16.
Retailers fell after a report showed that sales growth slowed to two-tenths of 1 percent last week, from four-tenths of 1 percent the previous week. "Customers aren't going out and banging the doors down to buy apparel," said Brian James, an analyst with Loomis, Sayles & Company, which owns retail stocks.
Wal-Mart Stores dropped 2 11/16 a share, to 53 1/4; Dayton-Hudson fell 4 3/4, to 61 1/16, and Kmart lost 1/2, to 9 3/8. Sears, Roebuck, the retailer Home Depot will replace in the Dow average on Monday, also fell 1 7/8, to 27.
The Dow average dropped 47.80 points, to 10,302.13. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 11.72 points, to 1,281.91. The Nasdaq composite index fell 4.48 points, to 2,811.47.
Along with Sears, the other stocks being removed from the Dow fell: Goodyear Tire and Rubber lost 3 15/16 a share, to 41 1/4, contributing most to the Dow average's loss. Chevron sank 2, to 88, and Union Carbide dropped 1/2, to 59.
The trading session was fairly heated, with an above-average 878.3 million shares changing hands on the Big Board.
The inclusion of Microsoft and Intel in the Dow "highlights the importance of technology in our everyday lives and the marketplace," said Michael Holland, chairman of the Holland & Company money-management firm.
Lucent Technologies, the world's largest maker of telephone equipment, gained 3 a share, to 62 7/8, after posting a fourth-quarter profit that surpassed analyst expectations by 2 cents a share.
Government bonds fell on concern that economic reports to be released this week will add to data that may prompt a third interest-rate rise by the Federal Reserve since June.
"The market is not ready to rally," said Sam Paddison, who oversees $12 billion in fixed-income assets at the First Capital Group in Philadelphia. As long as potential exists for another Fed increase this year, he said, the risk is for bonds to decline.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 11/32, to 96 22/32, pushing its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, up to 6.37 percent, from 6.35 percent on Monday.
So far this month, yields on 10-year notes, a benchmark for mortgage and other loans, have climbed 35 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.23 percent. That is likely to send the rate on 30-year mortgages reported by Freddie Mac, the second-largest buyer of mortgages, to more than 8 percent for the first time in two months when it's compiled this week, analysts said.
A Government report scheduled for release tomorrow will probably show that employment costs rose in the third quarter, following the biggest gain since 1991 in the previous quarter. Another report may show that the economy expanded at a 4.5 percent annual pace in the quarter, up from 1.6 percent in the second quarter.
"Most people have already made their bets," leaving little room for big swings in Treasuries before tomorrow's reports, said Barbara Kenworthy, a portfolio manager at Prudential Investment Advisors in Newark, which has $145 billion under management.
Signs of growth and faster inflation could raise chances of a Fed rate increase next month, traders said. The Fed already raised its target for overnight bank lending by a quarter-point each in June and August, raising it to 5.25 percent.
"Unless the data surprise us over the next few days, the path of least resistance is for a tightening" next month, said William Dudley, director of United States economic research at Goldman Sachs Group.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Dow TakesOn a New, High-Technology Look

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THE Dow Jones industrial average, whose performance has trailed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in recent years, dropped four lagging stocks yesterday and substituted four companies that have done much better.
By adding two high-flying technology companies, the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation, the editors of The Wall Street Journal, who determine the index's components, made it likely that the Dow will be more volatile than it has been. Whether it will also be a better performer is likely to turn on the question of whether large technology stocks remain market leaders. 
 Intel and Microsoft are the first stocks traded on the Nasdaq to join the Dow, ending the monopoly of New York Stock Exchange-listed companies in the average. The other stocks being added, effective on Monday, are Home Depot, the specialty retailer, and SBC Communications, one of the regional Bell phone companies.
The companies that are being dropped, all of which have been in the Dow since 1930 or earlier, are the Chevron Corporation; Sears, Roebuck & Company; the Union Carbide Corporation, and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
Paul E. Steiger, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, said the changes would make the Dow "even more representative of the evolving U.S. economy."
Since the last change in the components of the Dow, when four companies were added in March 1997, the index has risen 49 percent. But over the same period, Goodyear and Sears have declined in value while the other companies being taken out have risen less than the Dow. Over all, the companies being removed have declined.
By contrast, the four companies being added have been sterling performers. SBC is up about 65 percent; Intel has more than doubled and the other two have tripled.
John Prestbo, the markets editor of The Wall Street Journal, said that "stock performance is not a factor in deciding whether to take a company out, or which one to add." He said the editors had "made a conscious effort to get rid of duplicate companies," leading to the elimination of Chevron while the Exxon Corporation remained and to the dropping of Sears while Wal-Mart Stores Inc. stayed.
A calculation by this reporter indicates that had the four new stocks been added to the Dow at the time of the last change, in 1997, the Dow would have been up 71 percent since that change, significantly better than the 62 percent gain shown by the S.& P. 500. In fact, the Dow was up 49 percent over the period, leaving it well behind the S.& P. 500, although the Dow has done better in 1999.
At the peak this summer, the Dow would have topped 12,800 had the new stocks been in it. In fact, the high was 11,326.
The competition between indexes is more important now than it used to be because both Standard & Poor's and Dow Jones license their indexes for option and futures trading and make money based on how popular such derivatives are with traders.
The fact that Microsoft and Intel do not trade on the New York Stock Exchange had no effect, either on the decision to include them in the average now or on the decision not to add them earlier, Mr. Prestbo said. He noted that the Dow Jones transportation average had added Nasdaq stocks in 1991.
Still, the move served as a reminder of the inability of the Big Board, historically the place where large American companies traded, to attract the most successful technology companies away from Nasdaq. Frank G. Zarb, the chief executive of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the parent of the Nasdaq said, "The inclusion of these two Nasdaq companies makes the Dow more reflective of today's global economy."
The changes are likely to bring on substantial trading by index funds based on the Dow and by the managers of the so-called Diamonds, investment trusts that trade on the American Stock Exchange and mimic the Dow. With more than $1.1 billion in Diamonds, the managers will have to sell more than 500,000 shares of each of the stocks being removed and buy a similar number of each stock being added.
Until 1997, the Dow had just one large computer technology company, I.B.M. Then it added Hewlett-Packard, and now it is adding Microsoft, the dominant personal computer software company, and Intel, the leading maker of semiconductor chips for such computers. Because those stocks are relatively high priced, the technology stocks will make up 16 percent of the index. But that is below the 25 percent technology weighting in the S.& P. 500.
The 1997 changes to the Dow also added Johnson & Johnson Inc. and Travelers Group, now called Citigroup after merging with Citicorp. The companies taken out then were Texaco Inc., the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Woolworth -- since renamed Venator Group Inc. -- and Westinghouse. As is the case now, the companies that were removed had been poor performers in the years before they were taken out of the average.
Most of the 1997 rejects continued to lag the market since that move. Only Westinghouse, since renamed the CBS Corporation after taking over the television network, has outperformed the Dow since the last change. Of the four that were added, all but Hewlett-Packard have outperformed the index.
The Dow industrials are by far the most widely followed index of United States stocks, in part because it is the oldest index around, dating back to 1896 and with continual prices since 1914. The earlier version was dropped during World War I, and Dow Jones did not bother to make the new one continuous in terms of prices.
The definition of an industrial stock used by Dow Jones is a broad one, basically making all companies eligible except those that could be in the Dow Jones transportation or utility averages. The latter index has traditionally included electric and gas utilities, not phone companies.
While the S.& P. 500 is much broader, it dates only to the 1920's and is less well known. Ask money managers how they are doing over some period of time, and they will probably compare their performances to the S.& P. 500. But ask what the market is doing on a given day, and the same managers are likely to describe how far the Dow has moved.
Unlike most major indexes, which are weighted based on the market value of each company, the Dow is computed on a price-weighted basis. The closing prices of the 30 Dow stocks are added up and divided by a divisor, now 0.1974, which is adjusted whenever a stock in the Dow splits or when new companies are added.
As a result, the highest weighted stock in the Dow will remain the American Express Company, now worth about $144 a share. It will have a larger effect on the average than Microsoft, now worth about $92 a share, even though Microsoft has a market value -- and thus a weighting in the S.&P. 500 -- that is more than seven times that of American Express.
Yesterday, when stock prices were generally lower, two of the companies added to the Dow showed gains and another, Microsoft, was down only 6.25 cents. Of the companies dropped, all fell more than $1 except Union Carbide, which was down 50 cents.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: A Network of Their Own;
From an Exclusive Address, a Group for Women Only

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
For Janet Tiebout Hanson, leaving Goldman, Sachs after 14 years was "like stepping off a cliff." She had risen to vice president, after spending her entire professional career at the Wall Street firm, with all the power and prestige it conferred.
But having taken three years off to care for her children, Meredith, now 11, and Christopher, 8, Ms. Hanson found that being back at the investment banking firm was a huge disappointment. Changes in technology at the firm left her feeling out of touch, and she found her new position in marketing for the asset management division frustrating. "I wasn't special, and they weren't special," Ms. Hanson said. 
 Taking the plunge, she founded Milestone Capital Management in 1994. Now in Yonkers, it has nearly $3 billion under management, and she no longer has to commute from Bronxville to lower Manhattan.
Her experience set her to thinking. She had been one of just a few women professionals at Goldman, Sachs. Her male colleagues had honed networking over the decades into a science, whether it was schmoozing at the club or doing deals on the golf course. Those who ascended could rely on an endless supply of contacts to help them on their way.
But what about all the women who had left? Some had not worked for several years, staying at home with their children, and they found their Rolodexes out of date and their skills rusty. Others were thinking about starting their own businesses, in hopes of greater opportunities. All of them would benefit by pooling their contacts.
So Ms. Hanson created an organization two years ago called 85 Broads, a playful reference to the Goldman location at 85 Broad Street. There is nothing quite like the group. Other corporate alumni networks exist, though few are active. One exception is McKinsey & Company, which has a page of news and information about its 8,500 former consultants on its Web site.
Among other women's networks, the Financial Women's Association of New York has about 1,100 members. Female graduates of the Harvard Business School have set up clubs in several cities, including one in New York that caters to a "ready-made group" of 1,600 peers, according to Karen Page, founder of the Harvard network. Then there is the Committee of 200, an organization of high-profile professional women.
But Ms. Hanson's group is unusual in being a women-only corporate alumni network.
"The reason I can do this is that I made it out of Goldman into a successful entrepreneurial experience," Ms. Hanson said.
Already, about 70 former Goldman women have joined the club, including not only stay-at-home mothers but also many big names in American business and finance like Anne Cassells, the chief investment officer for Stanford University; Karen Cook, a partner at Steinhardt Management in New York, and Leelee Clement Doughty, an executive recruiter for Heidrick & Struggles in Los Angeles. Abby Joseph Cohen, the well-known managing director at Goldman, is an honorary member.
Last month, the group started its own Web site, www.85broads.com, as a way for women to connect outside of special events. Catherine Banat, a former Goldman professional with 7-year-old twins, a son and a daughter, is its volunteer president, having quit Lehman Brothers six months ago to decide what she should do next. Only members have access to the site. Logging on, they can find the names and phone numbers of former colleagues, many of whom have individual profiles on the site, and can exchange tips and informations.
The club is an attempt to replicate some of the aspects of the traditional old boys' network, in which phone calls are always taken and people are quick to make referrals. "Women haven't networked as well as they should -- or can," said Noreen Harrington, who worked at Goldman for 11 years and is a member of the group. "We're not always our best asset."
After leaving Barclays Capital last year as the co-head of fixed income for Europe, Ms. Harrington is trying to establish a money management firm with some others and expects to use contacts from the club as a way to share information.
Though the site is not fully off the ground, members are using it to share information about how to work for political candidates like Jon S. Corzine, the former Goldman co-chairman who is running for the Senate from New Jersey, and noting articles on current Goldman executives. There are places where they can peruse "favorite" lists of books and vacations, and the site even plans to create a chat room for Wall Street gossip.
Barbara Redinger, who left Goldman in the late 1980's, has not worked since her daughter, now 7, was born. "I'm trying to figure out how to take back some of my life without sacrificing my family's life," said Ms. Redinger, who lives in a Cleveland suburb. "I never thought I would miss pantyhose," she said with a laugh. Ms. Hanson is helping her find out what certification she might need to return to financial services.
For a suburban housewife with applesauce stains on her T-shirt, knowing that you can ask the advice of a former colleague who is still in the thick of the business can be a lifeline. Too often, women who have stayed at home for a while feel embarrassed about no longer being considered a heavy hitter. "You're no longer part of that club," Ms. Hanson explained.
It probably should not be surprising that this group was formed in the Goldman milieu. The firm has always boasted of recruiting the best and the brightest, and its new hires became very close as they went through its rigorous training programs. This was particularly true in the 1970's and 80's, when Goldman was much smaller and the atmosphere was more intimate.
Women professionals forged especially strong bonds as outsiders in a mostly male culture. "It was probably the most exciting time of my professional career," said Phyllis Esposito, who left Goldman in 1990 to found Artemis Capital with some other women investment professionals and is now a senior partner at Mathias & Company, a financial services consulting firm.
The networking group "is a tremendous source of individual and professional talent," she said. "We are proud to claim our Goldman heritage."
Former Goldman women still connect, although it may have been years since some last worked together and some had never met, according to Ms. Hanson. She remembers the "camaraderie and excitement" of a dinner she organized two years ago for about 30 of her former colleagues, at the Water Club restaurant on the East River.
Ms. Hanson says she realized the full power of networking shortly after she created Milestone, her money management firm. She was having lunch with Ms. Esposito, then a senior managing director at Bear, Stearns, who urged her to market her fund there. She did so, and now she credits Ms. Esposito's backing with helping Milestone get off the ground.
"It was a win-win for all of us," Ms. Esposito recalled.
But the number of women who are able to break through the so-called glass ceiling into the upper echelons of corporate America remains small, and Wall Street is particularly viewed as an inhospitable place to work. About 11 percent of Goldman's 693 managing directors are women.
Since networking on a professional level often involves connecting mostly with men, women often develop another network to talk to other women, according to Herminia Ibarra, a professor at the Harvard Business School. The other network represents a forum where there are enough women facing similar issues, like the difficulty of advancing or the challenge of raising children while working.
Ms. Hanson wants her group to serve as a resource for current Goldman women, too, many of whom may face the same quandary she did in deciding whether to take time off or leave. "My biggest hope for 85 Broads is that women at Goldman, Sachs will reach out to us in a way, informally," Ms. Hanson said.
"Where was this group 10 years ago?" she asked.
 
It's Not Rocket Science: Best Ways to Meet and Greet
People who don't belong to a ready-made career network like 85 Broads or the Harvard Business School alumni clubs may need to be creative in thinking about how to establish and use networks. While there are "various and sundry" networking groups, joining them is not always useful, according to Dee A. Soder, a career consultant for executives in New York at the CEO Group. "The people you want to meet and interact with are generally not going to go to those things," Ms. Soder said.
So what is the best way to meet and greet? Ms. Soder recommends focusing on organizations that you feel strongly about, whether it is Girls Inc. or City Meals on Wheels, because these groups can be a good way for like-minded men and women to get together. She recently attended a private reception at the Economic Club of New York, for example, where she made a variety of contacts.
People looking to connect should also not limit themselves to just one vehicle, says Herminia M. Barra, a Harvard Business School professor. Instead, she suggests exploring a broad variety of informal and formal ones, based on your interests and location. You might want to join a local alumni club, for example, as well as specific professional associations, depending on your job. But the more networks you join, the more worlds, opportunities and ideas you will be exposed to, she said.
Here, at least, women may have an advantage, Ms. Soder said. "Women are far more likely to have a variety of different people they know than men are," she said.

HEADLINE: First Lady Tries to Put Mayor on Defensive Over the Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
On Sept. 28 in Washington, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he would be against raising the minimum wage "until I saw that it had no impact on jobs." But by last Sunday, he said he expected to "eventually support" raising the minimum wage, although he wanted to see some studies first.
To Hillary Rodham Clinton's busy campaign spinners, the Mayor's comments were a classic "flip-flop." To the Mayor, it was the natural evolution of his position. Calling it a flip-flop, he said with irritation on Monday, "was one of the biggest canards I ever heard." 
 Whatever the point of view, Mrs. Clinton, who favors the wage increase, seems to have put the Republican Mayor on the defensive as he has tried to find a balance between following his party's orthodoxy and appealing to voters statewide. "The Mayor is now trying to climb out of the box, and we intend to make it difficult for him," said Howard Wolfson, the spokesman for Mrs. Clinton's unannounced Senate campaign.
At the same time, Republican leaders said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani's expected support of the wage increase, whether rooted in politics or ideology, would help him with crucial voters upstate, an anticipated war zone as the Mayor prepares to run against Mrs. Clinton. "Without question, it helps him in the city of Buffalo," said Robert E. Davis, chairman of the Republican Party in Erie County, the largest Democratic stronghold outside of New York City.
Robert W. Giarrusso, the Onondaga County Republican chairman, said that if Mr. Giuliani supported a rise in the minimum wage, it would "definitely" help with voters in Syracuse. Stephen Minarik, the Republican chairman for Monroe County -- where Rochester enjoys a healthier economic climate than that of Buffalo -- said business owners in his area might not like Mr. Giuliani's support of the minimum wage, "but I don't think he would lose any support because the alternative is not good." By the "alternative," Mr. Minarik meant Mrs. Clinton.
The issue affects 643,000 minimum wage workers in the State of New York, according to statistics compiled by the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. Mr. Giuliani's likely race against Mrs. Clinton is expected to be extraordinarily close.
While it has long been standard for the Republican Party to oppose raising the minimum wage, it has always been a difficult issue for statewide Republican candidates in New York, where increasing the wage is popular. Former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, for example, was in favor of raising the wage during his unsuccessful 1998 campaign against Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat.
In the House of Representatives, where bills to raise the minimum wage to $6.15, from $5.15, an hour over the next two years have some bipartisan support, the leading moderate Republican in favor of the increase is Jack Quinn of Buffalo. Asked yesterday if Mr. Giuliani could count on support in Buffalo if he favored raising the wage, Mr. Quinn at first said, "I don't know." But then, he amended his comment: "Let me put it this way: It will be better if he supports the minimum wage."
In the Senate, a similar bill has been stalled because of opposition from Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, and other leading Republicans. Mr. Giuliani first discussed opposition to increasing the wage "at this point" while in Washington on a fund-raising trip for his Senate Exploratory Committee. "When he's down asking for Trent Lott's support and money in Washington, he says one thing," Mr. Wolfson, Mrs. Clinton's spokesman, said, "and then when he's in New York, he says another."
Mr. Giuliani's aides counter that Mr. Wolfson is deliberately distorting the Mayor's words. "We're surprised Mrs. Clinton has gone so negative so early," said Bruce Teitelbaum, the director of the Mayor's exploratory committee. "This is precisely the kind of negative campaign that turns people off, and that New Yorkers will reject."
Asked about the shifts in his position, Mr. Giuliani said: "I'm doing exactly what I said I would do. But you've got to pay attention and you've got to be intellectually honest to come to that conclusion."
Mr. Giuliani's aides later distributed a transcript of comments that the Mayor made in a television interview with Mark Shields on Oct. 9. When Mr. Shields asked Mr. Giuliani why he was opposed to raising the minimum wage, the Mayor responded, "No, no, no, no, no, no, wait, wait, wait -- I didn't say that." Mr. Giuliani then said that increasing the minimum wage was "a good thing that we have to look at, but you've got to understand that you're going to be costing, you could be costing some of those people jobs."
The Mayor has said he is particularly concerned that raising the minimum wage could hurt the city's welfare-to-work program. On Sunday, he said he had asked the city's Human Resources Administration and the Economic Development Corporation to study the proposed increase.
A recent study by Alan B. Krueger of Princeton University and David Card at the University of California at Berkeley found that increasing the Federal minimum wage has not hurt job growth, and Mr. Krueger said in a telephone interview yesterday that he did not expect raising the wage to $6.15 to hurt jobs, particularly in New York.
But Mark Wilson, a research fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington, said yesterday that other studies showed that increasing the minimum wage hurt low-skilled workers because employers were not willing to pay more money for their services.

HEADLINE: Former Treasury Secretary Joins LeadershipTriangle at Citigroup

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
Robert E. Rubin, arguably the best-known financier of his generation and the recently retired Treasury Secretary, has taken a top position at Citigroup, the nation's largest financial services company.
Mr. Rubin, 61, a former top official of Goldman, Sachs & Company, said yesterday that he had joined Sanford I. Weill and John S. Reed, the chairmen and chief executives Citigroup, in what Mr. Reed described as a "three-person office of the chairman" that will oversee what has become the first true American financial conglomerate since the Depression. 
 The appointment came less than a week after the Clinton Administration and Congress agreed on a compromise bill that would overhaul the laws that regulate the financial industry, a measure that removes many of the restrictions preventing banks, securities firms and insurance companies from buying one another or engaging in one another's businesses. Both Mr. Rubin and Citigroup strongly supported the bill, which would greatly benefit the company. Mr. Rubin said he played a role in arranging the final compromise that will probably lead to the repeal of the so-called Glass-Steagall legislation. But he said that had nothing to do with his decision to join the company.
The appointment settles the speculation about what Mr. Rubin, who presided over the Clinton Administration's economic policy during one of America's longest economic booms, would do for an encore. Mr. Rubin also discussed jobs with American International Group, a leading life insurance company, and Warburg Pincus, a New York investment firm, before agreeing to join Citigroup, said people who were told about Mr. Rubin's negotiations. He also had discussions with Goldman, Sachs about serving on his old firm's board, people close to Mr. Rubin said.
Mr. Rubin declined to discuss his talks with other companies, and officials of those three companies also declined to comment. Citigroup officials said that while Mr. Rubin would be free to pursue outside endeavors, including a role in New York or national politics, he would not work for any financial company that competes with Citigroup.
Mr. Rubin will not become a third chief executive with Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed, who brought Citigroup together last year by joining Citicorp, one of America's leading banking companies, with Travelers Group, the large insurance company and investment bank. They have had a sometimes rocky relationship since then. But Mr. Rubin will head the executive committee of Citigroup's board, work full time at the company and participate in all significant managerial and strategic decisions, the three men said. Mr. Rubin will also have a corner office alongside Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed in the company's blond-wood and glass executive suite in midtown Manhattan.
"I really like the issues of managing a large institution, and I want to really get back involved," Mr. Rubin said in an interview. "I'd also like to fish, read books and play tennis, but life is a trade-off."
Mr. Rubin's role at Citigroup appears to be a delicate balance between his desire to take an active role in plotting the company's future and his wish to avoid becoming a chief executive with day-to-day responsibilities. No Citigroup employees will report to him directly. But Mr. Rubin plans to bring Michael Froman, his former Treasury Department chief of staff, to work at Citigroup.
The terms of his employment took five weeks of almost constant meetings to negotiate, people close to Mr. Rubin said.
"Bob has the best job in the company: no line responsibility, but he will be a full partner," Mr. Reed said during a meeting to announce Mr. Rubin's appointment at Citigroup's headquarters on the East Side of Manhattan. "He will not play a role as an executive officer of the company, as Sandy and I have to."
But after years as the Government's top economic official, Mr. Rubin brings to Citigroup a Rolodex of contacts that one bank analyst called priceless. To the extent that he is willing to use his contacts to promote Citigroup's banking business around the world, Mr. Rubin could generate hundreds of millions of dollars in fees for the bank.
Some analysts also saw the Rubin name on Citigroup's marquee as a draw for star bankers on Wall Street, potentially making the firm's Salomon Smith Barney investment bank a more formidable competitor to other firms, including Goldman, where Mr. Rubin spent the bulk of his career as a bond trader and senior executive.
"He has to be one of the most well-regarded individuals among senior Government officials and corporations worldwide. He can get a meeting with anyone he wants," said Joan Solotar, who analyzes Citigroup for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "They will win deals that they would not otherwise have won."
Mr. Rubin's return to Wall Street is not unprecedented. James A. Baker 3d, the former Bush and Reagan Administration official, joined Carlyle Group, a venture capital and buyout firm. Nicholas F. Brady, a Bush Administration Treasury Secretary, also followed Mr. Rubin's circular path from Wall Street to Washington and back. Mr. Brady now heads Darby Overseas Investments, an emerging-markets investment fund.
Citigroup, however, cuts a much higher profile. It has 100 million clients in 100 countries and is on course this year to earn $10 billion in net profits, far ahead of any of its rivals in the finance industry. It was also one of the leading forces in Washington pushing for an overhaul of financial laws, in part because Citigroup might have had to sell some of its businesses, including its insurance underwriting subsidiary, if Congress had not agreed to pass reforms this year.
Federal law requires retired Government officials to refrain from interceding with their former agency on behalf of a new employer for at least one year after leaving public service. The Clinton Administration requires its top officials to pledge that they will not lobby their agency for at least five years.
Mr. Rubin said that he would take a "belt and suspenders" approach to ethics questions, regularly consulting with a lawyer, if necessary, to make sure that his work for the company did not raise questions about influence peddling or conflict of interest.
"I don't think there should be any political sensitivity here," Mr. Rubin said. "I am involved in the business of this organization, not in lobbying."
Mr. Rubin acknowledged that even while he negotiating his own job with Citigroup, he had helped broker the compromise agreement repealing Glass-Steagall. He said he had a hand in urging Congress and the White House to preserve the Community Reinvestment Act, which requires banks to channel a portion of their lending to poor, inner-city areas. The future of that act had been a sticking point between Republicans and the White House that held up agreement on the financial overhaul package.
"I care greatly about C.R.A.," Mr. Rubin said, adding that he was pleased with the final legislative compromise. "I did have conversations about that."
Mr. Rubin and Mr. Weill said that they had come to know one another while Mr. Rubin was in office and Mr. Weill was constructing Citigroup, the formation of which involved required extensive talks with regulators. Mr. Weill was also perhaps Wall Street's most active lobbyist on behalf of the financial services overhaul, in which Mr. Rubin played a guiding role. Though both men are avid Democrats and have spent their careers in New York financial circles, they said they had not been close friends before.
But both Mr. Rubin and Mr. Weill said that they had not discussed Mr. Rubin's future when Mr. Rubin was at the Treasury Department. Citigroup officials said that Mr. Weill first raised the offer of a job at the company in mid-September, more than two months after Mr. Rubin resigned his post.
"It would have been inappropriate to discuss that while I was in office," Mr. Rubin said.
Mr. Rubin, Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed all said that Mr. Rubin's role at the firm would go far beyond cajoling corporate executives and government officials to hire Citigroup bankers. He intends to help plot the company's strategy. He and the two Citigroup executives said they would be walking in and out of one another's offices all day, running the company as a troika.
Citigroup officials declined to discuss Mr. Rubin's compensation package, although details will have to be disclosed in a proxy statement next spring because Mr. Rubin will be a director. Asked about his pay, Mr. Rubin declined to comment. But asked whether it would top his $150,000 salary as Treasury Secretary, he deadpanned: "That's a fair assumption."
He does not need the money. When he entered Government service in early 1993, Mr. Rubin put his assets, most of which consisted of partnership shares in Goldman, into a blind trust. The trust at the time was valued at about $100 million, though it has possibly increased considerably in value given the bull market in stocks since then.
Yet by leaving Goldman and accepting cash in exchange for his shares, Mr. Rubin missed the windfall other partners enjoyed when Goldman became a public company earlier this year. Had he remained the top executive at Goldman, the assets would have increased at least threefold and totaled more than half a billion dollars.
Moreover, his old Goldman pay pales in comparison with what Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed now earn at Citigroup. Last year, Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed had total compensation, including stock options, valued at about $27 million each. Mr. Rubin seems unlikely to earn as much as either Mr. Weill or Mr. Reed because he does not have the same executive responsibilities. But his senior role in the company suggests that he could easily earn more than $10 million in salary, bonus and stock options each year.
One of the most intriguing aspects of the yesterday's announcement had more to do with the relationship between Mr. Weill and Mr. Reed than with Mr. Rubin's new job.
People at Citigroup have said that the two executives have had difficulty working together, a conflict that resulted in a formal division of responsibilities made public several months ago. Mr. Weill was perceived as the victor in that reshuffling, with Mr. Reed agreeing to focus primarily on specific areas of the company, including legal affairs and Internet strategy.
Mr. Reed was candid about their earlier conflict yesterday, though he said their relationship had improved.
"I think we found it difficult," Mr. Reed said. "The buzz word is control, and in this kind of thing you lose control. You can't make decisions -- you can't even schedule a meeting -- without talking with the other guy. We had an adjustment process."
He said that in recent months, he and Mr. Weill had begun to work together "reasonably well, even quite well."
"Our ability to reach out to Bob like this says we are beginning to figure it out," Mr. Reed said.

HEADLINE: Social Security Scare-Mongering

 BODY:
Social Security is one of the oldest weapons in politics. By charging that various Republican schemes would wreck the Social Security system, Democrats over the years have blocked tax cuts, a constitutional amendment to balance the budget and the recent G.O.P. proposal to replace part of the retirement system with private investment accounts. Now the Republicans seem to be making political headway using the same weapon against Democrats. They are advancing a ludicrous claim that deep Republican budget cuts are needed to stop a Democratic "raid" on Social Security.
The Republican argument rests on a fallacy that spending budget money today compromises the government's ability to meet its Social Security obligations in the future. Instead of squabbling over dollars in this year's budget, Congress can do more for Social Security by producing sound budgets that make the right investments while keeping the economy growing. A prosperous economy is the best guarantee that workers in the future will be able to afford paying for their parents' retirement. 
 In January President Clinton called for setting aside nearly two-thirds of the total projected federal surplus, from Social Security and other sources, to help retire federal debt over the next 15 years. That was a sensible proposal intended to increase the savings rate and lower future interest rates. But the argument this year is over whether a small amount of the $140 billion Social Security surplus in the current year should be used to avoid spending cuts in other programs. In fact, no damage would be done to the economy, to Social Security or to the federal budget itself if that happened.
Asserting that it is merely trying to save money for Social Security, the Republican leadership in Congress wants to cut spending by 1.4 percent across the board and block the White House's initiatives for money to hire new teachers and police officers. The leaders' approach has been so wrongheaded that yesterday it provoked a revolt in the party rank and file, and the cuts were being scaled back. But it is not necessary to slash programs to "save" Social Security. More to the point, there are better places to save money, by cutting billions of dollars in pork-barrel projects and eliminating some of the expensive tax breaks for special interests that have made big campaign donations to the party in recent years.
President Clinton is right to veto spending bills that do not meet priority needs in education, foreign aid, the environment, law enforcement and other areas. As the White House notes, the Republican budget schemes approved so far have already tapped the Social Security system's surplus, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The fastest way to achieve a budget agreement would be to agree to a sensible budget and stop scaring the public into thinking that a modest amount of additional spending would jeopardize Social Security.

HEADLINE: Bush Under Attack as He Sags in New Polls

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
After months of relatively smooth sailing toward the Republican primaries, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas found himself in less placid straits today, with his two main Republican rivals attacking him at the same time that several new polls suggested some give in Mr. Bush's lead.
Both developments dulled the shiny aura of inevitability that has enveloped Mr. Bush since he announced his Presidential candidacy in June. And while this moment was inevitable, political analysts said, it also confirmed that Mr. Bush has yet to face his most intense scrutiny, from competitors and voters alike. 
 Alan K. Simpson, a former Republican senator from Wyoming, suggested that Mr. Bush would have to spend even more time mingling with voters in important primary states and scuffling with his opponents over the issues.
"It's time for him to gear up," said Mr. Simpson, who teaches at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "No one can stay loose like that and do what they have to do."
Mr. Bush's two most formidable challengers for the Republican nomination, Senator John McCain of Arizona and the publisher Steve Forbes, made arguably their strongest efforts to date to rattle Mr. Bush's composure.
Mr. McCain, campaigning in California on Monday, accused Mr. Bush's aides of planting and abetting an unflattering newspaper article about him. He was referring to a front-page article in The New York Times on Monday.
"Apparently," Mr. McCain said, "the memo has gone out from the Bush campaign to start attacking John McCain."
Mr. Bush's aides said today that Mr. McCain's accusation was wholly unfounded.
Meanwhile, Ken Blackwell, the national chairman of the Forbes campaign, issued a statement today denouncing a new television commercial by Mr. Bush that asserts that he significantly reduced the growth of government spending in Texas. Mr. Blackwell cited independent analyses that showed a 36 percent increase in spending under Governor Bush.
"It's unfair and it's misleading for him to represent his fiscal leadership to be of a conservative nature, when he really makes Bill Clinton and Bill Clinton's Administration look like conservative fiscal managers," Mr. Blackwell said in a subsequent telephone interview. "There's an old saying in Texas: all hat, no cattle."
Mr. Blackwell called on the Bush campaign to withdraw or amend the advertisement, which began running in Iowa and New Hampshire this week.
Mr. Bush's aides said they would do no such thing. They said that the 36 percent figure failed to account for inflation, increases in population that strained state services and other factors, and that the rate of growth of spending was higher under previous governors.
They also accused the Forbes campaign of reprising the negative tactics that Mr. Forbes used against Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner in 1996.
"This misleading attack says more about Steve Forbes than it does about Governor Bush," said Mindy Tucker, a spokeswoman for the Bush campaign.
Aides to both Mr. McCain and Mr. Forbes have long maintained that the overwhelming early support for Mr. Bush was not built on any real knowledge among voters and that Mr. Bush was more vulnerable than he appeared. The attacks today may well have been set off by new hints of that vulnerability.
A poll of New Hampshire voters, made public this week by Research 2000, showed that in that state, which holds the first Republican primary early next year, Mr. McCain trails Mr. Bush by 12 points. Mr. Bush held a 35-point lead in a poll in August.
In addition, two national surveys made public this week suggested that in a hypothetical contest between Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic front-runner, Mr. Gore is gaining ground.
A Gallup Poll of 1,005 adults showed Mr. Gore to be 9 points behind Mr. Bush; a similar poll by Gallup just two weeks ago put the spread at 16 points. The margin of sampling error for each survey was three percentage points.
Mr. Bush, campaigning in Iowa today, said, "I think it's too early to be talking about the general election."
Mr. Bush's advisers said that other recent national polls did not show any dent in the Governor's lead and that they had always expected his lead to shrink, a development that political analysts called inevitable.
"Bush's numbers were stratospheric and unsustainable over the long haul," said Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist.
But Mr. Gillespie added that those numbers were still extraordinarily promising and that rivals who were waiting for Mr. Bush to hurt himself were now realizing that, with only three months before the first Iowa caucuses, they had to inflict the pain themselves. "It's gone from 'if he stumbles' to 'I've got to trip this guy,' " he said.
Mr. Bush is making his own adjustments, his advisers said, adding that his campaign schedule will grow lighter on fund-raisers and heavier on events where he meets with voters.
These advisers said such changes were planned long ago. But one adviser acknowledged that the race had become more volatile with the departures of Patrick J. Buchanan and Elizabeth Dole, which narrowed the Republican field and raised the profiles of Mr. Bush's challengers.
"Elizabeth Dole took 12 percent of the vote and threw it up into the air as a jump ball," said the adviser, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "And there are really only three primary contenders clawing for that vote: Forbes, McCain and Bush."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ex-Treasury Chief Rubin Accepts a Top Citigroup Job
Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury Secretary, has taken a top position at Citigroup, the first true American financial conglomerate since the Great Depression. 
 Mr. Rubin, 61, the former top official of Goldman, Sachs, said he had joined Sanford I. Weill and John S. Reed at Citigroup in what Mr. Reed described as a "three-person office of the chairman." Page A1.
 
Compaq Earnings Exceed Forecasts
Compaq Computer earned 7 cents a share in the third quarter, beating Wall Street's expectations of a nickel a share. Michael Capellas, who became chief executive in July, said the company planned to cut $2 billion in annual expenses, largely by eliminating 7,000 jobs. C2.
 
Getting Off to a Shaky Start
Michael R. Bonsignore says he has had lots of "pivotal moments" at Honeywell, which at the moment he is busy merging with Allied Signal, trying to meld two cultures and defuse anxiety. But for sheer personal drama, no event can match the time he almost lost his first job there -- before he even showed up for work. Management. C12.

DaimlerChrysler reported a 14 percent rise in third-quarter adjusted net income to $1.60 a diluted share, topping forecasts of $1.40, but the stock rose only 75 cents to $76. C8.
 
Netscape Founder in New Venture
Marc L. Andreessen, a co-founder of Netscape and a multimillionaire, is teaming up with several Netscape executives to start a company in a spare room at an equipment company, a return of sorts to the legendary Silicon Valley garages where Hewlett-Packard and Apple Computer were started. C10.

Richard D. Nanula, the former chief operating officer at the world's largest hotel company, Starwood Hotels, has decided to run a fledgling Internet company, Broadband Sports. C2.

Both Lucent Technologies and the Nortel Networks Corporation of Canada reported strong quarterly financial results. Excluding one-time charges and gains, Lucent earned 31 cents a share, topping forecasts of 29 cents, sending its stock up smartly. Lucent also announced a reorganization into four core businesses and an executive shake-up. C8.
 
Stock Prices Fall on Retail Drop
Stock prices fell as retail issues slid after a report that sales growth had slowed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 47.80 points, to 10,302.13. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 11.72, to 1,281.91, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 4.48, to 2,811.47. C16.
 
Consumer confidence in the economy fell in October for the fourth consecutive month amid concerns about falling stock prices. C27.
 
Greater Car Safety Stressed
Because cars outnumber trucks, designing cars with improved protection for occupants will do more for automotive safety than designing sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks that are less lethal to car occupants in collisions, according to a new analysis. C8.
 
House Passes Cybersquatting Bill
The House of Representatives passed legislation to crack down on cybersquatting, the practice of buying up popular words as Internet addresses in the hopes of reselling them. C27.

Rocked by a real estate scandal that has cost it more than $2 billion, Munich's Hypovereinsbank forced out several top executives. C4.

HEADLINE: Giuliani's New Policy on Work for the Homeless Leaves Many Unanswered Questions

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
On an average night, 21,000 men, women and children bed down in the New York City homeless shelter system. In an average year, city data show, more than 80,000 different people use the shelters.
All those homeless people will be affected in some way by the Giuliani administration's plan to require that able-bodied homeless people work and meet other welfare rules as conditions of shelter. 
 There are many unanswered questions about how the city's plan will play out for various segments of the homeless population, from those who already work but do not earn enough to leave the shelter system, to families who often have to apply several times before they find shelter, and to the disabled and the mentally ill who, advocates for the homeless say, are often expected to work in some capacity.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stressed yesterday that the work requirement will not apply to all the homeless. "This applies to people who are able-bodied, able to work who aren't working," he said.
Some homeless people say a job is not an automatic ticket out of the shelter system. Kenneth Lindo is not only able to work, he is also working. But 10 months after he entered the city shelter system, he is still sleeping in a shelter bed, commuting from the Bronx to his $5.50 hourly wage as a Wall Street messenger and looking for a room he can afford. He was saving to put down a security deposit but recently had to use much of the money for shoes and winter clothing, he said yesterday.
Under the state social services regulations that Mayor Giuliani wants to apply to shelter residents before the end of the year, people like Mr. Lindo who earn more than they would get from public assistance are required to spend the excess to pay for their shelter bed, up to the actual cost, which is more than $20,000 a year, according to city officials.
"It doesn't make sense -- they're supposed to be there to help you, not hurt you," said Mr. Lindo, 44, who was recently transferred from the 30th Street Men's Shelter near Bellevue Hospital Center to the Franklin Avenue shelter in the Bronx.
The Mayor's press office did not respond to a question yesterday about whether working shelter residents would be charged for shelter. In a recent interview, Jason Turner, Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, said that question was "in flux operationally," but added his own questions: "Should the shelter system be just a free place to live? Is that the solution, to live in a homeless shelter?"
Questions also remain on how families will be affected by the new rules. In August 1996, stringent eligibility procedures took effect that cut the number of families allowed to enter the system. Last year, the average daily census was 4,800 families, down from 5,674 in 1995.
But though fewer families leaving the system were offered permanent housing by the city, the number of families applying for shelter remained steady, city records show. Many had to apply repeatedly to get into a shelter. One such parent was Lisa T., 28, a Bronx woman with a baby daughter who spoke about her case on condition that her last name be withheld. Ms. T. was living with a cousin and working as an attendant in a nursing home throughout her pregnancy but left her job when the baby was born and six months later, her cousin told her to move out, she said. Unemployed, her savings depleted, and her baby daughter showing symptoms of asthma, she turned to the city's Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx, the only portal for homeless families to enter the shelter system.
It took three applications, two denials and two stints of 10 days each in far-flung shelter hotels -- one in Harlem, one near La Guardia Airport in Queens -- before she and her child were assigned to a family shelter in the Bronx, she said. Though she had never been on welfare before, she was required to apply, because most family shelters, which are run by private, nonprofit agencies under contract to the city, are partly reimbursed through the residents' welfare grants.
She traveled to Brooklyn to notify her welfare caseworker when she was transferred from the Bronx shelter to one in Queens, she said, but mail from the welfare center continued to go to the first shelter.
She never received a notice telling her to appear for a recertification, and her case was closed, leaving her without the $109 monthly cash stipend she needed for diapers and clothes and extra food for her child, who was failing to thrive on the shelter diet, doctors at the Children's Health Fund said.
Under the new rules, however, the results could have been more dire: residents who lose welfare eligibility are no longer entitled to shelter, and their children could be taken into foster care, the city says.
"Over my dead body," said Ms. T., who found jobs as a home health attendant on her own, put her child in day care, and last spring, with the help of her shelter caseworker, obtained a government-subsidized one-bedroom apartment in the Bronx.
She said she does not think the new city policy is fair: "They kick me out of the shelter and the city take my daughter for something I got no control over? Thank God I'm out of that system."
Frederick Shack, the president of an group of 42 nonprofit agencies running family shelters under contract to the city, said that at any one time, 10 percent of the people in family shelters have been mistakenly cited for noncompliance with welfare rules.
It is also not clear how the new rules will affect the disabled.
Although the Mayor said that work would not be required for homeless people who are physically or mentally disabled, city welfare data reflect sharply tougher definitions of disability. In 1994, more than 20,400 adults on public assistance were considered disabled enough to be temporarily exempt from work, but in 1997, the number had dropped to 5,902.
Advocates for the homeless and those who run many of the smaller, specialized shelters for the mentally ill say many who are disabled are already being expected to work for public assistance, or they mistakenly lose their exemptions.
In one example cited by Ray Brescia, a lawyer with the Urban Justice Center, an advocacy organization specializing in mental health and homeless issues, a man with a long history of panic attacks and manic-depression was fired from a workfare job in a sanitation garage after he compulsively filled a canister with road salt, making it too heavy to lift. He lost his benefits, Mr. Brescia said, and under the new rules could have lost his shelter, too.
