SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 35; Column 2; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 4438 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Northern, Southern, Sleepy and Dynamic

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
This old river town, with a site of uncommon beauty and a populace of uncommon civility, has a reputation as a stick-in-the-mud all the same. Mark Twain suggested that he'd like to come here for the apocalypse because it was always 20 years behind the times. Decades later, John Gunther detected "a certain stately and also sleepy quality" in the place.
Even Gov. Bob Taft of Ohio, a member of the city's (and the nation's) longest-lasting political dynasty, told me when I ran into him at a football game that Cincinnati has "an inbred resistance to rapid change." Longfellow, on the other hand, described this as the "Queen City of the West," and in hard times Cincinnati has clung to that phrase like a life raft. 
 The most celebrated outcropping of the city's conservatism in recent years was the indictment on April 7, 1990, of the Contemporary Arts Center and its director on obscenity charges arising from an exhibition of 175 Robert Mapplethorpe photographs. A few of them depicted explicit homoerotic subjects. Much less attention was paid when a local jury, largely working-class in makeup, acquitted both defendants six months later.
Which was par for the course. People also tend to overlook the city's cultural traditions, especially its rich musical heritage, and its record of innovation in many fields. It had the first professional baseball team: the Cincinnati Red Stockings, now the Reds, founded in 1869. John A. Roebling's suspension bridge across the Ohio River, which remains in service to this day, opened in 1866, 17 years before the Brooklyn Bridge.
It was in Cincinnati as well that Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise of the Plum Street Temple, born in Bohemia, gave shape to modern Reform Judaism through the Hebrew Union College, the Central Conference of American Rabbis and the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. The rabbi called his Byzanto-Moorish temple "my Alhambra."
Play-Doh was invented here, and Formica, and soap that floats. Rather more significantly for human well-being, Dr. Albert Sabin developed his oral polio vaccine while working here, and Dr. Henry Heimlich perfected his life-saving maneuver for choking victims.
In recent years, a galaxy of groundbreaking architects, including Frank O. Gehry, Michael Graves, Peter Eisenman, Cesar Pelli and Harry Cobb, have designed new buildings for several local institutions, notably the University of Cincinnati. The Contemporary Arts Center, focus of the Mapplethorpe flap, and not some elite organization in California or New York, gave the highly regarded Iraqi-born architect Zaha Hadid her first big commission in the United States.
Mr. Gehry's Vontz Center for Molecular Studies, which opened on Sept. 23, looks like one of those cartoon buildings that are jumping off their foundations, almost ready to burst. The red-brick structure is defined by its bulges and the metal grids of its windows. It forms a vivid if startling gateway to the university, which Herbert Muschamp has described in The New York Times as "one of the most architecturally dynamic campuses in America today."
 
An Early Boom Town
A little bit Northern, a little bit Southern, Cincinnati comes close to the national average by a number of standards, including cost of living and median family income.
Before the Civil War, some Cincinnatians with extensive business dealings in the South defended that region's Peculiar Institution. But local abolitionists helped thousands of slaves escape across the Ohio River to freedom, defying apostles of the status quo. Lyman Beecher, a fiery Presbyterian preacher, spent two decades as president of a seminary here, and his daughter, Harriet Beecher Stowe, drew on her experiences in Ohio and Kentucky in writing the enormously influential anti-slavery novel "Uncle Tom's Cabin."
That history will be celebrated in an $80 million National Underground Railroad Museum, now in the planning stage. It will be a major element in the ongoing reinvention of the riverfront, the place where the city began. A pair of new sports stadiums will be there, too -- one for the Reds, to be finished in 2003, the other for the football Bengals, to open next year. (Pittsburgh, 400 miles or so back up the Ohio River, is building its own pair.)
The Ohio was one of the main highways west, and that made Cincinnati a boom town in the years after the Revolution. Founded in 1788, it was given its name by Arthur St. Clair, Governor of the Northwest Territory. Having fought as commander of the New Jersey militia at the battles of Trenton and Princeton, among others, and attained the rank of major general, St. Clair became a member of the Society of the Cincinnati, an organization of Revolutionary officers founded by George Washington. The society was named for Cincinnatus, a Roman patriot who returned to his farm after saving his city in battle, and this city, in turn, was named for the society.
Like the floodwaters that have often plagued it, Cincinnati spread slowly up and out from "the Basin," as the locals call the flatlands along the river, first into the adjoining valleys, then onto the hillsides.
As a Cincinnati Web site (www.insiders.com/cincinnati) puts it, "the steamboat changed Cincinnati almost as much as the apple changed Adam." By the 1840's, it was the sixth-largest American city and the center of the young nation's pig-processing industry. People called the city Porkopolis, and visitors complained of the smell. The English novelist Anthony Trollope wrote of "a stench that surpassed in offensiveness anything that my nose had ever hitherto suffered: the odor of hogs going up to the Ohio heavens."
 
After the Pigs
The porkers are gone, of course, remembered only by the flying pigs atop a dubious monument at Sawyer Point. But one of the companies founded to make use of pork by-products like lard lives on as Cincinnati's primary economic engine: Procter & Gamble, the nation's largest producer of products for use in the household.
P & G's twin post-modern headquarters towers dominate the eastern part of downtown Cincinnati. It has a new chief executive, Durk I. Jager, reputedly installed to shake things up, and the company still reaches into every city, town and hamlet in America with Tide, Ivory, Pampers, Crisco, Folger's, Old Spice and dozens of other brands.
Cincinnati is also home base for Federated Department Stores, the retailing leviathan that operates more than 400 stores nationwide, including Macy's, Stern's and Bloomingdale's in the New York area; Chiquita Brands, the world's biggest banana company, which forced The Cincinnati Enquirer to run a front-page apology and pay a $10 million settlement last year after the paper accused it of illicit operations in Central America, and Kroger, which grew from a single grocery store started in 1883 by Barney Kroger, with $372 of his own and $350 borrowed from a friend, into the nation's biggest supermarket chain.
General Electric, which makes more jet aircraft engines than anyone else in the world, makes many of them in a huge plant in suburban Evendale. And who could overlook the weirdly named Fifth Third bank, formed in a 1908 merger between institutions that insisted on retaining their identities?
But Cincinnati missed what may have been its biggest economic opportunity. At the turn of the last century, it was the world's biggest manufacturer of carriages; when a couple of entrepreneurs named Henry Ford and J. W. Packard came looking for capital to start their auto factories, the local bankers turned them down. So they went to Detroit instead.
The main east-west railroads, and eventually the main east-west superhighways, bypassed Cincinnati. Like people in St. Louis and other older cities in the Midwest, Cincinnatians watched as Chicago became the region's principal hub and their city fell into the second division.
An economic development expert from North Carolina hired recently to make an independent appraisal told local businessmen, "You have the remnants of a great city here," Cincinnati magazine reported.
Having already missed the information technology boom, business and medical leaders here are now working hard to make the city a leader in biotechnology. Led by Procter & Gamble and the University of Cincinnati, a task force is talking about the investment of years of effort and hundreds of millions of dollars. A study released by the group cited among the city's assets its quality of life; but in entrepreneurial culture -- the willingness to take a chance -- the study ranked this region 18th among 21 nationally.
 
A Teutonic Flavor
Perhaps because the region reminded them of the Rhineland, Germans flooded into the Ohio Valley in the 1840's and 50's, eventually constituting a quarter of Cincinnati's population. German-language newspapers were founded, beer gardens sprang up in every neighborhood and German was taught in the public schools. All that came to a swift end with World War I.
But the Teutonic flavor lingers. The arty neighborhood north of downtown is called Over-the-Rhine. Oktoberfest (inexplicably scheduled for mid-September) is one of the city's many annual fetes. Graeter's ice cream, dished up in shops around the city, is another, super-delicious survivor of the city's Germanic past.
Zoology is a German passion, too, and Cincinnati has long boasted one of the nation's premier zoos, under Edward J. Maruska, its widely respected executive director. Lately it has opened a new Manatee Springs exhibit, home to Douglas and Stoneman, a pair of the endangered cowlike marine mammals from the Florida coast.
The most important legacy, however, is the city's love of music. The May Festival, which dates from 1873, grew out of Saengerfests, or songfests, that were given starting in 1849, with up to 2,000 volunteer chorus members. The Music Hall, a sauerbraten Gothic palace that seats 3,400 people, with spectacular chandeliers and a lovely lobby in cream and gold, was completed in 1878 as a home for the festival. It now houses the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Cincinnati Pops and Cincinnati Summer Opera as well.
A distinguished roster of European conductors have taken charge of the festival, which still concentrates on choral music. Among them have been Eugene Goossens, Fritz Busch, Josef Krips and Max Rudolf. In 1906, Edward Elgar traveled to Cincinnati to conduct his "Dream of Gerontius."
Since 1974, Americans have been at the festival's helm: Cincinnati-born James Levine until 1979, James Conlon for the two decades since then. Maestro Conlon is one of those American musicians who have made their careers largely in Europe (mostly France and Germany, in his case), but Cincinnati recognized his gifts early. Now he is the principal conductor of the Paris Opera and the Cologne Philharmonic, but he nonetheless returns to Ohio each year.
The Cincinnati Symphony, founded in 1895, also has a distinguished history, having had Leopold Stokowski, Fritz Reiner and Thomas Schippers as conductors; Schippers, who died young, was a great local favorite who also worked at Bayreuth and, notably, at Spoleto in Italy. The Spaniard Jesus Lopez-Cobos is the current music director, and the orchestra, which plays a full September-to-May season, remains more adventurous than most.
This year the Cincinnatians are playing Glinka, Korngold, Honegger, Nielsen, Griffes, Scriabin, Weill and Zwilich in addition to more conventional musical fare. In January, they will present, in an afternoon and two evenings, a concert version of Wagner's "Lohengrin."
The Pops, probably the best-known such ensemble after Boston's, has gained an international reputation under Erich Kunzel. It has made no fewer than 65 records for Telarc, which have sold more than seven million copies worldwide and earned the charismatic Mr. Kunzel enough in the process to buy houses in the Bahamas and on Swan's Island off the Maine coast.
In the summer the Pops moves to Riverbend, a complex along the Ohio River five miles east of town that was designed for the orchestra by Michael Graves.
 
A Focus on the Arts
Cincinnati's theatrical pride and joy is the Aronoff Center for the Arts, built in the heart of downtown to a design by Mr. Pelli. It has three halls that can house everything from touring Broadway musicals to the productions of the Cincinnati Ballet to small-scale experiments.
The Playhouse in the Park, a professional company with the good fortune to perform in a leafy aerie overlooking the city, will present 10 productions this season, ranging from "Much Ado About Nothing" to "Wit," Margaret Edson's 1999 Pulitzer Prize winner. The small but enterprising Ensemble Theater performs in a converted bank building in Over-the-Rhine; Edward Albee has directed several of his plays there. And the Cincinnati Opera puts on nine performances of four operas every June and July ("Pelleas and Melisande" is one of the features in 2000) in the Music Hall.
As for the visual arts, the city has not one but two important museums -- the Cincinnati Art Museum and the Taft Museum -- both linked with the remarkable Taft family. The fact that both lent important works to the Ingres exhibition in Washington and New York this year, a connoisseur's show if ever there was one, suggests the quality of their best holdings.
It's worth digressing into politics for a moment to sketch in the story of the Tafts. Alphonso Taft was Secretary of War and Attorney General under Ulysses S. Grant. His son, William Howard Taft, a 350-pounder who had to have a special bathtub installed in the White House, was the 27th President and the 10th Chief Justice of the United States; he much preferred the latter role.
"I don't remember that I ever was President," he once remarked.
President Taft's son, Senator Robert A. Taft, a leading isolationist, came close to the Republican Presidential nomination in 1952. His son, Robert Taft, with no middle initial, also served in the Senate. And his son, Bob Taft, is the current Governor of Ohio. The Governor likes politics better than his great-grandfather did. How was he getting on in Columbus?, I asked. "I love being Governor," he replied happily. "I'm having a ball."
Mrs. William Howard Taft was an early supporter of the Cincinnati Art Museum, which has grown into a comprehensive collection housed in a Doric temple in Eden Park, atop Mount Adams. It has just chosen a new director, Timothy F. Rub, who has been director of the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College. The museum has good modern art, including a splendidly graphic Matisse called "Romanian Blouse" (1937) and a Warhol portrait of Pete Rose -- a k a Charlie Hustle, the Reds' tragic hero, who set an all-time record with 4,192 hits, only to be denied admission to the Hall of Fame because he had gambled. But its Old Masters are its real glory.
A vast Benjamin West, "Ophelia and Laertes," was bought in London by Robert Fulton, the steamboat man, then brought to Cincinnati by Nicholas Longworth, the founder of another local dynasty, as early as 1828. Closer to our own time, the Emery family enriched the collection with a fine Mantegna, a small but lustrous Botticelli and one of the best Bronzinos I know, a cool, austerely beautiful portrait of Eleanor of Toledo and her son.
This year the museum is showing the extensive survey of Jim Dine's early work that was organized by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York. Mr. Dine is one of several well-known artists from Cincinnati, including Tom Wesselmann and John Henry Twachtman.
The Taft Museum, quartered in a handsome Federal house overshadowed by the skyscrapers downtown, was given to the city by another branch of the Taft family, which produced several ambassadors, a mayor and a member of Congress. Its highlights, for me, are its fine Hals portraits; a brilliantly colored Gainsborough, "Edward and William Tomkinson," and a great late Turner, "Europa and the Bull," in which the figures vanish in a shimmer of gold and blue.
Across town, the old Union Terminal, a railway station that looks like a Bakelite Art Deco radio rendered in concrete, has been turned into the Cincinnati Museum Center. A landmark of Deco architecture, it continues to evoke the drama of travel in the golden age of rail, while sheltering a history museum, a children's museum, a museum of natural history and science and an IMAX movie theater under its soaring half-dome.
Its ice cream parlor is sheathed in Rookwood tiles. The Rookwood Pottery, Cincinnati's contribution to the Arts and Crafts movement, was founded by Nicholas Longworth's granddaughter, Maria Longworth Nichols. (Her nephew, Nicholas Longworth 3d, was the Speaker of the House and married Theodore Roosevelt's sharp-tongued daughter, Alice, who called Cincinnati "Cincin nasty.") You can see other, better Rookwood tiles in the Federal courthouse, which is named for Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court, a Cincinnati native, and on the facade of the Dixie Terminal.
In addition, the Art Museum shows 30 superb Rookwood vases.
 
A Vertical Idea
What everyone in Cincinnati who has anything to do with the arts is awaiting is the construction of Ms. Hadid's new Contemporary Arts Center on a street corner near the Aronoff. It will be a strongly vertical building, fitted into a tight space, that strikes some people as a Klee magic-square painting in three dimensions. A broad ramp ascending one side of the building is reminiscent of the escalators at the Beaubourg in Paris, except that visitors will be able to peer through holes into the galleries, which are to be arranged on seven levels.
The center has no collection of its own; it exhibits pictures and objects from elsewhere, like the group show of young Brooklyn artists, including James Hyde and Karen Arm, that has been on this fall.
As Ms. Hadid arrives on the scene (her building will open sometime after 2001), the city's best-known woman of the last 15 years, Marge Schott, is fading away. She was ordered on Sept. 5 by Major League Baseball to sell her interest in the Reds -- not because of what she did but because of what she said. Her Reds won a lot more than they lost, and her St. Bernards, Schottzie and Schottzie 02, were a side issue. The problem was impolitic remarks like "Hitler was good in the beginning, but he went too far."
Her departure, wrote Tim Sullivan in The Cincinnati Enquirer, marked "the end of an error."
 
Cincinnati Sojourn
 
Cincinnati is 644 miles from New York City. Here is a sampling of local attractions, as well as other information about the city:
 
Where to Stay
 
THE CINCINNATIAN, 601 Vine Street, (513) 381-3000. Designed by the city's favorite fin-de-siecle architect, Samuel Hannaford, and thoroughly rebuilt in 1987, this is now Cincinnati's pre-eminent hotel. A period lobby opens into a sunny atrium painted in post-modern colors, Tuscan ocher and pale sky blue. With only 143 rooms to look after (a few of them a little small), the staff has time to provide personal service, and does. Double room: $240 weekdays; $180 weekends.
 
OMNI NETHERLAND PLAZA, 35 West Fifth Street, (513) 421-9100. The decor is the thing in this Art Deco classic, built in 1930 and embellished with Rookwood tiles, chromium torchiers and a sea horse fountain. A 1983 renovation swept away a half-century's wear and tear, and the place sparkles as it did when Churchill and Roosevelt stayed there. The food in the pretty lobby restaurant, Orchids, doesn't live up to the surroundings. Double room: $210 to $230 weekdays; $130 to $150 weekends.
 
WESTIN, Fountain Square, (513) 621-7700. The location is perfect, the tastefully redecorated rooms have plenty of elbow room, and the hotel can even claim a footnote in history: the infamous "Jerry Springer Show" originated from the premises in its early days. But service can be dire. My bags were lost for two hours between curb and room, while undertrained, overcheerful people assured me every 15 minutes that they were "on the way up." Double room: $109 to $220 weekdays; $105 to $135 weekends.
 
Where to Eat
 
CAMP WASHINGTON CHILI, 3005 Colerain Avenue, (513) 541-0061. Created in 1922 by a Bulgarian immigrant, Cincinnati-style chili took the town by storm. This improbable passion has never abated, and now there are three chains with 150-odd outlets, plus independents. All serve "three-way" (chili made with cocoa, cinnamon and allspice, served atop spaghetti, with a crown of grated Cheddar cheese); I prefer four-way, with chopped onions, and homely old Camp Washington does it best. Lean over when you eat; the stuff stains.
 
MAISONETTE, 114 East Sixth Street, (513 721-2260. This is the Maisonette's 50th anniversary year. You can return to the 1960's in this traditional, formal, softly lighted place, ordering things like Dover sole along with the city's famously stodgy movers and shakers. Don't. If you ask, the chef, Jean-Robert de Cavel, will send out a succession of light, inventive dishes like a crab salad that incorporates seaweed, juicy red and yellow tomatoes, melon and a lemony dressing. Superb desserts and wonderful wines.
 
THE PALACE, Cincinnatian Hotel (see above). The best of the city's hotel dining rooms serves the closest thing Cincinnati has to New American cooking. The menu includes seasonal regional offerings like a soft-shell crab po' boy as well as many standard items like grilled swordfish. When I was there, a special card offered a half-dozen first-rate South African wines, which would have been startling in New York, let alone the Midwest.
 
JEFF RUBY'S, 700 Walnut Street, (513) 784-1200. A brash transplant from New Jersey, Jeff Ruby wore spats to the opening benefit at this addition to his chain of Cincinnati watering holes. Beef and lamb is dry-aged in a glass-walled cooler (cf Gallagher's, New York), and smokers can enjoy their Delmonico steaks and Bibb salads, their Jordan cabernet or Ducru-Beaucaillou and their cigars in the Toots Shor room.
 
TRIO, 7565 Kenwood Road, Kenwood, (513) 984-1905. A lot of the culinary action in Cincinnati is in the suburbs, and Trio stands out from a slew of other restaurants there for its mostly American wine list (three Ridge zinfandels, 36 selections by the glass, gentle prices). The food runs the middlebrow gamut from meatloaf to designer pizzas to fine wood-grilled salmon; I liked the grilled shrimp on narrow noodles with a Thai sauce.
 
Attractions

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Bankruptcy In Japan Gets The Attention Of 'Vultures'

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The vultures are coming! The vultures are coming!
The "vultures" are investors who specialize in buying bankrupt and distressed assets, and two of the top vultures are the Rothschild Recovery Fund, a private equity fund run by Rothschild Inc., and Japan Recovery Capital Partners, which is managed by a joint venture of Daiwa Securities and Sumitomo Bank. 
 On Friday, they are expected to announce a reorganization of Nikko Electric Industry, an automotive parts supplier that has the distinction of being the first Japanese company this century to be put into bankruptcy by its employees.
Such investors, most of them Americans, have been circling Japan for the last few years, but most have limited themselves to making investments related to real estate.
So Rothschild's move to take over Nikko Electric is yet another foray by a foreigner that would have been unthinkable in the Japanese economy even two years ago.
"I think this will open a new direction for other bankruptcies and distressed corporations in Japan," said Wilbur L. Ross Jr., senior managing director of Rothschild Inc. and an eminence grise of the American bankruptcy system.
But Mr. Ross and his partners intend to modify the standard American blueprint for reorganizing a bankrupt company. They are inviting some of Nikko Electric's biggest suppliers, which include Delco Remy International, Komatsu, Isuzu Motors and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, to become investors along with them.
"That would make it more like the Japanese system, where customers and vendors traditionally have counter-invested in each other," Mr. Ross said. "We're trying to blend American techniques with the historical way things are done in Japan."
The plan runs counter to current trends in Japan, where even the most staid companies are starting to shed their cross-shareholdings.
Rothschild and Japan Recovery say, however, that giving Nikko's customers a stake in the potential upside of the deal will insure their good will -- and continued business.
Whether they can coax Nikko Electric's lenders into writing off a substantial portion of the outstanding debt may be a bigger challenge.
The Nikko Electric bankruptcy is known in Japan because of the unusual way the company ended up under the administration of a court-appointed trustee. Japan is one of the few countries in the world where employees can petition the court to put their company under its care without management's agreement; Nikko Electric's employees did just that earlier this year.

HEADLINE: Stock Mutual Funds Post Rise In Cash Inflows for September

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The net flow of cash into stock mutual funds is picking up from subdued levels earlier in the year, official industry figures and private estimates showed yesterday.
The Investment Company Institute said flows of cash into stock mutual funds rose to $9.38 billion in September from a revised $8.91 billion in August. Previously, the institute put the August number at $9.21 billion. Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, a company based in Santa Rosa, Calif., that tracks fund data, estimated that stock fund flows soared in October to $22.5 billion. The figure, based on activity through Tuesday, could change. If the Trim Tabs figures turn out to be on track, it would be the second-best month this year for flows into stock funds, trailing only the $25.84 billion in April. 
 After a strong start in early October, redemption activity picked up in midmonth when the market headed downward after some unsettling news on inflation, but money began pouring back in later in the month, Mutual Fund Trim Tabs said.
"People were fairly calm" as stocks headed lower, said Carl Wittnebert, director of research. He said Trim Tabs estimated that some $5 billion to $10 billion of short-term trading money tended to head for the exits on a downturn, but the vast majority of investors seemed to be using "buy and hold" strategies.
Mutual Fund Trim Tabs tracks flows for about 90 fund groups representing 20 percent of fund assets and uses a statistical method to estimate flows for funds over all.
Year to date, the institute said stock funds had taken in a net $121.08 billion, trailing the 1998 pace of $138.64 billion by about 12.7 percent.
Hybrid mutual funds, which include both stocks and bonds, had an outflow of $1.14 billion in September, the institute said, after an August outflow of $816.6 million.
Taxable bond funds had an outflow of $2.21 billion in September in contrast to an inflow of $462.8 million in August. Flows into taxable bond funds for the first nine months were $16.12 billion, just over one-third the $46.04 billion of a year earlier. Municipal bond funds had an outflow of $1.75 billion in September, compared with an outflow of $1.47 billion in August. Money market funds had an outflow of $14.90 billion in September in contrast to an inflow of $27.91 billion in August.
The institute said the increased flow into stock funds in September was especially notable in aggressive growth and global funds.
Assets of stock funds fell by $41.57 billion, to $3.30 trillion, in September, a month-to-month decline of 1.2 percent, reflecting volatility in stocks.
Total assets of stock, bond and money market funds fell nine-tenths of 1 percent, to $5.98 trillion, in September, from $6.03 trillion in August.
The annualized rate of redemptions for stock funds, as a percent of average net assets, was 23.9 percent, compared with 23.7 percent in August and 20.2 percent in September.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Have a Broad Rally; Dow Climbs 227.64 Points

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A benign report on labor costs sparked a broad-based rally on Wall Street yesterday, as investors eagerly bought stocks, again believing that inflation is under control.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 227.64 points, or 2.2 percent, to 10,622.53, extending Wednesday's 92-point gain. It was the Dow's biggest advance since it rose 235.24 points Sept. 3. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 45.73 points, or 3.5 percent, to 1,342.44, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 72.70 points, or 2.6 percent, to 2,875.22.
Even so, some analysts suggested that the wave of buying was an extreme investor reaction to fairly modest Government data.
"The market was looking for an excuse to go up," said Bernie Schaeffer, chairman of Schaeffer's Investment Research.
Stocks shot higher after the Labor Department said its employment cost index rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter, slightly lower than the increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent many economists expected.
Economists regard the index as a significant barometer of inflationary pressures, so the lower-than-expected gain led to hope that when the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Open Market Committee meets Nov. 16, even if it raises short-term interest rates to ward off inflation, the increase could be the last for a while.
"The issue is not closed, of course," said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America, noting that the Fed will also carefully monitor next week's employment report for October. "But inflation pressures are not problematic at this time."
Bond prices rose for a second consecutive session, with the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond climbing a full point to a price of 98 10/32. That sent its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, down to 6.25 percent from 6.32 percent late Wednesday.
The retreat in bond yields, which earlier this month rose enough to lure some investors away from stocks, gave equities some additional support yesterday.
Bank and financial services stocks advanced for a second consecutive session, as traders reacted to the hope for stabilizing interest rates. Citigroup rose 3 a share, to 54 1/8, and American Express soared 10 3/8, to 161. Chase Manhattan was up 5 13/16, to 88 9/16.
While investors focused on the employment cost numbers, they largely ignored a Government report that the nation's gross domestic product expanded at an annual rate of 4.8 percent from July through September, the fastest pace this year. On a less optimistic day, the G.D.P. report could have prompted selling, analysts said.
"There seems to be a sense that whatever the Fed does, once we get it out of the way, the market can move higher," Mr. Schaeffer said.
In Nasdaq trading, Amazon.com fell 4 15/16 a share, to 71. The on-line retailer said late Wednesday that while its third-quarter results topped expectations, losses more than tripled from a year ago as it spent heavily to expand its menu of offerings.
MCI Worldcom rose 6 1/16 a share, to 83 5/8, after reporting that its third-quarter operating profits nearly tripled, compared with the period a year earlier.
Advancing issues outpaced declining ones by a 7-to-3 margin on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume totaled a robust 1.13 billion shares, compared with 894.4 million traded in the previous session.
Overseas, the Nikkei stock average in Japan rose two-tenths of 1 percent. The rally on Wall Street also helped to raise European markets, lifting the DAX index in Germany 2.1 percent, the FT-SE 100 index in Britain, 1.7 percent, and the CAC-40 index in France, 1.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Small Employers Describe Health InsuranceConcerns

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The rising cost of health insurance is hitting small employers particularly hard, with premiums for the smallest companies rising 9.2 percent last year, according to a new survey.
Researchers said this was one of several ominous trends in employer-based health insurance. "The fact that we really haven't seen any change in the percentage of employers offering coverage during an all-time boom economy is cause for worry," said Drew Altman, president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, the health research group that co-sponsored the survey of 1,939 companies. "This is as good as it gets." 
 Sixty percent of all small firms offered their employees health insurance in 1999, a percentage that was statistically unchanged from 1996, the survey found. Virtually all big employers -- defined as those with 200 employees and more -- offered health benefits.
The study, released at a news conference today in Washington, provides an annual snapshot of health insurance provided through the workplace, which is how most Americans get their health benefits. It showed that the managed care revolution has all but overwhelmed conventional, fee-for-service coverage: only 9 percent of Americans with job-based coverage are enrolled in a traditional plan, down from 73 percent in 1988.
By comparison, 28 percent were enrolled in health maintenance organizations and 38 percent were in preferred provider organizations, the most popular type of health plan last year. In contrast to H.M.O.'s, preferred provider organizations allow patients to go beyond the plan's list of participating doctors, if they are willing to pay more, and do not require patients to go through a primary care gatekeeper to see a specialist.
The shift to managed care is widely credited for having helped control health care costs for several years, but the survey confirmed that premium prices are beginning to rise again. Over all, in the year ending in the spring of 1999, premiums for employer-sponsored health coverage increased 4.8 percent, the biggest jump since 1994. Researchers said this was relatively modest compared with the double-digit increases of a decade ago, but still more than double the rate of inflation.
Moreover, said Larry Levitt, a Kaiser analyst, "the most fragile part of the health care system is getting hardest hit." Companies employing three to nine workers reported the highest increase in premiums: 9.2 percent. By comparison, companies with more than 200 employees reported a 4.1 percent increase in premium costs.
Mr. Altman said, "These increases will make it even harder for small businesses to provide health insurance for their employees in the future." Several researchers said that such strains in the employer-based system help explain why policy makers in Washington are searching for alternative means of helping the uninsured. The Census Bureau reported last month that 44.3 million people are uninsured.
Researchers also found that companies who finance their own health insurance reported substantially lower premium increases than the firms that bought it from insurance companies. Jon R. Gabel, one of the researchers, traced this to "catch-up pricing," with insurers trying to restore their profitability after several years of "underpricing" to get a bigger share of the market.
The survey released today was based on telephone interviews with human resource and benefit administrators at a random sample of companies and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. For several years the survey was conducted by KPMG Peat Marwick, but was turned over last year to the Health Research and Educational Trust, a nonprofit research group, which now conducts the survey with Kaiser.
Researchers also asked employers about the "patients' rights" proposals being debated in Congress this year, and found that a majority supported such measures as the right to external review, when a health plan denies care, and even the right to sue. But support was generally higher among small employers, particularly on the right to sue, which was backed by 61 percent of small employers, while more than half of the biggest firms opposed it.
Nearly three-fourths of all employers said they were worried that health care costs would rise faster than they could afford, and 65 percent said they were "somewhat" or "very" worried that they would have to switch health plans because of costs. By contrast, only 26 percent said they were "somewhat" or "very" worried that they would have to switch because of concerns about the quality of care.

HEADLINE: Nigeria Gets U.S. Help, but Bigger Plan for Africa Snags

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
As President Clinton met today with Nigeria's recently elected President and pledged a tripling of aid to the country, his Administration's biggest initiative for Africa -- a bill that could ease Africa's access to the American market -- seemed imperiled in the Senate.
Mr. Clinton's afternoon meeting with President Olusegun Obasanjo was an effort to show new American political support for a country tormented for decades by corruption, military dictatorship and violence. But when Mr. Obasanjo arrived here, he joined the parade of new democratic leaders who wanted to talk tariff rates and debt forgiveness. And during an afternoon news conference with Mr. Clinton, he spoke about Nigeria's new commitment to "a level playing ground" for investors, making sure that "investment can be secure." 
 Mr. Obasanjo's main goal was to reduce or reschedule more than $30 billion in debt. Paying down the interest and the principal takes up a huge part of Nigeria's gross national product. At the news conference, Mr. Clinton said, "It is neither morally right nor economically sound to say that young democracies like Nigeria, as they overcome the painful legacy of dictatorship or misrule, must choose between making interest payments on their debt and investing in the health and education of their children."
But under the debt-forgiveness plan for the world's poorest nations that Mr. Clinton announced last month, Nigeria would be only a partial beneficiary. The country has such large oil reserves that little of its debt would be forgiven outright. Instead, payments to the world's major powers and to the World Bank would largely be delayed.
But even as he was meeting with Mr. Obasanjo today, Mr. Clinton was trying to save the African Growth and Opportunity Act, which would reduce or eliminate duties on a range of products produced in sub-Saharan Africa, mostly those made with American-produced fabrics.
Until today, the bill appeared to be sailing toward easy passage. But late this afternoon, aides to the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, said the bill could be pulled from the Senate agenda on Friday because of a dispute with Democrats over amendments. This also threatened a similar trade bill for Caribbean nations, which is attached to the African bill.
On Tuesday, bipartisan support for the trade bill -- which would mean a great amount to sub-Saharan countries but would have a barely measurable effect on the American economy -- appeared extremely strong. The Senate voted 90 to 8 to cut off a filibuster led by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who fears the effects of African imports on his state's politically powerful textile makers.
On Wednesday, however, Mr. Lott said he feared that Democrats would try to to attach a raft of unrelated amendments to the bill. So he invoked a parliamentary maneuver to block Democrats from offering amendments.
That infuriated Democrats who had hoped to offer amendments on raising the minimum wage, a patients' bill of rights and a Medicare prescription drug bill -- all initiatives that Mr. Clinton has supported, and which Democrats hope to turn into campaign issues.
Mr. Clinton has been calling around on Capitol Hill -- including to Mr. Lott -- to save the bill. White House officials are clearly concerned that he not be accused of doing too little, the charge that Republicans leveled after the defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty two weeks ago.
The Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle, who supports the bill, today angrily denounced the Republican procedural tactics. He said the debate now revolved around any senator's fundamental right to offer an amendment.
Aides to Mr. Daschle said that barring a last-minute compromise, all 45 Democrats would probably vote against a second motion to cut off debate on Friday.
About 50 Republicans are expected to vote to end the filibuster, but a spokesman for Mr. Lott, John Czwartacki, said that if the majority could not muster the 60 votes necessary to cut off debate, the majority leader would pull the bill from the Senate floor agenda.
Mr. Czwartacki signaled that Republicans were ready to turn Mr. Clinton's own accusations of isolationism against Democrats if the procedural vote failed.
"If there is no cloture, the Democrats will have succeeded in bowing to the worst elements of isolationism in their own party," Mr. Czwartacki said.
Democrats said they were willing to pay that price to stand up for the larger procedural principles of the Senate.
"This is a sham," Mr. Daschle said on the floor. "There is nothing deliberative about the Senate today. They want to make this a legislative assembly line. You take something up, you vote it up or down, and you move it along."
Tonight, Mr. Lott and Mr. Daschle met to discuss a compromise, but it was unclear whether they would reach agreement before Friday's vote.

HEADLINE: In 2 Leaders' Words: An Outline for Hope in Nigeria

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday with President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, as provided by the Federal Document Clearing House, a transcription service:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
By President Clinton
 President Obasanjo, Mrs. Obasanjo, members of the Nigerian Government, welcome to the White House. The President has served his country in many ways, including a previous term as President, which was distinguished by his insistence on a peaceful transition to a successor chosen by the people. His recent election marks an even bigger turning point. 
 Since its birth in 1960, Nigeria's progress has been thwarted over and over again by military leaders with little concern for the 110 million people. . . . It is very much in America's interests that Nigeria succeed, and therefore we should assist them in their success. We intend to increase our assistance to Nigeria to expand law-enforcement cooperation and to work toward an agreement to stimulate trade and investment between us. We intend to do what we can to help Nigeria recover assets plundered by the previous regime.
But we must do more to realize the promise of this moment for Nigeria and for Africa. I want to mention just three issues. First, we need to recognize that barriers to trade are barriers to opportunity for Africans working hard to catch up to the global economy and for Americans who want to work with them. That's why it is vital that the Senate approve the Africa Growth and Opportunity Act, which is now pending and on which I spent much of the afternoon working.
The second concrete step we can take, as President Obasanjo has reminded us, is to help relieve the crushing debt burden that is making it so hard for developing nations to get on their feet. It is neither morally right nor economically sound to say that young democracies like Nigeria, as they overcome the painful legacy of dictatorship or misrule, must choose between making interest payments on their debt and investing in the health and education of their children. As Nigeria undertakes its reforms, I will support generous debt rescheduling through the Paris Club and encourage other countries to take further steps.
Finally, we must keep doing our part to bring an end to Africa's remaining conflicts. Many of you have heard about the unspeakable atrocities visited upon the people of Sierra Leone. Nigeria spent billions of dollars leading the international force that ended civil wars there and in Liberia. And for that, the whole world is in its debt. . . .
 
OPENING STATEMENT
By President Obasanjo
 Mr. President, it's just for me to take this opportunity, on behalf of my Government and the people of Nigeria, to express our deep appreciation for your concern and for your support for the new dispensation in my country for democracy. We thank you for your commitment and the commitment of your country to insure that democracy will continue to be nurtured and to be sustained in our country and in our part of the world. We believe that democracy is a process and not an event. And therefore we must continue to work to expand, to widen and to deepen the process of democracy, which we are committed to do.
We also thank you for the understanding you have shown for the commitment and the sacrifice which our country and our people have made and which we continue to make for peace and stability in our subregion and our region of Africa. We do this knowing and believing that peace is indivisible, and if there is no peace in any part of our subregion, it has implications for us.
We also thank you for the commitment you have made -- that while we make our commitment, you will continue to support our commitment. Because our own commitment, which will make peace and stability an enduring feature of that part of the world has significant contribution to the world of peace, to the world of harmony, to the world of order and stability, which is so dear to all of us, and which, of course, is of strategic importance and interest of the United States of America. . . .
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
MR. CLINTON: Thank you. We will now alternate questions between the American and the Nigerian press members here. . . .
Q. Nigeria lost a lot of money through a lot of -- I mean, our leaders' looting the Treasury and bringing the money not only to the U.S., but to Switzerland. What is the U.S. going to do about it to recover that money, the money in this country and the money that is in Switzerland? . . .
MR. CLINTON: Well, first I'll answer the question you asked me. I think it's important that we do whatever we can to help Nigeria recover money that was looted from the country and that belongs to the people of Nigeria.
The Attorney General came to our meeting today, Attorney General Reno, and we are working with the Government of Nigeria, and I will do whatever we can legally do to help recover funds that are in this country and whatever we can do to assist in recovering funds that may be in Switzerland or elsewhere.
You know, we have -- I may have to get some help -- some voluntary help from the Swiss. You know, the laws are different in different countries. But we think there are quite a number of things we can do here and we're committed to working with the Nigerian Government to do that.
MR. OBASANJO: Thank you very much. The only thing I can add to that is that the Swiss authorities have already frozen some accounts in Switzerland. And other steps that have to be taken will be taken as a result of what they have done so far. . . .
Q. In Oslo, sir, what do you expect between the meetings with Chairman Arafat and Prime Minister Barak? And what are the next steps? And are you looking for any concrete results?
MR. CLINTON: Well, first of all, I think it's a good thing that we're going to have this trilateral meeting, and it's just another step along the way. They've been making good progress, and they're working hard. I wouldn't want to raise expectations excessively about what the results of this meeting will be. But they have put themselves on an aggressive timetable, and they have a lot of tough issues to work through.
And since the United States has, at least in my time, primarily played a role as a facilitator, with greater or lesser degrees of intensity and initiative, including the Wye talks, when no one slept for nine days, I think that it's best for me not to speculate about what the substantial results will be.
Let me say this. I believe that both these leaders want to make peace. I believe they're committed to it. And I believe they know they're down to the difficult issues now.
And -- but I also believe they're imagining what a final agreement would look like, what they could live with, what would -- and what would be good for the other side and, mostly, what would preserve the integrity of their principles and the long-term peace of the region. . . .
Q. Mr. President, you have the largest democracy in Africa. What are the initiatives you hope to make it sustainable? And at the same time, also, as far as that constellation is concerned, what are some of the measures your Government is doing to attract businesses and investors to invest in Nigeria?
MR. OBASANJO: To invite investment into Nigeria, we have to create conducive environment for business to thrive. We have to create conducive environment for investors to want to invest in Nigeria, because investors have choices. Therefore we should make them choose to come to Nigeria.
And what are we doing? First of all, we are eliminating corruption as a way of life in Nigeria. You know, not many, if at all any, honest businessmen will want to rush into a corrupt atmosphere to do business. So we have to remove corruption, and we are doing that. We have to provide a level playing ground for all participants, so that there is equity, there is fairness, there is justice, and you can go in and compete. That we have done.
The rules and regulations must be clear, so that you know what it is. There must be transparency. There must be openness. . . . We are fighting against crime. Crime, in such a way that life and properties can be safe and secure, in such a way that investment can be secure.
These and all the things we are doing -- the rule of law -- so that when you have to seek arbitration by the court, you can be sure that you get fair deal from the court. We are doing all that we need to do to make the investors feel that all of the things put together, Nigeria is a better place to invest than any other place of comparative economic situation.

HEADLINE: Mayor Needs Old Magic in San Francisco Race

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
For an hour, it was 1995 again, when Willie Lewis Brown Jr. was the newly minted Mayor and San Francisco was dazzled by his possibilities.
Mayor Brown played the crowd at City Hall like Mozart on the piano, vowing to right what's wrong and better what's right, and tempering the high notes with quiet moments and meaningful pauses. And when he was finished on Monday with what he called this "last state of the city address to be given by any Mayor in this century," the chamber, so packed a person could faint, erupted in the loud, long applause usually reserved for a Broadway hit. 
 Then 1999, one week before the mayoral election, came rushing back. In the hallway outside the chamber, someone held a newspaper with the latest San Francisco Chronicle poll. It showed Mr. Brown gaining 33 percent of the vote, far short of the 50 percent plus one vote needed to win the election on Tuesday.
Nearby stood Frank Jordan, the former Mayor, who is one of Mr. Brown's three main opponents, drawing a crowd as he wondered aloud where the $1 billion increase in the city's budget over the last four years had gone.
Near him lingered Tom Ammiano, the president of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, who entered the race less than two weeks ago as a write-in candidate. Mr. Ammiano was exulting over the newspaper poll, which put him in a statistical tie for second place without even being listed as one of the candidates.
Given the polls, a run-off election in December seems likely. And while the prevailing thought is that Mr. Brown, who entered office as Mr. San Francisco, would win that race, no one is taking his victory for granted. The fact is, San Francisco's Mayor, a master of the political universe who spent three decades in the California Legislature (15 years as the Assembly Speaker before a new two-term-limit law forced him from office in 1995), is no longer Prince of the City.
Despite a booming economy, low unemployment and plunging crime rates that mirror the national trend, voters in politically obsessed San Francisco are not happy. And while this is not as surprising as it sounds -- San Franciscans are notoriously hard to please, not having re-elected a mayor in 16 years -- Mr. Brown, as colorful and irrepressible as the city considers itself, has disappointed voters on all sides.
To his more liberal constituents, he is too cozy with developers and other big business interests. To more conservative voters (a conservative here is a moderate Democrat anywhere else in the country), he does not pay enough attention to quality-of-life issues like traffic and is too close to the fringe groups that give San Francisco its reputation as a hotbed of radical chic.
Trying to cater to competing constituencies is a tricky business. Earlier this month, the Mayor ordered the confiscation of supermarket shopping carts that homeless people use to haul their possessions, on the grounds that they were stolen property. The move was seen as a response to merchants' complaints.
But even with public compassion towards homeless people at a seemingly all-time low, publicity about the operation brought outrage and sympathy. Mr. Brown stopped the operation before it began, both denying he had ordered it and claiming it was misunderstood. That, in turn, caused the more conservative pundits and business people in the city to label the Mayor a waffler.
The hard truth for Mr. Brown is that many San Franciscans believe the city is not better off than it was four years ago. Half the voters in the latest poll said that homelessness, considered the city's No. 1 problem, has gotten worse during the Mayor's term. A third of the voters said that the city's trouble-plagued public transit system, known as Muni, has deteriorated, while only 23 percent said it had improved. And 43 percent of those polled say that a major problem, the lack of affordable housing, has worsened, while only 14 percent said the condition had improved. The Mayor's administration has also been plagued with accusations of cronyism and corruption in several city agencies.
Until last week, at least, Mr. Brown had the edge among liberals. Both of his leading opponents until then -- Mr. Jordan and Clint Reilly, a political consultant and Mr. Jordan's former campaign manager, who has spent more than $3 million of his own money on his campaign -- are considered more conservative. So the Mayor concentrated his heaviest campaigning in the more traditionally conservative Asian neighborhoods. But the write-in candidacy of Mr. Ammiano, a former teacher who is gay, has thrown the liberal vote into question.
The Ammiano campaign, as it exists, has galvanized disenchanted voters who had planned to sit out the election, his supporters contend.
"Everyone I know was sitting around saying, 'Gosh, who am I going to vote for for mayor?' " said Tim Redmond, executive editor of The Bay Guardian, a liberal weekly newspaper that repeatedly urged Mr. Ammiano to run.
Mr. Redmond estimated that several thousand voters who had planned to stay home or vote for a fringe candidate would write in Mr. Ammiano. "All of this pent-up frustration has been released because all of a sudden people have a place to go with it," he said. "I haven't seen this kind of excitement in a while."
The Brown campaign seems resigned to losing some support.
"There is no doubt that we're disappointed that Tom Ammiano has entered the race and will probably help the more conservative candidates by doing so," said P. J. Johnston, a spokesman for the Mayor's re-election team.
In response to the threat, the Mayor's campaign brought the liberal heavy-hitter the Rev. Jesse Jackson to town on Tuesday. The Mayor and Mr. Jackson made a series of stops in neighborhoods like the Castro, the largely gay district, to remind voters of Mr. Brown's long civil rights credentials. Mr. Jackson's presence certainly attracted attention, though he tried to deflect it to the Mayor.
"Willie Brown is the real thing," Mr. Jackson would say, as passers-by vied to shake his hand.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy Expands Briskly, With Labor Costs Benign
The American economy turned in its best quarterly performance of the year this summer, expanding at a brisk 4.8 percent annual rate. That virtually guaranteed enough momentum to carry the nation to its longest economic expansion in history early next year. 
 Much to Wall Street's delight, inflation was mild, with the cost to employers of wages and benefits up only modestly. Page A1.
 
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, called the economy's recent growth rate unsustainable but said the rise in long-term interest rates appeared to be containing the risks of inflation. Addressing business executives on the pitfalls facing the economy, he gave no clear signal on whether he planned to raise interest rates for a third time this year. C6.
 
Stocks and Bonds Rally Smartly
Investors eagerly bought stocks in response to the benign labor report. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 227.64 points, to 10,622.53, The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 45.73 points, to 1,342.44, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 72.70 points, to 2,875.22. The bond market also rallied, with the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond climbing a full point to a price of 9810/32 . C8.
 
In Los Angeles, a Contrite Publisher
Faced with a rebellion by distraught and angry newsroom staff members, the publisher of The Los Angeles Times, Kathryn M. Downing, said her own "fundamental misunderstanding" of editorial principles led her to sign an agreement sharing the profits of the Oct. 10 issue of The Times's Sunday magazine with the Staples Center, the topic of the issue. C2.
 
Health Insurance Costs Rise
The rising cost of health insurance is hitting small employers particularly hard. Premiums for the smallest companies rose 9.2 percent last year, a new survey found. C8.
 
A.M.A. Creates Internet Company
The American Medical Association and six other medical societies have created an Internet company to publish consumer information on health care and help doctors communicate with patients by E-mail. C2.
 
At I.B.M., Flexible Transistors
I.B.M. researchers will report today that they have developed flexible transistors that can be embedded in thin curved surfaces. C2.
 
CBS Earnings Top Expectations
CBS said it earned a better-than-expected $47 million, or 7 cents a share. It cited strong television, radio and outdoor advertising. C7.
 
Insurer's Profit is Up 17.6 Percent
American International Group said it earned $1.27 billion in the third quarter, a 17.6 percent increase from the 1998 period of 1998. C19.
 
MCI Worldcom Shows Strong Gains
MCI Worldcom said that its third-quarter profit more than tripled as demand for data services surged. The company, which is acquiring Sprint in what will be the largest corporate takeover ever, said net income rose to $1.1 billion, or 55 cents a share, exceeding analysts' forecast of 54 cents. MCI Worldcom shares surged $6.0625, to $83.625. C6.
 
Offer for Air Canada Sweetened
Onex raised its offer for Air Canada by more than half and took steps to insure that a new, merged carrier is Canadian-controlled by removing American Airlines as a partner. C4.
 
Vulture Funds Circling Over Japan
Vulture funds -- which specialize in buying bankrupt and distressed assets -- have been circling Japan for years. Now Rothschild Inc. is moving to take over Nikko Electric. C4.

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Bradley's Gestalt Therapy

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H.

 BODY:
Thanks to this week's presidential debates forums, town halls, whatever you want to call them -- we now know that Bill Bradley's idea of a great leader is Jimmy Carter ("integrity"), Woodrow Wilson ("the ability to see around corners") or Mikhail Gorbachev ("courage"). Who could not find this interesting? Once again, Mr. Bradley demonstrated that he is a new kind of candidate, a man who skips the predictable tributes to Lincoln and F.D.R., and instead names three former heads of state so high-minded their constituents practically ran them out of town on a rail.
How many of you watched the debates on TV? (I don't want to see any hands from people who taped. Sure, you're going to watch them later, right after all six hours of "Middlemarch.") No matter. We'll boil them down for you. We have nothing better to do with our time -- in fact, we can travel right up to New Hampshire and watch them on the spot, in a large hall where people are not permitted to click over to the Weather Channel when Steve Forbes starts explaining his economic agenda. 
 The Democratic debate was actually the only game in town involving more than one serious presidential candidate. Republicans were stuck watching Senator John McCain jockeying with a whole bunch of peculiar people with single-digit poll numbers and a lot of time on their hands.
George W. Bush was forced to skip the event in order to watch his wife receive an award in Texas. Family is very important to Mr. Bush, who was undoubtedly looking forward to arguing foreign policy with Mr. McCain, and hearing more about his experiences as a heroic prisoner of war. But he apparently did not have enough clout to get the ceremony scheduled on another day. This is yet another reminder that Texas has a weak-governor system.
Al Gore has a personality without a thermostat, and when he tries to look animated he practically crashes into the wallboard. On Wednesday he hijacked the auditorium early on, begging for a chance to do a pre-debate Q.-and-A. ("This person has a question! Do we have time for his question?") He tossed in a little Spanish and a long joke, and made endless attempts to create Clintonesque mind-melds with the audience. ("How old is your child, Corey? . . . Are you unionized, Earl?") At the end, he refused to be dragged offstage. ("Can I say one more word? I would like to stay!") He bore an uncomfortable resemblance to the kid who asks the teacher for more homework. Mr. Bradley, lounging on his stool, arms folded across his chest, looked like the high school athlete watching the class nerd volunteer to stay and clap erasers.
"His gestalt is the gestalt of the time," said the Bradley adviser Rick Stengel. "This elbowing back and forth, that's history."
Either due to excess gestalt or lack of a good retort, Mr. Bradley refused to fight back when Mr. Gore attacked his health insurance plan, saying it would cost $1.4 trillion and eat up all the money for the rest of the Democratic agenda. That made the vice president look like the stronger candidate -- overstimulated, yes, but aggressive. If Mr. Bradley keeps refusing to grab the initiative, he is going to undermine the media-wide ban on use of basketball analogies and force somebody to start recalling how, when he was a Knick, he preferred passing the ball to making the critical shot.
But what, by the way, ever happened to Mr. Gore's own budget-busting Big Idea for HIGH-QUALITY PRESCHOOL FOR EVERY CHILD IN THE NATION, which he bellowed at every opportunity back when he was working on the theory that shouting a speech made it more interesting? The campaign contends it's still there, although on Wednesday night it had dwindled away to "we've got to focus on preschools."
Once you weed out 80 percent or so of the Gore-Bradley debate -- the parts where they agree with each other and the parts where each man starts talking about "dreams" -- you get down to some very interesting questions. Do Americans want a Big Idea, if it costs a lot of money? Which one? Is anybody willing to suggest trade-offs -- eliminating the new aircraft carrier we're building in Trent Lott's district? The new fighter planes we're building in Richard Gephardt's district?
There's plenty of time, the World Series is over, and we're actually finally about to enter the 2000 election year. Let the games begin. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Strong Summer Apt to Propel Economic Boom to a Record

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The American economy turned in its best quarterly performance of the year this summer, virtually guaranteeing enough momentum to carry the nation to its longest economic expansion in history early next year.
Strong growth often leads to shortages and rising prices. But as the economy expanded at a brisk 4.8 percent annual rate in the June-September quarter, inflation turned out to be mild and the cost to employers of wages and benefits rose only modestly. The news of robust growth with little evidence of higher inflation was so popular on Wall Street that the value of stocks and bonds soared. The Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 227 points, or 2.2 percent, to 10,622.53. Other indexes chalked up similarly impressive gains. 
 The stock market's sharp rise reflected an expectation that the Federal Reserve's policy makers -- who have raised interest rates twice this year out of concern that the economy might be overheating -- may be less likely to do so yet again at their next meeting, on Nov. 16. And even if the Fed does push rates slightly higher again next month, analysts say, it now appears more likely to refrain from further increases in the succeeding months unless inflation shows signs of clearly worsening.
The Commerce Department, at the same time as it provided its fresh snapshot of the economy, also released a sweeping revision of its past data, stretching back to 1959. The revision is intended to make the Government's measures of economic performance reflect the new electronic technologies that are now so important. The new numbers showed the 1990's to be a decade of stronger economic growth than originally reported, although not stronger than any of the last four decades. Page C1.
What distinguishes the performance of the economy in the 1990's is the length of the expansion, which began in March 1991 and will surpass the 106-month record set in the 1960's if it lasts until next February.
Clinton Administration officials cited the latest growth numbers as evidence of the success of their economic policies. President Clinton called the 1990's expansion "the soundest in decades." And Martin Baily, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, linked the economy to what he described as the Administration's success in shifting the budget from deficit to surplus.
"The private sector is generating the strong growth," Mr. Baily said, "but good economic policies have created an environment for growth."
Caveats, however, punctuated the euphoria. "What we have here is consumption and investment growing faster than income," said Albert Wojnilower, an economic consultant in New York. "How are people doing this? They are borrowing money, counting on the gains in the stock market and in the value of their homes to help them carry their debt."
Separately, the Labor Department released its employment cost index for the third quarter yesterday. This is the Government's broadest measure of labor costs, covering benefits as well as wages, salaries and bonuses. It is closely watched on Wall Street for evidence that rising labor costs will force companies to raise prices, a prospect that often prompts traders to sell stocks and drive up interest rates.
But despite the strong economy and the labor shortages evident in an unemployment rate of only 4.2 percent, the index rose by only eight-tenths of a percent and 3.1 percent over the last 12 months.
The broadest measure of the economy's performance is the gross domestic product, which tracks the rising value of all goods and services produced in the nation. Growth had slowed in the second quarter, to a 1.9 percent annual rate, but bounced back sharply in the third quarter, with the G.D.P. rising by $106 billion to an inflation-adjusted $8.88 trillion.
The largest component of that growth was consumer spending, which rose 4.3 percent from the second quarter. But a big part of the increase in output resulted from businesses deciding to build up their inventories rather than draining them as they did in the second quarter. They carried out this stockpiling in anticipation of future sales, particularly sales of new car models, and also as a precaution in the event of Year 2000 computer-related disruptions, analysts said.
"Much of the inventory expansion came from motor vehicle stockpiling at the dealer level," said Brent Moulton, associate commissioner at the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. "But manufacturers also stockpiled, mostly durable goods -- aircraft, appliances, machinery and equipment."
Stepped-up investment in computers, software, trucks, buses and aircraft also played a big role in the third-quarter jump in economic growth. And an increase in spending at all levels of government contributed to the rising economy. But strong growth in the future seems uncertain to many economists. They expect the economy to start slowing by early next year and point to what they see as the first signs of that slowing.
The housing market has weakened as mortgage rates have risen, they note. Vehicle sales have edged down from their summer peak, and consumer spending, though still strong, has grown more slowly since last fall.
"We have experienced four consecutive months of declines in consumer confidence, and debt is inordinately high," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI. "That has to take its toll."
The puzzles in today's reports were the mild labor cost increases despite widely reported labor shortages and the slower rise in a price index that the Commerce Department uses to calculate economic growth. The index rose at a 1.3 percent annual rate in the second quarter and 1 percent in the third.
"Whatever merchandise is in short supply because of the strong economy is brought in from abroad, and that helps to hold down prices," Mr. Wojnilower said, noting that imports rose in the third quarter.
Business executives insist that they have difficulty raising prices because of growing competition in a global marketplace. What is more, labor costs are not rising rapidly enough to force price increases -- for a variety of reasons, economists say.
One involves inflation. Because it is mild, workers are demanding smaller increases. The widespread availability of temporary workers means that employers are not under pressure to raise wages to fill jobs. Bonuses and profit sharing have increasingly replaced raises. And manufacturing employment has declined by 500,000 jobs since March 1998, with many of the displaced workers taking service sector jobs at lower pay.
Nancy Lazar, an economist and partner at the ISI Group, a Wall Street firm, cites mergers as still another explanation for mild labor cost increases. "The reason workers are not pressing for higher wages," she said, "is that mergers are running high and so are layoffs as companies combine operations. Layoffs keep labor on the defensive."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Helps a Campaign Hoping for Help in Return

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: CHEEKTOWAGA, N.Y., Oct. 28

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani today endorsed the Republican candidate for Erie County executive, Joel Giambra, who if he wins will overturn longtime Democratic control of one of the most powerful jobs in upstate New York. Mr. Giambra would also be of pivotal importance to Mr. Giuliani in his expected campaign for United States Senate next year.
Polls show that Mr. Giambra's 20-point lead over the Democratic incumbent, Dennis Gorski, has narrowed to 10 points in recent days, changing what many thought would be a debacle for Mr. Gorski into something resembling a race. But whether Mr. Giuliani's endorsement mattered was a frequent question here today, including from the Mayor himself. 
 "Actually, endorsements, I don't know how much value they do have," Mr. Giuliani said while standing next to Mr. Giambra at an Italian restaurant, Pranzo's, across the street from the Buffalo Niagara International Airport.
No one at the endorsement lunch, attended by some 70 businessmen and women from Buffalo and the surrounding Erie County, questioned that Mr. Giuliani's agenda stretched far beyond Tuesday's election. "The politics of it are clear," said Sal Martoche, a friend of the Mayor, a Buffalo lawyer and the former United States Attorney for the Western District of New York. "He's friend-raising right now."
When the Mayor was asked if it would be good to have Mr. Giambra as county executive should Mr. Giuliani run for the Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton, he replied that "it will be great to have Mr. Giambra in office as the Mayor of New York City. Whether I run for something else in the future, it'd be terrific."
Although George E. Pataki carried Erie County during his re-election last November, the county is home to the biggest Democratic organization outside of New York City. There is speculation that if Mr. Giambra defeats Mr. Gorski, there will be upheaval in the local party. As county executive, Mr. Giambra would lead the largest government in upstate New York and a political apparatus that could help Mr. Giuliani as he seeks support in an area where voters traditionally view the mayor of New York City as a politician out of touch with their concerns.
Mr. Giuliani called Mr. Giambra's candidacy "a chance for a new direction in Erie County" and praised his proposal for a 30 percent cut in property taxes over the next four years, then compared Mr. Giambra to himself. "I think the emphasis on trying to straighten out county government reminds me of the things that I had to do when I became Mayor of New York City," Mr. Giuliani said, adding that "to see economic revitalization occur in Erie County the way it's occurring in New York City, which he can bring about, will be very, very exciting for all of us."
Mr. Giambra returned the compliment, saying, "I'm learning a lot from the Mayor," and proclaiming "this is not just about politics."
Mr. Giambra, a former Democrat who became a Republican in 1998 to run for county executive, has incurred enormous wrath from his former party. Steve Pigeon, the Erie County Democratic Party chairman, this week called Mr. Giambra "a Benedict Arnold" and "an opportunist" who "walked away for 12 pieces of silver." He also said Mr. Gorski was behind in the polls because "the economy is flat upstate and you have a 12-year incumbent and he's the closest neck to strangle."
Mr. Gorski, in an interview today in his office looking out over Lake Erie and Canada, said he found political endorsements "repulsive" and the "height of arrogance" because "you have somebody from out of town telling people in the community who to vote for, knowing full well he knows very little or nothing about the community in question."
Mr. Gorski also said that the only time he sees Mr. Giuliani upstate "is when he comes up with Republican candidates."
As for his direct opponent, Mr. Gorski said that Mr. Giambra is "not capable" and "I don't think he understands the dimensions of this government."
Mr. Giambra, 42, is the City of Buffalo comptroller, but his two-year community college degree has become a campaign issue. "I admire people who had a greater ability to pursue higher education than I did," he recently told The Buffalo News, adding, "I don't think that made me any less of a person or any less able to be a leader."
On Sunday, The Buffalo News for the first time did not endorse the 55-year-old Mr. Gorski, saying that although he had done an "excellent job" keeping the county's finances in order, he was not an innovative leader. The newspaper instead supported the election of Mr. Giambra, saying that his vision and tax cut proposal "more accurately depicts the kind of leadership that Erie County needs at this time."
Mr. Giuliani also spoke today at a meeting of the Niagara County Mothers Against Drunk Driving, saying, "I respect what you do tremendously" and "I am an ally of yours."

I.M.F. AMENDS BRAZIL ACCORD

BYLINE: By Simon Romero 

 BODY:
Brazil's central bank reached an agreement with the International Monetary Fund allowing the bank to use more foreign reserves to prevent a sharp weakening of the domestic currency, the real.
