HEADLINE: Fed's Chief Calls Cooling Unavoidable

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, called the economy's recent growth rate unsustainable today, but said the rise in long-term interest rates appeared to be containing the risks of inflation.
With less than three weeks to go before the central bank next meets to consider monetary policy, Mr. Greenspan gave no clear signal that he planned to raise interest rates for a third time this year, but expressed enough concern about the pitfalls facing the economy to leave open the possibility. 
 In a speech to business executives in Boca Raton, Fla., Mr. Greenspan said there was a compelling case that huge investments in technology were driving a lasting increase in productivity growth, dampening inflationary pressures even as demand for goods and services grows at a robust pace.
But Mr. Greenspan warned that the growth rate of productivity would inevitably level off, leaving the economy vulnerable to a resurgence in inflation. He repeated his long-standing warning that the economy was running out of workers so fast that continued strong growth could lead to a surge in wages and then in prices. And he suggested that the growing trade deficit might crimp the flow of cheap capital into the United States from abroad.
"We do not have enough experience with technology-driven gains in productivity growth to have a useful sense of the time frame in which market pressures contain demand," Mr. Greenspan said.
"Moreover it is not clear as yet how much cumulative impact the rise in real long-term interest rates over the past two years will have on demand," he said. "Going forward, the Federal Reserve must monitor not only this response, but also the evolving capacity of our economy to meet higher levels of demand."
Much of Mr. Greenspan's speech to the corporate executives was given over to the topic that has preoccupied him for the last several years: the degree to which technology is reshaping the way business operates, making the economy more efficient and allowing higher growth rates with less inflation risk.
Mr. Greenspan said there remained a debate among economists about whether growth in productivity -- or output per worker for every hour worked -- was truly improving over the rather sluggish trend that began around 1970. But he said he was increasingly convinced that the improvement was for real.
"Although it is still possible to argue that the evident increase in productivity growth is ephemeral, I find such arguments hard to believe, and I suspect most in this audience would agree," Mr. Greenspan said.
The problem, Mr. Greenspan said, is that no one knows whether technological advances will continue at their current breathtaking pace, or whether businesses will be able to capitalize on them to offset increased costs. So far so good, Mr. Greenspan said -- there was no sign of trouble in the economic data released by the Government today.
"All the same, the rate of growth of productivity cannot continue to increase indefinitely," Mr. Greenspan said. "At some point it must, at least, plateau. Should, at that point, labor market tightness result in faster growth of nominal wage rates, there would be no offset from accelerating productivity. As a consequence, unit costs would likely rise, pressuring profit margins and prices."
Mr. Greenspan left no doubt that he was particularly concerned about the shrinking pool of available workers. The number of people seeking jobs has declined over the last two years and is heading lower as the economy hums along, he said.
Mr. Greenspan pointed out that under widely accepted economic theory, sustainable noninflationary growth cannot exceed the combined growth in productivity and the labor force. He suggested that the economy was currently in violation of that rule, a situation that cannot go on forever.
"Market pressures must eventually emerge that work to contain such unsustainable growth," Mr. Greenspan said.
Still, reining in the economy, Mr. Greenspan said, "may already be significantly advanced" because of "upward pressure on real long-term market interest rates, especially as economies abroad strengthen."
The problem for the Fed, Mr. Greenspan said, is that it can no longer assume that it knows when the economy is at risk of overheating. The Fed must not only make judgments about when demand is entering a danger zone, he suggested; it must now also gauge whether productivity improvements are increasing the economy's capacity to handle greater demand, and indeed the degree to which improving productivity stimulates demand.

HEADLINE: A Clearer View of the Economy;
TheCommerce Department Answers Its Critics

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With millions of Americans enjoying today's prosperity, some experts have complained that the Government's methods for measuring the economy have failed to capture its true strength and dynamism. Now the Commerce Department has responded with confirmation that the critics have been at least partly right.
But the revised numbers on the economy's performance in recent decades, published yesterday, still fall short of the prosperity achieved in earlier booms since World War II. The "New Economy" that many proclaim remains a vision rather than a reality. 
 True, the economy has grown faster in the 1990's than Federal statistics have acknowledged. Spending is stronger; investment is greater; productivity is higher; inflation is a little lower. It all adds up to an economy that produced an estimated $8.76 trillion worth of goods and services last year, according to the revised statistics, or $248 billion more than under the old method of calculating economic growth.
But the revision stopped short of recording a breakthrough to the promised land of a new economy -- one in which new technology is bringing about a transformation that makes the economy capable of productivity advances and economic growth reminiscent of the golden era of the 1960's.
"Growth is a couple of tenths of a percentage point higher, particularly in recent years, but there is no change in long-term trends," said Steven Landefeld, director of the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, the bookkeeping agency that published the revision of the statistics, reaching all the way back to 1959.
It is not simply that pockets of overlooked production have been belatedly discovered and incorporated into the gross domestic product. There was some of that, but, more important, the Government has provided a clearer view of the economy's performance by giving much more credit than in the past to computer software and banking improvements.
Moreover, downward revisions in the Consumer Price Index -- already present in the unrevised data since 1995 -- have been applied back to 1959, a process that raised the economy's inflation-adjusted "real" growth rate.
Illogical bookkeeping has also been fixed. The personal savings rate, for example, has been raised to 3.7 percent of income in 1998 from nearly zero by listing Federal contributions to the pensions of Government workers as savings rather than payments to social insurance.
"That does not change the trend in savings, which has been steadily downward," Mr. Landefeld said.
The main goal of the revision has been to capture in the numbers what the Federal statisticians say they believe to be the true strengths and characteristics of a modern economy. "The economy is still the same as it was before, but computer software and also banking are playing much larger roles, and with this revision we are measuring their contributions more accurately," said Brent Moulton, an associate commissioner of the bureau.
Economists on Wall Street found the revisions pleasing. "They show us that the economy has been growing somewhat faster than we had thought and inflation is slightly lower, and that revised mix is exactly what you like to see," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist for Prudential Securities.
Nothing jumps out of the bureau's new methods with greater force than computer software, which accounted for nearly two-thirds of all the revisions.
For years experts have held that software and the computers in which software is installed have enhanced the nation's productivity, making the sort of contribution that the spread of the automobile did in the 1920's. But until yesterday, the bureau had not quantified software's rising contribution or raised the growth rate of the economy as a whole to reflect software's importance.
That new recognition is at the crux of the "New Economy" argument. The rapidly advancing electronic and information technologies, so dependent on software, are viewed by this camp of economists and forecasters as transforming the way Americans do business. As a result, they are generating a breakthrough in economic growth that should be sustainable for years.
The bureau's fresh look failed to endorse this rosy perspective. Even in the strongest period of the current expansion -- the last four years through the third quarter of 1999 -- the G.D.P. rose at an average annual rate of 4.1 percent, up four-tenths of a percentage point from the earlier figures. But there were similar spurts of even stronger growth in the 1980's, 1970's and 1960's.
And the comparison is flawed. Most economists gauge an economy by comparing not just expansions but entire business cycles, with each cycle including a recession as well as an expansion. By that measure, the American economy in the 1990's has grown at an annual rate of nearly 3 percent, up half a percentage point after the revision. But nearly 3 percent turns out to be no stronger than the 1970's and 1980's and significantly weaker than the 1960's.
"The 60's were unprecedented, and they still are," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI, a data gathering operation.
There are some differences. While the overall growth rates for the last three decades are similar, the latest data show that more of the economy's growth in the 1990's was generated by improvements in output per person rather than simply by putting more people to work. The reverse was the case in the 1970's and 1980's.
But the revisions do suggest that the long expansion of the 1990's, with its combination of healthy growth and low inflation, could continue for a while.
Until recently, the Federal Reserve and most economists believed that the economy could grow over the long term at no more than 2.5 percent without suffering from shortages and inflation. Now the upper limit appears to be 3 percent or a bit higher, says Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate in economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
That is roughly the rate of growth since 1990. Implicit in this new higher growth rate is an upward adjustment in the productivity growth rate. Productivity measures the value of what a worker produces in goods or services during an hour on the job. When that output rises, partly because of advances in technology, so does the productivity growth rate.
That rate had advanced at a robust annual average of 2.8 percent from 1947 until 1973. And then for reasons never fully understood, the average plunged to 1 percent or so for nearly 25 years. There has been a partial rebound since 1995, and the revisions suggest that the average has lately been roughly 2 percent, or even a bit more. Complete productivity data, however, will not be available until the Labor Department incorporates the higher output in its own calculations.
"The productivity slowdown remains in place, it is just less than it was, as these revisions suggest, for which we should be grateful," said Jeffrey Madrick, an author who has written extensively on productivity.
Mr. Solow agrees. "When productivity grows at 1 percent a year it takes 72 years for the standard of living to double," he said. "At 2 percent, it takes just 36 years. It is possible that we are at that level now, although I will not take that to the bank until the 2 percent survives the next recession."
In the Commerce Department's new approach, software purchased by business, previously listed as an expense, becomes an investment, retroactive to 1959. The difference is considerable. A $100 software purchase counted the old way as an expense was included in the value of the final product sold by the company, like the steel that goes into a car. But that same $100 worth of software, properly counted, should be added directly to G.D.P., the bureau concluded.
Software is now classified like computers -- as a long-lasting investment capable of generating revenue for a company.
And indeed software helps to generate such things as greater revenue from telephone tolls and improved results from an automated, more efficient assembly line. The $100 value, once added to G.D.P., is subtracted or depreciated only gradually, over the three to five years considered by the bureau to be the life of a piece of software.
Banking is the other big change. Its contribution to G.D.P. had been measured indirectly, by computing the number of hours worked by the nation's bank employees and inferring a dollar amount. But as new technology has spread through the banking industry, hours have declined. Banking activity and revenue, however, have risen. So the bureau changed the yardstick. The new one is transactions: the number of checks cleared, the number of ATM transactions, the number of loans made.
The conceptual changes also coincided with various revisions that pop up every few years when more complete data on such things as wages, retail sales, consumption, profits and investment become available as a supplement to the surveys used to determine the quarterly growth numbers.
"What we are seeing here, apart from conceptual changes," said Martin Baily, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, "is a stronger economy than we had thought because of improved data collection."

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Says King Family Is Ready to Sell Papers to U.S.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28

 BODY:
The family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has indicated a willingness to sell 80,000 pages of the slain civil rights leader's papers to the Library of Congress for $10 million below their appraised value, the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus has said.
The chairman, Representative James E. Clyburn, Democrat of South Carolina, said he had discussed the purchase of the papers from the final six years of Dr. King's life with his widow, Coretta Scott King, and his sons, Dexter King and Martin Luther King 3d. And he has introduced legislation authorizing the purchase. 
 "All three seem willing to pursue that course," Mr. Clyburn said. "We are still in negotiation but I feel relatively sure that if we can get the authorization done, we can move forward and get a number we can ask Congress for."
Mr. Clyburn said Sotheby's auction house in New York last week appraised the 80,000 pages of King documents at $30 million. He said lawmakers had asked officials from the Library of Congress to inspect the papers this week and tell Congress that they are worth $30 million.
The Washington Post reported in Friday's editions that the Library of Congress had tentatively agreed with the King family to a sale price of $20 million.
Officials at the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change, in Atlanta, where the documents are housed, did not return telephone calls seeking comment on the negotiations. The talks were first reported this week by Roll Call, a newspaper that covers Congress.
Mr. Clyburn said Republican and Democratic leaders in the House were supportive of the idea. He said he was hopeful that both the authorizing legislation and the actual appropriation to buy the papers could be approved by Congress before it adjourned for the year in the next few weeks.
If the deal envisioned by Mr. Clyburn is completed, it would be the most Congress has ever paid for a manuscript collection for the Library of Congress.
Jill Brett, a spokeswoman for the library, said the largest previous outlay by Congress was $1.5 million in the early 1930's for the Vollbehr Collection of about 3,000 books from the 15th century, including one of three perfect copies of the Gutenberg Bible. Adjusted for inflation, that would amount to $14.6 million today.
Most of the documents in the library's manuscripts collection have been donated, Ms. Brett said, including the papers of 23 Presidents and 38 Supreme Court Justices.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Five Republican Candidates' Debate at Dartmouth

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a Republican Presidential candidates' forum last night involving Gary L. Bauer, former president of the Family Research Council; the publisher Steve Forbes; Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah; Alan Keyes, a radio commentator and former Assistant Secretary of State, and Senator John McCain of Arizona, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency. The candidates answered questions from an audience at Dartmouth College, in Hanover, N.H.
 
Q. Should the Republican Party be more inclusive by encouraging pro-choice voters to support their candidates? 

MR. McCAIN -- I worry a great deal about the unintended consequences of sending a message that we are not an inclusionary party.
I am a proud pro-life person. I have a 17-year record on that issue. But I believe that we must begin a dialogue and a discussion on the issue of abortion. Both pro-life and pro-choice people believe very strongly that we need to eliminate abortion. . . .
I and my wife, Cindy, are proud adoptive parents. We need to encourage adoption in America. We need to match up those children that have no families with those families that have no children. We need to improve foster care dramatically in America. We can work together. And my party, which is proud of its pro-life position, and I am proud of it, should send the word: We want you in our party. We can have respectful disagreements on specific issues, and we can work together on this one.
 
Q. There's growing concern that the control of health care is shifting from physicians to the bureaucrats of insurance companies and H.M.O.'s. Yet . . . physicians still bear the burden of liability for the care they are allowed to provide. . . . How would you propose to rectify this imbalance between the control of and responsibility for providing health care?
 
MR. BAUER -- I was very troubled when the leadership of my party in the Congress got themselves into the box of taking the position that average Americans shouldn't have the right to sue an H.M.O. if it provided inappropriate medical treatment. Now, I'm against big bureaucracy in Washington making health care decisions. I just have an aversion to bureaucrats. But it's not just Government bureaucrats. I don't like H.M.O. bureaucrats and insurance company bureaucrats either. And I think we need to level the playing field.
We need to make real reforms: medical savings accounts, allowing deductibility for insurance payments. Big companies can do that now; individuals can't. There are many things that we can do, and we need to do them now before we have a system where bureaucracy is making all of the decisions in health care; accountants making decisions instead of doctors.
 
Q. How do you plan to continue with the war on drugs?
 
MR. KEYES -- Well, it seems to me the first thing that we should understand is that we're not dealing with a material problem, we're dealing with a moral problem. When I was born in 1950, we didn't have a huge plethora of laws dealing with all kinds of drug use and abuse, and yet we also did not have an enormous drug problem in this country. The reason that we proliferated the laws is because the fundamental discipline that was prevailing in our society when I was born has broken down.
And I think sometimes we get all caught up in discussing what steps we will take to deal with the consequences of this problem; we don't want to deal with the problem. And the problem is very simple: You can't sustain self-government without self-discipline, and the drug problem is a symptom of that. . . .
And I think that the obvious solution is the one that stares us in the face, but we don't want to implement it because it requires that we look at the truth about our situation. We don't have a drug problem, an economic problem or any of these other problems, only that we say we have. We have a moral crisis. We have a crisis that goes to the heart of the question of whether or not we're a people that still acknowledges that there is a difference between right and wrong which we must pass on to our children and enforce, even if it means that we ourselves must accept inconvenience.
 
Q. What is the best policy, and I'm talking about domestic policy, you feel America is embarked on now, and why? And . . . what is the worst policy in your opinion, and why? And what would you do to put us back on track?
 
MR. HATCH -- I would say the best policy that I've seen . . . I came up here and campaigned for Ronald Reagan in 1980. . . . Reagan brought about a revolution that was really an important one, because he reduced marginal tax rates from 70 percent down to 28 percent by 1986. That's what's been driving this economy ever since. This President's taking credit for it, but literally that's what's doing it. Plus the fight for the balanced budget amendment, which I led for six or seven times since then.
Plus the appointment of Alan Greenspan, who has done a terrific job. I'll give this President some credit, too.
But plus, the first time in 30 years you had a Republican Congress has enforced a balanced budget on the American people. And let me just say this, The President deserves some credit, too, because he appointed Robert Rubin, who I think did a tremendous job. And he's been more pragmatic than other Democrats, so we can at least manipulate him into doing what's right occasionally. At least that's what we're trying to do. . . .
I think that The worst thing that I've seen in public policy in many years -- it's hard to say, because there have been a lot of worst things -- but one of the worst things I've seen is the way some of our Federal judges have become activists on the bench. They have usurped the powers of the other two branches of Government and have started to become superlegislators. on the bench in black robes. And they have violated the real role of judging, which is to interpret the laws, not make the laws.
 
Q. What we're watching is sort of a nomination process that reminds me more of an auction, where the nomination goes to the highest bidder. I'd really like to be able to ask this to the candidate who's not here, but I can't do that. Mr. Forbes, as nominee of the Republican Party or as President, what would you do to keep the future nominations from being bought?
 
MR. FORBES -- I share the frustration that Governor Bush is not here tonight. He didn't come to a debate last week because he had a fund-raiser. A couple of weeks ago, his plane got delayed, he had a choice between a fund-raiser and going to a school in Rhode Island with underprivileged kids. He chose the fund-raiser. So perhaps in the future at a forum like this, if we call it a fund-raiser, he might show up. . . .
I believe that in -- on the funding side, we should have a system in America where individuals can give as much as they want to a candidate as long as there is full and prompt disclosure.
The establishment loves these current rules because, unless you are blessed like me with independent resources, they have ways of shutting you out. And all 67,000 lobbyists in Washington, they have all rallied around Governor Bush. They want a coronation, not a real contest. And that's fundamentally wrong.
 The full text is available from The New York Times on the Web: http://www.nytimes.com/ 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Ads to Help Consumers

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Television commercials about a program for Connecticut consumers to choose their electricity suppliers are to begin next week.
Donald Downes, chairman of the Department of Public Utility Control, said competition among suppliers is expected to cut rates 10 percent to 15 percent beyond savings mandated by the state for the next four years. 
 The ads are part of a $4 million public information campaign.
Utility regulators acknowledge that the change, which takes effect next year, will be confusing for people who are used to their local utility monopoly -- and not used to thinking about where their electricity comes from.
A consumer's guide to electric choice is scheduled to be mailed to all homes and businesses in Connecticut.
Beginning Jan. 1 residents and businesses of 24 cities and towns most in need of economic development will be allowed to choose their electricity suppliers. The program goes statewide July 1.
More information is available by calling the state public utility department at (888) 922-DPUC (3782) and on a Web site, www.dpuc-electric-choice.com.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Some Haunted Houses Never Change

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
If the ever vigilant Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is truly determined to snuff out inflation aborning, then he can do no better than to take sharpened pencil in hand, make his way to the nearest theater showing 'House on Haunted Hill" and strike fearlessly until the film's feeble pulse beats no more.
"House on Haunted Hill" is a sorry reincarnation of the 1950's William Castle horror film in which an eccentric millionaire played by Vincent Price offered five strangers $10,000 each to spend the night in a spooky old mansion. 
 In the new version, the ante has been raised to $1 million apiece, which is why Mr. Greenspan may choose to become involved. Even allowing for inflation of roughly 570 percent in the 40 years since the original opened in New York on March 12, 1959, the reward for foolhardy courage in 1999 should come to only $57,113.47, the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis calculated yesterday.
But some things have not become devalued over the years -- words like junk, for example. "House on Haunted Hill" was pronounced junk in these pages in 1959. And it is still junk.
All the special effects in the world cannot compensate for an inability to generate tension, establish and sustain pace or create any character whose survival is worth rooting for.
Directed by William Malone from a screenplay by Dick Beebe and bearing such well-established names as Robert Zemeckis and Joel Silver among its producers, "House on Haunted Hill" is dead on arrival. This film wastes the talents of actors like Geoffrey Rush and Peter Gallagher in hollow roles and relies heavily on its sets and special effects to do the work that should have been accomplished by its director and writer.
The new version harks back to 1931, when the towering cliffside, seaside premises, helpfully described in the film's publicity as having been designed "in the monolithic style of Albert Speer, the infamous architect of the Third Reich," were home to the Vanacutt Psychiatric Institute for the Criminally Insane.
But one night, when the evil Dr. Vanacutt was performing surgery without benefit of anesthesia, the inmates got loose, fire raged out of control and death ran rampant.
Cut to the present, when the wealthy, nasty, mischievous theme-park magnate Steven Price, played behind a mustache by Mr. Rush in a role tailor-made for James Woods at his malevolent best, arranges to hold the birthday party for his not-very-beloved wife (Famke Janssen) in the old place.
But the guests, invited to compete for a total of $5 million if they survive till daybreak, turn out to be a surprise, all somehow related to the old institute or to each other. It seems that the premises are not at rest.
Mr. and Mrs. Price and their guests are in for a long night. But the real ordeal is reserved for the audience.
"House on Haunted Hill" is rated R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes copious amounts of blood, dismemberment, body parts, shootings, stabbings, nudity and language unsuited for the better birthday parties.
 
HOUSE ON HAUNTED HILL
Directed by William Malone; written by Dick Beebe, based on a story by Robb White; director of photography, Rick Bota; edited by Anthony Adler; music by Don Davis; production designer, David F. Klassen; produced by Robert Zemeckis, Joel Silver and Gilbert Adler; released by Warner Brothers. Running time: 96 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. AppealsTrade Ruling on Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The United States filed an appeal today against a World Trade Organization ruling that invalidated $2.5 billion in tax breaks to American companies with overseas subsidiaries.
The Foreign Sales Corporation provisions of the United States tax code, which give income tax relief to corporations that export through offshore subsidiaries, were challenged by the European Union as illegal subsidies to American companies. 
 Trade officials of the 15-nation European Union were jubilant over the victory, partly because of reverses they suffered when the United States successfully challenged Europe's banana import limits and its ban on hormone-fed beef, which have led to punitive tariffs on $300 million of European products.
The stakes are much higher in the tax case both because of the amount of money involved and because, if upheld, the ruling, which was made on Oct. 8, opens up a new area of conflict -- a country's control over its domestic tax laws.
The tax provisions at issue benefit major corporations like Boeing, Microsoft and General Motors.
In filing an appeal, the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said in a statement that the trade panel "committed multiple legal errors on both substantive and procedural issues."
Current United States law allows domestic companies to establish corporations in offshore tax havens, allowing manufacturers to get the tax exemption on products that generally are made in the United States. There are 3,600 such companies in the United States Virgin Islands.
The European Union argued that this law violates trade rules that goods sold for export may not be treated differently from those sold on the domestic market. Such distinctions are considered export subsidies, which are illegal under World Trade Organization rules.
In a 294-page ruling, the trade panel agreed. Such subsidies "are prohibited," concluded the panel, made up of Crawford Falconer of New Zealand, Didier Chambovey of Switzerland and Prof. Seung Wha Chang of South Korea.
The trade body's appellate review will take up to 90 days, delaying enforcement of the ruling until at least the end of January.
Under the ruling, the trade panel had given the United States until Oct. 1, 2000, to change its law, concluding that was adequate time for Congress to act. It agreed with American arguments that global trade agreements were not meant to dictate member-country tax systems but said that "certain W.T.O. rules do have implications for specific tax practices of members."
This is the second time such United States tax provisions have been challenged in the global trading system. Similar provisions were found to be an illegal subsidy under the trade organization's predecessor body, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, in 1981. They were replaced by the Foreign Sales Corporation rules in the early 1980's to comply with the objections.
The European Union argued that the economic effects of the new provisions remained the same.
Ms. Barshefsky maintained that existing tax breaks do not give United States companies an unfair advantage. "A careful review of the history of this issue, the fact of record and the applicable W.T.O. legal rules concerning income tax measures should result in a reversal of the panel's decision," she said.
To qualify for tax relief under the provisions, an American company must meet a number of criteria, including a minimum level of direct costs abroad for certain sales activities, including advertising and order processing.

HEADLINE: Charter Reform, on the Merits

BYLINE: By Rudolph W. Giuliani; Rudolph W. Giuliani is Mayor of New York City.

 BODY:
Next Tuesday, New Yorkers have a chance to make permanent many of the remarkable successes our city has enjoyed over the past six years. Fourteen proposed changes to the City Charter will be on the ballot, all designed to insure that New York City never returns to the days of high crime, high taxes and cyclical fears of bankruptcy.
Of course, not everyone agrees with these proposals. Charter revision is always a controversial process, and this year has been no different. What is different this year, however, is that the criticism hasn't been focused on the true issue: the changes that the commission I appointed has recommended. 
 Rather than discussing the proposed changes on their merits, critics first attacked the commission's timing. They complained that it had conducted its work too quickly, over the course of a single summer -- surely a candidate for the "only in New York" file. Since when is completing a job well in a timely manner a bad thing? After all, the United States Constitution was drafted in a matter of weeks. Surely, we could improve our City Charter within such a time frame -- and we did.
Critics reserved their loudest wails, however, to protest a change the commission didn't even recommend: implementing a special election to fill mayoral vacancies before the 2001 election. In short, these critics prejudged the Charter revision process and were proved wrong.
Now the critics have resorted to an even weaker argument: that while the commission's proposals are good ones, it would be better to adopt them through legislation. Funny that some of the people making this argument are members of the City Council, a body which has had ample opportunity to adopt many of these measures but either failed to do so or acted only after the Charter Commission issued its report.
More than a year ago, I submitted to the City Council a tough gun-safety bill that would require trigger locks on all guns purchased in New York City and impose tough criminal sanctions on violators. Although this bill would save lives, especially children's lives, the Council sat on it -- until the Council members realized that it would be on the ballot as part of Charter revision. Only this month, the Council adopted such a bill, but without the stiff penalties provided for in the Charter proposal.
Similarly, the Council has refused to make the Administration for Children's Services -- which in its four years has vastly improved child welfare and facilitated more than 11,000 adoptions -- a permanent city agency. The Charter proposals would do that.
And certain members of the Council have threatened to weaken the city's ability to fight organized crime, despite successes at the Fulton Fish Market and in the private carting industry that have saved New Yorkers $750 million a year by eliminating the "mob tax." That's why the Charter Commission proposed an Organized Crime Commission as a permanent fixture of city government. But putting this proposal on the ballot hasn't motivated the Council to act.
This record points to the purpose of the Charter revision process: to give citizens a vote on reforms that elected legislators have not put in place.
Critics further claim that the commission's budget proposals -- to limit city spending increases, to require a two-thirds vote to raise taxes and to create an emergency fund out of city surpluses -- would hamstring future administrations and somehow force them to raise property taxes (which, for legal reasons, would not be subject to supermajority vote).
Not true. First, the property tax is the one tax that politicians are least likely to raise, because it directly affects so many of their constituents. Second, if these budget reforms become permanent, we should not need to raise any taxes, because we would be spending less and holding surpluses in reserve for emergencies.
Indeed, over the past six years we have lived by these fundamental principles of fiscal restraint, and there have been no tax hikes whatsoever.
We've also ended the cycle of free spending, bankruptcy, bailout and more free spending that plunged the city into one fiscal crisis after another.
The result is a healthy economy, 325,000 new jobs, and an improved bond rating. A yes vote on Charter revision will make many of those changes permanent by imposing some much-needed fiscal discipline on city government.
We've come a long way as a city since the early 1990's. Let's make sure we never go back. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cracks in Canada's Glass Ceiling;
Women Get Some Top Posts, but Few Boardroom Keys

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 28

 BODY:
In the early 1990's, Barbara G. Stymiest, a partner at the accounting firm Ernst & Young here, was irritated to discover that her Toronto golf club reserved Saturday morning tee times for men, on the assumption that wives could play all week long.
But that golf rule has long ago been changed, and Ms. Stymiest has just become president of the Toronto Stock Exchange. 
 In the last decade, as social and economic changes have swept the country, women have suddenly begun appearing at the pinnacles of corporate Canada.
By some measures, they have been more successful than their American counterparts. Women now run two of the three largest companies on Canada's Financial Post 500 list: General Motors of Canada and the Ford Motor Company of Canada. Over all, women now run 10 of the largest companies in Canada. By comparison, just three of the companies on the Fortune 500 list -- and none of the top three -- are run by women.
And as Canadian women have moved from minority to majority status on college campuses, the trend seems likely to continue.
Despite these gains, waves of businesswomen are still bumping against certain Canadian glass ceilings as thick as the ice on a hockey rink. Disillusioned in part with a stodgy corporate culture here, the number of Canadian women entrepreneurs tripled over the last two decades, to 777,000 in 1997. And, with only 6 percent of boardroom seats occupied by women, Canada lags behind the 11 percent rate in the United States.
Then there is the big fish/little pond phenomenon. The Canadian economy is about one-twelfth that of the United States. And some people say that Canada's "branch plant economy" is responsible for the relatively high number of women running major companies here. Of the 13 largest Canadian companies with women as chief executives, 9 are subsidiaries of United States companies.
"Canada is seen as a good training ground that is relatively safe," said Ronald J. Burke, a professor at the York University School of Business here. "The norms in our country are modestly supportive of women. Our culture is not that different from American culture, so it is not a risky transition."
Many Americans working in Canada are startled by the prominence of women in business in a country sometimes equated with social conservatism.
"I have had more dealings with women at very senior levels, including president and C.E.O., here in Canada than I had when I was working in the United States," said Bobbie A. Gaunt, a Pennsylvania native who 18 months ago left her post as general marketing manager for Ford in Detroit to become president and chief executive of Ford Canada. "I never felt my gender surprised anybody."
The president of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce is Nancy Hughes Anthony. The Quebec Securities Commission has a chairwoman, Carmen Crepin. Margaret J. Barrett is president of the Bank of Montreal Mortgage Corporation, a company with a $33 billion portfolio, or 10 percent of the Canadian market.
If the college pipeline is any indicator, Canadian women will continue to advance in business in the 21st century.
Women, who earned 38 percent of all Canadian college degrees in 1972, earned 58 percent in 1997. A similar transformation -- with women now accounting for the majority of college students -- has taken place in much of the industrialized world, including the United States.
In the area of "business, management and commerce," Statistics Canada, a Government agency, reports that 51 percent of full-time and part-time undergraduate students in the 1996-97 school year, the most recent data available, were women. (The relative enrollment of American women in comparable programs was slightly lower.)
But Canadian women lag behind men in some fields that promise high earnings in the economy of the future. Women account for only one-quarter of Canada's computer programmers and computer science students. But by 1997-98 women made up 38 percent of all those pursuing Masters of Business degrees in Canada. By contrast, the American figure was 29 percent.
As the pressure of women in the pipeline builds at companies in Canada, many women have been bailing out and becoming entrepreneurs.
Annette Verschuren, for example, a native of Canada's hardscrabble Cape Breton region, left a Canadian company, Imasco Ltd., when she felt that she was not going to reach the top. She persuaded an American arts and crafts retailer, Michael's, to enter the Canadian market. After running the Canadian operations of Michael's for three years she was hired away to become president of a subsidiary of an American chain, Home Depot Canada, now with 44 stores.
Carol M. Stephenson left her job as chief executive of BCE Media, a satellite communications unit of Bell Canada's parent, last summer to became president and chief of Lucent Technologies Canada Inc., a subsidiary of a United States company. "The old boys' network," she said, "is alive and well -- it has not disappeared. The new phenomenon is that women are doing more networking. Most of us who are leading companies in Canada know each other, we talk with one another."
In the spring, the Women's Executive Network, a group that promotes contacts among women across Canada, surveyed 350 senior level women in Canada's five largest cities: Toronto; Montreal; Ottawa; Vancouver, British Columbia, and Calgary, Alberta. Just over half of the respondents said that men had better networking opportunities, but 74 percent said they had not taken up activities like golf to make more contacts. The reason in part was a lack of time: 6 in 10 said they earned more money than their husbands, but, on average, estimated that they did 53 percent of the housework.
Much of the networking happens spontaneously.
"The moment I arrived in Canada, Maureen Kempston Darkes hosted a party to welcome me to Canada," Ms. Gaunt, the Ford president, said of the local General Motors president. "It struck me as unusual in two ways: we are major competitors, and the 35 to 40 women there were university presidents, C.E.O.'s of companies, judges, senior partners in law firms, accounting firms."
Canada, a country sometimes called America Lite, is seen as a safe place for a corporate career climber to punch an overseas ticket. Americans head four of the nine largest American subsidiaries in Canada that are run by women.
American women executives here bridled when asked whether Canada was a softer assignment than elsewhere in the world.
"I asked to come to Canada," Ms. Gaunt said, noting that the Ford operation here, which employs 17,000 people, is the auto maker's third-largest foreign subsidiary, after those in Britain and Germany. The significance of her post is reflected back at world headquarters: after a year of running the Canadian operations, Ms. Gaunt also became a Ford corporate vice president.
Country-hopping can eventually result in a top job in the big pond. Cynthia M. Trudell, for example, a Canadian chemist for G.M., worked her way from Ontario to Michigan to England before landing in Tennessee this year to become president of Saturn, the first woman to run a major American auto division.
Some executives say that working in Canada requires -- and offers -- significant versatility.
"In the U.S., the scale is so much bigger, I would get stuck at the top of the sales silo or the marketing silo," said Sheelagh D. Whittaker, chief executive of EDS Systemhouse, the Canadian subsidiary of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation. "Here, I deal with treasury issues, human resources issues, policy issues."
The difference in scale is also one reason women have made slower advances into corporate boardrooms than in the United States, according to two surveys by Catalyst.
"Bigger boards tend to have more women on them," said Professor Burke of York University, who worked on the survey. "Canadian companies are small and have smaller boards."
In Canada, only 36 of the 500 largest companies had women on their boards; in the United States, 86 percent did.
"Canada also still has more of its major companies in traditional areas -- mining, oil and gas, wood products," he added. "They tend to be more male dominated, old boys' dinosaurs not used to capable women."
Most respondents in the Women's Network survey of executive women said that various forms of discrimination prevent women from winning fuller representation on boards.
"In Canada, there have been a lot of appointments of female C.E.O.'s as the heads of very large corporations," Micheline Bouchard, president of Motorola Canada Ltd., said. "I don't know if we have reached a critical point where we are no longer an oddity."
Reflecting the new trend, The National Post, a national newspaper, recently published a six-page advertising supplement sponsored by Canadian companies eager to showcase the women executives in their ranks. The theme was: "Performance, not gender, counts."
But old habits and stereotypes die hard. Ms. Whittaker, the E.D.S. president, sometimes finds it convenient to screen her calls by pretending to be her secretary. If the caller is someone she wants to talk to, she puts the person on hold, waits a moment, then picks up with her "executive" voice.

HEADLINE: Impasse in Senate Delays Action On Africa-Caribbean Trade Bills

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
The Senate today temporarily set aside a package of trade bills for African and Caribbean nations while Republican and Democratic leaders tried to break a partisan impasse over several unrelated amendments.
The bills would reduce or eliminate duties on a wide range of goods made in sub-Saharan Africa, Central America and the Caribbean, mostly those assembled with American-produced fabrics. President Clinton and a large majority of legislators support the measures. 
 But Senate Republicans who back the legislation fell 15 votes short of the 60 needed to cut off a filibuster led by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who fears that African imports would hurt his state's textile industry.
The vote could doom the measure for the year, just a day after Mr. Clinton stood beside Nigeria's President at a White House news conference and renewed his call for its passage.
The measure's supporters, who include a wide array of religious, international and business groups, expressed alarm that political wrangling jeopardized trade bills that could give a badly needed lift to lagging economies in Africa and the Caribbean region.
All 40 Democrats present today, most of whom endorse the trade bills, voted against ending the filibuster. They were protesting a parliamentary move by the Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, to bar amendments, like raising the minimum wage, that Democrats want to attach to the package.
After the vote, Mr. Lott sidetracked the trade package until next week while he and the Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, negotiate a compromise to allow the contested amendments to be considered elsewhere -- on a bill that seeks to change the nation's bankruptcy laws. This would leave the trade package relatively unfettered.
Mr. Lott said compromise must be reached by Tuesday, when the Senate is to vote again on whether to end the filibuster, a process called cloture. If the divisive amendments are not attached to another bill by then, he said, the trade package will be sacrificed.
"If we don't get cloture on Tuesday then it's dead," Mr. Lott said of the legislation. "We just don't have the time to grind down the Hollings filibuster."
Mr. Lott warned that if the Democrats did not change their votes, he would blame them for killing the trade bills. "They've got to live with that anti-free-trade, isolationist vote," Mr. Lott told reporters.
Mr. Clinton, his top national security aides and Senate Democrats have accused Republicans of isolationism in light of the Senate's rejection two weeks ago of a treaty to ban underground nuclear testing. Republicans today seemed only too happy to throw the charge back at the Democrats on the trade issue.
Members of the House, which approved a version of the Africa trade bill, 234 to 163, in July, urged the senators to strike a deal. "This bill is too important to let partisan politics stand in the way," said Representative Ed Royce, a California Republican, who is a sponsor of the House bill.
But Democrats say Mr. Lott's maneuvering has denied them a fundamental senatorial privilege, the right to offer amendments.
On Thursday, Mr. Daschle angrily criticized Mr. Lott's tactics and vowed to the hold the trade bill hostage: "We will never let this legislation pass if we can't offer an amendment, not because we don't support it -- I strongly support it -- but because I even more strongly support the right of every single Senator to be partners in the legislative process."

HEADLINE: Scaring the Salaryman Isn't the Japanese Way

BYLINE: By Andrew Gordon; Andrew Gordon is director of the Edwin O. Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies at Harvard University.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Mitsubishi Motors just announced plans to cut 10,000 jobs. Last week Nissan, now owned by Renault and answering to its tough-minded foreign boss, pledged to slash 16,500.
Similar reports from Tokyo for the past year have been greeted by American and British economists as signals that at last the famous Japanese practice of permanent employment is vanishing -- a profound, traumatic transformation that they insist Japan needs. 
 But there is less to the trend than meets the eye. Reading past the headlines, one discovers that Mitsubishi's cuts will not take full effect until March 2004. Even Nissan's new chief operating officer, Carlos Ghosn, known to the world as "The Cost Killer," will spread out the downsizing over three years. And Japan's companies are making many of their adjustments through attrition, hiring freezes, voluntary retirement buyouts and reassignment of employees to subsidiaries. What is striking about what is happening now is not that it represents a change in the way companies deal with workers, but that it shows remarkable continuity in nearly desperate economic times.
For decades, American analysts have been predicting that a change in the Japanese ways of doing business was imminent. In good times, like the 60's or 80's, labor shortages and affluence were expected to lead employees to reject the status quo and start job hopping. In bad times, like the 70's or 90's, the pressure of the bottom line was expected to lead bosses "finally" to a proper market-based system of employment.
The analysts who make these predictions do not understand the deep historical roots of Japan's employment practices, roots sunk in its legal system, the structure of schools, its systems of job recruiting and skill development, its decades-old cooperative relations between companies and unions, and the implicit expectations we call culture.
On the very day of the Nissan announcement, a back-page story in Japanese newspapers showed how firm the grip of these roots can be. The game maker Sega had fired a 35-year-old man for "lack of ability." He protested with a lawsuit, and the courts ruled in his favor. They called the termination an "abuse of the right to fire," decided the company had made "insufficient effort to train the employee" and ordered Sega to pay back wages.
Japan does, of course, need economic reform. But the country's current crisis is rooted in a paralyzed financial system and stagnant consumer demand, especially at home. It is not a crisis of unproductive or lazy systems of industrial production.
The financial system needs a thorough housecleaning, not only more transparent and effective regulation, but also internal reforms to insure that banks make more serious risk assessments when they start lending aggressively again. The country also needs public works spending and tax cuts to get commerce moving faster.
But it is probably a good thing that the Japanese system resists the sort of change that would please the economic seers who thrill to misleading reports about huge employee cutbacks. A working person's prescription for change would first note that the cuts that have taken place, timid as they are by American standards, have shaken the confidence of consumers. Job security and stable wages, and public policies to insure them, could reduce fears and make people feel more comfortable about buying, increasing domestic demand and promoting recovery.
It is worth remembering that for several decades, with the familiar employment system in place, the productivity of Japanese industrial organizations and their ability to cope with shocks -- like the oil crises or the tripling of the value of the yen against the dollar -- was the envy of the world.

HEADLINE: Armenia's Tragedy

 BODY:
The terrorists who assassinated several of Armenia's top political leaders on Wednesday do not appear to have been motivated solely by the government's controversial willingness to talk peace with its neighbor Azerbaijan over the disputed province of Nagorno-Karabakh. A statement broadcast as a prelude to their surrender cited a hodgepodge of grievances against Prime Minister Vazgen Sarkisian, one of their victims, including a loss of national pride, corruption and economic decline. The Nagorno-Karabakh war, however, is a factor. The assassinations will set back the peace talks. It is this war, moreover, that has kept Armenia in misery, degrading the economy and fueling corruption.
Nagorno-Karabakh is an Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan. The war broke out in 1988, when Nagorno-Karabakh sought greater autonomy. Then in 1991 it bid for independence. Armenian soldiers helped carve out a corridor linking the region to Armenia, and took control of nearby Azeri villages. Fighting killed at least 30,000 people and displaced a million before a 1994 cease-fire. But the dispute continues to cripple both countries' economies. Both spend disproportionately on the military. A blockade of tiny Armenia by Azerbaijan and Turkey has idled half the nation's industry. Azerbaijan wants to develop its oil reserves, but foreign companies are reluctant to invest or build vulnerable pipelines in an unstable region. Also, under a 1992 American law passed largely at the urging of the Armenian-American community, American companies cannot get loans for drilling or construction in Azerbaijan while the blockade continues. 
 Last year when Armenia's president, Levon Ter-Petrosian, appeared ready to make peace with Azerbaijan, Mr. Sarkisian and other hard-liners overthrew him to prevent any compromise. But as Prime Minister, Mr. Sarkisian realized that peace was the key to many of Armenia's problems, and began talks with Azeri leaders. Many Armenian nationalists accused him of selling out.
The issue continues to burn because of 1915. That year, hundreds of thousands of Armenians were killed or starved to death by Ottoman Turks. The massacre reshaped the culture as dramatically as did 70 years of Soviet Communism. To Armenian nationalists, negotiating with Azeris, who are ethnic Turks, is a sign of weakness. As long as the nationalists can use violence to veto any possible end to the war, they are dooming future generations to suffer.

HEADLINE: Senator Leads Move to Block Ruling on Strip Mines

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Led by Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Congressional delegation is planning 11th-hour legislation to block what environmentalists call a landmark Federal court ruling that severely restricts the state's strip mining of mountaintops.
After a White House meeting on Thursday on the ruling, which state officials warn will ruin the coal industry, participants from environmental groups said the Clinton Administration decided not to oppose the West Virginia delegation's effort to reverse the court decision. 
 "The White House staff told us President Clinton will not oppose this because it was a provision favored by Senator Byrd," said Anna Aurilio, staff scientist with the United States Public Interest Research Group, a civic advocacy organization.
Ms. Aurilio complained that this would violate the Administration's pledges to block anti-environmental legislative riders in the final days of the Congressional session.
White House officials denied that the pledge would be broken. An environmental official from the Administration said that any legislative action should be short-term and that the White House favored studying whether additional environmental controls were warranted for the problem.
The Oct. 20 ruling by Chief Judge Charles H. Haden 2d of Federal District Court in Charleston found that clean water and surface mining laws were being violated in the blocking of hundreds of miles of streams by rock waste dumped into nearby valleys during the strip mining of mountaintops. The technique involves shearing the mountaintops with explosives to get at the underlying low-sulfur coal, with mining wastes bulldozed into surrounding valleys.
This evening, as pressure grew here and in the state over the ruling on "mountaintop removal," as the technique is legally known, Judge Haden issued a temporary stay affirming his basic decision but allowing the state time to appeal. Lawyers familiar with the struggle speculated that the judge issued the unusual stay to head off Congressional actions that might weaken the environmental laws.
"If there is any life form that cannot acclimate to life deep in a rubble pile, it is eliminated," Judge Haden ruled in ordering West Virginia authorities to curb much of the waste dumping to protect vital waterways. "No effect on related environmental values is more adverse than obliteration."
Responding to the suit by the West Virginia Highlands Conservancy and individual citizens, the judge found that state regulators had loosely interpreted environmental law to allow the waste dumping in established streams that flow much or all of the year and are supposed to be protected by buffer zones. Federal regulations, he ruled, are clear in restricting dumping to areas of smaller streams that flow only temporarily after rainstorms and snow melts.
The decision has been denounced as devastating by Gov. Cecil H. Underwood, a Republican, who ordered a hiring freeze and 10 percent budget cut to prepare for negative effects on the state economy. But one of the successful litigants, Patricia Bragg, a valley dweller near a mountaintop mine in Pie, W. Va., said the state, after years of failing to enforce the law, was trying a "political ploy" to divide miners and other residents in the coal region.
"The mountaintop mining has gotten closer and closer to our communities in the hollows," Ms. Bragg said, describing a chain of problems, from cracked walls to spoiled wells to the endless boom and dust of explosives.
"The problem goes beyond the environment to the very people the coal industry comes in and hires," said Ms. Bragg, the wife of a retired miner. "We're the workers, but we're also the victims."
With coal industry and union officials warning that the state's mining could be destroyed, the state Congressional delegation said today that it was "continuing to aggressively pursue all possible legislative options." A rider to one of the remaining appropriations bills is considered the likely vehicle in the closing days of Congress.
Last week, Mr. Byrd and Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, both Democrats, and the state's House delegation called on the Administration to join in the state's plan to appeal the ruling. They warned that the decision would "have a dramatic effect on the lives of thousands of coal miners."
But environmental groups insisted that pro-industry officials were trying to panic the Federal authorities into a legislative reversal of the ruling. Judge Haden, in an unusual postscript, complained on Wednesday that "people are interested in engaging in hyperbole" about the ruling's effects.
"Under a valley fill," Judge Haden declared in his ruling, "the water quality of the stream becomes zero. Because there is no stream, there is no water quality."
William M. Eichbaum, a vice president of the World Wildlife Fund who helped draft the mining controls as a Federal official, said the state and the coal industry had "overblown" the judge's ruling.
"I'm concerned Senator Byrd is putting this at such a high level, refusing to deal with all sorts of other issues, that the Administration will be put in a very difficult position," Mr. Eichbaum said.
Mr. Byrd's office denied that the Senator was pressuring the Administration beyond the merits of the issue, in which the state delegation insists that Judge Haden ignored the intent of Congress in passing the Clean Water and Surface Mining Control laws.
The director of the Federal Office of Surface Mining, Kathy Karpan, said she had received the first reports of job layoffs in the state.
"The industry is going to come to a virtual halt," Ms. Karpan warned.
In carrying out the ruling, she said, state officials estimated that only 3 of 62 previous mountaintop mining projects could go forward.

HEADLINE: Hurdles to Tobacco Pact Seen at Global Meeting

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 29

 BODY:
More than 100 nations agreed this week on the need for a global treaty to control tobacco sales, but some of the big hurdles to such a pact quickly became evident.
Health officials meeting here over the last five days outlined their ideas about what topics a treaty should deal with. The initiating agency, the World Health Organization, says tobacco is responsible for the deaths of four million people a year from cancer, bronchitis, emphysema and cardiovascular diseases. 
 At the closed-door meetings, two of the largest tobacco exporting countries, the United States and Japan, supported general guidelines instead of specific and enforceable provisions, according to activists who sat in on the sessions. A request for a copy of the United States position did not receive a response.
"The Japanese started their presentation by reminding the meeting that two-thirds of their industry is owned by the Government," said Lucinda Wykle-Rosenberg, of Infact, a Boston-based group.
At a news briefing, representatives of the watchdog groups said tobacco-exporting nations had not joined together to block the treaty. But several representatives said they feared that the tobacco industry would insert itself once full-fledged negotiations got under way.
Activists are campaigning for a tough document that would include a global ban on advertising, a crackdown on cigarette smuggling and elimination of subsidies for tobacco growers. They also want strong labeling requirements and strict protection for young people.
The United States, nongovernmental groups said, indicated that it would not support a comprehensive ban on tobacco industry advertising because of Constitutional protections for free speech.
"The U.S. delegation's opening salvo was that the notion of an advertising ban was not on the table," said Judith Glanz of the National Center for Tobacco-Free Kids in Washington, D.C.
The World Health Organization has spearheaded the negotiations. This week's meeting was the first round to examine what issues could be included in the treaty, which produced a list of 13, including such areas as advertising, tax, labeling and subsidies. These deliberations will be followed by a second round in March to winnow the list.
Mapping out the treaty will take place among the 191 W.H.O. member governments in May. "Everybody who has taken part in the deliberations here has spoken strongly for the idea of a Framework Convention," chairman Kimmo Leppo, director of Finland's Health and Social Affairs Ministry, said at a final news briefing. "There was not a single dissenting opinion in this respect."
But others at the meeting said that health ministry officials were prominent at this meeting but that as negotiations progressed, officials from ministries with competing interests, like economics and trade, would get involved. And that could disrupt the progress of the talks.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Shares Surge Again, With Nasdaq in Lead

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks extended their powerful rally yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index moved into record territory and blue-chip stocks pulled to within 5 percent of the record they set in August.
Seventy years ago to the day, on the historic Black Tuesday, the market crashed 11.7 percent. 
 Trading was heavy yesterday, surpassing a billion shares on the New York Stock Exchange for the second consecutive day, and analysts were also cheered by another session, rare for much of this year, in which far more issues rose than fell. Long-term interest rates eased again, as much as one-tenth of a percentage point for many Treasury securities.
"We got a follow-through from the euphoria" produced by economic data released on Thursday and reassuring words by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Andrew M. Brooks, chief trader at T. Rowe Price in Baltimore. "What a difference a couple weeks make."
At midmonth, the Dow Jones industrial average was more than 11 percent below the peak reached on Aug. 25, qualifying the downward move as a correction, and it seemed destined to slip below the 10,000 mark and possibly deteriorate by 20 percent into a bear market.
But the index, which rose 107.33 points yesterday, or 1 percent, to 10,729.86, has posted 7 hefty advances in the last 10 sessions as investors and traders acted on a round of generally buoyant profit reports, Government statistics suggesting that inflation remained subdued and a growing belief that Mr. Greenspan would decide that only one more increase in short-term rates would be needed.
Mr. Greenspan told top corporate officials on Thursday evening that the rise in rates this year had clearly begun to work, and his comments seemed to nudge market sentiment closer to a toss-up about whether the Fed will raise rates at its policy meeting on Nov. 16.
A poll by Reuters yesterday found 18 economists expecting a quarter-point increase and 12 predicting that the central bank would leave rates alone. Confirming the Greenspan view, the Commerce Department said yesterday that new homes were sold in September at the slowest pace in nearly two years.
Other positive developments have been the agreement in Washington to lift Depression-era barriers on the banking, securities and insurance industries, and the drying-up of tax-motivated selling by mutual funds as they approached the end of their bookkeeping year.
"We're seeing a number of things that undercut or at least mitigate the inflation fears," said Clare W. Zempel, chief investment strategist at Robert W. Baird in Milwaukee, citing among other things the Government report on Thursday showing that upward pressure on wages and benefits was lower than expected over the summer.
Treasury prices also responded favorably to the data and Mr. Greenspan's comments. The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 1 5/32, to 99 16/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.16 percent from 6.25 percent on Thursday. The price climbed 2 1/2 points during the week, the biggest weekly gain since Oct. 2, 1998.
In another good weekly performance, the Dow added 260 points after a 450-point surge the previous week. The record for the average -- which will add Microsoft, Intel, Home Depot and SBC Communications and remove Goodyear Tire and Rubber, Sears & Roebuck, Chevron and Union Carbide on Monday -- is 11,326.04, set on Aug. 25.
Nasdaq's surge yesterday was even more impressive, 91.21 points, or 3.17 percent, to 2,966.43, handily surpassing the record of 2,915.95 set on Oct. 11. Intel set the pace, rising 5 1/4, to 77 7/16, after it said it could satisfy demand for computer chips. Microsoft, Cisco and Sun Microsystems were also big contributors.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 20.49 points, or 1.53 percent, to 1,362.93, which is 4 percent below its July 16 peak.
The resurgent optimism was reflected in a spectacular market debut by Akamai Technologies. The company, based in Cambridge, Mass., provides a service that speeds delivery of Web pages but it had no revenue, much less profit, in 1998. Its shares, offered by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter at 26, began trading at 110 and traded as high as 166 before closing at 145 3/16.
Financial stocks mostly took a breather after a string of gains -- American Express, down 7, to 154, was the biggest drag on the Dow -- and Lockheed was battered after announcing a 50 percent reduction in likely earnings next year and the departure of its president. Its shares dropped 2 15/16, to 20, after trading as low as 16 3/8.
Paper stocks were outstanding, with International Paper jumping 4 3/16, to 52 5/8, to make the biggest positive contribution to the Dow. Bowater and Champion also spurted more than 4 points each while Georgia-Pacific rose more than 3.
Overseas markets were sharply higher, with major indexes up 3 percent in Tokyo, 3.9 percent in Hong Kong, 2.95 percent in Paris, 1.7 percent in London, 2.3 percent in Mexico City and 2 percent in Toronto. Frankfurt was 0.85 percent higher while Sao Paulo, Brazil, was unchanged.

HEADLINE: Clinton, at Rally in Philadelphia, Is Doubtful About Endorsements

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29

 BODY:
President Clinton raised doubts today about whether Presidents can sway the results of local elections, even as he came to the aid of a Democratic mayoral candidate here who is in danger of losing City Hall to a Republican for the first time in half a century.
"I want you to know I came here not as President to tell you how to vote," Mr. Clinton said at a rally at LaSalle University for John F. Street, a City Councilman in a tight race. "But I hope you will listen to me as someone who has tried to be a good friend to Philadelphia." 
 As the President made a spirited endorsement of Mr. Street, the candidate smiled broadly at his side. Philadelphia voters are registered 4-to-1 Democratic, but Mr. Street's campaign is facing a strong challenge from a Republican businessman, Sam Katz, only four days before Tuesday's election.
What should have been a runaway election for Mr. Street has turned neck and neck in public opinion polls. Both local newspapers have endorsed Mr. Katz, whose campaign has shown an appeal among Democrats that is making Mr. Street's backers anxious. Mr. Katz, who is white, is even challenging Mr. Street, a former City Council president who is black, for the support of Democratic black and Hispanic voters.
Although Mr. Clinton's own campaigning days are over, he clearly cannot get the excitement of campaigning out of his blood. Besides his visit here, the President in recent days has taped a radio advertisement for Mr. Street, lent his name to campaign mailers and, in a telephone call to the host of a local radio talk show, pressed for the election of Mr. Street. In that conversation, Mr. Clinton warned that a Republican victory in the mayoral race here could be bad news for Democrats in next year's Congressional and Presidential elections.
In his speech today, the President said he was mystified by newspaper accounts of the campaign that portrayed Mr. Street, who is 56, as lacking vision and charisma. "This is a young, vigorous, brilliant, committed public servant," Mr. Clinton said. "You heard him up here today. His heart is on fire for the children and the future of the city. He has all the experience in the world."
The President recalled that former President Ronald Reagan had visited Arkansas to endorse the Republican challenger when Mr. Clinton was running for re-election as Governor, and said the endorsement had little effect on the outcome. Mr. Clinton's last endorsement effort, when he went to New Orleans last month on behalf of William J. Jefferson, the Democratic candidate for governor of Louisiana, was similarly fruitless.
Last week Mr. Jefferson, a 52-year-old Congressman who sought to become Louisiana's first black governor, lost soundly to the incumbent, Mike Foster, a Republican. With this in mind, Mr. Clinton said he purposely did not pull out his "big, whoop-de-do political speech." He even offered a back-handed compliment to Mr. Katz, saying that he was campaigning well and "singing a good song," but would be judged in the end on whether he could deliver.
Mr. Street and Mr. Katz have debated three times, outlining their differences on school vouchers, economic development and other issues. Although the campaign has been remarkably free of attacks, Mr. Street has sought to cast his rival as a Republican who is new to politics and out of touch with the city's needs.
Mr. Katz, 49, has played up his experience in business, where he has been a sports world deal-maker, and stresses his genial personality.
"People get excited when they find out I can tap a keg with the best of them," Mr. Katz said in an interview in The Philadelphia Inquirer, adding that he had "danced the chicken dance in the German American Festival."
Mr. Street's backers were confident that Mr. Clinton's 11th-hour appearance would be enough to attract undecided Democrats -- the group that both campaigns agree will be critical in determining the successor to Mayor Ed Rendell, who is retiring.
"When you have the President in town, it has to make a difference," said Joseph Rauscher, president of the Philadelphia Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., whose members are telephoning registered voters on Mr. Street's behalf. "The man is loved by just about everyone in this town."
Even Bob Barnett, the campaign director for Mr. Katz, is a Clinton supporter. But Mr. Barnett, a Democrat who campaigned for Mr. Clinton and served in his Administration as head of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, said his former boss was right that local issues, not a Presidential endorsement, would decide the race.
"When President Clinton leaves, the abandoned car on the street is still there," Mr. Barnett said. "This is not about foreign policy or the nuclear test ban treaty. Philadelphia has not reacted well to people coming in from out of town to tell them how to vote."
The Katz campaign considered it a day like any other. While the President lavished praise on Mr. Street, Mr. Katz spoke at a center for the elderly. Later, he greeted voters at a bar and appeared on a local television station's "meet the candidates" night.

HEADLINE: September New-Home Sales Fell

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell in September to the lowest level in almost two years as higher mortgage costs cooled housing from the robust pace earlier this year, Government figures showed today.
New single-family home sales fell 12.8 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 811,000 units after dropping four-tenths of a percent in August, the Commerce Department said. September's was the slowest pace since December 1997. 
 Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.76 percent this week, more than a full percentage point above the rates earlier this year, according to Freddie Mac. Potential home buyers are also bidding up prices. The median price in September for new homes was 5 percent higher than at the beginning of the year.
A separate report today showed that manufacturing is picking up in the Midwest. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago's monthly index rose to 58.8 in October from 53.8 in September. Readings above 50 mean the number of manufacturers who said business improved was larger than the number saying it deteriorated.
The purchasing managers' report showed that new orders, production and employment are increasing at Chicago-area factories. For the first time in five months, fewer manufacturers said they paid higher prices for raw materials, probably because of declines in oil prices. The index of prices paid for raw materials fell to 65.4 last month from 71.0 in September.
