HEADLINE: Flat-Tax Follies

 BODY:
The Republican presidential candidates who debated in New Hampshire Thursday night did not quarrel much. But it was especially discouraging that they embraced a flat tax to replace the progressive income tax. In the 1996 G.O.P. primaries, Steve Forbes made the flat tax a centerpiece of his campaign, only to have Bob Dole demolish the idea by pointing out the absurdity of lowering tax rates on rich people like Mr. Forbes and raising them on the middle class. This week Mr. Forbes said he was delighted at the revival of his issue. But Republicans would do well to drop it or risk being seen as a servant of the privileged.
The current economic boom has benefited the wealthiest Americans while the working class has struggled to stay even. That is one reason the Republicans' $792 billion tax cut scheme, weighted heavily toward the rich and vetoed by President Clinton, stirred so little support over the summer. Contrary to Alan Keyes's overheated description of the income tax as slavery and a Marxist-Leninist plot, progressivity in tax rates has been accepted by Americans at least since the Civil War. 
Except for Mr. Keyes, the flat tax was embraced in one form or another by all the other debaters, including such otherwise sensible Republicans as Orrin Hatch and John McCain. The candidates dwelled on the bewildering complexity of the current tax system. But as Gary Bauer noted, it is not the overall tax rate that makes the tax system confusing so much as the array of tax breaks, deductions and definitions of income in the tax code. Flat-tax advocates say they would eliminate many of these deductions, but they disagree over which ones. Such steps might demystify the system, but having the rich and the middle class pay the same marginal rates would make the end result unfair.
Gov. George W. Bush, who did not participate in the debate, has said he favors a "fairer and flatter" tax, but he has not yet specified what he means. The best point scored in the debate was by Senator McCain. He noted that what keeps overall rates high is the ability of powerful business groups to get tax breaks in return for campaign donations. "Every time we pass a tax bill," he said, "we add another special loophole and a special deal for the special interests." Mr. McCain may be getting some traction for his idea that the soft-money ban he is pushing in the Senate would actually bring about tax relief for average Americans.
Taxes have been at the center of American presidential campaigns at least since 1980, when Ronald Reagan won by promising a sweeping tax cut. It is healthy to have a quadrennial discussion on whether to cut taxes or spend government funds on health, education and social programs. But the idea that the flat tax is needed in order to simplify the tax code is disingenuous, when the basic result would ease the tax burden on the super-rich. That cannot be what most Americans want.

HEADLINE: Holiday Masquerade At the Pumpkin Patch;
Poor Crop Tests Farmers' Wits

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: DOVER, N.Y., Oct. 23

 BODY:
It took the Rivera family two interminable hours to drive from the Bronx to a farm that had escaped the great pumpkin shortage of 1999, but the reward was a bonanza. "We'd heard of the shortage, so we were glad to see these fields were full," said Jamie Rivera, a New York City police officer.
His 8-year-old son, Jamie Jr., pointed to the 10-pounder he had picked for his grandmother. "And that one, that's for my teacher, Mrs. Grant," he said of the tiny pumpkin at his feet. 
 Generations of Dutchess County residents and citified interlopers have made an annual pilgrimage to pick a patch of pumpkins at Dykeman's Farm here, near Pawling. And this year's customers have not been disappointed. They can stumble over 2,000 pumpkins in the Dykeman family's eight-acre field on Pleasant Ridge Road.
By taking heroic measures to beat last summer's drought and save their cash crop, the Dykemans have enabled Halloween pumpkin pickers to engage in one of the obligatory rituals of autumn, along with leaf peeping, apple picking and trick-or-treating. "Irrigation saved our crop, but a lot of other farmers were hurt," said Henry Dykeman, 71, the family patriarch.
Halloween, America's fastest-growing holiday as measured by consumer spending, is helplessly dependent upon its symbolic gourd. And so, the Halloween boom has created an insatiable need for the pumpkins of New York, which happens to be -- who knew? -- the nation's second-largest pumpkin-growing state, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
But months of extreme weather have been disastrous for the state's pumpkin supply. The shortage has not only caused wholesale pumpkin importation and instances of vegetable subterfuge, but has also unleashed pumpkin handle deception in the jack-o'-lantern wars at the New York region's farm stands and garden centers.
There are fewer pumpkins right now because of the scorching summer heat and severe drought of June and July. The brutal weather kept seeds from germinating, discouraged bees from pollinating pumpkin flowers and shriveled root systems. Worse, many of the surviving pumpkins ripened prematurely in August and September; they rotted well before Halloween.
Then, in September, many farmers were devastated by floods brought on by Tropical Storm Floyd. "Pumpkins just hate standing water," said Pete Gregg, a spokesman for the State Department of Agriculture and Markets in Albany, "so we got a lot of flat-sided, misshapen pumpkins. And many were discolored with grayish fungus that customers don't find desirable."
As a result, "it's an off year in terms of yield and quality," Mr. Gregg said, "and many pumpkin farmers in the lower Hudson Valley and Long Island were severely affected."
Agriculture analysts have estimated that this year's harvest from the nation's 74,000 acres of pumpkin fields will be more than 50 percent below average. In New York State, drought-related damage to all crops has cost farmers $186 million, Mr. Gregg said.
Now, this fall, the Halloween-minded have discovered that pumpkins are smaller, often more expensive "and there are fewer of them," said Tony Mannetta, director of Greenmarket, a nonprofit organization that operates 28 open-air farmers' markets in New York City.
"My advice has been to shop early," Mr. Mannetta said, "because pumpkins are not available to our customers in nearly their ordinary abundance."
Abundance was hardly in question at Dykeman's Farm. "We got all paranoid about the shortage, but here we don't have to worry," said Jack Bonacorso. He had arrived with his picking crew -- his wife, Donna, and daughters Bryana, 8, and Kayleigh, 6 -- from nearby Wingdale.
"Halloween without a pumpkin," he said, "would be like Christmas without a tree."
Nearby, Heather Bassano, 9, hugged her favorite pumpkin and said she was going to paint a face on it. Erin Ryan, 8, her best friend, said she would be carving hers. "Picking these is so much better than getting them at the A.& P.," said her mother, Charlou Ryan.
At the farm stand, George Kuklevsky and his 10-year-old son, Simon, had just put their six pumpkins on the scales: they weighed 100 pounds and cost $40. "I figured with the shortage, they'd make us pay through the nose," Mr. Kuklevsky said. But at Dykeman's, the price, 40 cents a pound, "was the same as last year," he said.
The beastly weather of 1999 was more of a blow to New York's farmers than it might have been only a few years ago thanks to "the growing industry of Halloween," as Mr. Gregg put it.
The state's pumpkin acreage increased by nearly 20 percent from 1992 to 1997, the last year for which figures are available, according to the Federal Department of Agriculture. It has calculated that New York, with 5,388 acres harvested in 1997, is second only to Illinois, with 7,631 acres harvested.
Although there are spot shortages around the region, small, locally grown pumpkins are generally available. But there is a scarcity of the large, perfectly formed jack-o'-lanterns essential to success in the Halloween competition among roadside stands, garden centers, nurseries and vegetable markets.
Therefore, merchants have relied on ingenuity to save their season. For example, Mr. Gregg said, New York has seen a wholly unpublicized influx of pumpkins from Canada, "where there was no drought and no Floyd."
Even at humble farm stands, authenticity is not a certainty this season. "Some of the roadside stands that make their money from pumpkin sales had to buy their supply," said Dave Tetor, the Dutchess County agriculture program leader at the Cornell Cooperative Extension in Millbrook.
Furthermore, some pick-your-own pumpkin fields have run out of produce and have purchased imported "ringers." "People want the fun of finding them in the field, and if you don't have any pumpkins left you have to plant them at midnight," Mr. Tetor said.
Even cosmetic reconstruction has not been unheard of in this season of crisis. Drought-induced brittleness has caused some growers to experience problems "with the handles on the pumpkins," said Jean M. Warholic, executive secretary of the New York State Vegetable Growers Association, a trade group. "Some customers won't look twice at a pumpkin without a handle. We won't ask whether anyone glued them back on."
When Henry Dykeman started his pumpkin-picking operation in 1974, "we were the only one doing it within a 25-mile radius," he said, "and now everyone is copying us."
Mr. Dykeman and his wife, Jean, own the farm along with their 45-year-old son, Wright, and Wright's wife, Beth.
"Last summer we irrigated the fields for 70 consecutive days, for 20 hours a day," said Wright Dykeman. "I ran out of ambition before I ran out of water."
The Dykemans say it was the hottest, driest summer in memory, and the experts concur. "I've been in Dutchess County 27 years and this is the worst drought I've seen," said Mr. Tetor. "Not every farm has Mr. Dykeman's soil, or his irrigation capability."
Many farmers were not so lucky. "I lost my whole pumpkin crop," said Eugene Froehlich, 55, a vegetable farmer who has grown pumpkins for 25 years on his family farm in Montgomery, across the Hudson from Dutchess County. "It was like planting them in the desert."
Pumpkin farming "is a gamble every year," said the elder Mr. Dykeman, noting that in addition to drought and flood, the neighboring deer population devoured "1,000 of my best pumpkins." Mr. Dykeman smiled, shook his head, then said, "A farmer has to depend on the Lord."
Standing amid rows of pumpkins, Mrs. Ryan made it clear, however, that she would not be dependent on Dykeman's Farm for her pumpkin pie. That "will come out of a can this year," she said. "All the work that's involved with a real pumpkin, it's not worth it -- it tastes exactly the same."

HEADLINE: Nassau County Republicans Pass Budget With Large Tax Increase

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., Saturday, Oct. 30

 BODY:
Faced with a weekend budget deadline and elections on Tuesday, the Nassau County Legislature early this morning approved a new budget for the year 2000 that would eliminate this year's $300 million deficit, cut spending next year by $45 million and, for the first time in seven years, impose a major increase in property taxes.
The final vote was 14 to 4, with only Democrats dissenting. One Democrat was absent. 
 The county's portion of the tax bill for the average homeowner will increase by $90, or about 9 percent, said the Presiding Officer, Bruce Blakeman.
The vote on the budget was the latest twist in a long political saga in Nassau, one of the wealthiest and most populous suburban counties in America, whose powerful Republican political machine has been rocked by disastrous deficits.
At a time when many state and municipal governments have prospered because of a booming economy, Nassau's spending in the last two years has created so much red ink that the county's bonds have been downgraded to a level hovering just above junk.
Mr. Blakeman, along with other Republican members of the County Legislature -- all of whom are up for re-election -- have promised to eliminate waste in county spending.
Mr. Blakeman said that money raised through the sale of bonds covered by anticipated revenues from the settlement with the tobacco industry would serve to reduce a large portion of the $300 million debt. He said he expected a deal on the bonds to be completed within the next two weeks.
Threatened with a revolt by voters on Tuesday, the Republican lawmakers turned against their fellow Republican, County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, who is not up for re-election until next year, and rejected his proposed $2.2 billion budget for the year 2000, declaring it "irresponsible" and "just another house of mirrors."
Mr. Blakeman said that the 14 Republicans in the 19-member Legislature reached final agreement on their own budget about 7 P.M. Friday and submitted it to the full Legislature early this morning for a final vote. "As a result of our efforts, Nassau will be entering the new year leaner than it has ever been," he said. "When we shredded the administration's proposed budget a month ago, we pledged to examine county spending, line by line, eliminate waste and cut to the bone," Mr. Blakeman said. "In fact, we've cut into the bone."
The final vote, which came just after 1 A.M., was not without opposition, however. Democrats said they were never provided copies of the Republican budget to study, and received only a verbal briefing on its contents during a short meeting Friday night with Mr. Blakeman in the office of the minority leader, Judith A. Jacobs.
"We never saw any paperwork," Ms. Jacobs said. "We never had any public hearings. We are really captives here, so we all decided to vote against the budget."
"We have been left out of the entire process, so we can only question the validity of their figures and the need for any tax increase," Ms. Jacobs said. "What property owners are being asked to do today is pay for years of mismanagement by the Republicans.
"We Democrats refuse to be a rubber stamp," she continued. "We represent 350,000 people, all of whom have been left out of this budget process. We can only hope that the budget works. No one wants to see the county go under."
Mr. Blakeman said the spending cuts for next year totaled $45 million and would force county commissioners and department heads to "manage more efficiently and do more with less." The cuts range from beepers and cell phones to 33 patronage jobs.
Among the cuts are $4.5 million in overtime cost in 13 departments and $2.5 million in general expense cuts in 23 departments and agencies.
Some departments, including Minority Affairs and Human Rights, are to be merged, permitting the elimination of three directorships, which will bring a savings of hundreds of thousands of payroll dollars, Mr. Blakeman said. "However, the consolidation plan will have absolutely no impact on the services," he said.
Also planned for consolidation are the Department of Drug and Alcohol Addiction Control and the Department of Health. The Department of Commerce and Industry will be merged with the Planning Department, eliminating two top-level patronage jobs. The Police Department will lose $4.1 million in budgeted spending on commercial and other expenses. Mr. Blakeman said, however, that these cuts would have no impact on police services. Mr. Blakeman said law enforcement unions had done their share by agreeing to $6 million in cuts.
"Weeks ago we promised to prepare a fiscal blueprint that would eliminate wasteful spending, make county managers more accountable, minimize the need for large tax increase, all with the aim of putting our county on a sound fiscal footing," Mr. Blakeman said. "Tonight we have made good on that promise."
Mr. Gulotta, who had declined to engage in any debate with the Legislature over his budget, has said only that he welcomed its recommendations. He did not return calls to his office late Friday night for comment on the Legislature's budget package. In any event, the Republican majority is veto-proof.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 562 words

HEADLINE: Stow All Pythons in the Overhead Bin

BYLINE: By Kinky Friedman; Kinky Friedman's latest novel is "Spanking Watson."

 BODY:

Big Trouble
 By Dave Barry.
 255 pp. New York:
 G. P. Putnam's Sons. $23.95. 
 A lot of people have been killing a lot of trees lately. Maybe that's why it comes as something of a cultural colonic to discover that Dave Barry has created that rarest of all literary creatures, the genuinely funny mystery novel. "Big Trouble," Barry's first foray into fiction, begins with the author acknowledging his debt to Carl Hiaasen, whom he terms the master of the "Bunch of South Florida Wackos genre." Barry also includes a warning to youngsters about "adult language" in his book. "I did not necessarily want the characters to use this type of language," he contends, but "some of them just went ahead and did. That's how some characters are."
Barry is apparently somewhat squeamish about using truly obscene words in front of a c-h-i-l-d. This cloyingly peculiar morality bodes well for him as he embarks upon this maiden voyage of every mystery writer: embracing the vital, convoluted, god-like work of demarcating right from wrong in the shell game of life. He also, quite naturally, evinces concern about his ability to come up with a serviceable plot. Upon this matter he consults the Three Wise Men -- Stephen King, Elmore Leonard and the aforementioned Hiaasen, all of whom tell him the plot's not too important just as long as you keep killing trees.
It is almost poignant that Barry, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who has numerous best sellers under his belt and who has had a television sitcom based upon his life, would find it necessary to consult these icons of imagination, but such is the daunting nature of fiction. It unmasks the author more ruthlessly than any other form of writing. In Barry's case this is a blessing -- we see, possibly for the first time, what a charming, witty, insightful storyteller he truly is. As a writer somewhere once observed: "Plots are for cemeteries."
Far be it from me to demystify "Big Trouble," in terms of, well, plot. There are more important spiritual matters in this book to entertain the reader, like "a man wearing an official Greg Norman golf shirt, official Greg Norman hat and official Greg Norman slacks"; a highly agitated, abusive husband who believes the family dog is Elizabeth Dole coming to suck out his soul; the funniest portrayal of the wasteland that is sports talk radio that has ever been written; a hit man who blows away a large pet python named Daphne at Miami International Airport (a mildly jarring note for animal lovers like me, who probably would've been Buddhists if it weren't for Richard Gere); two arms merchants from an "extremely tribal nation whose economy was based primarily on revenge"; and a cop who tells a thug who wants to know if he gets his gun back: "Of course you do! Just as soon as we run a couple of tests and a giant, talking marshmallow is elected President."
In the great visceral Florida-focused tradition of Hemingway and John D. MacDonald, Dave Barry succeeds wildly with "Big Trouble." He is a welcome leavening agent in the artery-clogged, overly intellectualized and spiritually constipated genre that we now refer to as mystery fiction. Maybe more important, there is a comforting element of Kurt Vonnegut-like cosmic integrity to Barry's work that keeps his crazy characters credible and -- if not always humane -- at least almost human.

HEADLINE: The Forgotten War

BYLINE: By Chris Tomlinson; Chris Tomlinson has reported extensively from eastern and central Africa for a variety of news organizations.

 BODY:

INSIDE SUDAN
 Political Islam, Conflict, and Catastrophe.
 By Donald Petterson.
 209 pp. Boulder, Colo.:
 Westview Press. $25. 
 Peace talks to end one of the world's oldest civil wars collapsed in Nairobi, Kenya, last July. On the same day, rebels and aid workers in southern Sudan reported that the Government's sole bomber had dropped a shell that spewed a green gas. Within a week, doctors said, hundreds of people were seriously ill. Elsewhere in southern Sudan, fighting between the northern Islamic Government and Christian and animist southerners had cut off more than 160,000 refugees from the foreign aid they needed to survive.
There was no international debate on what to do, or any urgent message from the Oval Office. Unlike the refugees of Kosovo, the four million people driven from their homes in Sudan receive only marginal world attention. The deaths of 1.9 million southern Sudanese since 1983 remain a little-known statistic.
News reporting from Sudan has long been difficult. Government and rebel restrictions make covering the country practically impossible. Reporters are usually able to get in only by accompanying aid workers, and see only those areas where aid agencies can operate.
If there is little daily journalism coming from Sudan, there are even fewer books, and like most news dispatches they have focused on the humanitarian catastrophe. Bringing a veteran diplomat's perspective, "Inside Sudan," by Donald Petterson, is a welcome addition to the limited number of publications on 20th-century Sudan.
Petterson became the United States Ambassador to Sudan in 1992, four years after the military coup that brought the current Government to power. He left in 1995, before conditions in Khartoum had become so tenuous that the United States Embassy was closed and moved to Nairobi. Petterson's tenure is an important chapter in American relations with Sudan.
A veteran diplomat specializing in Africa, Petterson had served in Zanzibar, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Somalia, Tanzania and Zimbabwe. Even though he acknowledges that Khartoum was one of the least desirable assignments in the Foreign Service, he welcomed the challenge of engaging a government that was at odds with Washington on almost everything.
Sudan and the United States have never been on very good terms. Political and economic chaos began in Sudan with independence in 1956. Two years later, Sudan's military took power in the first of four coups. But the mostly black, animist or Christian southerners, forever fearful of Arab and Muslim dominance in the north, had already taken up arms in 1955, and except for a hiatus from 1972 to 1982, they have fought steadily for an independent nation.
The Sudanese Government refused to join the United States in opposing the Soviet Union in the 1960's and broke off diplomatic relations with Washington from 1967 to 1972 to protest American support for Israel. From 1972 to 1983 relations improved, but Washington reduced aid in 1985, after the war in the south reignited and the Government proved increasingly dictatorial. The coup in 1989 activated an American law that cut off all assistance except for food and medicine.
So Petterson started out with little diplomatic leverage. As he explains here, he also learned upon his arrival that the embassy had lost radio contact with the United States Agency for International Development office in the southern town of Juba. A month later, a military officer reported that four Sudanese employees of the embassy had been executed for treason.
Petterson protested the executions, but in what he describes as an amazing lack of concern for human rights, Hasan al-Turabi, the head of the National Islamic Front and the real power in Sudan, replied that the men were unimportant and that Washington would soon forget about its dead employees. Turabi would be proven wrong. Three years later the Government nominated a general who was involved in the executions to be Sudan's Ambassador to the United States. Washington and Petterson rejected the nominee, setting off another crisis.
Petterson recounts his meetings with government and rebel leaders, always saying the encounters ended cordially despite an inability to agree on anything. Ever the diplomat, he splits the blame for the war evenly between the warring sides. The southerners want independence and an end to Islamic law. The Government believes in unity and political Islam.
Aid workers are the heroes in the book, struggling to stave off starvation in huge refugee camps that often come under attack. But Petterson glides over how both rebel and Government troops siphon off aid for their war effort.
And, unfortunately, his book leaves out volumes. He doesn't tell us where the Government or the rebels in such an impoverished country get the money for a 16-year civil war. He doesn't discuss the extensive and highly prized oil fields discovered by an American oil company along the line where Sudan could logically be bisected.
While Petterson describes regional peace efforts, he offers only a few sentences on the geopolitics. He briefly mentions Ugandan and Eritrean support for the rebels, but does not note Sudanese backing for the renegade Lord's Resistance Army, which raids elementary schools in northern Uganda, kidnapping hundreds of children and turning them into soldiers or sex servants. There is also no mention of the chattel slavery still practiced by Arab tribes.
Finally, "Inside Sudan" fails to deliver any revelations on United States policy. Petterson states over and over again that Sudan aids terrorists and commits human rights violations, but he doesn't provide any details that have not already been reported in the news media. Similarly, he repeatedly says that there was no support for any greater American role in Sudan than diplomatic engagement and nonmilitary aid, but he doesn't lay out what other options were discussed.
At one point Petterson encounters Sudanese opposition leaders who had hoped that following its victory in the gulf war, the United States would turn its attention to Sudan. Petterson soberly convinces them that this was not about to happen. Now that the United States has, after Kosovo, established a doctrine of using military intervention for human rights purposes, one wonders if those same men are fruitlessly getting their hopes up again.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Washington

BYLINE: By CYNTHIA HACINLI; CYNTHIA HACINLI is co-author of "Romantic Days and Nights in Washington, D.C." (Globe Pequot).

 BODY:
Call it the calm before the electoral storm. As the city cranks out dollars and spin for the Presidential sweepstakes, the bigger news at the moment is the return of boom times. Northern Virginia's high-tech hub, arguably the epicenter of the Internet, is fueling a robust economy.
The real estate market has gone wild and hotels and museums are being renovated at a breathtaking clip. Cloaked in its racy Michael Graves scaffolding, the Washington Monument symbolizes a capital in flux. The cultural season is in full swing with a raft of shows at art museums -- the new sculpture garden at the National Gallery of Art is the jewel in this top-heavy crown. 
 Washington's generally mild weather means street and cafe life well into November. A fixture on the local Sunday scene is the Dupont Circle Farmers Market, 21st Street between P and Q Streets NW, where vendors sell organic goat cheese and heirloom fruits and vegetables from 8 A.M. to 1 P.M. through November.
And when pumpkins are history, holiday revels begin with the Christmas Pageant of Peace and the lighting of the National Christmas tree on Dec. 8 at 5 P.M. on the Ellipse, E Street between 15th and 17th Streets NW. Bleacher seats are sold out, so it's standing room only. Singers, bands and choruses will perform free nightly on the Ellipse from 6 to 8:30 until Dec. 30, except Dec. 24 and 25. The tree stays up until Jan. 1. Information: (202) 208-1631.
 
Events
At the newly renovated Phillips Collection, 1600 21st Street NW, Duncan Phillips, who in 1921 opened his Dupont Circle home to the public and, in that instant, founded the nation's first modern-art museum, gets his due in a 350-work show "Renoir to Rothko: The Eye of Duncan Phillips." The show, on view till Jan. 23, includes such works as Renoir's "Luncheon of the Boating Party," Picasso's "Blue Room" and Arthur Dove's "Flower Mill II." Admission $7.50 (free on Wednesday). Closed Monday; (202) 387-2151.
Fans of Annie Liebovitz's celebrity shots in Vanity Fair can delve deeper in "Women," at the Corcoran Gallery, 500 17th Street NW, through Feb. 28. The exhibit covers portraits of a broad spectrum of American women, from politicians to strippers to scientists. Closed Tuesday. Suggested admission is $3, but $5 timed tickets are necessary for "Women"; (202) 639-1700.
The National Museum of African Art, 950 Independence Avenue SW, examines sartorial customs in "Hats Off: A Salute to African Headwear," including a red feathered Cameroon headdress and a chief's hat from Congo, through Dec. 26. "Wrapped in Pride: Ghanaian Kente and African-American Identity," to Jan. 2, looks at ways of weaving the colorful cloth. Open daily, free; (202) 357-4600.
Ernest Hemingway comes alive at the National Portrait Gallery, F and Eighth Streets NW, in "Picturing Hemingway: A Writer in His Time," photographs, memorabilia and paintings of the writer and his cronies. Also worth seeing is "Edward Sorel: Unauthorized Portraits," featuring his sly caricatures of Presidents and other celebrities, and "Tete-a-Tete: Portraits by Henri Cartier-Bresson," chosen by the French photographer for a show in Paris when he turned 90 last year. The first two run through Jan. 2, and "Tete-a-Tete" to Jan. 9, when the gallery will close for renovation until 2003. Free; (202) 357-2700.
The ornate Elizabethan theater at the Folger Shakespeare Library, 201 East Capitol Street SE, will look familiar to anyone who has seen "Shakespeare in Love." Through Dec. 5, the theater is offering an offbeat "Hamlet" (the lead role is played by four actors). Tickets, $24 to $38. On exhibit at the Library Gallery through Dec. 30 is "Fooles and Fricassees," highlighting food in Shakespeare's England in early manuscripts, books and drawings. Closed Sunday. Free; (202) 544-7077.
 
Sightseeing
Claes Oldenburg's witty oversized eraser -- the kind with a brush on one end -- sets the mood at the National Gallery of Art sculpture garden (on the Mall between Seventh and Ninth Streets). Come Nov. 15, the garden fountain will be transformed into a skating rink. It will be open daily, except holidays, weather permitting, with skate rentals available; (202) 737-4215.
The big news at the National Zoo, 3001 Connecticut Avenue NW, is a trio of 4-month-old Sumatran tiger cubs, which can be seen from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. The zoo is open daily and is free; (202) 673-4800.
The often balmy fall weather makes pedaling the monuments a favored pursuit. An easy route starts at the Lincoln Memorial, 23d Street between Independence and Constitution Avenues, follows the Reflecting Pool east to the Washington Monument then bears right along the paved path closest to the southern edge of the Mall to the Tidal Basin and Jefferson Memorial. All monuments are open daily, free. Big Wheel Bikes, 1034 33d Street NW, rents bicycles; (202) 337-0254.
Fall is ideal for a stroll around Georgetown's handsome streets. Amble along P Street to No. 3271, where Jacqueline and John F. Kennedy lived when they were newlyweds. A block or so over, off R Street, Dumbarton Oaks, 1703 32d Street NW, is still vibrant (gardens open 2 to 5 daily, free); (202) 339-6410. For a restorative, Patisserie Poupon, 1645 Wisconsin Avenue (near Q Street), has pastries and homemade French ice cream. Closed Monday; (202) 342-3248.
Though too far to walk from Georgetown -- unless hiking is your thing -- the Washington National Cathedral, Massachusetts and Wisconsin Avenues NW, offers rest and respite for the weary. You can get lost in the cavernous interior, and on the south grounds, through a door right out of a Grimm's fairy tale, is the Bishop's Garden, a lush oval of evergreens, boxwood and herbs. Cathedral tours lasting 30 to 60 minutes are given Monday through Saturday from 10 to 11:30 A.M. and 12:45 to 3:15 P.M. and Sunday from 12:30 to 2:45 P.M.; (202) 537-6200. Suggested donation, $3 and $1 for children.
 
Where to Stay
The Hotel George, 15 E Street NW, (800) 576-8331, fax (202) 347-4213, provides some of the city's hippest accommodations. This 139-room hotel on Capitol Hill has a 24-hour fitness center, spacious rooms and avant-garde art. Doubles start at $159 on weekends until Nov. 18, $129 in late November and $119 in December. Bistro Bis, serves sophisticated French comfort food (vegetable tarts and escargot ragout).
An uproarious sequence in the movie "Dick" put the Watergate Hotel, 2650 Virginia Avenue NW, back on the map -- that and an overhaul of the 250 rooms and suites and a new name, Swissotel Washington. Rooms have mahogany and red chintz furniture, taupe bedspreads and marble baths. Doubles: $179 to $595; (202) 965-2300, fax (202) 337-7915.
Budget: Popular with finicky parents of students at the nearby George Washington University is the St. James Suites, 950 24th Street NW, on Washington Circle. The 195 suites, in shades of maroon or green, all have kitchens and living areas. Suites begin at $109, dropping to $99 Thanksgiving weekend and into December, with Continental breakfast; (800) 852-8512, fax (202) 659-4492.
On a quiet street off Dupont Circle, the intimate all-suite Canterbury Hotel, 1733 N Street NW, has a sizable European clientele. The 99 green floral-themed junior suites in this modern hotel have queen- or king-size beds and kitchenettes. Rates are $140 to $235, including Continental breakfast and a pass to a nearby Y.M.C.A.; the AAA rate is $119; (800) 424-2950, fax (202) 785-9581.
Luxury: A magnet for celebrities (Harrison Ford stayed there while filming "Random Hearts"), the Four Seasons, 2800 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, has added 60 rooms and suites (for a total of 260), a health club and spa, and an indoor pool. Standard doubles, in blue and yellow, are $315 on weekends, the newer, bigger rooms $410, including parking; (202) 342-0444, fax (202) 944-2076.
The Hay-Adams, 800 16th Street NW, is as close as you can stay to the White House. The 143 rooms and 32 suites have mahogany furniture and are done in shades of cream, blue and beige. Smallish doubles with a courtyard view begin at $310, while a larger room with a glimpse of a White House is $495. Lafayette, the sun-splashed dining room, is known for its afternoon tea overlooking Lafayette Park ($18.95); (202) 638-6600, (800) 323-7500, fax: (202) 638-2716.
 
Where to Eat
Already one of the city's top Northern Italian restaurants, Galileo, 1110 21st Street NW, has added Laboratorio Galileo, a new glass-walled kitchen and dining area, where a lucky few can watch the chef, Roberto Donna, work and indulge in a multicourse meal for $95 a person. The Lab menu varies, but past hits include leek custard with black truffle and prosciutto, and rockfish with pig ears and shallots. Reservations for the Lab at least six weeks ahead are suggested. The main dining room, also redone, is easier to get into, and the banquettes along the left wall are particularly romantic. Dinner for two with wine is around $150; (202) 293-7191.
Goldoni has a new pale-hued home at 1120 20th Street NW, but the chef Fabrizio Aielli's modern Venetian cooking is as dazzling as ever: he dares to pair chocolate-scented pasta with rabbit ragout and eggplant with a sweet-sour glaze. The second level feels more private. Dinner for two with wine, $150; (202) 293-1511.
Mr. Aielli's week-old showcase, Teatro Goldoni, 1909 K Street NW, dishes up pasta and Venetian seafood like lobster with black truffle sauce to a backdrop of harlequin glass and an open kitchen. Dinner for two with a glass of wine, about $110; (202) 955-9494.
In just a few months, Equinox, 818 Connecticut Avenue NW, at Pennsylvania, has become a hit with the White House crowd. The chef, Todd Gray, conjures up lush pan-carmelized duck foie gras and barbecued salmon with corn and red peppers. Dinner for two with wine, around $100; (202) 331-8118.
Also new and justly popular is Johnny's Half Shell, 2002 P Street NW, which flies in French bread from New Orleans for its oyster and soft-shell crab po'boys. Corn pudding, seafood gumbo and Manhattan clam chowder are tops, too, and at lunch, the hot dog with onions and blue cheese ($5.95) steals the show. No reservations. Dinner for two with wine, about $85; (202) 296-2021.
The wood-oven pizzas at Pizzeria Paradiso, P Street between 20th and 21st Streets NW, are dead ringers for the crisp-crusted pies of Naples. Rounding out the menu are paninis, inventive salads, an extraordinary antipasto and homemade gelato. Dinner for two with wine, around $30; (202) 223-1245.
The serene tea shops known as Teaism are hip places for steaming pots of tea (there are more than a dozen green teas alone) and Asian-inspired meals. At breakfast, candied ginger scones are the choice. Lunch and dinner revolve around tea-smoked salmon, sandwiches, homemade soups and addictive chocolate creme brulee. Dinner for two around, $25. Outlets at 2009 R Street NW, (202) 667-3827; 400 Eighth Street NW, and 800 Connecticut Avenue NW, (202) 835-2233, where dinner is not served.

HEADLINE: The Search Engine

 BODY:
As described in Michael Lewis's article (Oct. 10), Jim Clark is a walking study of the way asset bubbles are formed: give the markets some mystical technology, a few outrageous claims and venture-fueled quick growth, then stand back and watch the feeding frenzy.
Lewis's acceptance of the principles of the "high-tech economy" does not allow us to measure Clark by his tangible accomplishments, or maybe I'm just old-fashioned. Netscape, for example, was supposed to be a technology giant to challenge Microsoft -- now it's basically a provider of chat-room software. 
 Clark's new venture, Healtheon, is now a company of millionaires because of its promise to make health care more efficient. Has it done it? Does it even need to now?
Clark and his Silicon Valley followers are uncannily good at creating new bubbles. They are even better at being far away, working on the next "new thing" when the bubbles pop.
 
Vincent P. Donovan
San Francisco 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2395 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Prescriptions for a Troubled Patient: The Theater

 BODY:
Earlier this month, nine American playwrights gathered in Provincetown, Mass., to discuss the future of American theater. The meeting, organized by the Provincetown Repertory Theater, was recorded before an audience in the town hall. The moderator, Steven Drukman, who is writing a history of American avant-garde theater, began by asking whether there are two separate theater cultures in the United States: nonprofit and commercial Broadway. Here are edited excerpts from the session.
JOHN GUARE. Broadway has always been the marketplace. It was where "Death of a Salesman" was done, where O'Neill worked, where "The Glass Menagerie" and "A Streetcar Named Desire" came. And then suddenly there was an Off Broadway, which became a much more viable place for serious plays. Broadway is the place where tourists come. When I was a kid at Yale Drama School back in the 60's, you dreamed about having a play on Broadway. I don't think anybody dreams that today. You dream of having a play at the Seattle Rep, or Louisville, or the Goodman or Trinity Rep. That's where the theater is, and that's healthy.
The only dangerous thing about it is that so much of the for-profit theater is learning to use the not-for-profit theater as a way of developing for-profit pieces. Another major problem is that so many producers are becoming fearful. The question is not where are the new playwrights? Or where are the new actors? It's where are the new producers who know how to produce a play, understand the writer's intention and protect that?
TERRENCE McNALLY. I do dream of having a play on Broadway, John. It doesn't mean my dream is going to come true. But it's a valid dream. Broadway theaters are still the best real estate in Manhattan in which to have our plays performed. It's easy to bash Broadway.
I don't think we have two theaters. What has happened is that the plays that used to be done on Broadway, by writers of my generation, we've taken over Off Broadway. There was room for us when I began writing. Now, the younger generation finds it very hard to get established even Off Broadway. The Off Broadway movement was a significant change in our theater. But something has to be done about the economics of all theater, where they are less and less willing to take chances on the Terrence McNallys.
LANFORD WILSON. I have a play that could possibly come to Broadway from the Hartford Stage and it terrifies me that theater people seem to know more about West Ireland than they know about the Midwest.
PAULA VOGEL. When we talk about the future of the American theater we have to talk about the future of our economic structure. There is none supporting the theater. And that is becoming an increasing concern. Not only is it exorbitant to produce in New York, it's exorbitant everywhere. And the funding is tied up with the attitude of government officials, who can do a kind of benign censorship. So I think the whole economic infrastructure is at risk.
JON ROBIN BAITZ. I was having breakfast recently with someone who's a rock star and he's a friend. And he was sort of stoned. He looked at me real queer and said, "Why would a young person become a playwright?" He just didn't understand it. It had no context.
People are making little movies now for very little money. When you can make a smart, sexy movie for under $100,000 on digital video, it becomes what the theater might have been. It is evidence that the culture might have moved past the theater for now, to some extent. And maybe it will come back to the theater.
CHRISTOPHER DURANG. As long as I've been around the theater, which is 25 years, everyone is always saying the theater is dying, blah-blah-blah. And yes it is. On the other hand, will it really end? If somebody wants to make a movie, maybe they're not meant to be a playwright.
BAITZ. I'm not saying it's over. I'm saying that this priesthood of being a playwright is sort of straining to survive.
DRUKMAN. But are you making a smart, sexy little comedy for under $100,000?
BAITZ. I can't write about sex. I would if I could. There's just a white noise in here.
WENDY KESSELMAN. But Robbie, if you have to write about something, you have to write about it. For many people, the theater is the only way to really write that. It can be put into a film but it's never quite the same. And I agree with Terrence about the dream -- now, having been on Broadway as the adapter of "The Diary of Anne Frank," revived in 1997 , I can't wait to go back.
AUGUST WILSON. Having had six plays on Broadway, I would hate to see playwrights abandon it. I think it's vital, primarily because the American people see it as the mecca and because the straight play, or the honest, serious playwright, should be represented there.
However, when you talk about the future of the American theater, the question that comes to my mind is what is American about the American theater? We have, in American theater, an art form that is based on European dramatic values, an age-old dramaturgy that is handed down from the Greeks. That is the art form that I work in and one that I embrace.
America is a society that is multiracial and multicultural. Yet the values of the American theater are based on European-American values. Values of other cultures are not seen as valid. As an example, the theaters that seek to preserve and promote the values of African-Americans do not have relationships to the funding sources because they do not meet the sociological criteria of being European-American. If we're going to have something that is called an American theater, then we have to allow room for the esthetic values of Hispanics, for Asians, African-Americans, for all the racial and cultural groups that make up this society, as well as for the age-old tried-and-true values of the European-American.
The theater is a tool by which one makes a speech, if you will. And you can look at it in terms of the First Amendment right to free speech and the Constitutional guarantee of that. But the lack of access to funding that will allow you to make that speech can be considered a prior restraint.
DRUKMAN. That point is indisputable. But I think what Robbie was getting at is that this new, disaffected youthful artist will get together a group of people, a camera and a sound person. There isn't a comparably active, new avant-garde theater culture that is getting into the theater, which is reflected in Robbie's friend's comment, "Why would you ever be a playwright?" I'm not sure that's only a question of access.
VOGEL. Playwriting isn't a calling as much as it is a hazing process, in which one is actively discouraged by lack of funding, by poverty, by lack of access. Off Broadway is an impossible goal for playwrights who do not fit the mold of, yes, European dramaturgy.
DRUKMAN. How experimental are we allowing ourselves to be? And are plays getting edgier, or are they becoming more homogenized?
A. R. GURNEY. All really good theater has an element of anarchy underneath it, of chaos, of real darkness. I think that's why we go to the theater, to see people put on masks and try to put shape on that darkness. And that can be frightening not only to the standard bourgeois audiences that go to plays, but to the people who fund plays. And that's a serious thing. When a play becomes too dangerous, too tricky, then the odds are it might not be produced.
AUGUST WILSON. We are all contemporary playwrights and the plays we write are much different from plays that were written in, say, 1930 and 1949. That is because we have built on the tradition of American theater, which was at one time experimental. So the experiment proves the value of the tradition: the playwright sits down and uses or discards at will that which he is given by his predecessors.
If you look at American society in the last 30 years, we have made tremendous changes from the time when I was a young man until now, when I am in my middle age. I don't think there is a theater that has kept up with that change.
One of the things that playwrights wrestle with, to my mind, is the influence of television. We cannot go backward. Television is here. I think that playwrights are in the process of trying to figure out how to absorb that influence and to make dramatic art out of an influence that wasn't there in the 1920's.
GUARE. I was teaching at a university a few years ago and there were two people in the class who were remarkably talented, where you just say, "Ah, there is a future for the theater." They had gone so far into debt to take this writing program that when their two years were up, both of them went out to California just to get work in episodic television to pay off the enormous debt they had incurred. And they are lost because they are both now very successful. They have learned to work in a corporate voice and feel that the theater is elite because it's the voice of one playwright. They like the comfort of working on a half-hour comedy that goes into 50 million homes. Those two people will never come back to the theater. Now the amount of money that it costs just to go to Yale or N.Y.U. makes your future impossible, because you incur an extraordinary debt that then paralyzes your life paying that off.
AUGUST WILSON. There is something disturbing about what you're saying.
GUARE. Which is?
AUGUST WILSON. I never took a course, for instance, or went to school. I think there is something called an artist and either you want to be an artist or you don't.
GUARE. But what I'm saying is I don't think we live in a society that gives people the confidence to be an artist. I think that you're very, very, very rare.
AUGUST WILSON. It's something that you have to claim though. And you pay your dues or you do whatever is necessary. I'm sure that Picasso could have made more money in graphic art, but he was an artist.
VOGEL. It's still a matter of access. I don't think that film is necessarily the enemy. A while ago I had probably the most extraordinary teaching opportunity I'll ever get. I did a playwriting workshop for women in maximum security at an adult correctional institution. Those women did much better than my graduate playwrights. They had to. They wanted to. But they had never seen a play. They had never gone to the theater. We could only approach what theater was by talking about television and film, which was storytelling they know. So a lot of this to me is access.
Theater is unmediated between a living and breathing audience and a living and breathing actor on the stage. There are no lenses in between us. There is no director's cut. It's really about a community dialogue and that is why I think that access is made difficult in this society. Those women in maximum security don't become playwrights because they would tell us a thing or two about realism.
GURNEY. I think it has again to do with funding, but a different kind of funding, namely funding for our schools. Just the way the symphony orchestra is having a great deal of trouble now, because the high schools are not able to fund school orchestras and kids don't get a chance to pick up an instrument and learn what it is to be a part of an orchestra. It's the same thing with school drama programs. Somehow the schools have got to introduce the arts.
DRUKMAN. Are there ultimate taboos in American playwriting? Are there things you feel you shouldn't or mustn't----
DURANG. No elephant dung.
AUGUST WILSON. I can't think of a taboo I would impose upon myself. If I did, I'd write a play about it.
BAITZ. I think race is still a taboo. Even though people do write about it, it's very, very difficult, because there is so much rage and guilt. It's the great subject in this country, this race rage on all sides.
KESSELMAN. There is another interesting taboo I've come up against and that's children. If you portray children as having deep, serious emotions, you are absolutely lambasted.
LANFORD WILSON. Children know that they are lying and performing for their parents. But we can't write that.
KESSELMAN. The play I'm talking about involved a brother tormenting his little sister. When we had discussions with children in the audience -- "Have you ever done such a thing?" -- they were just thrilled to tell how they put their sisters in trunks and everything else.
AUGUST WILSON. I want to get back to something that Jon Robin Baitz said. I agree with you. I think race is a great subject and an important subject because it deals so much with the history of this country and the aftermath of that history, which we are all a living part of. Obviously I don't find it a taboo.
BAITZ. For me, I guess, the question is, Am I qualified to know what's in my heart? Am I qualified to speak for myself, even?
AUGUST WILSON. When you say race, you are not just talking about African-Americans. You are a member of a race also.
VOGEL. When we talk about writing about race, I keep going back to when Anna Deavere Smith told me that strangers are much more likely to talk to each other about sex than race. It's absolutely true. In another conversation she said white writers have to do the race work. It can't just be writers of color, in terms of reading and thinking it through. And that is when I started thinking about this. It's not a matter of research. It's a matter of thinking it through carefully so that you can stand on the ground from where you write in terms of race. I think that white writers -- whether it's guilt or not wanting to go through that journey -- we're in the state of denial.
BAITZ. To me, I feel that black people and white people in this country are still terrified of one another on a basic, almost a -- to steal a David Hare phrase -- mineral level. I want to write about that. I think we understand one another even less as the century ends. And the divide becomes even bigger. So, as a taboo, the longer you're silent, the harder it is to grasp.
LANFORD WILSON. Well, art is born out of, among other things, necessity. Writing a play for me is like walking down this landscape of the self. Many things that you confront sometimes are not the best parts of yourself. But you have to be willing to deal with them so that you emerge at the end with a brighter and stronger spirit, ready to go through the next journey.

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
Atlantic City Is Expanding a Renewal Area

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
THE renewal of Atlantic City's Northwest Inlet oceanfront neighborhood, which since 1987 has transformed a ragged urban wasteland into a bright new enclave, is being extended inland to 20 adjacent blighted blocks.
The latest redevelopment program, for what is known as the "uptown area," calls for filling the vacant lots and replacing the smattering of shuttered buildings bounded by Adriatic, Massachusetts, Atlantic and Tennessee Avenues with 600 mixed-income, rental and for-sale housing units. The first single-family-home project, which is to start in December, will start with eight houses based on original designs by Frank Lloyd Wright for American System Built Homes, the architect's early 20th century version of prefabricated affordable housing. The rest of the 40-home first phase, which will be called Washington Square and will also be based on Wright designs, may ultimately include a total of 135 homes. 
 Following a national trend, 214 of the 600 new residences will replace an equal number of public housing units in two of the area's existing mid-rise projects, which will be razed. Twenty-two replacement units currently under way are for-sale, side-by-side two-family houses. The remaining 192 units, mostly rentals, will also be side-by-side two-families.
Like the Northwest Inlet, the uptown redevelopment program, which is expected to cost $200 million and take five years to complete, is being spearheaded by the state's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, with the city as a partner. The authority was created under a 1984 law to channel casino money into urban-renewal projects.
The redevelopment program, said Mayor James Whelan, is "an opportunity to rebuild another neighborhood and will go a long way in removing blight and redefining Atlantic City as a place where people want to live."
It will also enhance the corridor leading to the inlet and the nearby casinos, a corridor that now entails "passing through some rough neighborhoods," said James Kennedy, executive director of the casino authority. "It was the logical next place to develop," he said.
Washington Square, he said, will be "a selling point," given its link to Wright. "In a town that has seen a lot of its history torn down the project will create a neighborhood that could have been built in 1917," Mr. Kennedy said.
Financing for the overall uptown redevelopment includes $90 million that will come from the city's 12 casinos, each of which must put 1.25 percent of its gross annual gaming revenue for 25 years into bonds issued by the authority at below-market rates for projects the authority approves.
Atlantic City also received a $35 million federal grant for the public housing component, Mr. Kennedy said, adding that the rest of the funds would come from the city and the proceeds from sales of units in the project.
Mayor Whelan said the redevelopment approach for the uptown area would be different from the one used in the inlet. "There," he said, "everything was knocked down and rebuilt, because there wasn't a lot worth salvaging."
This time, he said, the redevelopment will fit into the neighborhood; commercial, residential and community structures -- such as churches -- that are solid will remain. Because of planned road improvements, such as the widening of North Carolina Avenue, some businesses will be relocated, but to somewhere else in the neighborhood, the Mayor said.
Another departure is Washington Square. Many say the project will bring a distinct housing product to the city and, it is hoped, a bit of national fanfare.
While not replicating the original American System Built Homes, the houses will be based on its designs and be updated. And they will be put in use for the first time on the East Coast, according to Taliesin Architects, the firm that traces its heritage back to the architectural practice started by Wright in 1893. The firm, which will execute the designs for Washington Square, is part of the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation and has its southwestern headquarters, along with the foundation and an architecture school, at Taliesin West, a 600-acre campus in Scottsdale, Ariz.
THE project's up to $15 million 40-home first phase will be constructed by a joint venture between Claremont/ NFF of Far Hills and the Rubicon Companies L.L.C of West Orange. Paul Cocoziello, who is Rubicon's president and is credited with the idea of bringing American System Built Homes to the city said: "We saw it as a perfect fit."
Taliesin allows the use of the designs for a licensing fee, which Mr. Cocoziello paid. His firm is able to build such homes in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states.
In 1917, Wright, designed American System Built Homes in an effort to make homes affordable to moderate-income people. They were intended to fit on urban infill lots and to be built as modular or prefabricated homes.
The architect teamed with the Richards Company, a lumber company in Milwaukee, which precut, numbered and bundled wood panels and marketed them as housing kits that could be trucked to and assembled on the buyer's lot. The venture lasted until 1920, when it was cut short by the poor economy after World War I. It resulted in 11 homes in the Chicago and Milwaukee areas costing $1,200 each, according to Nirmal Mangal, a Taliesin architect in charge of the Washington Square project.
These homes differ from Wright's Usonian Homes, which while also considered affordable, were designed for specific clients in the post-World War I years. Sixteen Usonian homes can still be found in New York communities, particularly Pleasantville in Westchester County.
The Washington Square homes will reflect Wright's original designs for American System Built Homes, but follow current construction codes, said Mr. Mangal.
Mr. Mangal said his firm got involved with the project because "we want to continue to address Mr. Wright's issue of affordable housing." The homes, which are spacious, "still look contemporary," he added.
While the Washington Square homes will be modified for their seashore setting and will feature such modern amenities as a garage, Mr. Mangal said the architect's trademark uses of large overhangs, sloped or flat roofs and earthtone colors would be visible. The houses will also have front and rear porches to encourage interaction among residents. Construction of all the houses will be a combination of stick-built and prefabrication, Mr. Mangal said.
Construction of the first homes, with two and three bedrooms and 1,260 to 1,630 square feet, is to start after the Atlantic City Planning Board approves the project, which is expected next month. They will rise on a vacant lot along Tennessee Avenue and will sell for $125,000 to $150,000.
There already is a list of six people who want to buy the homes, said Alvin Taliaferro Jr., executive director of Vision 2000, a community-based organization that is the project's nonprofit sponsor.
Some of the Washington Square homes will also incorporate Wright's designs for wood trim, light fixtures and furniture. They will be reserved for nonprofit groups, like Vision 2000, said Mr. Kennedy of the casino authority.
Meanwhile, he said, his agency continues to acquire land -- some of which it or the city's public housing authority already owns -- for the rest of Washington Square as well as for the overall uptown redevelopment project.
Mr. Taliaferro said neighborhood residents "are excited so far about the first project." As for the overall redevelopment, he added, "we will work to insure community residents are served."
Development continues in the Northwest Inlet, where 600 homes have been built and 400 more are planned. One project under way along Gardner's Basin lagoon is Smugglers Cove, which consists of five separate components meant to preserve Atlantic City's maritime history. The components include six homes, each with 1,400 square feet on average, that will feature architectural details, like wide roof eaves, evocative of bungalows in the 1920's and 10 waterside lots for sale at $150,000 whose buyers must build homes according to certain architectural guidelines.
Mr. Kennedy said that redeveloping the Inlet and uptown areas was "like a giant puzzle."
"We started on the outside with the more desirable and valuable waterside land and now are moving to the city's center," he explained.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In /Morristown, N.J.;
Presence of the Past in a Lively Downtown

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
HISTORIC Morristown, twice George Washington's headquarters in the Revolutionary War, is in the midst of a downtown revival as retail chains return and the demand for housing soars after years of stagnation.
"Five years ago, many of our stores and offices were vacant," said Mayor John J. DeLaney. "Now we have 150 new businesses and new apartment buildings are being leased before completion." 
 "People call from all over the world, looking for houses," said Kathryn R. Godby, a local independent real estate broker. "Multinationals in the area, including AT&T and Allied Signal, are transferring people into Morris County and telling them that Morristown is a good place to raise families."
And the central business district, consisting of Park Avenue, South Street, Speedwell Avenue and Washington Street, is buzzing with a mixture of small shops, banks and chain stores. Its five dozen restaurants do a thriving lunch trade on the 60,000 people who funnel into town daily to work in offices in this Morris County seat. Some of those offices are headquarters or major facilities of 70 Fortune 500 companies, according to Michael Fabrizio, executive director of the Morristown Partnership, a quasi-public economic development agency.
Among the more popular restaurants are the Grand Cafe (French) on Washington Street, Settebello Il Caffe (Italian) on Cattano Avenue and La Campagna (Italian) on Elm Street. The Community Theater of Morristown, which holds 80 performances annually in a partially renovated old 1,200-seat movie house, keeps restaurants busy on many nights and weekends.
The Mayor credits the Morristown Partnership with polishing the town's image by adding new street lights, renovating sidewalks and curbs and recruiting major chains, such as Starbucks, GapKids and Footlocker, to fill vacancies. The town also benefits from the arrival three years ago of New Jersey Transit's Midtown Direct rail service, which bypasses Hoboken and shortens the trip into Penn Station by one third, to one hour.
The downtown radiates from a trapezoidal green that was set aside by the town's first Presbyterian settlers, who arrived from New England in 1715. Large, older homes on tree-lined streets, 30 houses of worship, national historic sites and good schools are among Morristown's attractions.
Last week just 23 houses were on the market, ranging in price from $135,000 for a home that needs work in the Second Ward to $795,000 for new construction on Overlook Road, near the Spring Brook Country Club, most of which is in Morris Township.
Housing prices have risen by more than 10 percent over the past 12 months, according to Phyllis Lunetta, a broker at Coldwell Banker on South Street. Homes in the historic district, which begins at the green and encompasses nearly half the buildings in town, fetch the highest prices. Some of those houses have sold for nearly $800,000, with the new owners investing an equal amount in upgrades.
"People want to be able to walk to everything," Ms. Godby explained. "And they like purchasing something unique."
LIKE many other buyers, John M. Russo, a training manager at a credit union in nearby Bedminster, willingly paid a premium for his 1920's three-bedroom colonial on Georgian Road, on the fringe of the historic district in July. The house, which has wide, chestnut moldings, a richly detailed wooden mantel over the fireplace and original brass doorknobs, cost $368,000.
"I wanted an old house with character, a real downtown with small shops and good restaurants, and easy access to highways," Mr. Russo explained. "I had already lost one Morristown house by not bidding in time. This house came on the market at 11 A.M. and by 3 P.M. we were signing a contract."
Morristown has a total of 550 condominium units, mainly in 10 complexes of 20 or more units. The largest is the 141-unit Windmill Pond town-house complex, off James Street. which was built in 1980 with two- and three-bedroom units. A three-bedroom is currently listed at $274,900.
Mayor DeLaney said that 50 percent of Morristown's residents are renters. The largest new rental project is the two-year-old Chancery Square, a 131-unit complex of one- and two-bedroom luxury units on Cattano Avenue. Rents range from $1,100 to $1,800 and the building was filled shortly after the apartments were put on offer, the Mayor said. In older structures, such as the 270-unit Jacob Ford Village garden apartment complex off Valley View Drive, one-bedrooms rent for $690 to $900 and two-bedrooms for $750 to $1,200.
Just south of the historic district, on Washington Place, is the three-acre Washington Headquarters site, with its Headquarters Museum (which houses Revolutionary War relics) and the Ford Mansion, where Washington wintered in 1777 and 1780 while his troops were camped in nearby Jockey Hollow in Harding Township. The park and Jockey Hollow are two of four Morristown area historic sites administered by the National Park Service. The others are the New Jersey Brigade Encampment in Bernardsville and the 20-acre Fort Nonsense site, off Ann Street in Morristown, where in 1780 the Continentals built earthen fortifications that they regarded as busywork. Admission to the Headquarters Museum, Ford Mansion and Jockey Hollow, which are open daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., is $4 for adults, free for children under 16.
The other major historical site is the 7.5-acre Historic Speedwell Village, off Speedwell Avenue. It is on the National Register of Historic Places as the site of the 19th-century Speedwell Iron Works and the place where the telegraph was perfected by Samuel F. B. Morse and Alfred Vail in 1838.
The eight buildings include the Vail House mansion, which shows life in the 1840's, and the S.S. Savannah Exhibit, with artifacts from the first steamship to cross the Atlantic (in 1819). Speedwell is open Sunday and Thursday 1 to 4 P.M. Admission is $5 for adults and $3 for children under 18.
Morristown is completely surrounded by Morris Township, which shares the 4,500-student Morris School District. It has three K-2 schools, three 3-5 schools, Freylinghuysen Middle School for grades 6-8, and the 1,300-student Morristown High School, which is also attended by students from nearby Morris Plains.
In addition, the district has the K-5 Normandy Park Multiage Magnet School, where students are not marked and are allowed to progress in accordance with their abilities, rather than their ages. In addition to its regular public schools, Morristown is home to the Unity Charter School, a 90-student K-8 public school that stresses environmentalism.
Computers are introduced in kindergarten, with at least one terminal in every elementary school classroom. The middle school has more than 100 computers for its 900 students and the high school has nine computer laboratories.
Morristown High School offers 14 advanced placement courses in English, history, the sciences, mathematics and foreign languages. Among its many amenities are television and radio studios and an indoor swimming pool. The school competes in 27 interscholastic sports, including baseball, soccer, football, track, fencing, field hockey, hockey and lacrosse.
Dr. Dwight R. Pfennig, the Superintendent of Schools, says that the high school has produced two winners of the prestigious Westinghouse Science awards, a competition whose name was changed in 1998 to the Intel Science Talent Search, and last June's 270-student graduating class earned more than $1 million worth of scholarships. Five students were semifinalists in the National Merit Scholarship test and 88 percent of the graduates went on to higher education. On the SAT Morristown seniors scored a joint verbal/mathematics average of 1,059, which was 54 points above the state's average and 43 points over the national average.
LOCAL private schools include the 300-student k-8 Peck School on South Street, with annual tuition ranging from $11,550 to $15,400; the 440-student 6-12 Morristown-Beard School on Whippany Road, with tuition of $17,700; the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary Roman Catholic school for nursery through grade 8, where tuition is $2,620 for parishioners and $3,024 for nonparishioners, and the Montessori Children's House on Cutler Street for pre-k-6, which costs $4,575 for half-day students and $7,700 for full-day students.
Although most residents rate Morristown positively, it is not without problems. The highway system that eases the commute to work in Morris County and New York City also snarls traffic during rush hours, as motorists leave the two Morristown exits off Interstate 287, heading for nearby communities.
Municipal taxes have been raised by 12 percent in each of the previous two years and are expected to rise by 6 percent this year, as the town attempts to pay off a $100 million debt incurred over the last 20 years. Racial tensions are near the surface between a group in the mainly minority Second Ward and the municipal government over a former junkyard in a flood zone that residents want used for low- and moderate-income housing and a community center. And development pressures in the historic center of town are pitting preservationists against developers who want to build high-rise apartment complexes.
"We have traffic because we have activity," says Mayor DeLaney. "And the development pressures in the Second Ward and the Historic District are both good, because it shows that people are involved."

HOME OF SANTA'S HELPER: Among the many well-preserved 19th-century homes in Morristown is Villa Fontana, which was bought by the political cartoonist Thomas Nast in 1872. Nast created the Republican elephant, the Democratic donkey, Uncle Sam and the Tammany Tiger, which became a symbol of corruption in New York City government. He also created the round-bellied, red-suited, white-bearded image of Santa Claus when he illustrated Clement Clarke Moore's "A Visit From St. Nicholas." Among the luminaries who visited the Nast home on MacCulloch Avenue were Mark Twain and Ulysses S. Grant.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
Reckson Invests Heavily in Its Manhattan Portfolio

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
FOR several years after breaking out of its home base on Long Island, Reckson Associates Realty Corporation conspicuously avoided New York City. In a 1996 interview, Scott Rechler, the company's president, defined its operating territory as "within a 50 mile radius of Manhattan with Manhattan and the boroughs carved out."
But now the company is not only heavily invested in Manhattan but is continuing to buy New York properties at a time when many other real estate investment trusts have been lying low because of the depressed prices of their shares. Earlier this month Reckson said it had reached an agreement to acquire 1350 Avenue of the Americas, a 540,000 square foot office building at 55th Street, for $126.5 million. 
 That boosted the company's Manhattan portfolio to 3.5 million square feet, out of a total of 25 million square feet in the New York metropolitan area.
Mr. Rechler now says that greater exposure to the other suburbs of the metropolitan area convinced him that the Long Island economy he grew up in is unique and isolated from the city. Westchester and Fairfield Counties and the New York City suburbs of New Jersey, he said, are much more closely linked to the city, making it an advantage to own property both locations.
"As we expanded in the rest of the tristate area, it became clear how important Manhattan is to the marketplace in terms of tenant flows," he said. For example, he said, 1350 Avenue of the Americas will be marketed as a high profile Manhattan satellite office for suburban-based companies because of its location and the ability to divide the floors into smaller spaces.
He said that population and office space statistics supported the argument that the Long Island economy was more self-sustaining than others in the city's suburbs. While Long Island has about 25 million square feet of office space for a population of 2.7 million, he said, Westchester County has a similar amount of office space, but a population of only about 800,000. This, he said, shows that Westchester is strongly linked to a larger, regional economy.
As a result of identifying this linkage between New York and its western and northern suburbs, Mr. Rechler said, Reckson is the only area REIT to own Class A office space both in the city and along its fringes.
But Mr. Rechler concedes that doing business in Manhattan has been a different undertaking than the company's operations in the suburbs.
Reckson grew out of a family-owned development and management company based in Melville, N.Y., that was transformed into a REIT that sold shares to the public for the first time in 1995. As it went on to make acquisitions in Westchester and Fairfield Counties and in New Jersey many of its early targets were similarly family owned and managed businesses. Reckson acquired the F.D. Rich organization in Fairfield County, Halpern Enterprises in Westchester and Sym Heller in New Jersey and used them as the basis for its expansion in those markets.
Some of these companies had been weakened by the recession of the early 90's and were happy to join forces with a REIT that had access to capital. But the wealthy, proudly independent real estate barons of Manhattan were not about to give up their independence to a suburban upstart.
Mr. Rechler said he had spent a year trying to buy an existing, family-run company in the city without success. "We met with all the major landlords," he said. "But in Manhattan, the major players are celebrities in their own right."
RECKSON'S opportunity came when Tower Realty Trust, a Manhattan-based REIT that had not found favor on Wall Street, became available. Recksonoriginally planned the acquisition in conjunction with another REIT, Crescent Real Estate Equities of Fort Worth, but pressed ahead on its own when Crescent retreated, paying $680 million in stock, cash and the assumption of debt for Tower's 4.6 million square feet of property.
Tower was a mixed bag of Class A and B properties in Manhattan with additional office developments in Arizona and Florida. In the last year, Reckson sold the Class B properties, which included buildings at 286, 290 and 292 Madison Avenue and 90 Broad Street, to S.L. Green Realty Corporation, a Manhattan-based REIT specializing in such properties. The Arizona and Florida projects were also sold.
That left Reckson with a core of Class A properties, including buildings at 100 Wall Street, 810 Seventh Avenue and Tower 45 at 120 West 45th Street. Since then the company has also acquired the building at 919 Third Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets.
Tower's management did not come with the deal and analysts said the success of the transaction could depend on finding a manager savvy in the ways of Manhattan real estate.
Even if Mr. Rechler had been successful in acquiring one of the privately owned real estate companies in Manhattan, keeping the management in place might not have been as successful as in the suburbs. When Vornado Realty Trust, a Saddle Brook, N.J.-based REIT, bought the Mendik Company in early 1997, its chairman , Bernard H. Mendik was named co-chairman of Vornado along with Steven Roth. But that arrangement only lasted about a year and a half, before Mr. Mendik resigned.
Subsequently, Mr. Mendik said he preferred to operate independently rather than as part of a corporate structure.
Mr. Rechler chose Philip M. Waterman 3d, a managing director of Tishman Speyer Properties, to manage Reckson's Manhattan operations. The privately held Tishman Speyer manages and has partial ownership in such well known New York landmarks as Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building.
Mr. Waterman, who is known as Tod, said he had been initially skeptical that he would be given the latitude to manage the business in Manhattan. The glamour of the market, he feared, would be too much for executives in Melville to resist the temptation to get involved.
But Mr. Rechler said his job was to manage the broad swath of Reckson's business, not the particulars of any individual market. "I'm a big delegator," he said. "As long as we are the landlord of choice in our markets, I don't have an interest in the details."
Although the price of Reckson's shares, like most REIT's, has been battered by the stock market -- it was trading recently at about $18 a share, near its low for the year -- the company is still actively shopping for property. The company keeps its war chest funded by selling properties that are not core to its business or where it stands to make a tidy profit. In addition to the Tower dispositions, the company recently concluded the sale of some industrial properties for $310 million.
Mr. Waterman said there were still some bargains to be had in Manhattan, despite the current high values established properties are fetching. He said Reckson is looking for complicated, messy deals that other REIT's tend to avoid.
He noted that the Tower deal had to be restructured after Crescent withdrew as an active participant. The building at 919 Third Avenue involved acquiring a mortgage that was in default from a group of Japanese investors. The long distance negotiations will eventually give Reckson ownership of the property at a discount from its face value, he said, but it is not as uncomplicated as some investors prefer.
The deal to buy 1350 Avenue of the Americas, Mr. Rechler said, included negotiations involving 50 members of the Minskoff family, which had been unsuccessful in previous attempts to sell the property. "We only allocate time and capital to complicated investments," he said. "We think the ability to execute these transactions is a competitive advantage."
