HEADLINE: The Father of Parks, and Traffic

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
ROBERT A. CARO was running late, terribly late. Driving from the Bronx to Long Island to interview Robert Moses for what would become the book "The Power Broker," Mr. Caro had gotten hopelessly stuck in traffic -- on the very network of bridges and expressways that Moses had built.
Although the incident happened some three decades ago, Mr. Caro still describes it as if it were yesterday. In an animated interview last week, his eyes flashed as he leaned forward, perched on the edge of a wide plush chair beside a marble fireplace in his apartment on Central Park West. 
 When he belatedly arrived at Moses' cottage in on that long-ago day, Mr. Caro recalled, he apologized for the delay and tried to explain about the snarled roads. But the imperious Moses would not hear of it.
"Traffic jam -- on the Long Island Expressway?" Moses thundered incredulously. "At this hour?" Then he slammed his hand down on the table with a startling bang and roared: "Nonsense!"
"End of discussion," Mr. Caro recalled.
Their session that day was one of seven interviews that Moses granted before he broke off his cooperation on the book, closed his files, ordered his aides to clam up and otherwise did his utmost to thwart the determined young author.
Ultimately, of course, Mr. Caro got the last word -- an epic 650,000 last words, to be exact. This month is the 25th anniversary of the publication of "The Power Broker" (Knopf, 1974). Despite attacks by Moses and other critics over the years, the book has become as much of an icon in the literary and political science worlds as any of Moses's monumental projects is in the field of public works.
Although the book is subtitled "Robert Moses and the Fall of New York," it is also about the rise of Long Island and Moses's role in molding suburban life here. "The Power Broker" forever changed the perception of Long Island as well as of its Master Builder.
"Long Island is shaped the way it is largely because of Robert Moses," Mr. Caro said. "Long Island is a perfect example of how political power shapes people's lives every day."
The Island played a seminal part in Moses's career and in the birth of Mr. Caro's book. What would become Moses's statewide empire, extending to hydroelectric power plants on the Canadian border, really began on the Island. His creation of Jones Beach State Park in the 1920's as a playground for the sweltering working-class families of the city was a phenomenal smash hit with the public and politicians alike. Moses followed it with numerous other parks across Nassau and Suffolk Counties, and the system of parkways and expressways to get there.
"His dream of Jones Beach and the other state parks was really quite wonderful," Mr. Caro said. "He preserved open space, and Long Island still enjoys it today. It is one of the most noble uses of power to create something worthwhile that I ever heard of.
"But" -- and in Mr. Caro's view it is a gigantic but -- "Moses also had this vision of Long Island exemplified by the automobile and the roads, and he wanted single-family, low-density suburbs." The result was endless sprawl, stunted mass transit, ailing village downtowns, traffic congestion and a shortage of varied housing.
Spurning the pleas of other planners, whom he despised, Moses blocked forever the use of the Long Island Expressway's median for a new commuter rail line. He stubbornly persisted as the champion of the automobile, Mr. Caro said, long after it was clear that "by building more highways, you would only create more congestion." He and other critics say that the rail line could have spawned adjacent apartment houses offering modest-priced rentals and enough density to promote thriving village centers while still allowing for single-family homes nearby and good train service for all.
"If Moses hadn't done certain things that were only his decision, Long Island would have a spine," Mr. Caro said. "Long Island would be a very different place today."
There would be more apartments that are sorely needed by retirees, singles, young couples and lower-paid service workers, he said. Traffic would be reduced.
"There would still be congestion, but not nearly as much," he said, "and there would be the amenities of downtowns -- bookstores, museums, live theaters."
Moses had strong ties to Long Island. When not at his home in Manhattan or his headquarters on Randall's Island beneath his Triborough Bridge, he spent much of his time living near the water in Oak Beach and in his office in Belmont Lake State Park.
Numerically, Moses was involved in far more projects in the city. His works there included the United Nations headquarters, Kennedy International Airport, Shea Stadium, Lincoln Center, Riverside Park, the Central Park Zoo, the Grand Central Parkway, Stuyvesant Town and Co-op City, to name but a few.
"But Long Island is probably the place you can see, in the clearest form, the shaping from his hand, because he was working on a tabula rasa," Mr. Caro said. The Island "was ripe for the imposition of a vision."
Like Moses, Mr. Caro found Long Island to be the stage for a turning point in his career. A Princeton graduate, he developed as a star reporter at Newsday and became increasingly intrigued at how often he encountered the vast Moses octopus.
"Nobody knew how he got his power," he said. "I would sit at Newsday and get a press release saying something about City Parks Commissioner Moses -- and what did that have to do with parkways on Long Island? -- or about Triborough Authority Chairman Moses -- and what did that have to do with upstate electric plants? This was man who had never been elected to anything and had more power than people who had been elected."
A Carnegie fellowship and an advance of a few thousand dollars (he says he no longer remembers the exact amount) from Simon & Schuster propelled Mr. Caro into starting the book, which he estimated would take nine months. But he did not finish it until seven years later, nearly going bankrupt in the process. To scrimp, he and his wife, Ina, sold their house in Roslyn and moved to Riverdale in the Bronx and still had trouble making the rent. She worked to support them and also helped in the reporting.
After Mr. Caro drafted a major portion of the book, his editors praised it but said it was not marketable. "They said, 'Nobody's going to buy a book about Robert Moses,' " he said. "It was a terrible night."
But when it came out, the book got a sensational reception. It won the Pulitzer Prize for biography and garnered numerous other awards. The former Times reporter David Halberstam said it was "surely the greatest book ever written about a city."
The executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, who was among Mr. Caro's hundreds of sources, said: "If I were limited in a political science course to assigning only one book, without hesitation, I would say this is the book. It's the definitive book on New York politics and on the universal clues to how politics operates."
"The Power Broker" has been extolled as a groundbreaking work of history, biography and investigative reporting. It is required reading at hundreds of colleges for courses ranging from political science to urban planning to transportation to journalism.
Knopf does not disclose sales figures, but the book has accomplished the rare publishing feat of remaining in print continuously for a quarter century, in both hard cover and paperback. "It's still a big thrill to see it in the bookstores, to see people reading it," Mr. Caro said.
Moses, who died in 1981 at the age of 92, loathed it. Although the book hailed him as "America's greatest builder" and credited him with $27 billion worth of projects in 1968 dollar values, the book also portrayed him as antidemocratic, corrupted by power, ruthless, vindictive, underhanded and racist. The book says he sabotaged mass transit, enforced de facto segregation by race and class, bulldozed neighborhoods and callously displaced half a million New Yorkers under the banner of slum clearance, urban renewal, road construction and assorted other civic improvements.
In his own defense, Moses issued a rebuttal. "I raise my stein to the builder who can remove ghettos without moving people," he said, "as I hail the chef who can make omelets without breaking eggs."
Other critics called the book "tendentious," "endlessly repetitious" and lacking historical perspective. Dr. Barbara M. Kelly, curator of the Long Island Studies Institute at Hofstra University, praised the book as highly informative but said: "I think he is overly hard on Moses. If you look at our beaches and compare to what happened to Atlantic City or Cape Cod, the man has been redeemed."
Robert W. Greene, a Pulitzer Prize-winning former reporter and editor at Newsday who describes himself as a friendly competitor and admirer of Mr. Caro, said that "he captured Moses brilliantly," but added: "I would argue that Moses, for all his occasional faults, was a magnificent planner. I think his longterm effect was positive, while Bob makes a more negative assessment, but those are judgment calls."
Kenneth Jackson, an urban history professor at Columbia University, has said that the book ascribes too much significance to Moses. Federal highway and housing policies and societal trends were as much responsible for the rise of modern suburban structure as anything Moses himself did, the professor said.
And some critics have said that the racial lines in Moses's policies should be viewed as reflecting an era in which the white establishment in general fostered separation for blacks, as evidenced by Federal housing rules and the segregated military.
But Mr. Caro stands by his book. Even with the benefit of a quarter century's worth of hindsight, there is nothing he would delete, he said, and there has even been talk of restoring about 400,000 words that were cut from the original manuscript, though that apparently will not happen. "I really can't bear to go back," he said.
While the subtitle's reference to "the Fall of New York City" might seem dated in an era of falling crime, the Wall Street boom and the Disneyfication of Times Square, Mr. Caro said it accurately described the city's prior decades of decline. He views the persistent problems of discrimination, unemployment, poverty and slums as products, in part, of Moses policies.
"Academics are always writing these articles attacking one aspect or another of the book," Mr. Caro said, shrugging off the criticisms.
He is especially emphatic on the racial issue. He recalled that Moses referred to minority groups and the poor as "the animals." His book recounts how Moses barred a rail spur to Jones Beach, then built low overpasses over many of the parkways to keep buses out. And when some buses with blacks circumvented those obstacles, they were given a hard time on required permits and were shunted off to more distant beaches.
"With past immigrant groups, the city always made this effort, with the Irish and Italians, to reach out and bring them into the fabric of the city," Mr. Caro said. "Because of Moses, that really was not done for 40 years" for black and Hispanic residents.
Mr. Caro himself voices mixed feelings about Moses. "I was awed by him, astonished by his intelligence, by his ability to see a whole vast area as a region," he said. Unlike anyone before or since, Moses was able to build many major projects, he said. "But I was also horrified to see the destruction in East Tremont," a Bronx neighborhood devastated by the construction of Moses' Cross Bronx Expressway.
"You knew you were in the presence of genius," Mr. Caro said, "but you also knew you were in the presence of a genius who had gone blind. He opened the Triborough Bridge, and it just made things worse for traffic. He opened the Whitestone, and it made things worse. He opened the Throgs Neck, and they still got worse. Then he wanted the next one at Oyster Bay. If he had his way, he would have built bridges every few miles all the way to Orient Point."
If Moses saw himself as society's great omelet chef, Mr. Caro took as his mission the examination of the shattered shells and broken yolks. "If you really want to show power in its larger aspects, you need to show the effects on the powerless, for good or ill -- the human cost of public works," he said. "That's what I try to do, show not only how power works but its effect on people."
The success of the Moses book unleashed Mr. Caro on an even bigger subject who wielded power on a national and even international canvas: Lyndon B. Johnson. He is several months from completing his third volume on Johnson -- the first two were award winners -- and a fourth installment awaits.
Mr. Caro, who turned 64 yesterday, still works hard but enjoys the comfort of a second home in East Hampton -- which keeps him in touch with Long Island's ever worsening traffic jams.
Some things about Moses remain a mystery -- why, for example, the man who built 416 miles of green, leafy parkways never learned to drive. If there is a Rosebud answer, it has been lost.
"As he became powerful, of course he was chauffeured everywhere," Mr. Caro said. "For him, driving was a different experience than for most of the rest of us."

HEADLINE: Hiding a Secret? Not From Your Garbageman

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: COPIAGUE

 BODY:
THERE is perhaps only one other professional who knows as much about you as your bartender. This stranger knows something about your spouse's morning habits; he knows the cuckold, the insomniac, the moneyed, the repossessed and the hammer-toed. He knows your brand of breath mint and he knows your shoe size.
This stranger is your garbage man. Specifically the suburban garbage man. And the suburban garbage man knows many things about you because he spends the dark hours of the day auguring your tea leaves and coffee grounds, piecing together your private life by the public disposal of your detritus. 
 "Pretty much we just lift it," says Pete Giammona, 32, a nimble-minded, nimble-footed sanitation man who has been driving a garbage rig for his entire adult life. "But we know more about people than the city sanitation guys because we're, like, intimate with their waste. Out here, it doesn't sit around in Dumpsters or big plastic piles, it sits in front of your house so there's no doubt about who it belongs to. And when you're lifting the same people's garbage over and over again, you start noticing things."
Mr. Giammona and his two-man crew comb the suburban streets of Babylon in a large Mack truck. They begin in dark morning hours when the drunks return home and the working stiffs climb into their leased cars, steaming mugs of coffee in hand.
What they hear in these boisterous good times is a quiet desperation enveloping the suburbs, a profound longing to be something more, at least a little bit more than your neighbor. And some go hungry in this pursuit, the trash men say.
"You see some guy's got a Lexus in his driveway, but his wife's making him TV dinners," Mr. Giammona says as a robed man who had forgotten it's Tuesday chases his truck down, trash bag in tow.
One unassailable economic postulate of the street cleaner holds that the better the times, the fuller the garbage cans. And the garbage man says you're creating more rubbish than ever, a certain sign of the high-flying economy.
The government numbers confirm his calculations. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, American households created 151 million tons of garbage in 1980, about 180 million tons in 1987 and 216 million tons in 1997 -- 1,600 pounds per person. And it is anticipated that 1999 will be a record-setter for refuse. And suburbanites with their nice lawns and two car garages, create most of the nation's waste.
"The more affluent, the more effluent," says Nick Artz, an engineer with Franklin Associates, an environmental consulting firm that crunches garbage numbers for the Federal Government.
Garbage men, of course, don't have the time to ruminate about your pecuniary habits, but they are catching a subtle whiff riding in on the economic winds. It is a scent hardly noticed by the cigar-soaked nostrils on Wall Street. Consumers are spending, but they're spending money they don't have.
"Let's put it like this," says John Chase, a gargantuan man who hangs off the back of Mr. Giammona's Mack truck and goes by the handle Chocolate Thunder. "You seeing this house here, they threw away a whole dinette set. You got the boxes that the new dinette set came in. It came from Wal-Mart, not Ikea. That says to me that they're trying to save some money because they already spent most of the money they had."
According to the latest economic data, people are still spending feverishly. But that same data support Chocolate Thunder's analysis -- people don't have much in the bank. The trash man's economic forecast slants toward the belief that people will become more parsimonious with their pennies, causing a downturn in the economy. And while Wall Street middlemen are paid hundreds of thousands of dollars for their expert opinions in this area, the three men on a garbage rig are paid $15 an hour and charge no consulting fee.
A trash collector is not just an economist and a a demographer bundled up in muscle and topped off with a dash of Brut cologne. He's also a social worker.
Through the course of their route, the trash men will exchange greetings with a half-dozen elderly people. "Old people get lonely in the suburbs," Mr. Giammona says. "They're alone in their houses and a lot of them are too old to drive. Some days we might be the only people they see. And when they stop coming to the windows, you know something's wrong."
The sanitation worker almost always knows when Grandma has died. Whenever you see a couch tossed to the curb, an armoire in the alley, a settee in the street, it usually means that the matriarch has gone to meet the Maker.
"The grandson don't even care that he's throwing antiques away, he's just trying to empty the house out as fast as he can so he can sell it," Chocolate Thunder says.
As the sun begins to rise, the trash men gather around to inspect a lawn strewn with discarded bookshelves, clothes and cheap furniture. "Either the sheriff's been here, or they slipped out in the middle of the night," Mr. Giammona said. "Either way, they couldn't make the rent."
"Yeah, and they had babies too," tisked Chocolate Thunder in sympathy as he pitched a miniature sneaker into the maw of the compactor.
The suburban trash man knows where the immigrants live, especially the poorer ones. He knows that as many as five families live in a single family home so they can make the rent. "Rule of thumb is two people equal an extra garbage can," the shorn-headed Giammona says. "So when you're seeing seven or eight cans, you know there's a lot of people crammed in a house."
And then there is the housewife with the pill problem and two dozen cats. It seems like every subdivision has one, says Chocolate Thunder. "You can smell that house all the way down the street, and that's saying something, because I got my face stuck in the back of a garbage truck."

HEADLINE: The Market: Inventory Down, Prices Up

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP

 BODY:
BY some accounts, the house on New Rochelle's Van Meter Fenway was a mess, the sort of home that should have gone for a relative pittance to anyone who was ready to stomach perhaps $100,000 in repairs.
The house, according to real estate agents, needed everything: a shoring up of its foundation, a new kitchen, new flooring, new landscaping, a hard-core paint job on the outside and a new roof to replace the one that had caved in over the screened-in porch. 
 In a less frenzied real estate market, the house might have taken a year or more to sell. But within a week of being listed at $265,000 early last summer, it had more than 30 offers.
Ultimately, the house sold for $335,000, and little wonder: In New Rochelle, as in many communities within the New York metropolitan area, homes for sale, many brokers say, seem to have simply vanished.
To be sure, the problem appears more severe in certain communities and for homes within certain price ranges. And real estate agents report that there are still houses that are taking months to sell, usually because they are unusual properties that have highly specialized features, or because they are seriously overpriced.
For the most part, however, the New York metropolitan area appears to be in the midst of an inventory drought that many real estate professionals say they have never seen before. As a result, they say, homes coming on the market are more often than not spurring bidding wars that frequently leave both buyer and seller gasping in disbelief. In New Rochelle, for example, overnight price increases of 25 percent are no longer uncommon.
"We're not negotiating here -- it's like an auction," said Hiedi Ross, a sales agent for the local Century 21 King David office. She said that one of her current clients, a couple who have a mortgage commitment of $650,000, can't seem to land a house because they are persistently outbid by at least $20,000 every time a house comes up within their price range.
"We've never seen the market like this," said Gerald Ziering, president of the Century 21 King David office. "In most markets you usually have an inventory surplus that keeps moving along with the market, but in this case the surplus was eaten up about a year ago, so now there's nothing that we're carrying forward."
Of course, much of the inventory crunch can be pegged to a strong economy, as well as years of relatively low interest rates. But real estate brokers cite other factors as well.
First, because of rising land values, new-home construction is virtually nonexistent in many areas of suburban New York and the city itself, especially the most desirable sections; for the same reason, many homeowners are deciding to stay put and renovate rather than move. A contributing but statistically untrackable factor, brokers and others knowledgeable about the market say, is that the flush economy is spurring homeowners, mostly in the suburbs, to try to sell homes on their own rather than listing them with a broker and paying a subsequent fee. Brokers, meanwhile, are reacting to the inventory crunch by increasingly asking that listings be considered exclusives rather than sharing listings with their peers.
All this has already fostered a mountain of anecdotes. There are tales of brokers who used to routinely have dozens of listings at a time but now are hard-pressed to come up with enough to count on one hand; open houses that have long lines of potential buyers snaking out the door, and brokers who are slashing commissions -- perhaps by half -- to get listings. There are stories of smaller real estate firms that have gone out of business for lack of listings, as well as sellers who have become so overwhelmed by multiple bids for their homes that they have whisked them off the market. And finally, there are examples of just how dispirited many potential homebuyers have become.
"For the last three sales that I've had, the first question I was asked was how long had the house been on the market," said Katy Anastasio, the founder of Anastasio Associates Inc. Realtors in Huntington, N.Y., which has been in business since 1980. "It seems that if a house is on the market for longer than a week, then people wonder if there is something wrong with it."
In some communities, the current inventory drought apparently has less to do with fewer houses coming on the market overall, and more to do with lightning-fast turnover, which has caused so-called standing inventory to reach dismally low levels.
For example, Linda Hodge, a broker at the Greenwich, Conn., office for Preferred Properties, said that brokers in her area actually had slightly more listings for single-family residential properties -- 1,910 listings versus 1,899 -- through the first eight months of this year than they did for the same period last year.
"It's not so much that inventory is low, as it is responding to market turnover," said Ms. Hodge. "It's a turnover situation because houses that were once just satisfactory are moving faster than before."
Ebie Wood, regional manager for Houlihan Lawrence in Pound Ridge and South Salem, N.Y., agrees.
"We probably have the same amount of homes coming on to the market as in the past, but now they're coming on at time where there are a lot of serious buyers who are not lingering when they see a house that meets their needs," she said.
Still, many real estate agents report that they are actually seeing far fewer listings than before. Moreover, they report that the drought doesn't appear to be tied to the fact that fall is a time when generally fewer houses go on the market. For example, Ms. Anastasio said that in her area, which is the north shore of western Suffolk County, there are currently only about 150 listings of houses for sale, as opposed to 350 at the same time last year. Ms. Ross added that over the last six months of this year, brokers in New Rochelle had only 182 listings, a number that traditionally would have been perhaps 500 or 600.
CERTAIN types of homes appear to be especially scarce. For example, a year ago, Evelyn Atanas, the founder of the 15-year-old Atanas Realty in Williston Park, N.Y., had some 20 homes to show in central Nassau County that were priced in the low $200,000's. But now her least expensive home is a "tiny" house in Mineola, for $249,000; most of her listings are priced at $279,000 or more.
In New Jersey, the supply of town houses and condominiums that are relatively close to New York City is especially tight.
"In a healthy market we would probably have about five months of town-house inventory, which means we would have 75 listings for every 15 reported sales," said Jacelyn Botti, regional vice president for Weichert Realtors in central New Jersey. "But now we have less than a 30-day supply of such homes, which means we have fewer listings than we do reported sales."
What about Manhattan?
In general, "we've been in a low inventory situation for years," said Lawrence Sicular, an appraisal analyst for Brown Harris Stevens, which handles mostly blue-chip properties. Nevertheless, Mr. Sicular added that supply -- relative to demand -- appears to be substantially tighter for certain types of properties versus others, and is now generally tightest for larger apartments, which have also experienced the largest price jumps over the last few years.
Since April, Mr. Sicular has conducted a monthly inventory survey for his firm of the most expensive sections of the Upper East Side and Central Park West. And he cautioned that his results are often based on relatively small sample sizes, because certain types of apartments for sale, such as prewar six-room units, are relatively rare to begin with. Nevertheless, in his most recent survey, taken last week, he found that there are now roughly 28 percent fewer Classic Six prewar co-op apartments -- with two bedrooms, a dining room and a maid's room -- for sale in those neighborhoods than there were in April. On the other hand, he said, the supply of similar postwar apartments in those neighborhoods has grown 110 percent, while the number of 1,500-square-foot or more lofts downtown has grown 34 percent since July.
In general, however, Mr. Sicular suspects that the inventory crunch in Manhattan has eased a bit since Labor Day, for seasonal reasons and possibly because a jittery stock market has put some potential buyers at bay.
In northern Manhattan, "We're in a situation where demand for one- to four-family homes has far exceeded supply," said R. Kenyatta Punter, the founder of a real estate firm with the same name. "We started to see signs of an inventory problem in the fourth quarter of 1998, and it's been a tight market since then."
As an example of how tight the situation has become, Mr. Punter, who is also president of the Greater Harlem Real Estate Board, said that open houses in his area now bring, on average, 50 to 75 attendees, whereas in 1997 attendance might have been 15 to 20 people.
"By Monday, it's not atypical now to receive 10 offers from an open house, whereas in 1997 you might solicit just two or three offers," he said, adding that the inventory crunch has also caused prices in his area to rise 20 to 25 percent since January. He said that a brownstone in the Hamilton Heights area near City College that had an asking price of $500,000 in February is now in contract for $625,000.
In the brownstone communities surrounding Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, and Park Slope, Christopher Thomas, director of the Brooklyn offices for the William May Company, said that there is currently less town-house inventory available, compared to last fall, but that the number of co-op apartments for sale has probably stayed about the same.
"The increase in prices here has been driven heavily by the lack of inventory," Mr. Thomas added. According to his figures, Brooklyn town houses that were selling for between $1.7 million and $2 million this time last year are now available for $2.3 million and up. As for co-op apartments, prices have risen, on average, some 15 percent since January, he said.
The inventory crunch may, however, be easing, according to Jeffrey G. Otteau, president of the Otteau Appraisal Group in East Brunswick, N.J., who said that a sharp drop in the number of sales contracts in New Jersey suggests that buyers may be resisting paying the higher prices.
Some of the buying resistance, Mr. Otteau said, is seasonal: Most local buyers tend to buy in the spring and summer months, so that they can move before school begins. Nevertheless, he added, his firm is now seeing cases of sticker shock.
"Buyers are looking at significantly higher prices for less desirable homes than what we had available six months ago, and that has created price resistance," he said.
Mr. Otteau added that the resistance helps explain why home sales in New Jersey -- as measured by signed contracts --- appear to have dropped dramatically since last summer -- some 40 percent -- as well as why prices appear to have peaked. By comparision, Mr. Otteau said, sales from the summer to the fall last year dropped between 15 and 20 percent, less than half the rate for this year.
THE only exceptions to the sharp drop in sales, he said, appear to be entry-level houses that cost less than $250,000, and homes in so-called secondary markets, those markets that consumers tend to settle for when they can't afford the more desirable primary markets. According to Mr. Otteau's figures, housing prices in New Jersey's primary markets have jumped between 15 and 20 percent over the last year, but they have risen only 5 to 10 percent in the state's secondary markets
Nancy Hodes-Stempler is a home shopper frustrated by the price jumps in her area, as well as the dearth of inventory.
Along with her husband, 2-year-old son, and brother, Ms. Hodes-Stempler now lives in a rented five-bedroom, three-bathroom house in Fresh Meadows, Queens. After four years of renting, the family is ready to buy a home. But Ms. Hodes-Stempler and her husband couldn't afford to buy the home they live in -- a house that went on the market this fall for $389,000 and that received a successful bid, for $375,000, in just two weeks. Nor can they afford anything else in Fresh Meadows.
As a result, the couple are now looking on Long Island, where they hope to find a home that costs roughly $300,000, to balance the higher taxes there.
Ms. Hodes-Stempler has seen dozens of houses since August, through a dozen different real estate agents. Still, she feels as though she is being shown the same recycled inventory. "Agents are acting like all their listings are fresh, but usually when they call, I've already seen the house," she said.
In mid-October, Ms. Hodes-Stempler did hear of one house that fit her needs: a four-bedroom Cape on a large lot in New Hyde Park that was listed for $299,000, and that would have had an annual real-estate tax payment of just $3,900. But by the time her broker was finally able to get her an appointment to see the house, it was too late: the owners had already accepted a bid. Still, Ms. Hodes-Stempler liked the house enough to send the owners a check for $1,000, to hold her own bid.
"It's not a mad land grab here, but it is sort of desperate," she said. As an example, she pointed to 30 or so real estate agents and their clients who were parked on the lawn of her rented home when she came home from work one day a few weeks ago. They were waiting to see a house that Ms. Hodes-Stempler thinks would have sold for roughly $100,000 less just two years ago.
Real estate brokers say Ms. Hodes-Stempler's experience isn't unusual. Indeed, they claim that many consumers have become unusually aggressive at getting the house they want.
Take the couple who attended an open house that Ms. Atanas, the Williston Park broker, recently sponsored in Mineola. The open house was for a three-bedroom Colonial that was priced at $235,000, a rarity, by any measure, in central Nassau County.
According to Ms. Atanas, the first day the house was on the market, its owners received three offers, all full-priced. In the end, however, the owners accepted a bid from a couple who refused to leave the house until they knew they had it.
Ms. Atanas called a mortgage broker that she works with, who pre-approved the couple's mortgage on the spot. Meanwhile, the couple arranged to have an engineer inspect the house Monday afternoon.
"The contract went out on Tuesday, and within a week it was signed, sealed, and delivered," she said. "That's how fast this couple worked."
Not every home is moving at such speed, of course. Ms. Wood, for example, can think of one home in northern Westchester that was recently put on the market by its owners -- an estate -- for $550,000, but which she thought should have been priced at $495,000. Soon after it went on the market, the house received two bids, for $480,000 and $485,000, but the estate turned both offers down. After several months of paying carrying charges for the property, however, the estate reduced the price of the home to $475,000, and eventually sold it for $450,000.
I N this market, if that house had been priced properly, it would have sold immediately," Ms. Wood said. "Sellers should remember that their home will probably sell for less than it would have sold for if it had gone to market at the right price, and while this is usually a real-estate truism, it's especially true in a very active market such as what we now have."
But Mr. Otteau also urges sellers not to get too greedy. Based on what he has recently noticed within the New Jersey real estate market, he thinks that homeowners who want to sell their homes over the next three or four months will need to price them more competitively than was necessary six months ago.
Meanwhile, Betsy Goss, a sales agent at Prudential Connecticut Realty in Darien, urges sellers to remember that the fall and winter months often bring in a different kind of buyer than do the spring months. "Often these buyers have been looking and looking, and are educated enough to know the market," she said.
What about buyers? Ms. Goss advises them to get preapproval for a mortgage before they start looking, and to come see the house as soon as they can with checkbooks in hand. As for Ms. Ross, the real estate agent in New Rochelle, she urges buyers to take a reality check.
"The reality is that the asking price no longer gets you the house," she said. "If it's a good house, you've got to go over that price immediately."

HEADLINE: In the Region /Westchester;
Avalon Joins New Roc City for New Rochelle Revival

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
WITH New Roc City, the massive entertainment and retail center in the heart of the downtown, up and running for a month, site work has begun on the next component of this city's revitalization.
Groundbreaking for the new element, a 24-story luxury rental tower, was held Oct. 19. At the ceremony, Mayor Timothy C. Idoni noted the huge infusion of private capital in the two projects. "That's $300 million in just two blocks," the Mayor said. 
 The city is pinning most of its hopes for revitalization on the 1.5 million square foot New Roc City, which is expected to draw crowds back into its downtown. The beige stone complex that replaced the old Macy's mall has its own Main Street and police station, and includes a 19-screen movie theater, an IMAX theater, a sports and entertainment center, a supermarket, three restaurants, a hotel, office building and health club.
About a block away, Avalon on the Sound, a 412-apartment building that is to rise across from the Metro-North train station is being built at an estimated cost of $95 million by Avalon Bay Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Alexandria, Va. "It's always been imperative to get people downtown," the Mayor said, "and the best way to do that is for them to live there."
A third major project, now in the planning stage, is the $15-million Intermodal Transportation Center, which is to replace the Metro-North and Amtrak train station. It is to include new bus and train terminals, as well as taxi and limousine stands.
"It will centralize all modes of transportation, which is extremely important to the Avalon Bay project as well as to office workers and for people using New Roc City," said Joseph Madonna, Commissioner of Development. "These three projects are the key components to the city's revival."
With Hillary Rodham Clinton in attendance at the groundbreaking, there were considerably more reporters on hand than would normally cover a routine groundbreaking. Security was tight, with Secret Service agents present and a full complement of police officers checking credentials and turning away even people with invitations, if they arrived too late.
This kind of attention would have seemed inconceivable just a few years ago when New Rochelle was having trouble seeing any project through to completion. Through the early 1990's, a string of developers tried and failed to remake the old Macy's mall.
Then in 1993, New Rochelle was in the running to be the world headquarters for Unicef, the children's-relief agency, which ultimately chose to remain in Manhattan.
Even the latest projects were slow to become realities, according to the Mayor. "Avalon was waiting to see what would happen with New Roc City," he said. "Now that it's open and doing well, it was time for this groundbreaking, the next thing."
At Avalon on the Sound, which will be the city's tallest building, apartments will range from studios to three bedrooms, with rents from $950 to $3,000.
Residents will have access to a health club, outdoor swimming pool, basketball court and community room at no extra cost. There will also be some shops and food services -- "the type of thing you'd expect, a place to get coffee and some conveniences," according to Frederick Harris, a vice president for development with Avalon.
The project here is one of Avalon Bay's few public-private ventures, according to Mr. Harris.
W E'VE worked out a 30-year payment plan with the city for the land and taxes on the property," he explained. "The payments are based on our net income, and it's no secret that it works out to be a lot less than if we were paying up front and were taxed at the full rate."
Despite its name, Avalon on the Sound will rise on Huguenot Street, about a mile from Long Island Sound. "Every apartment will have a bay window," Mr. Harris said. "And most will have Sound views. Also a large percentage will have balconies."
If all goes well with leasing, Avalon Bay will also build two additional phases with a total of 600 apartments. "But that depends entirely on the market," Mr. Harris said.
It also depends on the impact of the city's other projects, especially New Roc City. It has been attracting 35,000 to 45,000 people a week, according to Jeffrey Castaldo, executive director of real estate for the center. "We track that through movie ticket sales and number of dinners served," Mr. Castaldo said. "We expect that number to increase to 100,000 people weekly once we're fully operational."
One of New Roc City's major attractions, Mr. Castaldo said, aside from the movies, is its entertainment and sports center, which features two ice skating rinks and a climbing wall, as well as a motion simulator and virtual reality rides.
Another element in the center is an attraction called the Space Shot, a 235-foot free-fall ride. A health club and 120-room Marriott Residence Inn are expected to open next month and in December, respectively.
Mr. Castaldo said the extended-stay hotel would focus on guests who were relocating, on temporary assignments or in training programs. The suites will have one and two bedrooms, with fully equipped kitchens. "They're for people who want to stay one night or a couple of months," Mr. Castaldo said.
He said he still had 62,000 square feet of retail space after signing a lease last week with the Modell's sports chain for 18,000 square feet. He added that he has been talking to record and book stores and an "upscale" Italian restaurant and was now also actively seeking tenants for New Roc City's 100,000 square foot office building.
Now that New Roc City is almost complete, the city expects to turn its attention to the Intermodal Transportation Center, "which is especially important for the hotel," Mr. Madonna said.
The city has already received about $12 million from Federal and state sources to finance the transportation center. "We'd like to get a couple of million more," Mr. Madonna said. "We should have the first environmental studies completed in the first quarter of the year 2000."
In addition, the city just received $500,000 in Federal grants for the rehabilitation of North Avenue, the city's main north-south thoroughfare. "North Avenue connects to our waterfront, and after we've completed our work on the downtown, that's the next place where we'll turn our attention," said Mayor Idoni.

HEADLINE: Residential Life Is Returning to Atlanta's Downtown

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
BILL GOULD said he felt like an urban pioneer when he stepped through a kudzu-shrouded doorway and into what would be his new home nine years ago.
The 25,000-square-foot brick building dated to the 1880's when Standard Oil of Kentucky built it for a barrel-making operation; more recently it had been an automobile parts supply house and a junk dealer's warehouse. 
 Just beyond the backyard lay a railroad yard, while next door were other industrial buildings, also empty, also hidden by kudzu vines. And yet this industrial no man's land stood at the edge of a growing downtown.
Mr. Gould, a photographer, envisioned loft apartments, spaces for artists like himself to live and work in at a reasonable cost.
Now 39, Mr. Gould is a pioneer no more.
Hundreds of residential units, both in new high rises and conversions of industrial buildings , have been built in the last few years as developers have discovered a heady market for living in downtown Atlanta.
The two-square-mile downtown had long been overlooked in favor of fancier midtown addresses or the even-more elegant Buckhead area, both to the north. Families tended to trek farther out to suburban enclaves in neighboring counties, subdivisions that literally sprawl for miles across the landscape.
"It was scary out here," said Mr. Gould, whose Allied Factory Warehouse now includes eight apartments and work space for more than a dozen artists. "The area had almost returned to wilderness."
He was attracted to the site first by an intrinsic love of industrial buildings and then by a cobblestone street at the rear, a rarity here.
"The one thing about Atlanta that doesn't appeal to me is everything is new," he said. "We've been tearing down buildings since the Civil War."
To be sure, Atlanta is a place where new is revered. High rises were built only after smaller, older buildings were demolished in a steady progression beginning in the 1960's and continuing until the early 1990's. One of Atlanta's best-known companies, the Coca-Cola Company, left downtown in 1919 -- the year that Ernest Woodruff bought it for $25 million -- for a campus-like setting in midtown Atlanta.
But in 1976, the Cable News Network opted to buy a 1.5-million-square-foot building at the edge of downtown for its headquarters. The building is now nestled between two new civic-related developments, Centennial Olympic Park, built for the Olympics, and Phillips Arena, home to Atlanta's Thrashers hockey team and its Hawks basketball team. The arena was built by Ted Turner, founder of CNN; Philips Electronics North America paid for the right to have it named for the company and to have its huge sign on the building.
Since 1990, $1 billion has been invested in downtown Atlanta. Much of the money was spent on Olympics-related construction, such as the park and Turner Field, used for the Olympics and now home to the Atlanta Braves, and landscaping along downtown streets. In that same period, 2,690 housing units were built downtown, according to a report for the Centennial Olympic Park Area, a private, nonprofit organization founded to guide development around the 21-acre park.
One of the agency's first projects is a three-acre site at the northeast corner of the park that is to include about 100 condominium units, 200 rentals, retail spaces and, possibly, a children's museum. The agency paid $6.5 million for property, which is to be developed by a private developer sometime next year.
Meanwhile, across the park, Legacy Property Group expects to break ground next month on a 10-story residential condominium at the rear of the Embassy Suites Hotel. Called Centennial Park West, the units will range in price from $200,000 for 1,000 square feet of space with one bedroom to $1 million for 4,000 square feet and four bedrooms, according to John Pauli, an architect whose firm, Stang & Newdow, is designing the interior. The firm of May & Pinska of New York City designed the outside.
Most developers here credit the Olympics with not only making the city more attractive but also with spurring the first projects that brought people back to the city. Some of the games' sponsors subsidized projects to convert three downtown office buildings into apartments.
One, the 89-unit Metropolitan, once the home of the First National Bank, is now being sold as condominiums, ranging in price from $50,000 to $120,000. The other two -- the 65-unit Muses and 114-unit William-Oliver -- are still rental apartments, according to a report by Dale Henson Associates, a real estate consulting firm here.
"We have a mild to severe case of condo-mania," said Dale Henson, a real estate consultant here. "There is a frantic effort to get into the market before it gets too filled out or we have an economic setback."
IN addition to the office-building conversions, several industrial buildings close to Mr. Gould's property in the Marietta Street area have been converted into lofts and many of them have been sold as condominiums. The site of a former gasket manufacturer was turned into 30 units that sold for $145,000 to $337,000, while a seed company's building was transformed into 18 condominium units ranging in price from $137,000 to $240,000.
Mr. Gould said he had decided to rent out space because his development proceeded one unit at a time, without bank financing. Now that the renovation is nearly complete, he is considering selling the units as condominiums.
Another area seeing a surge in residential development is the Fairlie-Poplar neighborhood, once a high-crime area of bars and rundown hotels. Several buildings have been converted to loft condominiums, while the first new residential construction downtown in many years is taking place at what will be 123 Luckie Street, now the site of a parking lot. Prices for the 49-unit condominium will range from $190,000 for a one-bedroom to $550,000 for four bedrooms, said Mr. Pauli, the project's architect.
Mr. Henson noted, however, that while the market looked vibrant the actual number of units recently completed or under way is less than a thousand.
"How many does it take to create a community?" he asked. "There's not enough to create an environment that will make a difference," he said.
Living in a downtown like Atlanta's certainly poses challenges, Mr. Gould said. The area could be considered in its infancy for residents, meaning few restaurants open at night and only one grocery -- a Kroger Supermarket across the street from the State Capitol -- anywhere close.
Moreover, there is a perception that crime is worse here than in the outlying areas. But Mr. Gould, as well as city leaders, say that is perception, not reality. Reported crime has decreased since the police increased street patrols and put neighborhood precincts in storefronts across the city.
The city has made attracting downtown residents a priority as well. The need for a vibrant middle class was highlighted in a 1998 report issued by the Atlanta Renaissance Program, which called its absence "missing rungs in the ladder to progress." The report showed the city had become home to the poor and the wealthy and set goals such as improving education and transforming deteriorated areas to attract more middle-income families.
John A. Williams, chairman of Post Properties and president of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, said the city was working hard to solve those problems so that it can be home to others besides empty-nesters, young marrieds and singles.
One element city leaders see as crucial to this end is keeping Macy's open on Peachtree Street in the heart of the city. Mr. Williams's company has offered to buy the six-story building, lease the ground floor to Macy's and put offices on the second and third floors and 150 residential units on the top three floors.
"The key to a vibrant downtown is people," he said. "The city is now very popular, a response to rebellion against sprawl that has infected Atlanta. The customer is making a choice to live in an environment different than suburbs."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
Mattie Grady-Smith, a lawyer, has been appointed to direct the county's Affirmative Action/Equal Employment Opportunities program. Her appointment is part of County Executive Andrew J. Spano's effort to increase the number of women and members of minorities in the county's work force, Mr. Spano said.
Ms. Grady-Smith, 47, will earn $79,945 a year to promote employment opportunities, conduct a sensitivity training program for supervisors to deal with sexual harassment and conflict resolution and develop a program for Civil Service test preparation. 
 The percentage of women and minority-group commissioners and deputies has risen to 20 percent from 5 percent during Mr. Spano's term in office.
The County Executive has also revived the Hispanic and African American Advisory Boards and developed an economic development policy, which encourages participation by women and minority-owned businesses.
Of the county's 5,980 full-time employees in January, there were 3,844 full-time white employees, 1,539 black employees, 423 Hispanic employees, 164 Asian employees and 4 American Indian employees. (Employees may be represented in more than one group.) Of those, 2,803 were men and 3,177 were women.
Ms. Grady-Smith worked for the Department of Social Services from 1973 to 1991, when she was appointed to the Office of Risk Management, a position she held until 1995. There she handled medical malpractice and general liability claims at the Westchester Medical Center satellite office. From 1995 until her recent appointment, she worked for the Medical Center's Department of Risk Management. ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
Kathleen Maura Nolan, a daughter of Patricia and Jack P. Nolan of Providence, R.I., was married last evening at the Providence Biltmore Hotel to Eric Murray Schoenfield, a son of Eli and Roberta Schoenfield of New York. Rabbi Sol Goodman officiated at the ceremony, with the Rev. Anne Coburn, an Episcopal priest, taking part.
Ms. Nolan, 29, is keeping her name. She is a research associate on health policy at the Institute of Medicine in Washington. She graduated from Carleton College in Northfield, Minn., and is studying for a master's degree in public health at George Washington University. 
 Her mother is the director of the Rhode Island Department of Health in Providence. The bride's father, who is retired, taught history at University High School in Tucson, Ariz.
Mr. Schoenfield, 30, is the executive assistant at the Foundation on Economic Trends, an organization in Washington that studies scientific, health and environmental trends. He graduated from Hunter College.
His mother is a financial adviser at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the securities brokerage firm in New York. His father is a founding partner in Kay Collyer & Boose, a New York law firm.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Catherine Rinaldi, David Skoblow

 BODY:
Catherine Alice Rinaldi, an aide to Gov. George E. Pataki, and David Victor Skoblow, a lawyer, were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Brian Brennan performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Ms. Rinaldi is keeping her name. She is a senior assistant counsel and legislative adviser to the Governor in Albany and Manhattan. She graduated summa cum laude from Yale University and received a law degree from the University of Virginia. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rinaldi of Huntington, N.Y. Her father, a retired lawyer, had a private practice in Garden City, N.Y. From 1972 to 1988, he was a deputy counsel to State Senator Warren M. Anderson, then the Senate's majority leader in Albany. 
 Mr. Skoblow, who works in Manhattan, is the associate general counsel to the American subsidiary of CLS Services, which provides banks with foreign-exchange settlement services. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received a master's degree in foreign service and a law degree from Georgetown University. He also holds a Master of Laws degree from the London School of Economics and is a member of the Board of Visitors of the University of Chicago's Divinity School.
He is the son of Emilie G. Skoblow of Stuyvesant Falls, N.Y., and the late Seymour Skoblow. His mother retired as a customer relations representative in the Flushing, Queens, branch of the Republic National Bank. His father was the controller in Manhattan for Solcoor, an equipment importer and exporter.

 BODY:

Healing With Music
 
TUESDAY -- The singer Phil Collins and his manager, Tony Smith, will be honored for their support of the Nordoff-Robbins Music Therapy Foundation, which uses music to treat children with a wide variety of physical and emotional disabilities, at a dinner at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street. Cocktails and a silent auction begin at 6:30, followed by dinner and a live auction that includes trips to London and Paris. Tickets, $500, from (212) 707-2818. 

Boys to Men
 
WEDNESDAY -- Orlando Cepeda, Wayne Embry and Eric Dickerson are among those who will be inducted at the Boys Club of New York's All Sports Hall of Fame Dinner, at the Waldorf-Astoria. The black-tie event, which will support the organization's camps, scholarships, and athletic and educational programs, begins with a cocktail reception at 6:30 P.M., followed by dinner at 7:30. Len Berman, a sports anchor on WNBC-TV, will be the host. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 997-0100.

Living Landmarks
 
WEDNESDAY -- The New York Landmarks Conservancy's sixth annual Living Landmarks gala will be held at the Plaza. The organization will honor Patricia Buckley and her husband, William F. Buckley Jr.; Marian S. Heiskell and her husband, Andrew Heiskell; Anthony Drexel Duke; Peter Jennings, and Harvey Weinstein and his brother, Bob Weinstein. The event benefits the group's preservation efforts. Liz Smith, the columnist, will be the host of the black-tie evening, which begins with drinks at 7. Dinner and dancing to the music of Peter Duchin and his orchestra will follow. Tickets, $500, from (212) 995-5260.
 
Action on Child Care
 
WEDNESDAY -- A reception will be held at Landmark on the Park, 160 Central Park West (at 76th Street) to raise money for the Child Care Action Campaign and its efforts to create pre-kindergarten programs nationwide, increase business investment in child care and expand language development in preschool-age children. Cocktails, a silent auction and a buffet dinner begin at 6. A live auction that includes a cruise for two on the Queen Elizabeth 2 will follow, as will an awards ceremony. Tickets, $150, or $50 for those under 35, from (212) 239-0138, ext. 228.

Suffragists on Celluloid
 
WEDNESDAY -- There will be a dinner and screening at the Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, where a clip from Ken Burns's new documentary about the suffragists Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony will be shown. The evening, which begins with cocktails at 7, will benefit the American Film Institute and the National Breast Cancer Coalition. Throughout the evening, readings of the suffragists' letters will be presented by Jessica Lange, Meryl Streep, Rory Kennedy and others. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 245-6570.

Airmen Land at the Hilton
 
THURSDAY -- Members of the Tuskegee Airmen will be among those honored at a black-tie dinner and dance at the New York Hilton and Towers to raise money for the New York chapter of 100 Black Men. The organization supports economic development projects and provides educational assistance, including tutors, mentors and scholarships, to students in New York's public schools. Al Roker of "Today" will be the master of ceremonies. The evening begins at 7:30, with a buffet dinner and dancing throughout. Tickets, $250, from (212) 777-7070.

HEADLINE: Bringing Out the Dead

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

DATELINE: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y.

 BODY:
IT was cold and dark in the cemetery where Latoya Franklin stood stone still, her arms clinging to a friend from behind. It was quiet, so quiet that the friend, Vern Witherbee, could hear Latoya's bones shake. They looked straight ahead. There was a squeak. Then Latoya jumped four feet backward, screaming bloody murder. Tears streamed down her face as huge gray rats scampered out of a coffin and across her feet, before disappearing into a hole.
Latoya, 17, a high school student in this upstate town, collapsed to the ground, shaking all over. When she regained her composure, her party of five continued on, passing ghouls feasting on corpses, scientists cooking bats and snakes, and blood gushing from a patient on an operating table as he was being hacked up with a cleaver. After 25 minutes and many more fits of screaming, the party emerged dazed into the bright light of a warehouse, outside the area where volunteer firemen had set up a house of horrors. 
 Across the country, as the veil separating the living from the dead is once again lifted during the Halloween season, the latest fright to capture the popular imagination is the haunted house designed not for children, but for adults.
With some costing around $1 million, and employing Hollywood-style special effects, live rodents and dozens of actors, the attractions are aimed at grown-ups who increasingly crave more graphic chills. A sign near the entrance of the Plattsburgh haunted house, which expected 4,000 visitors during its week of operation, reads, "Not recommended for children under 13." The children who did enter invariably bailed out immediately by a door designed for the purpose. Most were in tears.
"We made one adult gentleman go to the bathroom in his pants; need I say more?" said Brian Herkalo, one of the volunteers running the attraction, whose $3 admission price went to support local charities.
A Web site, HauntedAmerica.com, lists 3,000 haunted houses in operation around the country in October, up from 2,300 last Halloween season. Ninety percent of them are aimed at adults. "There are more adult haunted houses than there have ever been, entertaining millions of people," said Joe Jensen, a co-founder of the Web site and formerly the operator of a haunted house in Chicago that he said drew 75,000 visitors a season. "The haunted houses are becoming scarier and scarier. The audiences are demanding it."
Some fright factories are in basements or warehouses, with staffs of volunteers who build sets and impersonate ghouls to raise money for charity. But more often, they are profit-making businesses, which charge up to $30 for admission and are as elaborately constructed as theme parks, employing actors to ride "headless" on horseback through woods or a farm.
At Spooky World in Foxboro, Mass., four haunted houses sprawl over 60 acres behind Foxboro Stadium, home of the New England Patriots football team. The monthlong attraction was built at a cost of $4 million, tripling in size from last year when, at a more residential location, it caused huge traffic snarls.
On Oct. 23, 8,700 people visited Spooky World, most of them in their 20's and 30's. Linda Blair from "The Exorcist" and Kane Hodder of "Friday the 13th" have been celebrity guests. But the biggest star is probably Ruth Phelps, a k a the Mouse Girl, who smears her body with peanut butter and lets 200 mice run over her.
"She has been bitten, but she doesn't mind," David Bertolino, a co-owner of Spooky World, said. The Mouse Girl's one request is that she be smeared with smooth, not chunky-style, peanut butter. "The mice were eating the chunks off her face," Mr. Bertolino explained. "It wasn't an unreasonable request."
In Newton, Pa., a haunted house called the Dredd Funeral Home admits visitors in groups of 10. At one point, a guest mysteriously disappears. "It's eerie," said April Woodall, 41, a dean at the Academy of Vocal Arts, an opera training school in Philadelphia, who has visited three times.
The remaining "mourners" then enter a room to pick out a casket for their departed friend. But all of a sudden the missing visitor appears in a casket. "I don't like to be jumped up from behind and shouted 'Boo' at," Ms. Woodall said. "That's predictable. The good haunted houses give you something to think about a long time afterward."
Each year, owners and experienced visitors say, haunted houses have been getting more elaborate, with gorier costumes, more expensive special effects and scenarios that play mind games with visitors, rather than simply startling them. Buffs who travel far and wide to visit haunted houses, and experts like Mr. Jensen of the Web site -- collectively known as "haunters" for their passion -- say that Americans have a taste for more graphic fright because of popular entertainment like "The X Files" and Doom, the video game. This summer's hit horror movies, including "The Mummy," "The Blair Witch Project" and "The Sixth Sense," also seem to have swelled the audience this fall for haunted houses.
Lewis Cole, the chairman of the film division at Columbia University, said that horror as a genre is more in demand when the economy and politics are unroiled. "When everything is sort of stable, people want to see things that make them feel something," he said.
"If you think of the 50's and 'Psycho,' " he went on, "it was a placid time, yet there were all sorts of elements that were about to explode, and then you had the 60's." In that decade, there was plenty of excitement in the streets and screen horror was not so popular.
A subgenre of haunted houses, operated by conservative Christian churches around the country, depict scenes from hell with an express moral lesson: here is what awaits drug users, abortionists and homosexuals. They have sometimes stirred local controversy, and in late October, a church in Cedar Hill, Tex. that set up a Hell House depicting the high school murders at Littleton, Colo., landed in the national news for its perceived insensitivity.
The great majority of haunted houses are secular, and the frights they impart are intended to be thrilling, perhaps cathartic, but not moralizing. One of the most popular scenarios, duplicated by many operators, begins when visitors enter a crypt. They see an upright coffin, which is open, and suddenly a hand pushes them in. The floor of the coffin opens and the visitors descend by ramp into hell, where dead souls in ragged clothes cry out. Some have missing limbs, others have faces that look like they've been gnawed.
Mr. Jensen, whose Chicago haunted house was named Hades, used to study Aztec and Mayan traditions to plan new frights. "Their death legends are most graphic and least known," he said.
Other popular tableaus at haunted houses around the country this year include the following:
* The Black Hole, a tunnel that is spinning around you. It's pitch black and all you can see are the stars on the tunnel, spinning, spinning. It creates an extreme sense of vertigo.
* The Demon Puppets, eight-foot-tall creatures that lunge at visitors from the darkness.
* The Chainsaw, as held by a seemingly crazed person. "That still scares people the most," Mr. Jensen said.
At the Headless Horseman Hayrides and Haunted House in Ulster Park, N.Y., the owners, Michael and Nancy Jubie, have learned to ratchet up the frights each year. On their 45-acre farm, more than 25,000 people have visited in the five weeks preceding Halloween. They ride by wagon through fields unveiling the works of a fictitious Dr. Joseph Blight.
As the story goes, Dr. Blight, after many years of research in Madagascar, has been infected by an unknown spore, and now has plant and human DNA. He has created a new form of life that is half human, half plant. Participants visit his two homes, where his species live. In one room an angry half-plant, half-man punches a hand through a woman's chest, and it comes out the other side.
"We're sold out every night," Mrs. Jubie said. "Demand is greater than supply. But once Oct. 31 is over, people don't want to be scared. They turn their heads toward Christmas."
In the week leading up to Halloween, Oct. 31, the haunters have been out in force. Elizabeth LaBrake, 21, a community-college student in Plattsburgh, was waiting with two friends to visit the firefighters' haunted house.
"Plattsburgh is very boring," she said. "You need something to put you on the edge, to get your heart going."
A friend, John Akin, 20, had a different reason. "I just want to watch her freak out," he said.
And Latoya, the teen-ager who had fallen to the floor shaking when rats scampered over her feet -- they were mechanical, not real -- was still wiping away tears. Asked after emerging from the spook house if she would ever go through it again, she hesitated a moment, then answered, "Absolutely."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Chat: Alan to Bill to Trent, Janet to Bill, and Larry to Bob

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
IT was a busy week in Washington for politics and policy on economic and financial issues. Imagine that you could take a peek at the E-mail traffic among the big players. You might, or might not, have seen something like this. (And no, the addresses are not real.)
 
To: billc@whitehouse.gov
From: greenspan@fed.gov
Thank you, Mr. President, for letting me know privately that you will reappoint me to a fourth term as Fed chairman when the time comes next year. It will be a privilege to continue in public service and to seek to maintain the vibrancy of the Greenspan Economy -- I mean, Clinton Economy. 
 By the way, and I probably should have mentioned this earlier: We may have a situation developing here. This darned economy of yours is just tooting along like a freight train.
Though I've tapped the brakes a few times, I may have to apply a bit more force to slow things down. In fact, this baby may be so resilient that I have to keep raising rates into next year.
With your legacy already secure, I know this is of little matter to you personally. But your sidekick there is counting on strong growth, low unemployment and a fizzy stock market to carry him into the White House. So you might want to pass on to the Gore folks a heads-up that by next October or so, joblessness is likely to be rising and confidence sinking, and an opportunistic opponent might then be able to capitalize on one little economic pothole to suggest it's time for a change.
But then, I guess you already know how that works.
 
To: lott@senate.gov
From: billc@whitehouse.gov
Trent, I wanted to congratulate you for your part in our mutual effort to put aside the temptations of short-term partisan advantage and set the nation on a course of fiscal responsibility and prudent debt reduction.
You had me going there with that $792 billion tax cut for a while. What a jokester!
And I'm sure you understand that I was just having a little fun with those pesky liberal Democrats in the House when I proposed using the budget surplus to subsidize prescription drugs for everyone 65 and older. Big spending programs have never been my priority.
No doubt, the American people will reward both of us for our farsightedness in leaving the surplus largely untouched and improving the Government's long-term economic strength.
Because of our courageous decisions, we have given the country confidence that it will be able to deal with the problems that threaten the prosperity of voters not yet born.
By the way, I also look forward to working with you on the international issues that face us, you isolationist, nativist, never-had-a-passport hick who doesn't know his W.T.O. from his C.T.B.T.! :-)
 
To: gates@microsoft.com
From: reno@justice.gov
Congratulations on your company's stock becoming a component of the Dow Jones industrial average. Now every triumph on your part will lift the single most widely quoted indicator of the country's economic vibrancy to new heights.
Unfortunately, I suppose, it also means that more than ever, every piece of bad news about Microsoft will send investors into spasms of panic, undermining the economy and eroding the political support that has permitted the Clinton Administration to survive all the late unpleasantness.
Which brings me to this little misunderstanding about your Web browser and the exuberance with which you seek to share the fruits of your product development with consumers. Just because that judge is about to rule that you are a heartless monopolist intent on atomizing the competition -- I have no idea why my antitrust division put such ideas in his head -- doesn't mean that we can't quietly come to some agreement to keep Microsoft from being chopped up into 1,000 pieces.
As a sign of my sincerity, I have instructed the F.B.I. to purge all Netscape products from Justice Department computers. I would hope that your counteroffer would include options on a few hundred thousand shares for the charity of my choice.
 
To: rubin@citigroup.com
From: summers@treasury.gov
I knew there was a reason I spent countless hours locked in a room with Phil Gramm getting a deal on updating the laws governing the financial services industry.
It must have been to assure your employment with a financial services mega-conglomerate that can use the freedom granted to it under the new legislation to gain control over every aspect of personal and corporate finance in the United States and throughout the industrialized world.
Glad to be of assistance.
Just remember, though, that you're not going to be dealing with regular guys like me and Greenspan anymore. Unlike Washington, Citigroup is a viper's nest of competing egos and agendas, and it's pretty clear that you're there to play referee.
So if things don't work out for you at Citigroup, the latest polls suggest that I will be available to replace you once again, anytime after Jan. 20, 2001.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Raising The Specter Of an Oil Shortage

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
JUST about a year ago, some analysts were saying oil prices could fall to $5 a barrel by year-end. Oil company executives told Congress that prices would linger around $10 a barrel for the next decade.
That was then. 
 Now, thanks to rising demand and discipline on the part of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Mexico and Norway, prices are north of $21 a barrel, double what they were last fall. Inventories are lean and winter is coming. Instead of $5, the talk is that by year-end prices could be around $30 a barrel, maybe higher. And some people have started to whisper about gasoline lines by spring.
Matthew R. Simmons, president of Simmons & Company International, a Houston-based energy investment bank, is one of those people. Only he's not whispering. He took some time last week to discuss what he worries may happen over the next six months. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
Q. For the last four or five years you have been talking about the potential for an increase in oil prices. We've had a spike this year, but you are still worried. Why?
 
A. I started getting worried about our vulnerability to an imbalance between supply and demand about four or five years ago, but I have never been as concerned as I am right now. Unless certain things happen, demand will outrace supply.
 
Q. What are the supply and demand numbers for oil?
 
A. The International Energy Agency estimates that in the fourth quarter worldwide demand for oil will be 77.2 million barrels a day, rising to 78.3 million barrels a day in the first quarter.
On the supply side, non-OPEC production, including natural gas liquids, is estimated at just over 48 million barrels a day in the fourth quarter, and will only inch up slightly from that level in the first quarter. OPEC is producing just over 26 million barrels a day.
The official thought is that there are enough inventories to cover this shortfall. As of the end of August, the I.E.A. estimated total Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development inventories were 2.69 billion barrels, and said stocks will be drawn down by 1.2 million barrels per day in the third quarter.
Now, the single biggest lack of knowledge in the petroleum industry has to do with stocks. Most of them are not usable. And the I.E.A. estimates on non-OPEC production, which assumes a 1.4-million-barrel-a-day increase between the second quarter of 1999 and the first quarter of 2000, are a joke, because nothing has been started yet on new oil projects.
Last week, five of the major oil companies reported their third-quarter results. On average, daily production at those companies was down 2.5 percent compared to a year ago. If it turns out non-OPEC supply is flat rather, then you have to add another 1 million barrels a day to the draw on stocks.
 
Q. So what happens if you're predictions about a shortage are right?
 
A. If OPEC sticks to its production quotas, which I think they will, and the winter is not as mild as the last couple have been, I am worried about a physical shortage that creates a violent price rise. In my view, most of our petroleum stocks are at the low end of anything we have operated with.
 
Q. How big a price increase could we see?
 
A. I am probably the only person in the oil industry who has never given a price forecast. But letting demand get ahead of supply terrifies me. If that happens you could get a price increase of at least $5 to $10 a barrel.
A big price increase unleashes all sorts of bad things . . . I think there are gasoline lines in our future, and Americans don't like gasoline lines. I don't know how we would handle gasoline lines now, because we don't have attendants at gasoline stations now, as we did in the 1970's.
 
Q. Since there are always stock drawdowns in the fourth and first quarters, if this jump doesn't occur in the next six months, will it not happen?
 
A. If it hasn't shown up by the end of March, it won't show up. And the pressure for a price jump will start to get significant by mid-November, when peak demand starts to kick in.
 
Q. From an investor's perspective, who are the big winners if your scenario plays out?
 
A. I think you would see a terrific spike in oil service stock price prices, companies like Schlumberger, Halliburton and Baker Hughes. But with the run-up in oil prices into the $20-a-barrel range, they are going to do well next year anyway.
Clearly, profitability of all oil and gas companies will be helped by this, but the top 10 to 15 independent oil producers and the bottom 3 major oil companies will also be star performers.
We happen to need a lot more supply, and that means more exploration. But many of these companies have downsized and it will take time to gear up again.
