HEADLINE: Muted Echoes of the Civil War

BYLINE: By JENNIFER MOSES; JENNIFER MOSES is the author of "Food and Whine: Confessions of an End of the Millennium Mom" (Simon & Schuster).

 BODY:
MY 9-year-old son, Sam, thinks I've become morbid, and maybe I have. For some years now, I've been drawn to cemeteries. Which may be why our first stop, after landing in Biloxi, Miss., is the old city graveyard, conveniently situated just a couple of blocks from our B & B.
Like other graveyards in the Deep South, this one -- with its above-ground crypts, moss-covered stones, intimations of the War Between the States, and tendrils of Spanish moss -- is hauntingly resonant. Above me, birds call in the heavy canopy of the live oaks. To my right, Sam is playing shadow-tag among family tombs of people called Reynoir, Agregaard and Bousquet. And to my left -- where Highway 90 stretches along the coast from Mobile, Ala., to New Orleans -- a grape-juice-colored shuttle bus, courtesy of the New Palace Casino, whizzes past. 
 Biloxi's brief moment of glory came in 1720, when for two years the city was the capital of French colonial Louisiana. In 1722 it lost that title to New Orleans, but Biloxi went on to sustain itself with lumber, seafood and tourism.
Regular monster hurricanes notwithstanding, the city is thriving in its latest incarnation as the coastal capital of casino gambling, drawing snowbirds, retirees, college students on spring break and families looking for an affordable vacation. I'm told that in the warm months Highway 90 is a snarl of traffic, lined with concession stands, jet-ski rentals, and T-shirt cabanas, and the beach is a mass of supine bodies. The Redneck Riviera, it is sometimes called, and, during the age of grand seaside hotels and steamer ships, the American Mediterranean. But in February it's too cold to swim, and Sam and I have the town to ourselves.
He drags me away from my meditations on death and the vagaries of history, demanding that we do something fun. Thus we head for the nearest souvenir shop, where I buy him a Batman kite, even though he thinks Batman is stupid, and then to the clean, white, wide-open beach, the world's largest artificial one, built to shore up the sea wall, which itself was built in 1924 to shore up the eroding coastline. Today the beach is empty save for ourselves, the sky is a wash of blue, and the winds coming off the Mississippi Bay are brisk.
On the far side of the bay lies a string of barrier islands that make up Gulf Islands National Seashore, and beyond them lies the Gulf of Mexico. From March through October, in fact, you can take a boat to Ship Island, home of Fort Massachusetts, once a camp for Confederate prisoners. The boats aren't running now. Sam, heedless of everything but his new toy, runs up the beach, his kite soaring above him.
Biloxi is surprisingly pretty; it's also amazingly ugly. It depends on where you are and which way you look. If you stick to the old residential stretches along the shoreline, where Highway 90 splits to become a long boulevard divided by a wide grassy median graced by towering palm trees, you see lovely old boxy houses gazing out over the water, deeply shaded front yards, wide front porches, azaleas bursting into bloom, and, as evening approaches, a pink-flecked Southern sky.
But if you head either east toward Gulf Shores or west toward the old downtown, what you get is one big modern casino after the next -- hulky oversized structures with tacky embellishments like the leaping pink plaster dolphins at the entrance to the Isle of Capri Casino. There's also the immense Keesler Air Force base smack in the middle of town, which we were prevented from visiting when we confessed to the airman on duty that we weren't, actually, military personnel. But in between there are enough points of interest and historic sites to capture the attention of even the most hyperenergetic boy on a winter holiday with his mother.
Plus there are hamburgers -- hamburgers as far as the eye can see, which pleases Sam, who suffers, during nonvacation times, from hamburger deprivation. His belly full, we head for Beauvoir, the last home of Jefferson Davis. As soon as our minivan swings through the gates and onto the grounds, even Sam seems to notice that we've entered a world far from the bumper cars at Fun City, let alone the slot machines at the Treasure Bay Casino Resort.
Right away you can see why the former President of the Confederacy accepted the offer of Beauvoir's owner, Sarah Dorsey, to write his memoirs here. The house, which was built in the middle of the 19th century by a rich Mississippi planter, is an open, airy, single-story raised cottage with a front veranda that is approached by wide stairs and rooms filled with antique furnishings and Davis family memorabilia. In pre-air-conditioned times, the floor-to-ceiling triple-hung windows let in the Gulf breezes, and a jar filled with honey trapped errant insects.
Some years after Jefferson Davis's death, the estate was sold to the Mississippi division of the United Sons of Confederate Veterans, who maintained a soldiers' home on the property.
Today you step out of the house and onto grounds that stretch north toward a sluggish bayou and, beyond that, a Confederate veterans' cemetery and the Tomb of the Unknown Confederate Soldier, on which visitors have placed flowers and small Confederate flags. The grounds also include the newly opened Jefferson Davis Presidential Library, a modern museum with displays about Davis's life and times.
As we head back to Highway 90, I explain to Sam that in the hot, dusty, humid and smelly days before modern sewage and electricity, Biloxi drew city dwellers from New Orleans and Mobile eager to escape the threat of yellow fever for the relatively salutary climes of the coast. Until 1870 they arrived by steamship; afterward, and into the late 1960's, they came by train. In response, Biloxi built hotels grand and small, but today, only one still stands: the classical revival Magnolia Hotel, built in 1847 near the steamship dock, and now the Biloxi Mardi Gras Museum. (Mardi Gras parades, somewhat tamer than those in New Orleans, roll through Biloxi every year.)
Now Sam and I, into our second day, have stopped at the visitors center to pick up a guide to a walking tour, and find ourselves in front of the old hotel on Rue Magnolia. Behind us is Biloxi's most famous restaurant, Mary Mahoney's, in the looming, graceful Brunet-Fourchy House (circa 1835). I love meandering around the heart of the old downtown, but Sam is beginning to get a little antsy looking at the buildings -- Greek Revival and neo-Classical and Victorian and neo-Classic Revival and Creole and Gothic. Then we land at the Cathedral of the Nativity, built in 1902, unexceptional from the outside but housing exquisite German-made stained glass windows depicting scenes from the life of Jesus. Sam is stunned and captivated. "How did they make these?" he asks. As we leave the church, we look up to see the pale orange, and not yet complete, Beau Rivage casino, hovering over the old town like a giant space-age bat.
Also in the heart of the old downtown is the George E. Ohr Arts and Cultural Center. For those -- like myself -- not in the know, George Ohr, "the mad potter of Biloxi," struggled for recognition during his lifetime (he died in 1918), but is now regarded as a master ceramist -- an artist who reached new heights as a colorist and glazer, his quirky works imbued with expressiveness. In the museum you can see the largest permanent exhibition of his work in the United States.
We duck into McElroy's, a family-owned seafood restaurant on Biloxi's small-craft harbor, where the decor is strictly back-to-basics sparse, the seafood is absolutely fresh, and the hamburgers, Sam tells me, are first rate.
Biloxi is built on a peninsula that juts out on one side into the Biloxi Channel, and is bordered on the other by what's called the back bay of Biloxi. There are fish, an aquarium, seafood and deep-sea fishing vessels. After lunch, we dawdle for a while at the harbor, where Sam decides which boat he'd most like to hire for a fishing trip. Next we visit the J. L. Scott Marine Education Center, where we gaze at the creatures swimming around the 40-odd tanks, including the 42,000-gallon Gulf of Mexico tank, where a lazy eel, five feet long, has looped himself around a tire, placed just so in the water, as if for his personal comfort. "That's what you look like in the morning," Sam says.
From there we go to the Maritime and Seafood Industry Museum on Point Cadet. Along with exhibits that preserve maritime artifacts, and displays depicting the life that grew up around the seafood industry, the museum also owns two full-sized schooner replicas, which can be hired out for full- or half-day cruises. The seafood industry was for many years the lifeblood of the town, and changed the face of Biloxi, drawing workers from new places: Cajuns from Louisiana, Bohemians from Baltimore, Dalmatians from Yugoslavia, and Poles. They lived in company-owned shotgun houses and worked in the canneries and on the factory piers shucking oysters, peeling and de-veining shrimp, and shoveling oyster shells to be used in paving roads.
Men, women and children all worked in the seafood industry, which thrived despite the hurricane of 1893 that virtually wiped out the city's fishing fleet; despite the one in 1901 that created 25-foot waves in the Sound or the one in 1915 that eroded much of the shoreline; despite the one in 1947 that buckled the highways; and despite Hurricane Camille, in 1969, that destroyed the remaining Point Cadet fish factories. Here in the museum you can also see a hokey but fascinating video about Camille, the most severe hurricane ever recorded.
Though seafood no longer plays quite so pronounced a role in the local economy as it once did, the city continues to mark the opening of the shrimping season with the Blessing of the Fleet. It includes a parade of decorated boats in Biloxi Harbor that moves past a "blessing boat," on which a Catholic bishop stands, sprinkling each vessel with holy water. Next year the event will be heldon May 1 and 2.
We'd booked ourselves into the Father Ryan House (built in 1841), a B & B distinguished by the giant palm tree growing out of the middle of the front steps. Another good B & B in town is Green Oaks, Biloxi's oldest remaining beachfront house, which is surrounded by old live oaks, and elegantly appointed with period furnishings.
Back at the Father Ryan House, neither Sam nor I cares much about the antique furnishings or the glasses of wine that have been placed in the dining room for guests. That's because Sam has discovered that the house was once the home of Father Abram Ryan, who was known as the poet-priest of the Confederacy. On a credenza he finds a copy of Ryan's poetry, and reads aloud:
Old trees! old trees! in your mystic gloom
There's many a warrior laid,
And many a nameless and lonely tomb
Is sheltered beneath your shade.
"Do you want to go back to the cemetery with me and do some grave rubbings?" I ask when Sam finishes reading the poem. But Sam says enough is enough, and we go out for a hamburger instead.
 
What else to do in a casino town
 
Where to Stay
At the Father Ryan House, 1196 Beach Boulevard (Highway 90), (228) 432-7677, built in 1841, prices range from $100 a night for a double room with a garden view to $175 a night for a two-room suite, with full breakfast and afternoon tea. All rooms include private baths. Major credit cards accepted. The innkeepers recommend that reservations be made at least a week in advance for a weekend stay, and at least two days in advance for weekdays. No smoking.
Green Oaks Bed and Breakfast, 580 Beach Boulevard, (228) 436-6257, has eight rooms furnished with period antiques. Doubles range from $125 to $155, and include full breakfast and mint juleps at teatime. Smoking on the veranda only.
 
What to See
Beauvoir, the site of the Jefferson Davis Home and Presidential Library, is at 2244 Beach Boulevard; (228) 388-9074. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. from March through October; and to 4 between from November through February. Admission is $7.50, $4.50 for children 6 to 16.
The George E. Ohr Arts and Cultural Center is in the old downtown, at 136 G. E. Ohr Street; (228) 374-5547. Admission is $2, and $1 for seniors. Free for members, students and children. The museum is open from 9 A.M. until 5 P.M., Monday through Saturday, Sunday 10 to 4.
 
Where to Eat
McElroy's Harbor House Seafood Restaurant, on Biloxi's Small Craft Harbor, (228) 435-5001, is popular with residents and visitors alike, and often has lines. Prices range from $5.95 for a fish sandwich with fries to $17.45 for the fisherman's platter.
Mary Mahoney's Old French House Restaurant is on the corner of Water Street and Rue Magnolia, just off Highway 90; (228) 374-0163. Open 11 A.M. to 10 P.M., closed on Sundays. Most entrees are priced at around $23.
 
Ship Island
Boats for Ship Island leave from the Gulfport Yacht Harbor, on Highway 90. In the spring and fall, departures are at 9 A.M. and noon on weekends (return trips leave the island at 2:30 and 5 P.M.), once a day, at 9 A.M., during the week (leaving the island at 2 P.M. In summer, boats leave daily at 9 A.M. and noon. The round-trip fare is $16, $14 for seniors and $8 for children 3 to 10. The telephone number is (228) 864-1014.

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
Before the Prosperity, There Was Barbecue

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: LAWNSIDE

 BODY:
When the Olympic champion Carl Lewis came home to Willingboro to accept an award earlier this year, he brought a couple of friends, Oprah Winfrey and her boyfriend Steadman Graham. Word had it that before the ceremony, the three sneaked over to this town in Camden County.
If so, they would not have been the first. Sarah Vaughan used to do it all the time when she performed in Philadelphia or New York. So did Ella Fitzgerald, Joe Louis and Jersey Joe Walcott. 
 For more than a half-century, people of all stripes flocked here, the oldest incorporated black community in the Northeast, to try out one of its many barbecue joints.
No more.
This summer, the last bar serving barbecue here, Hilly's Place, closed its doors. Down a bit on Evesham Avenue, the cement porch sign announcing "Gerry's Family Barbeque" with its painted pig head, is there, but the ramshackle dining room and open-pit cooking area have been demolished. Other signs announce "BBQ" and "Soul Food," but the signs on the buildings behind them read "For Sale." Around the corner on the White Horse Pike, even the relatively new Classic Kitchen has shut its doors.
"An era has clearly ended in Lawnside," said Linda Waller, president of the Lawnside Historical Society. "But who knows if it is a bad thing?"
In reality, Lawnside is having something of an economic revival. Settled by free blacks in the 19th century, this town of 2,800 has long been a working-class black town tucked behind affluent neighbors like Haddonfield, Tavistock and Cherry Hill. But in recent years, a large shopping center has replaced an abandoned orchard, and a former trash dump will be the site of town houses selling in the six figures. The land where Gerry's and Hilly's recently stood may be similarly developed before long.
But that does not stop people like Clarence H. Still, a lifelong borough resident and unofficial historian here, from having a few pangs of nostalgia.
"It's definitely missed by the older group," said Mr. Still. "Us older folks will talk about the neighborhood, remembering things that happened there."
Lawnside was a center of black clubs and amusement parks in another boom time, the 1920's, when some entrepreneurs took an open field near a commercial area by Evesham Avenue and the White Horse Pike and turned it into a sort of amusement park.
"I'm almost 78 and I was like 5 or 6 years old and the first thing I remember, there was a picnic grove," said Spencer C. Moore, who now lives in nearby Magnolia. "There was a club, the Cotton Club, and they put up a nice pavilion with wooden benches and tables. One thing led to another and they got a liquor license and then they enclosed it and had shows in there."
By the 1930's, a stream on the property was dammed up and two lakes for swimming and boating were formed. Summers found a swimming pool filled and one local man with an eye for a dollar set up arcade games, even a Ferris wheel. The clientele was almost exclusively black.
"Things thrived because of segregation," said Mr. Still. "There had been nowhere for black folks to come to be comfortable and be entertained. Clubs grew up across the street. It became the place to go. I'd sit on my porch as a kid and see buses and buses. Black folks on double-decker buses from Philadelphia, and then touring buses from Ohio and North Carolina and who knows where else."
And when people wanted to eat, they wanted to eat something familiar.
"Everyone tried to outdo the other one with the cooking," said Mr. Still. "That was a big attraction. "Was it Southern-style barbecue? No, it was Lawnside-style. People started asking for their barbecue that way."
Mr. Still and Mr. Moore said Lawnside-style barbecue probably got its reputation because people were eating it while they were in a partying mood, so they were predisposed to think it was the greatest.
At least through the 1940's, the entertainment district thrived. Even Philadelphia didn't have the reputation among blacks for partying that the little town 10 miles to the east did. There was the Whippoorwill Club, just inside the Magnolia town line, and next to that was Wilcox's Cafe. Then on down to Harrison's Barbecue and Hilly's and Dreamland and the Cotton Club.
"There was also Showell's Tea Room, where they didn't ever serve tea," said Mr. Moore. "The gimmick was they would serve the liquor in teacups and teapots.
"And then there was a guy named A. B. Johnson who had a joint, a bar without too much entertainment," he added in reverie. "Johnson was a bully when he had a couple of drinks. He bullied this little guy named Brown. Brownie went home and got a shotgun. He came back into the bar and shot it through the handrail. But that is where A. B.'s arm was, and in the end, he had to have it amputated."
As segregation dwindled and blacks were more welcome in what were once white city entertainment districts, Lawnside became less of a draw. Through the 1960's and 70's, there was still a lot of partying on Saturday nights, but it was mostly local. By the early 1990's, the bars ceased to offer entertainment, but there were still some barbecue joints filled on weekend evenings.
"In recent years, they just didn't draw," said Mr. Waller of the Lawnside Historical Society. "When the shopping center went in, that was the last straw. There was more reason to hang out there. I'm glad it's doing well, because it's good for the economy here. But we have lost just about every family-owned business, including the barbecue places. On the whole, it is good, but you lose something when local people don't run things."
And at least Lawnside barbecue has found its niche.
"People just do it at home now,' said Mr. Still. "It smells just as good around here on a summer night. They just don't sell it any more. Every once in a while, a church has a barbecue night -- fish, chicken, ribs. It's real good. Then us in the older group can sit back and tell stories. Entertain the young ones."
And eat.

HEADLINE: It's a Law. Estate Owners Will Keep Their Distance.

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: BERNARDSVILLE

 BODY:
Grazing cows were about the only residents of Meadowbrook Farm visible from Mine Brook Road here on a brilliant fall morning last week, when the wooded Somerset hills were ablaze with the colors of autumn. Mayor Hugh Fenwick would no doubt have been pleased.
In a move that the popular Mayor said is intended to protect the environment, limit flash-flooding around the town's lower elevations and preserve Bernardsville's rural character, the Borough Council approved an ordinance on Oct. 18 that limits the size of houses based on the size of their lots. 
 The ordinance will work like this: A house on a three-acre lot will be allowed to take up 5 percent of the lot, or 6,534 square feet. A house on a five-acre lot will be permitted to take up 4 percent of the lot, or 8,712 square feet.
"We have traditionally, in Bernardsville, been rural, country, whatever the word," said Mr. Fenwick, who lives on a 17-acre estate (the house is not visible from Mendham Road) left to him by his late mother, Milicent Fenwick, who represented the area in Congress for eight years before her death in 1983. "One of the ways we have been able to be that way is to have a few wealthy people build very large houses on very large properties, so they did not encroach on the road."
While Bernardsville is not exactly being invaded by the Beverly Hillbillies, the new wealth generated by the region's economic prosperity has prompted a boom in which ever-larger houses are rising on lots that could hardly be called country estates. In the exclusive Bernardsville Mountain section, traditional refuge of the landed gentry, the new houses tend to be close to the road and highly visible.
Currently, the 62-year-old Mr. Fenwick said, the limitations specify merely that houses on lots of three acres or more lots be set back at least 125 feet in front and 75 feet on the sides. That has allowed for a proliferation of what some local planners have taken to call McMansions -- squeezed together in all their gaudy suburbanization.
"When we looked at our protection against what might be called wall-to-wall housing, we had nothing to protect us from houses that might be 150 feet apart, but the house might be 200 feet long," Mr. Fenwick said.
To be sure, not everyone agrees with the new restrictions. James F. Williams, one of two members of the six-member council to vote against the ordinance, said it would force some residents whose houses are already near the size limit to apply for a variance before building a cabana, guest house or other structure.
"To me, all you're doing is driving many of our existing residents to the Board of Adjustment," Mr. Williams said.
Mr. Williams, who himself lives in a relatively modest Cape Cod, said he did not like the thought of rows of inappropriately large houses, either. But, the 58-year-old councilman added, "unfortunately, you can't legislate taste."
Mr. Fenwick conceded that the ordinance could give the impression -- falsely, he insisted -- that the town's landed gentry were trying to tell the new 90's millionaires and other nouveaux riches how to spend their ample disposable income.
The newly rich are fine with him.
"We are allowed to plan the way we would like the town to look," he said, "so in doing that, it could look like the old money would be trying to tell the new how they should be spending their money. I would not be in favor of doing that. I don't like the message it sends.
He added: "It doesn't bother me that we have the second-highest income in the fourth-richest county in the United States. That doesn't bother me. People with money don't bother me."
The ordinance, which goes into effect tomorrow, is merely a precaution, Mr. Fenwick said. Anyone who has already applied for planning board approval or a building permit is exempt from the ordinance, he said.
Patrick O'Keefe, executive director of the New Jersey Builders Association, declined to comment, other than to say that size is not necessarily a factor in the profitability of a house.
Even if the ordinance is intended to curb the consciousness of consumption among the economic boom's beneficiaries, it could be for their own good, said one local builder, who preferred to remain anonymous.
"We've got people who spend money like it's going out of style that we call the nouveaux riches," said the builder. "Those are the people the Mayor and council are protecting. Because if this bubble bursts, they're never going to afford that."

HEADLINE: Mayors and Their Challengers;
Incumbents Cite Achievements, and Contenders Appear Undaunted by the Odds Against Them

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
WHEN Mary Margaret Mulrooney was an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, a judge nicknamed her the bulldog. As she seeks to unseat Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers, she says the name still fits.
"Whether it's a court case or a political cause, when I sink my teeth into something, I shake my head and don't let go," Ms. Mulrooney said last week. She is a 46-year-old Democrat and a lawyer in private practice. Mayor Spencer is a 52-year-old Republican and a former city councilman. 
 The candidate challenging Mr. Spencer shares similar characteristics with two other mayoral hopefuls, although each comes from a different background. All three challengers are relatively unknown but apparently undaunted by the odds against them.
In Mount Vernon, the odds that favor incumbents have actually encouraged Emilio John Bosco Jr., a Democrat who is running on the Republican, Independence and Liberal tickets against Mayor Ernest D. Davis, also a Democrat and the one who got the Democratic nomination.
"I'm a man who loves a challenge," said Mr. Bosco, a retired 56-year-old businessman with no political experience who ran in a field of five candidates for Mayor four years ago, and came in second with 32 percent of the vote. "I look for things that take chutzpah." As a young man, Mr. Bosco served with the Army's 101st Airborne Division, and in 1962 he was a personal guard to James Meredith, the first black person to attend the University of Mississippi.
But Hank Bartels of New Rochelle says it takes more than guts and grit to unseat an incumbent. Mr. Bartels, 41, a Republican and Conservative who is running against Mayor Timothy C. Idoni, a Democrat, said, "It also takes a thick-skinned, even-tempered candidate who's willing to persevere against the odds and fight for his ideas."
In addition to their personality traits, the challengers share something else in common: their belief that in a prosperous economy, the incumbents have sought out big business ventures at the expense of small and middle-size entrepreneurs.
In Yonkers, Ms. Mulrooney said that the current administration favors condominium development and private use of the waterfront over businesses like restaurants and convention centers, for example, which would attract the public to the Hudson River's shores.
In Mount Vernon, Mr. Bosco wants to bring back the little stores and neighborhoods in place of the Mayor Davis's plan to build a large hotel and convention center.
And in New Rochelle, Mr. Bartels, the son of blue-collar workers, said he was concerned that Mr. Idoni's efforts to see the city grow are leaving out the neighborhood merchants who once formed the city's backbone. He said discussions of taking land by eminent domain for giant stores have frightened downtown residents. "Mr. Idoni's vision is not the people's vision," Mr. Bartels said. "Mine is."
In response to their challengers, the incumbents cited their accomplishments in office and their opposition's lack of government experience. None of the three challengers has held an elected office. The incumbents brushed aside complaints and criticism as political rhetoric and distortions of the facts.
William Dentzer, a spokesman for Mayor Spencer, said Ms. Mulrooney was manufacturing issues.
The mayor's campaign literature counts among his achievements in office the reduction in the city's income tax surcharge, the first no-property-tax-increase budget in 30 years, the end to the oversight by the state's Emergency Financial Control Board, a 21 percent decrease in crime, record increases in state financing of schools, control over where and how to build new dwellings in the 19-year-old housing desegregation case and the ability for the school district to design its own curriculum to correct the effects of desegregation, among other things.
Mr. Spencer also cites the beginning of a public and private revitalization of the waterfront and downtown area by securing county, state and Federal financing, elimination of graffiti with strict laws and the establishment of professional management training in City Hall and performance-based evaluations.
The Mayor would not allow a photographer to take his picture, saying that other photographs had already been taken and he did not want his time wasted. "Every time I do an interview with the media, they distort the issues, and they make a controversy when one doesn't exist," he said, explaining why he declined to be interviewed. "The media ruins people's lives."
Ms. Mulrooney has criticized Mr. Spencer, who is running on the Republican, Independence, Conservative and Right to Life tickets, for being inaccessible and remote -- a charge Mr. Spencer denies.
Ms. Mulrooney, who has made a campaign promise to do away with some of the Mayor's powers -- specifically the ability to appoint school board members -- also blames Mr. Spencer for creating the divisive atmosphere between the school board and teachers that preceded a four-day walkout by teachers this fall.
As the election approaches on Tuesday for the full-time job that will pay $133,000 a year beginning in January, Ms. Mulrooney is banking on the tendency of the state's fourth-largest city to favor political upstarts. In 1979, for example, a brash young Democratic City Councilman, Gerald E. Loehr, ousted the incumbent Mayor, Angelo R. Martinelli, with a campaign promise of restoring fiscal integrity to Yonkers and of eliminating the divisiveness that he said had often characterized the city's politics. In 1987, Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a City Councilman, won the mayoral race in an upset of Mr. Martinelli -- who by that time was a six-term Mayor. In 1991, Mr. Martinelli, again the favored candidate and hoping to make a comeback, lost his bid to Terence M. Zaleski, the son of a factory worker and a onetime science teacher and lawyer.
"It has been known to happen," Ms. Mulrooney said.
In Mount Vernon, Mayor Davis, 61, said his opponent, Mr. Bosco, was also manufacturing issues. He said his achievements spoke for themselves: new jobs for residents, a reduced crime rate (burglaries down by 29.4 percent and robberies down by 30.6 percent), more than $1 million invested in low interest loans to rehabilitate housing, real estate values up 12 percent and the smallest tax increases in a decade.
Mr. Bosco questioned Mayor Davis's effort to refinance Levister Towers, a low-cost housing development, which Mr. Bosco said has been the victim of "uncaring, neglectful and incompetent management." He has also said that the Mayor's repairs to Memorial Field have not been enough, and that he should be doing more. Mr. Bosco also said that Mount Vernon needs to be run more like a business that treats taxpayers as stockholders.
Mr. Davis said, "Mr. Bosco thinks you can take a problem like Levister Towers and cure it overnight with a wave of a magic wand." Mr. Davis has proposed bringing in a developer and restructuring the housing project so that tenants can become stakeholders.
"People will be able to afford to live there," Mr. Davis said. "No one will be removed, and we will get payments for back taxes. How can you criticize that?"
The same argument about overnight miracles applies to Memorial Field, the Mr. Davis said, adding that the city is developing a master plan for the ballpark and working closely with the county on it.
As for government being run like a business, Mr. Davis said: "What does that mean? Businesses sell products and make profits. The purpose of government is to empower people and protect them and help them do things they can't do by themselves. If profit is the motive, then something is seriously off, because services like garbage removal and paving are not profitable, even though they are important."
The full-time mayor's job in Mount Vernon pays $80,000 a year.
In New Rochelle, Mr. Idoni, 44, is seeking a third term and relying on his record.
"Who would have thought just a few short years ago that New Rochelle would have a nationally recognized entertainment center instead of a broken-down mall in its downtown?" Mr. Idoni's campaign literature says.
Mr. Idoni, a part-time mayor who earns $63,500 a year, said he is proud that, among other things, luxury rental apartments and a park have replaced vacant lots on Huguenot Street, that crime has dropped more than 30 percent and that the city's most recent tax increase was less than 1 percent.
"The opposition just needs to find something wrong with our efforts," he said.
Answering the concerns of Mr. Bartels about where medium-size businesses fit into the plan, Mr. Idoni said the city is already courting ladies apparel retailers, shoe stores and enterprises like Borders Books and Music for its downtown.
Mr. Bartels, a marketer and manager for a dental materials concern, said the city -- in addition to encouraging small and medium-size businesses -- needs more consistent law enforcement to promote safer streets and cleaner neighborhoods. A member of the school board and co-president of the Halycon Park Neighborhood Association, he said he backs more accessible parking, lower property taxes for the school district and holding the line on city taxes.
 
Peekskill Window of Opportunity for Democrats
 
PEEKSKILL
WITH this city's 73-year-old incumbent Republican Mayor, Frances S. Gibbs, stepping down after three terms, the race for the top spot here has opened up the possibility that for the first time in 38 years, there might be a Democratic Mayor.
Mayor Gibbs's retirement has also generated discussion on two pressing issues that arose during her current term, when Peekskill residents were arrested for speaking out at public meetings and when residents accused city officials of racism for their efforts to install cameras in housing projects where minority groups live and also on public streets.
The questions are whether surveillance cameras are the answer to the city's crime problem and how to make government more responsive. Although Mayor Gibbs supported the use of cameras and opposed residents' speaking on issues not previously scheduled for discussion at City Council meetings, not even John J. Kelly 3d, the Republican candidate in this race, has taken a similar stand.
In the election two years ago, Mr. Kelly, 42, ran against Mayor Gibbs on the Conservative and Independence Party Lines and describes himself as a reform Republican. He is distancing himself from members of his party who associated themselves with Mayor Gibbs.
"The current G.O.P. does not have its finger on the pulse of the public and is not open to criticism or new ideas," Mr. Kelly said. "I'm part of the new Republicans, not the old breed."
Mr. Kelly, a former history teacher and a school administrator in Orange County, said he supports more open public meetings -- "although not a circus atmosphere," he said. And although he said he supports the limited use of surveillance cameras in parking garages and at public pools, he said he does not back their use on streets and other public places, where a traditional police force should be stationed, he said. He is also running on the Independence and Conservative lines.
Opposing Mr. Kelly is Eileen Yajure, 40, who said she wants to be the first Democratic Mayor since 1961."Sometimes when one party is entrenched for so long, officials start acting like the king and queen of the court, and they are stunned when their authority is questioned," she said. "My response is, 'Hello, this is a democracy!' "
Ms. Yajure said she opposes the use of surveillance cameras in public places and she promised to make city government more responsive."The greatest need of Peekskill's citizens is to be listened to and to have a relationship with government," she said.
Looking ahead to the coming two-year term, Mr. Kelly said Peekskill's greatest need "is to get aggressive in promoting the economic development of the downtown."
The part-time mayoral position pays $12,000 a year. Mr. Kelly said that because the Mayor's job is to set policy, he would be able to attend to both his school administrative duties and his responsibilities as Mayor.
Ms. Yajure, who works as a freelance computer software consultant, also said that she had no worries about balancing two sets of responsibilities. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: Mayors and Their Challengers;
Incumbents Cite Achievements, and Contenders Appear Undaunted by the Odds Against Them

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
WHEN Mary Margaret Mulrooney was an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, a judge nicknamed her the bulldog. As she seeks to unseat Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers, she says the name still fits.
"Whether it's a court case or a political cause, when I sink my teeth into something, I shake my head and don't let go," Ms. Mulrooney said last week. She is a 46-year-old Democrat and a lawyer in private practice. Mayor Spencer is a 52-year-old Republican and a former city councilman. 
 The candidate challenging Mr. Spencer shares similar characteristics with two other mayoral hopefuls, although each comes from a different background. All three challengers are relatively unknown but apparently undaunted by the odds against them.
In Mount Vernon, the odds that favor incumbents have actually encouraged Emilio John Bosco Jr., a Democrat who is running on the Republican, Independence and Liberal tickets against Mayor Ernest D. Davis, also a Democrat and the one who got the Democratic nomination.
"I'm a man who loves a challenge," said Mr. Bosco, a retired 56-year-old businessman with no political experience who ran in a field of five candidates for Mayor four years ago, and came in second with 32 percent of the vote. "I look for things that take chutzpah." As a young man, Mr. Bosco served with the Army's 101st Airborne Division, and in 1962 he was a personal guard to James Meredith, the first black person to attend the University of Mississippi.
But Hank Bartels of New Rochelle says it takes more than guts and grit to unseat an incumbent. Mr. Bartels, 41, a Republican and Conservative who is running against Mayor Timothy C. Idoni, a Democrat, said, "It also takes a thick-skinned, even-tempered candidate who's willing to persevere against the odds and fight for his ideas."
In addition to their personality traits, the challengers share something else in common: their belief that in a prosperous economy, the incumbents have sought out big business ventures at the expense of small and middle-size entrepreneurs.
In Yonkers, Ms. Mulrooney said that the current administration favors condominium development and private use of the waterfront over businesses like restaurants and convention centers, for example, which would attract the public to the Hudson River's shores.
In Mount Vernon, Mr. Bosco wants to bring back the little stores and neighborhoods in place of the Mayor Davis's plan to build a large hotel and convention center.
And in New Rochelle, Mr. Bartels, the son of blue-collar workers, said he was concerned that Mr. Idoni's efforts to see the city grow are leaving out the neighborhood merchants who once formed the city's backbone. He said discussions of taking land by eminent domain for giant stores have frightened downtown residents. "Mr. Idoni's vision is not the people's vision," Mr. Bartels said. "Mine is."
In response to their challengers, the incumbents cited their accomplishments in office and their opposition's lack of government experience. None of the three challengers has held an elected office. The incumbents brushed aside complaints and criticism as political rhetoric and distortions of the facts.
William Dentzer, a spokesman for Mayor Spencer, said Ms. Mulrooney was manufacturing issues.
The mayor's campaign literature counts among his achievements in office the reduction in the city's income tax surcharge, the first no-property-tax-increase budget in 30 years, the end to the oversight by the state's Emergency Financial Control Board, a 21 percent decrease in crime, record increases in state financing of schools, control over where and how to build new dwellings in the 19-year-old housing desegregation case and the ability for the school district to design its own curriculum to correct the effects of desegregation, among other things.
Mr. Spencer also cites the beginning of a public and private revitalization of the waterfront and downtown area by securing county, state and Federal financing, elimination of graffiti with strict laws and the establishment of professional management training in City Hall and performance-based evaluations.
The Mayor would not allow a photographer to take his picture, saying that other photographs had already been taken and he did not want his time wasted. "Every time I do an interview with the media, they distort the issues, and they make a controversy when one doesn't exist," he said, explaining why he declined to be interviewed. "The media ruins people's lives."
Ms. Mulrooney has criticized Mr. Spencer, who is running on the Republican, Independence, Conservative and Right to Life tickets, for being inaccessible and remote -- a charge Mr. Spencer denies.
Ms. Mulrooney, who has made a campaign promise to do away with some of the Mayor's powers -- specifically the ability to appoint school board members -- also blames Mr. Spencer for creating the divisive atmosphere between the school board and teachers that preceded a four-day walkout by teachers this fall.
As the election approaches on Tuesday for the full-time job that will pay $133,000 a year beginning in January, Ms. Mulrooney is banking on the tendency of the state's fourth-largest city to favor political upstarts. In 1979, for example, a brash young Democratic City Councilman, Gerald E. Loehr, ousted the incumbent Mayor, Angelo R. Martinelli, with a campaign promise of restoring fiscal integrity to Yonkers and of eliminating the divisiveness that he said had often characterized the city's politics. In 1987, Nicholas C. Wasicsko, a City Councilman, won the mayoral race in an upset of Mr. Martinelli -- who by that time was a six-term Mayor. In 1991, Mr. Martinelli, again the favored candidate and hoping to make a comeback, lost his bid to Terence M. Zaleski, the son of a factory worker and a onetime science teacher and lawyer.
"It has been known to happen," Ms. Mulrooney said.
In Mount Vernon, Mayor Davis, 61, said his opponent, Mr. Bosco, was also manufacturing issues. He said his achievements spoke for themselves: new jobs for residents, a reduced crime rate (burglaries down by 29.4 percent and robberies down by 30.6 percent), more than $1 million invested in low interest loans to rehabilitate housing, real estate values up 12 percent and the smallest tax increases in a decade.
Mr. Bosco questioned Mayor Davis's effort to refinance Levister Towers, a low-cost housing development, which Mr. Bosco said has been the victim of "uncaring, neglectful and incompetent management." He has also said that the Mayor's repairs to Memorial Field have not been enough, and that he should be doing more. Mr. Bosco also said that Mount Vernon needs to be run more like a business that treats taxpayers as stockholders.
Mr. Davis said, "Mr. Bosco thinks you can take a problem like Levister Towers and cure it overnight with a wave of a magic wand." Mr. Davis has proposed bringing in a developer and restructuring the housing project so that tenants can become stakeholders.
"People will be able to afford to live there," Mr. Davis said. "No one will be removed, and we will get payments for back taxes. How can you criticize that?"
The same argument about overnight miracles applies to Memorial Field, the Mr. Davis said, adding that the city is developing a master plan for the ballpark and working closely with the county on it.
As for government being run like a business, Mr. Davis said: "What does that mean? Businesses sell products and make profits. The purpose of government is to empower people and protect them and help them do things they can't do by themselves. If profit is the motive, then something is seriously off, because services like garbage removal and paving are not profitable, even though they are important."
The full-time mayor's job in Mount Vernon pays $80,000 a year.
In New Rochelle, Mr. Idoni, 44, is seeking a third term and relying on his record.
"Who would have thought just a few short years ago that New Rochelle would have a nationally recognized entertainment center instead of a broken-down mall in its downtown?" Mr. Idoni's campaign literature says.
Mr. Idoni, a part-time mayor who earns $63,500 a year, said he is proud that, among other things, luxury rental apartments and a park have replaced vacant lots on Huguenot Street, that crime has dropped more than 30 percent and that the city's most recent tax increase was less than 1 percent.
"The opposition just needs to find something wrong with our efforts," he said.
Answering the concerns of Mr. Bartels about where medium-size businesses fit into the plan, Mr. Idoni said the city is already courting ladies apparel retailers, shoe stores and enterprises like Borders Books and Music for its downtown.
Mr. Bartels, a marketer and manager for a dental materials concern, said the city -- in addition to encouraging small and medium-size businesses -- needs more consistent law enforcement to promote safer streets and cleaner neighborhoods. A member of the school board and co-president of the Halycon Park Neighborhood Association, he said he backs more accessible parking, lower property taxes for the school district and holding the line on city taxes.
 
Peekskill Window of Opportunity for Democrats
 
PEEKSKILL
WITH this city's 73-year-old incumbent Republican Mayor, Frances S. Gibbs, stepping down after three terms, the race for the top spot here has opened up the possibility that for the first time in 38 years, there might be a Democratic Mayor.
Mayor Gibbs's retirement has also generated discussion on two pressing issues that arose during her current term, when Peekskill residents were arrested for speaking out at public meetings and when residents accused city officials of racism for their efforts to install cameras in housing projects where minority groups live and also on public streets.
The questions are whether surveillance cameras are the answer to the city's crime problem and how to make government more responsive. Although Mayor Gibbs supported the use of cameras and opposed residents' speaking on issues not previously scheduled for discussion at City Council meetings, not even John J. Kelly 3d, the Republican candidate in this race, has taken a similar stand.
In the election two years ago, Mr. Kelly, 42, ran against Mayor Gibbs on the Conservative and Independence Party Lines and describes himself as a reform Republican. He is distancing himself from members of his party who associated themselves with Mayor Gibbs.
"The current G.O.P. does not have its finger on the pulse of the public and is not open to criticism or new ideas," Mr. Kelly said. "I'm part of the new Republicans, not the old breed."
Mr. Kelly, a former history teacher and a school administrator in Orange County, said he supports more open public meetings -- "although not a circus atmosphere," he said. And although he said he supports the limited use of surveillance cameras in parking garages and at public pools, he said he does not back their use on streets and other public places, where a traditional police force should be stationed, he said. He is also running on the Independence and Conservative lines.
Opposing Mr. Kelly is Eileen Yajure, 40, who said she wants to be the first Democratic Mayor since 1961."Sometimes when one party is entrenched for so long, officials start acting like the king and queen of the court, and they are stunned when their authority is questioned," she said. "My response is, 'Hello, this is a democracy!' "
Ms. Yajure said she opposes the use of surveillance cameras in public places and she promised to make city government more responsive."The greatest need of Peekskill's citizens is to be listened to and to have a relationship with government," she said.
Looking ahead to the coming two-year term, Mr. Kelly said Peekskill's greatest need "is to get aggressive in promoting the economic development of the downtown."
The part-time mayoral position pays $12,000 a year. Mr. Kelly said that because the Mayor's job is to set policy, he would be able to attend to both his school administrative duties and his responsibilities as Mayor.
Ms. Yajure, who works as a freelance computer software consultant, also said that she had no worries about balancing two sets of responsibilities. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL /2000 Ford Focus;
The Econobox Turns a Corner and Picks Up Some Edge

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
JUDGING by the models arriving in dealer showrooms this fall, one might think that small-car sales are booming and profits from economy models are soaring.
But the opposite is true. The small-car market has been in a slump for nearly three years as cheap gasoline and stable vehicle prices have drawn buyers to larger vehicles, including sport utilities. Profits from small cars are negligible to nonexistent. 
 Still, auto makers must churn out small, fuel-efficient automobiles to help bring down their federally mandated corporate fuel economy averages, which are being pulled higher by brisk sales of big, gas-guzzling vehicles. In addition, econoboxes are aimed largely at young, often first-time buyers, a group expected to grow to as much as a third of the market by 2005, according to J. D. Power & Associates, the market research company.
Despite the doldrums in the small-car market, the auto makers' latest efforts to lure buyers to their much-improved products have been valiant.
Last spring, DaimlerChrysler revamped its Neon for the 2000 model year, giving it a more grown-up look but maintaining its fun-to-drive character. This fall, Toyota introduced the Echo, an unusual-looking small car with a price that starts around $10,000. Saturn has spruced up its dated S-Series, and in the spring Nissan will bring out a new Sentra, which is expected to be certified in California as the world's first gasoline-powered "super ultra low emission" vehicle. Honda will revise the segment's best-seller, the Civic, next year.
Among the most impressive small cars of recent years, however, is a new entry, the Ford Focus, which melds edgy styling with a spacious interior and superb handling.
After a month with four versions of the Focus -- the base and midlevel sedans, the station wagon and the sporty, top-line sedan -- I concluded that the car is well suited to buyers who want more than basic transportation, but still want an entry-level price. It is a subcompact I could happily live with.
The Focus, which began arriving in dealer showrooms on Oct. 1, is intended to replace the Escort eventually, but for now that car will stay around; the Focus is priced and sized between the Escort and the compact Contour. The Focus comes as a ZX3 hatchback, a wagon and a sedan in three versions -- the base LX, the big-volume SE and the sporty ZTS. The American car is virtually identical to the one introduced in Europe a year ago, which auto writers voted European Car of the Year.
Like the Mercury Cougar, the Focus is cloaked in a rather extreme example of Ford's New Edge styling, which features crisp lines and taut surfaces. The Focus won't be mistaken for anything else on the road. I found more people liked its look than hated it, and few were indifferent.
The interior is unusually spacious for a small car, with a high roofline that comfortably accommodates 6-footers. Rear legroom is among the best in class. The very supportive seats are raised higher than in most small cars, and entry and exit is easy through tall, wide doors. If nearly 13 cubic feet of trunk space isn't enough, one simply folds the split rear seats to add capacity.
To anyone accustomed to the clean, generic interiors of small Japanese cars, the Focus seems awfully busy, a puzzle of assorted geometric shapes. Still, the pieces fit snugly and the interior materials seemed to be of good quality.
The controls are large and easy to operate; the gauges use large numbers, making them easy to read.
Ford said it used human and electronic testers to insure a pleasant new-car smell, but I still detected the acrid odor of plastic parts that haven't cured long enough.
The Focus has many conveniences, including a steering wheel that tilts and telescopes, a height-adjustable driver's seat, useful cup holders and a console with storage space and a pen holder.
Safety features include seatbelts with pretensioners and retractors to keep occupants in the safest position in a crash, child safety seat anchors and an emergency release in the trunk. Side air bags are optional at $350. Anti-lock brakes, standard on the ZTS, cost $400 on other models.
After driving away, Focus buyers receive a welcome package in the mail from Ford, part of a youth-oriented marketing campaign that includes live television ads and Webcasts. The welcome items include a watch; a picture frame that attaches to the dashboard; an expandable, megasized cup holder, and a sunglass case. To further personalize the car, as young buyers often do, Ford plans to sell several accessory packages: one for pet owners has a color-coordinated water bowl, among other things; a Friends Package has seat covers, a candy dispenser and an ice cooler.
I could do without the candy or dog bowl. The car's driving dynamics would seal the deal.
This little car is darn fun to drive. It reminded me of Ford's sporty Puma, a wonderful coupe sold overseas.
The Focus is available with two 2-liter, four-cylinder engines, either a 110-horsepower, single-cam version or the 130-horsepower, dual-cam Zetec, which is standard on the GTS and ZX3. Transmission choices are a five-speed manual or a new electronically controlled four-speed automatic.
The dual-cam engine puts the Focus in a league with the peppy Dodge Neon and versions of the Civic that have a zippy Honda engine with variable valve timing. It handily accelerated onto the freeway even when carrying five adults. The base engine did not measure up so well, however, and it felt especially sluggish in the heavier station wagon, where it is the only engine available.
Regardless of the engine or the trim level, the Focus handles crisply and responsively. The steering is precise and the brakes feel sturdy. The ride is comfortable for a car of this size, though road noise is excessive, especially in the back seat.
The Focus hatchback starts at $12,280, sedans at $12,540 and the wagon at $15,795. The prices seemed attractive when they were announced last spring, but Toyota upstaged Ford by putting a sticker of $9,995, plus shipping, on the Echo hatchback.
With its edgy styling, ample space for people and cargo, great handling and numerous features, the Focus makes a big impression. It is a lot of small car for the money.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A funky-looking subcompact for drivers who like to drive.

HEADLINE: Bitter Pills for Ailing Hospitals

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
"I COULD take off my shoe and show you I don't have a cloven hoof," said David Hunter, putting a self-mocking spin on his contentious line of work.
Famous as a slash-and-burn cost-cutter who can do the dirty work that floundering hospitals cannot bring themselves to tackle on their own, Mr. Hunter is often greeted as the Devil incarnate. No one's job is safe when his 70-member consulting firm, Hunter Group, wields the axe: along with thousands of clerks, technicians, nurses, doctors and other workers, Hunter has recently displaced chief executives at major university-affiliated teaching hospitals in Chicago, Detroit and San Francisco. The company's latest emergency rescue plan is for the premier medical center in Philadelphia. 
 No question, these institutions and others like them are staring at daunting problems. Battered by big cuts in Medicare payments, rising drug costs and managed care plans that force them into below-cost deals, teaching hospitals around the country face mounting financial stresses. The hardest-pressed among them, generally large hospitals in inner cities, find themselves with no choice but to cut costs drastically to keep their doors open.
That is when Mr. Hunter, 54, a no-nonsense management expert with 11 years of experience operating on wounded hospitals, is called in by hospital trustees. "If they are using guys like us," he said, "the problems have to be enormous." He calls the hostile reception he often gets "a shoot-the-messenger issue," adding that "the problems were there before we got involved."
But critics say Hunter Group's shock therapy endangers the triple mission of the medical centers: educating doctors, treating patients of all income levels and conducting the breakthrough medical research that has little or no place at for-profit hospitals. Officials of medical faculty associations and nursing unions, for example, say the job cuts tend to be of the meat-axe, across-the-board variety, hitting vital services as hard as ancillary areas.
"What is happening today is the invisible destruction of the great academic medical centers," said Dr. William M. Kelley, chief executive of the financially troubled University of Pennsylvania Health System. "We will be more efficient and able to deliver care at a lower price, but we will not be able to do the things that made us great," like experimenting with new surgical procedures.
"Our ability to develop the medicine of tomorrow is going away," Dr. Kelley said.
Academic medical centers play a vital role in American health care that is important even to people who never set foot in them. They treat the toughest cases and train the best new doctors, who often hone their skills serving the poor before beginning practice elsewhere. Teaching hospitals develop and test new medicines and surgical procedures on the frontiers of medical knowledge. In many cities, academic medical centers are also the largest employers of both skilled and entry-level workers.
But as inflation in health care revs up after a four-year lull, the great hospitals are under growing pressure from Government and private payers to take yet another tuck in their world-class expenses.
Hunter Group's forte is emergency work, and it loses no time once an engagement begins. Teams of operations and finance experts move from the home base of St. Petersburg, Fla., into nearby hotels and motels and shuttle to the troubled hospital in hired limousines and rental cars paid for by the client.
Referring frequently to a portfolio of "benchmarks" like the ratio of nurses to beds or floor polishers per square foot, drawn from consulting stints at 100 hospitals across the country, they analyze the hospital's operations from the wards and surgical suites to the billing department to the executive suite. "We take a real hard look at the expense side," Mr. Hunter said.
Within 14 weeks in most cases, the consultants present a plan to a steering committee of hospital board members and senior management:
 
 * Cut jobs 20 percent, they said in Philadelphia, where the prestigious University of Pennsylvania Medical Center had an operating loss of $198 million the year ended June 30. Late this month, the hospital said that it would eliminate 2,800 health services jobs out of 14,000 over the next 14 months.
* Close a money-losing satellite hospital that serves the poor, they said in San Francisco, where a merger of two nationally acclaimed hospital systems was bleeding $2 million a month in operating losses. Though the two medical centers, those of Stanford University and the University of California at San Francisco, said on Thursday that they would dissolve the merger, U.C.S.F. said it would go ahead with the closing of in-patient and emergency room services at Mount Zion Hospital. A similar recommendation in Detroit led to the closing of Mount Sinai Hospital there.
* Find a new chief executive, they said in Detroit, Chicago and San Francisco. Someone from Hunter will mind the store in the meantime: David Hunter himself became interim chief executive of California-Stanford; what his role will be after the dissolution of the merger was not clear on Friday. A longtime aide of Mr. Hunter ran the Detroit Medical Center and later the University of Illinois at Chicago Medical Center.
* Flatten management, reduce the numbers of laboratory tests and electrocardiograms, get rid of hundreds of salaried physicians, reduce support money flowing to medical education from patient fees and pare teaching budgets, they say nearly everywhere.
* When the financial problems seem intractable, simply sell the hospital. An 80 percent stake in the George Washington University Medical Center in Washington, for example, was sold in 1997 to a for-profit chain, Universal Health Services.
The discussions between the Hunter team and the client hospital can be tense, said a top hospital executive who has participated in such meetings.
Not every recommendation is accepted: in Boston, the New England Medical Center spurned a Hunter Group proposal that it should sell out to a for-profit company, later arranging its own merger with a nonprofit health care system in Providence. But it is hard for hospital boards to say no when management is temporarily ceded to the consultants.
Rank-and-file doctors, nurses and technicians at the hospitals say they get little or no chance to contribute suggestions or influence the consultants' decisions on cuts. "We knew we were on the chopping block," said a nurse at the San Francisco hospital. "We heard about it on the whisper circuit."
Hunter Group gets the lion's share of assignments to turn around troubled academic medical centers, said Larry Lewin, director of hospital strategy for Lewin Group, a Washington-based consulting firm. But a growing number of health care turnaround firms are competing for the business, and Ernst & Young, the giant accounting and consulting firm, also jumped in recently.
Candidates for the consultants' ministrations have been exploding in number since last year's cuts in Medicare payments to hospitals. The nation's 120 academic medical centers operate 200 hospitals, but some hospital executives doubt that they can all survive without severe cutbacks and closings. A survey of its members by the University Health System Consortium of 80 big teaching hospitals last summer found that two in five had losses in operations in their most recent quarterly results.
In New York City, the five big academic medical centers are headed for a drop of $100 million in their combined annual operating income this year, and shortfalls at the three teaching hospitals of the State University of New York are straining the university system's statewide budget.
"Academic medical centers are the crown jewels of our health system," said Dr. Bernard Ferrari, a consultant at McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm. "They often deliver the most expensive care to the people who are least able to pay. They are an endangered species." A handful have large endowments or other sources of investment income that have tided them over while the stock market has been booming, but even they are now struggling with declining revenue.
Medical schools are attracting fewer applicants than they were a few years ago, but health care economists debate whether the centers are still training too many specialists, too many general practice doctors, or both. Though union officials and politicians stress the importance of the centers in providing tens of thousands of jobs and vital health services for low-income people in cities, deteriorating finances are robbing many of them of the ability to play these roles and still be self-sustaining.
"It is questionable whether Boston, Philadelphia, Washington and New York can support multiple big medical school organizations," Mr. Hunter said.
The hospitals that recently sought help from Hunter Group all have especially steep losses.
The Detroit Medical Center posted operating losses of $160 million last year and $93 million in the first seven months of 1999. The University of Pennsylvania Health System in Philadelphia lost $288 million on operations in the last two years.
University of California-Stanford Health Care projected a $65 million surplus for the first two years after it was created by merging the hospitals of Stanford and the University of California in November 1997. The projection was over-optimistic by $111 million; the center lost $46 million. The two top executives at California-Stanford resigned last August.
Still, in some cases, critics say, Hunter-inspired economizing made it harder, not easier, to stanch the losses. Senior physicians at the New England Medical Center said it took much longer for the hospital to collect outstanding bills after it made deep cuts in its billing department. At the same hospital, a profit-generating liver transplant unit was out of action for a week until replacements could be found for blood bank technicians whose jobs were cut.
But Mr. Hunter's fans point to a return to profitability at beleaguered hospitals in several cities as evidence that broadly, his methods work.
Mr. Hunter, a former hospital executive at Duke University and in Mount Holly, N.J., started Hunter Group with two partners in 1988. Mr. Hunter and his partners sold the firm to 16 of its executives last year for an undisclosed price. Mr. Hunter stayed on as chief executive on contract and retains a financial interest in the company.
"We can do things that existing management can't do," he said in a recent conversation on the front porch of his century-old stone house in Newtown, Pa., outside Philadelphia. For one thing, most academic medical centers operate by consensus among turf-guarding medical superstars not known for small egos. Decision-making in such an environment can be excruciatingly slow, and resistance to outside criticism can run high.
"Ninety-five percent of our members are trying to keep David Hunter out of their institutions," said Robert Baker, president of the University Health System Consortium.
When the Hunter Group is brought in, it is typically for a few months of drastic cutting. "We're not there long term," Mr. Hunter said, and clients rarely sign up for a return engagement. "They never want to go through it again."
Many of the problems that lead a medical center to call the Hunter Group were all too evident in the short, unhappy merger in the San Francisco area.
Stanford Health Services and the University of California San Francisco Medical Center both ranked among the nation's top 10 hospitals in independent surveys before their merger, which was motivated by a desire to overcome the challenges of operating in the vortex of one of the nation's most intense markets for health care plans.
The merger, however, just made the financial problems worse, at least for the short run. Instead of cutting staffs and eliminating duplication, the merged entity wound up adding 1,000 employees, including new managers to coordinate hospitals 40 miles apart at Palo Alto and San Francisco. Unforeseen millions were spent on computers and consultants, including $100 million for Year 2000 upgrades.
Desperate to reverse the trend, the hospital's board called in Hunter Group, at a cost of $414,000 a month plus expenses.
The consultants found that the merged medical centers were spending $15,000 more for each patient than other large hospitals did, reflecting teaching, research and treating the indigent. The number of emergency patients increased sharply, adding to unreimbursed costs last year, after the medical center expanded emergency room capacity at its main hospital in San Francisco.
To attack the cost problems, Hunter consultants negotiated staff reductions with the medical school faculty and the managers of hospital departments and examined ways to get better prices on supplies. Taking care of poor people is both a duty and a financial drag. The merged medical center loses $80 million annually on uncovered services to Medicaid patients, said Peter Van Etten, who was chief executive until August.
Susan Cieutat, a pediatric intensive care nurse who is active in the California Nurses Association, said cuts in staffing levels are causing problems. "There used to be one nurse for three or four patients," she said. "Now it's five or six patients. Nurses are exhausted, stressed, demoralized. Many are looking for work elsewhere."
Mr. Hunter acknowledges that cutting the nursing staff can be delicate because good nursing is crucial to quality of care. And in some places there is a shortage of nurses ready to do stressful jobs. "It's more 'Can we get them?' than 'Can we cut them?' " he said.
As for revenues, Mr. Hunter proposed trying to renegotiate contracts with managed care companies that were based on capitation -- a flat monthly fee for each health plan member -- or on fixed day rates for hospital care; both are money-losers for the hospital, he said, and it would be better off with a fee schedule that varies with the patient's diagnosis. That will not be easy in California, a bastion of managed care.
The cost of care for poor people poses an even more difficult revenue problem. Costs that hospitals have to swallow have been rising as health plans raise their premiums, causing a growing number of working people who are not eligible for Medicaid to drop their coverage. Hospitals are stuck with much of the cost of caring for such patients.
In the glory years before the managed care squeeze and Medicare cutbacks, payments from patients subsidized teaching and research. No longer. Dr. Warren Gold, chairman of the U.C.S.F. medical school faculty association, noted that Hunter Group had recommended "a major cutback in payments from professional fees" -- the money faculty doctors bring in when they treat patients at the hospital -- to finance teaching and research. Instead, according to Dr. Lee Goldman, the acting dean of the medical school, the main concern was to retain money in the hospital to buy state-of-the-art equipment like $3 million gamma knives for delicate brain surgery.
"What is really at risk here is clinical innovation, the interface between a faculty that does research and tries to make advances, and the clinical care," Dr. Goldman said.
"The U.S. is indisputably the leader in this," he added. "In the 1860's it was Germany. Now everybody comes here. It's a great American triumph. But we could screw it up."
But the real choice facing the most troubled medical centers, Mr. Hunter argued, is not one of preserving research financing or cutting it back; it is a choice of ruthlessly cutting expenses or closing the doors. Like it or not, the money to operate the old way simply will not be there in the future, he said.
Mr. Hunter predicted that revenues at academic medical centers would fall by at least 10 percent a year for the foreseeable future, though he acknowledged his estimate might be colored by his close-up knowledge of hospitals in deep trouble. "We're not," he said, "looking at the Miss Americas."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL /2000 Ford Focus;
The Econobox Turns a Corner and Picks Up Some Edge

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
JUDGING by the models arriving in dealer showrooms this fall, one might think that small-car sales are booming and profits from economy models are soaring.
But the opposite is true. The small-car market has been in a slump for nearly three years as cheap gasoline and stable vehicle prices have drawn buyers to larger vehicles, including sport utilities. Profits from small cars are negligible to nonexistent. 
 Still, auto makers must churn out small, fuel-efficient automobiles to help bring down their federally mandated corporate fuel economy averages, which are being pulled higher by brisk sales of big, gas-guzzling vehicles. In addition, econoboxes are aimed largely at young, often first-time buyers, a group expected to grow to as much as a third of the market by 2005, according to J. D. Power & Associates, the market research company.
Despite the doldrums in the small-car market, the auto makers' latest efforts to lure buyers to their much-improved products have been valiant.
Last spring, DaimlerChrysler revamped its Neon for the 2000 model year, giving it a more grown-up look but maintaining its fun-to-drive character. This fall, Toyota introduced the Echo, an unusual-looking small car with a price that starts around $10,000. Saturn has spruced up its dated S-Series, and in the spring Nissan will bring out a new Sentra, which is expected to be certified in California as the world's first gasoline-powered "super ultra low emission" vehicle. Honda will revise the segment's best-seller, the Civic, next year.
Among the most impressive small cars of recent years, however, is a new entry, the Ford Focus, which melds edgy styling with a spacious interior and superb handling.
After a month with four versions of the Focus -- the base and midlevel sedans, the station wagon and the sporty, top-line sedan -- I concluded that the car is well suited to buyers who want more than basic transportation, but still want an entry-level price. It is a subcompact I could happily live with.
The Focus, which began arriving in dealer showrooms on Oct. 1, is intended to replace the Escort eventually, but for now that car will stay around; the Focus is priced and sized between the Escort and the compact Contour. The Focus comes as a ZX3 hatchback, a wagon and a sedan in three versions -- the base LX, the big-volume SE and the sporty ZTS. The American car is virtually identical to the one introduced in Europe a year ago, which auto writers voted European Car of the Year.
Like the Mercury Cougar, the Focus is cloaked in a rather extreme example of Ford's New Edge styling, which features crisp lines and taut surfaces. The Focus won't be mistaken for anything else on the road. I found more people liked its look than hated it, and few were indifferent.
The interior is unusually spacious for a small car, with a high roofline that comfortably accommodates 6-footers. Rear legroom is among the best in class. The very supportive seats are raised higher than in most small cars, and entry and exit is easy through tall, wide doors. If nearly 13 cubic feet of trunk space isn't enough, one simply folds the split rear seats to add capacity.
To anyone accustomed to the clean, generic interiors of small Japanese cars, the Focus seems awfully busy, a puzzle of assorted geometric shapes. Still, the pieces fit snugly and the interior materials seemed to be of good quality.
The controls are large and easy to operate; the gauges use large numbers, making them easy to read.
Ford said it used human and electronic testers to insure a pleasant new-car smell, but I still detected the acrid odor of plastic parts that haven't cured long enough.
The Focus has many conveniences, including a steering wheel that tilts and telescopes, a height-adjustable driver's seat, useful cup holders and a console with storage space and a pen holder.
Safety features include seatbelts with pretensioners and retractors to keep occupants in the safest position in a crash, child safety seat anchors and an emergency release in the trunk. Side air bags are optional at $350. Anti-lock brakes, standard on the ZTS, cost $400 on other models.
After driving away, Focus buyers receive a welcome package in the mail from Ford, part of a youth-oriented marketing campaign that includes live television ads and Webcasts. The welcome items include a watch; a picture frame that attaches to the dashboard; an expandable, megasized cup holder, and a sunglass case. To further personalize the car, as young buyers often do, Ford plans to sell several accessory packages: one for pet owners has a color-coordinated water bowl, among other things; a Friends Package has seat covers, a candy dispenser and an ice cooler.
I could do without the candy or dog bowl. The car's driving dynamics would seal the deal.
This little car is darn fun to drive. It reminded me of Ford's sporty Puma, a wonderful coupe sold overseas.
The Focus is available with two 2-liter, four-cylinder engines, either a 110-horsepower, single-cam version or the 130-horsepower, dual-cam Zetec, which is standard on the GTS and ZX3. Transmission choices are a five-speed manual or a new electronically controlled four-speed automatic.
The dual-cam engine puts the Focus in a league with the peppy Dodge Neon and versions of the Civic that have a zippy Honda engine with variable valve timing. It handily accelerated onto the freeway even when carrying five adults. The base engine did not measure up so well, however, and it felt especially sluggish in the heavier station wagon, where it is the only engine available.
Regardless of the engine or the trim level, the Focus handles crisply and responsively. The steering is precise and the brakes feel sturdy. The ride is comfortable for a car of this size, though road noise is excessive, especially in the back seat.
The Focus hatchback starts at $12,280, sedans at $12,540 and the wagon at $15,795. The prices seemed attractive when they were announced last spring, but Toyota upstaged Ford by putting a sticker of $9,995, plus shipping, on the Echo hatchback.
With its edgy styling, ample space for people and cargo, great handling and numerous features, the Focus makes a big impression. It is a lot of small car for the money.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A funky-looking subcompact for drivers who like to drive.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk
